Sea level rise has been predicted some time ago, can you explain sunny day floods experienced in SE USA?', u'recommendation_count': u'6', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1509246368000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'a one degree increase in atmospheric temperature above pre - industrial times', u'effect': u'a 7 % increase in rainfall'}], u'author_id': u'12400752', u'in_reply_to': u'107476107', u'id': u'107479126', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Alan1987', u'text': u'Well, James Hansen the godfather of the the meme, he who said publicly and in a court of law that it was morally right to commit criminal acts, including violence if it furthered the 'cause'.

Can you not see the parallels between this and the Theophilus Painter chromosome scandal?', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1509212246000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'their published statements of the coming effects', u'effect': u'catastrophic is the obvious prenom to agw'}, {u'cause': u'high winds', u'effect': u'and there will be tape across the windows across the street'}, {u'cause': u'he feels morally obliged to do so', u'effect': u'commit criminal offences'}], u'author_id': u'11342996', u'in_reply_to': u'107455967', u'id': u'107461940', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'"thee 1910 - 1940 period whose warming rate is almost an exact match for the 1970-2000 period."
The former period included a major European and a major Eurasian war which caused problems with the provision of reliable temperature data.
"However, there was no real increase in CO2 during this period."
Atmospheric CO2 increased by around 10ppm from 300 ppm to 310 ppm over the thirty years from 1910 to 1940. 10 ppm is a real increase.
"In public the proponents, kind of hand wave and declare 'oh Solar and Aerosols' it is nonsense but they don't really expect to be challenged."
I have already asked you what you mean by a proponent in this context. A proponent of what? You seem to be the one talking nonsense when you can't answer simple questions.
I have read peer reviewed papers by a number of scientists discussing the role of aerosols and solar variation in affecting global and regional temperature over varying periods. These we sober evidence based papers, not hand waving.
While it is both unethical and illegal to listen to the private conversations or intercept the mail of hardworking individuals neither suspected nor convicted of any crime, the illegally hacked conversations between Tom Wigley and Phil Jones make perfect sense in explaining the 1940s temperature blip in addition to the measurement problems already discussed.
Note Tom is a fellow Australian whose work on the meteorology of the Nullarbor Caves I have familiar with since the 1960s. It's not surprising that as an Australia he was familiar with the difference in aerosol distribution between the Southern and Northern Hemispheres and the consequences thereof.', u'recommendation_count': u'6', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1509244372000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'which', u'effect': u'problems with the provision of reliable temperature data'}], u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'107454243', u'id': u'107478714', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'idontreadtheguardian', u'text': u'And yes, I think the IPCC is partisan and the UN is a joke.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1509243474000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12466762', u'in_reply_to': u'107474139', u'id': u'107478470', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'glacier', u'text': u'It would be a pretty stupid person who would bet on such a stupid proposal - since physics have to count in the concept of feed-backs (that may or may not be too complex for people living in a linear understanding of stuff).

Let me remind you - I bet it is possible to cycle on wheels made up by only 8 straight lines angled to approach a circle. So you are in affect saying that if we look at the wheel closely enough - you have proven that a pair of skis can function as wheels on your car. 
Good luck with that bet. 
I know this can be difficult for people who kind of ended analytical studies by succeeding in making a linear regression. But common sense should obviously make anyone with common sense to spot you as a denier without much understanding.', u'recommendation_count': u'12', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1509212209000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4706143', u'in_reply_to': u'107460416', u'id': u'107461920', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'rockyrex', u'text': u'The problem you have is that not one professional scientific organisation on Earth agrees with the so-called climate sceptics.
Not in any country.
Not in any field of science.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1509212116000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2923581', u'in_reply_to': u'107440139', u'id': u'107461864', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'idontreadtheguardian', u'text': u'You don't have to be clueless or corrupt to overstate something; you just have to be human. In my lifetime, the dangers of saturated fat, cholesterol contained in food and cannabis have all been overstated by intelligent, well-meaning people. I don't think it's physicists and oceanographers overstating the dangers of climate change. It's researchers with a degree in climate science who work for publicly-funded institutions; and journalists who report only the bad news because that's what sells.
Ever since Al Gore's movie An Inconvenient Truth came out, there has been constant hyperbole about the dangers of climate change; with all sorts of people throwing around terms like "imminent danger", "catastrophic consequences", point of no return" and "destroying the planet". Our species isn't going to be around for ever; but right now there's more of us than there's ever been and I don't believe a few degrees of warming or a few metres of sea level rise is going to have that much impact. Plus, we'll probably invent some way of reversing the change anyway.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1509243379000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u"that 's what sells", u'effect': u'who report only the bad news'}], u'author_id': u'12466762', u'in_reply_to': u'107474139', u'id': u'107478447', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'uncletimrob', u'text': u'Yes a joke, the man is a fool.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1509242529000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14293845', u'in_reply_to': u'107416567', u'id': u'107478239', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'rockyrex', u'text': u'Sadly Judith Curry is not reliable these days.', u'recommendation_count': u'7', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1509211269000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2923581', u'in_reply_to': u'107453243', u'id': u'107461346', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'FrankJames', u'text': u'I'll make a bet with anyone who cares to take it up that this scenario is just plain bollocks. It's easily testable: The authors claim a sea level rise of 16mm pa over the next 82 years. Because I'd like to collect on my bet, my wager is that GSL will not exceed 80mm by the end of 2023 from the beginning of 2018.
As alarmists are convinced of the 97% consensus, I'll offer generous odds of 10:1 i.e. your 10 against my 1. 
If you're up for it I'll find a bookmaker to hold the wagers.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1509209659000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17902043', u'id': u'107460416', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Erik Frederiksen', u'text': u'Scientists predicted decades ago that continuing to burn fossil fuels would rapidly warm the planet and raise sea levels.
And they were right.', u'recommendation_count': u'15', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1509241078000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15131989', u'in_reply_to': u'107476107', u'id': u'107477879', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'Anyone who has tried to count chromosomes even in grasshopper testes squash preparation would not find the above story as amazing as you do.
I note that your link is to a creation website.
Don't underestimate the complexity of intracellular structure, biochemistry and genetics in comparison to the evolution of planetary heat budgets. Technical artifacts occur in both systems as discussed above with respect to the measurement of the temperature of grid squares. Complexity also occurs in many fields of science such as well and can be dealt with in the usual systematic and rigorous way.
Scientists are ordinary mortals but I expect you have an unwarranted dismal and pessimistic view of the abilities of ordinary mortals - or maybe its just the people you hang around with and the websites you consult.', u'recommendation_count': u'6', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1509240923000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'107453690', u'id': u'107477837', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'loco_p_man', u'text': u'BQSTART
The net result is that our renewables market is extremely unhealthy, almost a monopoly of suppliers only willing to invest if a public subsidy is forthcoming.
BQENDThis is just 100% nonsense. They invest if they can make a profit. Subsidies are reducing rapidly - just look at the latest UK CfD figures. In some parts of the world, PV is waaaaay below the cost of any other option (see the Saudi bid at $17.9 per MWhr) and onshore wind is now just about as cheap as anything, even if politically difficult. Subsidies have enable the investments so that a viable industry can be created - and now we can all reap the benefits.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1509208421000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13126382', u'in_reply_to': u'107428183', u'id': u'107459790', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'loco_p_man', u'text': u'BQSTART
Hopefully we can agree that without storage we can’t fully exploit wind or PV energy effectively - so growing capacity without storage doesn’t help to reduce the amount of alternative capacity required
BQEND
No, I'm afraid we can't agree on this. You can get to much higher penetration of renewables than we see in the UK today without having to spend a great deal on backup. There are a couple of good papers published which explain why and how much :
https://www.carbonbrief.org/in-depth-whole-system-costs-renewableshttps://www.theccc.org.uk/publication/value-of-flexibility-in-a-decarbonised-grid-and-system-externalities-of-low-carbon-generation-technologies/I suggest you read those to see the implications of a flexible grid.
BQSTART
So why isn’t storage, given its critical nature not a mandatory part of any wind or PV installation?
BQEND
Obvious. This is because the financials don't yet stack up. They will - but not for a couple of years (my estimate). People are working today on building batteries into wind turbines.

https://www.gerenewableenergy.com/wind-energy/technology/integrated-energy-storage-for-wind-turbines
BQSTART
a great deal of lobbying is done to ensure that renewables can expand without any requirement for storage, even though, we must both agree that this makes no sense at all,
BQEND
You misunderstand this. I am not suggesting, and I don't believe many serious commentators are either, that we transition to 100% wind and solar. We need to have nuclear in the mix - at least for the next few decades, as we build more and more renewables into the generation grid. The important thing is to decarbonise and it is not going to come with a single technology. A whole lot of other elements need to be in place too. V2 smart meters, highly variable tariffs, interconnectors to other countries, smart demand management, hydro storage and increasingly, domestic and grid-scale storage.
Stop fixating on a 100% wind and solar future. It's not going to happen in the short term.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1509208131000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u"the financials do n't yet stack up", u'effect': u'this is'}], u'author_id': u'13126382', u'in_reply_to': u'107429627', u'id': u'107459662', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'When I studied biochemistry, genetics and cytology in the 1970s, I knew there were 23 human chromosome pairs, though was easier to count those in grasshopper testes than those in humans. It's also easier to get hold of healthy grasshopper testes. It's also much easier to count the four pairs of grasshopper chromosomes than it is to count the 23 pairs of human chromosomes that often get in each other ways in the field of view of the three dimensional cell.
All members of the Hominidae, except Humans, Neanderthals, and Denisovians, have 24 pairs of chromosomes. Humans have only 23 pairs of chromosomes. The closest human relative, the chimpanzee, has near identical DNA sequences to human chromosome 2, but they are found in two separate chromosomes.
 Counting chromosomes is more an exercise in cytology than biochemistry. Painter is thought to have failed to identify chromosome 1 as a single chromosome because of a staining artifact. Chromosome 1 is a large metacentric chromosome with a considerable amount of heterochromatin at its centromere, which failed to take up the iron hemotoxylin stain he was using. The two extra chromosomes pictured in Painter's 1923 ordered display of 24 chromosomes correspond to the two arms of chromosome 1 separated by not visible centromere and heterochromatin.
https://www.nature.com/scitable/topicpage/human-chromosome-number-294', u'recommendation_count': u'6', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1509239383000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'a staining artifact', u'effect': u'to have failed to identify chromosome 1 as a single chromosome'}], u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'107453690', u'id': u'107477375', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'aBlokefromTassie', u'text': u'The problem is that none of the proposed or functioning methods of producing electricity are currently carbon free. Production of wind turbines and solar panels is incredibly energy intensive (as well as being quite polluting in general). Hydro electric plants require thousands of tons of concrete and steel (both of which involve CO2 production).
So unfortunately your initial argument against nuclear has equal impact on other "alternate" (to coal and gas) means of generating electricity. IMO the only answer to that that I see, is to transition as quickly as possible to electricity generation techniques that don't inherently produce carbon (even if they do currently because of the coal power required to develop them). 
In support of @tryout; my reading suggests that gen II nuclear plants are almost on par with wind power WRT CO2 production and are currently far better than PV solar. Gen III nuclear plants (as currently under construction in US and China) are slated to lower that significantly (I guess the proof will be in the pudding).
Claims that dealing with the radioactive waste is problematic lay in stark contrast to the current scientific consensus that we have safe ways to store it. To believe one scientific consensus (climate change) but not another (the safety of storing nuclear waste) strikes me as cherry picking based on opinion and/or irrational fears, rather than rational consideration of the evidence; and the opinions of the experts in the relevant fields.
Don't get me wrong, I personally prefer using a wide range of sources of energy. "Renewable" energy (i.e. doesn't require constant inputs) has got to be better than energy production that constantly requires fuel. But in order to reduce (or hopefully eliminate) the worst potential impacts of climate change, we need to act as fast as possible. To remove the option of nuclear from the table because of an irrational dislike or fear, strikes me as short sighted.
Having said that, it's still completely unclear what impacts removing energy from the atmosphere (i.e. via solar and/or wind) might have in the longer term. I guess that's why I err on the side of using as many different sources of electricity generation as possible. The climate model projections of climate temperature have corresponded to what has ensued further showing that the various established theories and facts underlying the models agree with reality.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1509176072000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'107439481', u'id': u'107444398', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'"Of course the adjustments were 'objective' because scientists are like that aren't they?"
The adjustments were objective, that is not influenced by personal feelings or opinions, as the evidence of the biases derived from urbanisation, and exposure changes and of the zero errors of past means of measuring sea surface temperature, is solid. If scientists aren't objective in practicing their discipline they are brought into line by their colleagues or peers.
"They would never dream of giving false results"
In cases where scientists have published false results they have been fired from their job and their career has ended. If they ever dream of giving false results they're having a nightmare.
"or just accepting data that supports an existing meme and rejecting data that doesn't."
In their day to day work scientists deal with established theories, hypotheses and evidence, whereas memes are virally transmitted ideas in popular media. They don't accept or reject data on face value but instead investigate how it was gathered and if necessary replicate the results and investigate alternatives. It's always a case of show me the evidence.
My old colleague did this with the popular media meme that stomach ulcers were caused by low stomach pH, finding an alternative underlying cause in the form of Helicobacter pyrlori which made the stomach wall vulnerable to the normal low pH of its contents.
"Also if they saw real problems with an existing meme they should stand up and say so."
They do that. While popular media memes are not their daily bread and butter, today's scientists have responded to problems with the truth of existing memes as they did with the meme that there was widespread lack of acceptance among the scientific community of the evidence support the current anthropogenic global greenhouse warming.
"The wouldn't be constrained by powerful authority figures and consensus, worrying about their academic appointments, grants, reputation etc by going against the consensus? Apart from a rare one they are above that sort of human behaviour." 
Scientific consensus is based on the quality of the evidence. A scientists reputation and ability to attract grant monies is determined by the quality of their research proposal and the quality of their published work which are based on the evidence they have gathered and the quality of their analysis of that evidence. In fifty years of experience in a range of scientific fields I have found colleagues more concerned about the quality of their work and the evidence it uncovers than about whether their discoveries go against the consensus (in fact they are excited when it does). Academic appointments have followed good quality science based on sound evidence. Scientific authority is also a synonym for quality evidence as in science authority in the sense of being an authority in your field means to know the evidence and what shows about how the world works.
The habits of scientists go against confirmation bias as they continually challenge each others evidence and interpretation thereof. This evidence based approach is not confined to scientists but can occur in other fields even politics. So scientists are not special people but they may well be more reality based than yourself and the people you talk to and read.', u'recommendation_count': u'6', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1509235190000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'scientists are like', u'effect': u"that are n't they"}, {u'cause': u'low stomach ph', u'effect': u'stomach ulcers'}], u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'107453690', u'id': u'107475804', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'littlepump', u'text': u'Opinions only stop being assertions when they come with some sort of justification. That rule is not determined by people such as James Hansen but is obvious to anyone who looks at a graph of yearly or monthly global temperature data over a century or so. It is also obvious that the variation that determines the rule is the product of ENSO phase changes. The longer term changes you refer to the late 1940s to 1970 cooler time and the 1972 to 1998 warmer time and the 1999 to 2013 cooler time are the product of the Inter-decadal Pacific Oscillation. The Pacific is the biggest thing on the surface of the Earth. Reality determines the rule.
You keep talking about ENSO driven variations in global temperature of a few years as if they were significant in terms of the underlying climate temperature trend.
The forcing effect of CO2 is due to its concentration not the amount extra that is added yearly as net emissions, though increase this and you increase the concentration. The cause is not declining any time soon. That knowledge is based on evidence not faith. 
Since 1990 global climate temperatures have risen at O.15 degrees C per decade which would produce a further 1.2 degrees C climate temperature rise in the 80 years to the end of the century on top of the almost 1 degree C climate temperature rise that has occurred since the 19th century.
Most of the extra heat due to global warming is going into the oceans. The movement of warmer waters to the Arctic Ocean is the product of ocean currents driven by the Atlantic meridional overturning circulation which has slowed since the 1930s. A recent paper by Sevelloc et al (2017) explains "How Arctic sea-ice decline weakens Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation".https:www.nature.com/nclimate/journal/v7/n8/full/nclimate3353.html

In climate science there is a problem because of thee 1910 - 1940 period whose warming rate is almost an exact match for the 1970 - 2000 period. However, there was no real increase in CO2 during this period. In public the proponents, kind of hand wave and declare 'oh Solar and Aerosols' it is nonsense but then they don't really expect to be challenged.

So Tom Wigley wrote to Phil Jones
"Phil,
Here are some speculations on correcting SSTs to partlyexplain the 1940s warming blip.
If you look at the attached plot you will see that theland also shows the 1940s blip (as I’m sure you know).
So, if we could reduce the ocean blip by, say, 0.15 degC,then this would be significant for the global mean — butwe’d still have to explain the land blip.
I’ve chosen 0.15 here deliberately. This still leaves anocean blip, and i think one needs to have some form ofocean blip to explain the land blip (via either some commonforcing, or ocean forcing land, or vice versa, or all ofthese). When you look at other blips, the land blips are1.5 to 2 times (roughly) the ocean blips — higher sensitivityplus thermal inertia effects. My 0.15 adjustment leaves thingsconsistent with this, so you can see where I am coming from.
Removing ENSO does not affect this.
It would be good to remove at least part of the 1940s blip,but we are still left with “why the blip”.
Let me go further. If you look at NH vs SH and the aerosoleffect (qualitatively or with MAGICC) then with a reducedocean blip we get continuous warming in the SH, and a coolingin the NH — just as one would expect with mainly NH aerosols.
The other interesting thing is (as Foukal et al. note — fromMAGICC) that the 1910-40 warming cannot be solar. The Sun canget at most 10% of this with Wang et al solar, less with Foukalsolar. So this may well be NADW, as Sarah and I noted in 1987(and also Schlesinger later). A reduced SST blip in the 1940smakes the 1910-40 warming larger than the SH (which itcurrently is not) — but not really enough.
So … why was the SH so cold around 1910? Another SST problem?(SH/NH data also attached.)
This stuff is in a report I am writing for EPRI, so I’dappreciate any comments you (and Ben) might have.
Tom."

The wouldn't be constrained by powerful authority figures and consensus, worrying about their academic appointments, grants, reputation etc by going against the consensus? Apart from a rare one they are above that sort of human behaviour.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Confirmation_bias
Well let's look at a situation in science involving something pretty simple in science compared to the huge complexity of the Earth's climatic processes. Lets look at biochemistry.
Fairly early in the 20th century the distinguished scientist Theophilus Painter produced studies showing there were 24 pairs of chromosomes in a human cell.
This of course was not correct there are actually only 23 pairs.
However, this became the consensus other scientists subsequently did similar peer reviewed 'studies' and all said that they indeed did find 24 also. Of course they couldn't have found this because it was not true.
So were they were all either totally clueless or fraudulent, or did confirmation bias kick in, or did they indeed see 23 but were not prepared to go against authority and consensus?
Chromosomes pairs were held to be 24 pairs until 1956 when a scientist did publish a study showing the correct figure of 23.
 Checking photographs of chromosomes reprinted in textbooks and studies, researchers later found that 23 pairs were clearly shown—and yet captions under the photographs declared the figure to be 24 and the text continued to say humans have 24 pairs of chromosomes.
https://creation.com/great-chromosome-fiasco
Amazing right? Also this was just a relatively simple problem, unlike the hugely complex climate science where it is actually far far more easy to keep your head down hidden by the complexity,

I also believe that their approach is rational, they have succeeded in massively reducing their fossil fuel burn given their economic growth and energy demands. Not only are they the largest market for renewables, they are 50% of the global renewables market.
But vitally, their renewables policy is providing identifiable benefits for their consumers, while promoting a competitive market to deliver renewable energy.
This is the vital difference between their approach and the approach taken by the UK, US, et cetera - in the UK all consumers pay a mandatory tax to provide a subsidy to predominately foreign companies to generate electricity at a guaranteed price unrelated to the spot market.
Suggesting that the transmission network be reengineered to take advantage of wind is great, but who’s going to pay for it? Let me guess, the consumers again?? And given it’s going to take decades to update even if the budgets are available, it simply means a continuation of fossil fuel burn.
And why so pessimistic about energy storage, China already has 23Gw of pumped storage and is planning 40GW by 2020 – they’ll also have 250MW of battery storage online soon both of which are expanding due to private investment.
But apparently our only option is sticking a few batteries in wind turbines to smooth out electrical delivery, and it’s going to take a couple of years?? That’s simply pathetic.
My issue is the UK’s along with other Western nations fixation on wind and solar as if it was some type of panacea and their obsession with subsidising large multinationals to supply it without any obligation to provide energy storage, grid upgrades or anything else your links have identified as critical, when it may impact their profitability.
The UK could be focusing on renewables that provide consumers benefit - solar thermal would provide consumer benefits while dropping fossil fuel consumption, just as combined wind, PV and storage would benefit communities, especially rural communities, and the list goes on.
I believe in renewables, they are a future - but what’s been done in the UK today, particularly offshore wind is a travesty, its sole purpose is to fleece consumers out of money while destroying the viability of other far more useful renewable schemes that would provide customers direct benefits.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1509222884000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'private investment', u'effect': u'both of which are expanding'}], u'author_id': u'18130674', u'in_reply_to': u'107459662', u'id': u'107468688', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Kennyryan1', u'text': u'My beach house is very safe , even for my grand kids', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1509222674000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17975026', u'in_reply_to': u'107468533', u'id': u'107468583', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ID2310987', u'text': u'BQSTART

(2013) Discussion at: https://judithcurry.com/2017/09/26/are-climate-models-overstating-warming/#more-23412', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1509194131000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17902043', u'in_reply_to': u'107451827', u'id': u'107453243', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'As we are measuring global temperatures as complete as possible spatial grid square coverage is needed. The HadCRUT data base does not use interpolation to fill in missing values. Adjustments are carried out for objective reasons to more accurately measure what the intention is to measure - the temperature of the grid square in question.
HadCRUT is a data base of the temperatures of grid squares worldwide, not a program. Neither Phil nor his team programmed a data base.
The satellite record is not a record of land and sea surface temperatures but reflects the temperature of the atmosphere at higher altitudes. When I drive up or climb a sizeable mountain or fly in an unheated light plane, I take a jumper and sometimes a parka. HadCRUT more accurately reflects what happening on the surface of the Earth.
As already explained above, data spanning the period from 2001 to 2014 covers insufficient time to tell you anything about climate.
The El Nino of 2015-16 was of similar magnitude to the El Nino of 1997-98 and smaller than that of 1981-82; but was hotter than both of them. Similar sized El Ninos produce similar sized temperature peaks off the underlying climate temperature. 2015-16 was hotter than 1997-97 because the underlying climate temperature was hotter due to global greenhouse warming produced by increasing atmospheric CO2. So the cause was that extra CO2.
July to November 2016 was a brief La Nina event following the continuing weak El Nino of the first half of 2016. 2017 has been weakly neutral but our states ENSO expert is calling a weak La Nina for the coming year as the storms roll in and I plant my garden with ferns. These are typical ENSO variations that can been seen in the global temperature record of the last century. The variation continues around a rising climatetemperature trend as the graph you refer to demonstrates. 
You need 30 years to measure climate temperature. The global climate temperature of 2020 will include the temperature data from 1991 to 2020 including two very large El Ninos. If 2017-18 is a weak La Nina as seems possible, we'll have to wait and see what 2018-19 and 2019-20 bring us in the way of ENSO weather patterns.', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1509194023000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'the underlying climate temperature was hotter due to global greenhouse warming produced by increasing atmospheric co2', u'effect': u'2015 16 was hotter than 1997 97'}, {u'cause': u'global greenhouse warming produced by increasing atmospheric co2', u'effect': u'hotter'}], u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'107415379', u'id': u'107453199', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JamesCA', u'text': u'BQSTART

Production of nuclear electricity is not carbon free, because the production of nuclear fuel for these reactors is significantly energy intensive. While it is true that most nuclear reactors do not emit CO2 at the point of generation, reactors are a small part of the nuclear fuel cycle, which emits large amounts of CO2. These arise from the so-called front end of the fuel cycle - uranium mining, ore milling, uranium hexafluoride conversion, fuel enrichment and, finally, fabrication of the fuel rods. Moreover, nuclear waste management at the "back end" is already energy hungry in treatment, conditioning, transportation and final disposal in some future repository (if ministers ever give the green light).
BQENDSo, ignoring the risk from highly radioactive waste for which we have no solution for long term storage, nuclear power isn't far safer than renewable energy.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1509192116000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'the production of nuclear fuel for these reactors is significantly energy intensive', u'effect': u'bqstart production of nuclear electricity is not carbon free'}], u'author_id': u'3080543', u'in_reply_to': u'107443977', u'id': u'107452336', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'DennisHorne', u'text': u'If humans were rational the fossil fuel propagandists wouldn't have been able to brainwash them so easily and thoroughly and we would have started reducing GHG emissions 30 or 40 years ago.', u'recommendation_count': u'9', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1509171625000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4446531', u'in_reply_to': u'107442218', u'id': u'107443159', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JamesCA', u'text': u'BQSTART

It's not a given that any solar panel will produce more energy than is required to construct, transport and install it. What if it doesn't work, for example? Or if it works poorly?
BQEND
Of course any individual panel can fail. But on average, they pay back the energy to produce them in under 4 years, then produce effectively free energy for another 26. 
Put another way, the carbon footprint is down around 10% or less of coal-based electricity, even if the manufacturing was powered entirely with coal-based electricity. Now the databases don't give you the actual measurements they adjust them with a computer program to more truly reflect a global rate as temperature recording."
The CRU in HadCRUT stands for Climate Research Unit, which began its production from 1978 onward of its gridded dataset of land air temperature anomalies based on instrumental temperature records held by national meteorological organisations around the world. In 1986 sea temperatures were added to form a synthesis of data which was the first global temperature record, demonstrating unequivocally that the globe had warmed by almost 0.8 degrees C over the last 150 years.
HadCRUT 3, first published in 2006, included a more complete statistical model of uncertainty including estimates of errors, biases due to changing exposure and urbanisation, and uncertainty due to incomplete coverage of the globe by observations of temperature.
HadCRUT 4, introduced in March 2012, included newly digitised measurement data, both over land and sea, new sea surface temperature bias adjustments and a more comprehensive model for describing uncertainties in sea-surface temperature measurements. Overall, the net effect was was an increase in average temperature anomaly, especially around 1950 and 1885, and less significantly around 1925 and 2005.
I'm not sure why you're talking about what Phil did in 2015. The first thing you need to consider in talking about measurements is what it is you are measuring. The afforementioned exposure and urbanisation factors give a false measure of regional temperature over the grid square in question, hence the need for adjustments. Means of measuring sea surface temperatures have improved with the deployment of Argo buoys and past measurements adjusted for the error or bias inherent in their means of measurement of sea surface temperature. When I commenced year 9 high school physics in 1963, the first thing we learnt about was zero error in measurement.

description: University of Melbourne paper combines latest understanding on Antarctica and current emissions projection scenarios
og_fields.og:description: University of Melbourne paper combines latest understanding on Antarctica and current emissions projection scenarios
og_fields.og:title: Sea levels to rise 1.3m unless coal power ends by 2050, report says
text:
Coastal cities around the world could be devastated by 1.3m of sea level rise this century unless coal-generated electricity is virtually eliminated by 2050, according to a new paper that combines the latest understanding of Antarctica’s contribution to sea level rise and the latest emissions projection scenarios.
It confirms again that significant sea level rise is inevitable and requires rapid adaptation. But, on a more positive note, the work reveals the majority of that rise – driven by newly recognised processes on Antarctica – could be avoided if the world fulfils its commitment made in Paris to keep global warming to “well below 2C”.
In 2016, Robert DeConto from the University of Massachusetts Amherst revealed that Antarctica could contribute to massive sea level rise much earlier than thought, suggesting ice sheet collapse would occur sooner and identifying a new process where huge ice cliffs would disintegrate.
But that paper only examined the impact of Antarctica on sea level rise, ignoring other contributions, and didn’t examine the details of what measures society needed to take to avoid those impacts.
The new paper by Alexander Nauels from the University of Melbourne and colleagues uses simplified physical models that allowed them to explore all known contributions to sea level rise, and pair them with the new generation of emissions scenarios which the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) will use in the next set of reports.
Under all scenarios we are going to have to adapt
They found that if nothing is done to limit carbon pollution, then global sea levels will rise by an estimated 1.32m. That is 50% more than was previously thought, with the IPCC’s AR5 report suggesting 85cm was possible by the end of the century.
But the extra contribution from Antarctica would not kick in if warming was kept at less than 1.9C above preindustrial levels, the researchers found. Temperatures above that threshold risked triggering the additional processes in Antarctica identified in the 2016 paper, causing much greater sea level rise.
“The 1.5C limit in the Paris Agreement is a much safer bet to avoid this additional contribution than only achieving 2C,” Nauels said.
The work, published in the journal Environmental Research Letters, showed that the current carbon reduction pledges which governments have made as part of the Paris Agreement by 2030 – their Nationally Determined Contributions (NDCs) – are so weak they would require very deep cuts between 2030 and 2050 to avoid triggering those extra processes in Antarctica.
Since the authors used the next generation of emissions scenarios (the “Shared Socioeconomic Pathways”), which include assumptions about socioeconomic factors that are driving emissions – such as energy demand, energy generation, population growth and GDP – they were able to examine what actions could be taken to avoid the sea level rise.
Those scenarios suggested coal could only make up 5% of the world’s energy mix by 2050 if sea level rise is to be limited to about half a metre.
Similarly, those scenarios suggested a global carbon price would have to be well over US$100 per tonne, since at that cost, sea level would rise by 65cm by 2100.
John Church, a leading sea level rise expert from the University of New South Wales who was co-convening lead author of the chapter on sea level in the third and fifth IPCC Assessment Reports, told the Guardian the work was further confirmation that the world needed to prepare now for substantial sea level rises.
“Under all scenarios we are going to have to adapt,” Church said. “We cannot stop all sea level rise.”
He said the research community was not in consensus yet about the accelerated contribution of Antarctica to sea level rise, identified in the 2016 paper and modelled in this study, but examining the implications of those findings was still important.
DeConto, the lead author of the landmark paper from 2016, said it was important to recognise the good news in his original findings and this extension of that work.
“In the aggressive mitigation pathways, where we assume that the global community gets its act together and we reduce emissions, it’s a much rosier picture. There’s a much reduced risk of dramatic sea level rise from Antarctica,” he told the Guardian. “This study fully reinforces that.”
Nauels said his team’s work assumed that Antarctica would contribute to sea level rise as was suggested by the 2016 paper by DeConto, but more work was needed to confirm those findings.
“We still have to find out what’s going on in Antarctica,” he told the Guardian. “We can’t base all future sea level rise projects on just one paper. And the Antarctic ice sheet community are frantically working on the new insights.”

headline: O
og_fields.og:description: UN warns that drastic action is needed to meet climate targets set in the Paris agreement
og_fields.og:title: Global atmospheric CO2 levels hit record high
text:
The concentration of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere increased at record speed last year to hit a level not seen for more than three million years, the UN has warned.
The new report has raised alarm among scientists and prompted calls for nations to consider more drastic emissions reductions at the upcoming climate negotiations in Bonn.
“Globally averaged concentrations of CO2 reached 403.3 parts per million (ppm) in 2016, up from 400.00 ppm in 2015 because of a combination of human activities and a strong El Niño event,” according to The Greenhouse Gas Bulletin, the UN weather agency’s annual flagship report.
This acceleration occurred despite a slowdown – and perhaps even a plateauing – of emissions because El Niño intensified droughts and weakened the ability of vegetation to absorb carbon dioxide. As the planet warms, El Niños are expected to become more frequent.
The increase of 3.3 ppm is considerably higher than both the 2.3 ppm rise of the previous 12 months and the average annual increase over the past decade of 2.08ppm. It is also well above the previous big El Niño year of 1998, when the rise was 2.7 ppm.
The study, which uses monitoring ships, aircraft and stations on the land to track emissions trends since 1750, said carbon dioxide in the atmosphere is now increasing 100 times faster than at the end of the last ice age due to population growth, intensive agriculture, deforestation and industrialisation.
The last time Earth experienced similar CO2 concentration rates was during the Pliocene era (three to five million years ago), when the sea level was up to 20m higher than now.
The authors urged policymakers to step up countermeasures to reduce the risk of global warming exceeding the Paris climate target of between 1.5C and 2C.
“Without rapid cuts in CO2 and other greenhouse gas emissions, we will be heading for dangerous temperature increases by the end of this century, well above the target set by the Paris climate change agreement,” World Meteorological Organisation chief Petteri Taalas said in a statement.
The momentum from the Paris accord in 2015 is faltering due to the failure of national governments to live up to their promises. In a report to be released on Tuesday, UN Environment will show the gap between international goals and domestic commitments leaves the world on course for warming well beyond the 2C target and probably beyond 3C. International efforts to act have also been weakened by US president Donald Trump’s decision to quit the accord.
Prof Dave Reay, professor of carbon management at the University of Edinburgh, said: “This should set alarm bells ringing in the corridors of power. We know that, as climate change intensifies, the ability of the land and oceans to mop up our carbon emissions will weaken. There’s still time to steer these emissions down and so keep some control, but if we wait too long humankind will become a passenger on a one-way street to dangerous climate change.”
“The numbers don’t lie. We are still emitting far too much and this needs to be reversed,” the head of UN Environment Erik Solheim said in reaction to the new report. “What we need now is global political will and a new sense of urgency.”
The report comes amid growing concerns that nature’s ability to deal with CO2 is weakening. Recent studies show forest regions are being cleared and degraded so rapidly that they are now emitting more carbon than they absorb.
“These large increase show it is more important than ever to reduce our emissions to zero – and as soon as possible,” said Piers Forster, director of the Priestley International Centre for Climate at the University of Leeds. “If vegetation can no longer help out absorbing our emissions in these hot years we could be in trouble.”
The World Meteorological Organisation predicted 2017 will again break records for concentrations of carbon dioxide and methane, but the growth rate will not be as fast because there is no El Niño effect.

description: Scientists find that climate change has helped push first frosts later across the country
og_fields.og:description: Scientists find that climate change has helped push first frosts later across the country
og_fields.og:title: US winter has shrunk by more than one month in 100 years
text:
The length of the US winter is shortening, with the first frost of the year arriving more than one month later than it did 100 years ago, according to more than a century of measurements from weather stations nationwide.
 The trend of ever later first freezes appears to have started around 1980, according to data from 700 weather stations across the US going back to 1895 and compiled by Ken Kunkel, a meteorologist at the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration’s National Centers for Environmental Information.
Kunkel compared the first freeze from each of the 700 stations to the station’s average for the 20th Century. Some parts of the country experience earlier or later freezes every year, but on average freezes are coming later. 
The average first freeze over the last 10 years, from 2007 to 2016, is a week later than the average from 1971 to 1980. 
This year, about 40% of the Lower 48 states have had a freeze as of 23 October, compared to 65% in a normal year, according to Jeff Masters, meteorology director of the private service Weather Underground. 
In Ottawa, Illinois, the average first freeze for the 20th century was 15 October. The normal from 1981 to 2010 based on NOAA computer simulations was 19 October. Since 2010, the average first freeze is on 26 October. Last year, the first freeze in Ottawa came on 12 November. 
Almost certainly, according to a statement issued by the World Meteorological Organization on Tuesday. “Climate change means that when we do have an event like Harvey, the rainfall amounts are likely to be higher than they would have been otherwise,” the UN organisation’s spokeswoman Clare Nullis told a conference. Nobody is arguing that climate change caused the storm, but it is likely to have made it much worse.
Warmer seas evaporate more quickly. Warmer air holds more water vapour. So, as temperatures rise around the world, the skies store more moisture and dump it more intensely. The US National Weather Service has had to introduce a new colour on its graphs to deal with the volume of precipitation. Harvey surpassed the previous US record for rainfall from a tropical system, as 49.2 inches was recorded at Mary’s Creek at Winding Road in Southeast Houston, at 9.20am on Tuesday.
There is a proven link – known as the Clausius-Clapeyron equation – that shows that for every half a degree celsius in warming, there is about a 3% increase in atmospheric moisture content. This was a factor in Texas. The surface temperature in the Gulf of Mexico is currently more than half a degree celsius higher than the recent late summer average, which is in turn more than half a degree higher than 30 years ago, according to Michael Mannof Penn State University. As a result there was more potential for a deluge.
Yes, the storm surge was greater because sea levels have risen 20cm as a result of more than 100 years of human-related global warming. This has melted glaciers and thermally expanded the volume of seawater.
Last year was “way off the charts” nationwide, Kunkel said. The average first freeze was two weeks later than the 20th century average, and the last frost of spring was nine days earlier than normal. 
Overall the United States freeze season of 2016 was more than a month shorter than the freeze season of 1916. It was most extreme in the Pacific Northwest. Oregon’s freeze season was 61 days – two months – shorter than normal. 
Global warming has helped push the first frosts later, Kunkel and other scientists said. Also at play, though, are natural short-term changes in air circulation patterns – but they too may be influenced by man-made climate change, they said. 
This shrinking freeze season is what climate scientists have long predicted, said University of Oklahoma meteorology professor Jason Furtado. 
A shorter freeze season means a longer growing season and less money spent on heat. But it also hurts some plants that require a certain amount of chill, such as Georgia peaches, said Theresa Crimmins, a University of Arizona ecologist. 
Crimmins is assistant director of the National Phenology Network . Phenology is the study of the seasons and how plants and animals adapt to timing changes. 
Pests that attack trees and spread disease aren’t being killed off as early as they normally would be, Crimmins said. 
In New England, many trees aren’t changing colours as vibrantly as they normally do or used to because some take cues for when to turn from temperature, said Boston University biology professor Richard Primack. 
Research, said natural variability, especially an El Nino, made last year exceptional for an early freeze, but “it represents the kind of conditions that will be more routine in a decade or two” because of man-made climate change. 
“The long-term consequences are really negative,” said Primack, because shorter winters and hotter temperatures are also expected to lead to rising seas that cause worse flooding during heavy storms. 

 Associated Press contributed to this report

I'm not the one claiming it possible to undo millennia of sociological conditioning, changing the very structure of society..', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1509491624000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15009244', u'in_reply_to': u'107604650', u'id': u'107612625', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ElectricalMonk', u'text': u'So,... your reply to the fact that correlation is not causation is to point out... that there's lots of evidence of a correlation. That doesn't change anything. Clearly energy per se is not the cause - rather its the uses we put it to - many of which (e.g. water treatment) are easily serviced by intermittent power sources like solar or wind, which are also cheaper to build, especially in developing areas where electricity infrastructure needs to be built for large scale plants to be of any use. In addition to this trends show an increasing decoupling of energy use and emissions (see article below)
Furthermore, the correlation (as you point out) is logarithmic - i.e. there are diminishing returns as power consumption rises, with the vast majority of the effect at very low levels of electricity use. This means that reducing energy use in currently high energy-using nations would (even if directly causative) have little effect on quality of life in those nations and, in fact, would provide the necessary drop in emissions to enable low-use (developing) nations to be able to substantially increase their energy use. Looking at the correlative graphs in the article below, you can see that the development index of the highest energy-using nations is not substantially higher than of nations with 1/5th of the energy use. In fact, the data suggest that the development index might actually peak at ~ 150 GJ per capita and that nations with higher per capita use and emissions (> 300 GJ per capita) sit below the curve.

#1 - It won't happen.#2 - It would devastate millions, primarily the poor.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1509477519000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'10783567', u'in_reply_to': u'107580270', u'id': u'107603629', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'John Egan', u'text': u'I agree that consumption of "stuff" in the western world is absurd.And that gas-guzzling RVs the size of buses are unnecessary.

Will you deny 2 billion Indians and Chinese the sort of living standards we in the West take for granted: clean water, enough food, air conditioning, lights at night, mobile phones and tablets, medicine, etc, etc?
BQEND
None of those things (except air conditioning) use large amounts of energy if arranged sensibly. Instead of loads of air conditioning you use passivehouse design (very high insulation/airtightess/active ventilation), so that only a very small amount of energy is needed.
The things that cause excessive consumption is lots of high-carbon travel: mostly flying, shipping and individual vehicles. Those things have to be decarbonised or massively reduced. Everyone can develop to a healthy, 2-or-fewer children, decent housing, enough food, communication access level without blowing the carbon budget. Further development is possible, but only if it can be done in a carbon-neatral way, and if it genuinely increases wellbeing, which much of western consumer society has not actually done.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1509467893000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'that', u'effect': u'excessive consumption'}], u'author_id': u'4307215', u'in_reply_to': u'107565372', u'id': u'107596804', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'derekcolman', u'text': u'Thank you for your reply. Your link just registered a server error, but I have tracked the document down with a Google search, and bookmarked it for reading later when I have time.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1509466585000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2600028', u'in_reply_to': u'107585245', u'id': u'107595766', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'xwookey', u'text': u'BQSTART
If you were to cull all Yanks and Aussies (less than 400 million people), we'd be halfway to solving the world's CO2 emissions problem
BQEND
It doesn't work like that. Getting rid of the richest 700 million would halve emissions. The richest 400 million would perhaps be 40%, but they are not all in the US and AU, despite their high average consumption. This graph (Fig E1: http://piketty.pse.ens.fr/files/ChancelPiketty2015.pdf) shows where the richest 10% live: 40% in the US, 19% EU, 10% china, 7% Russia, 5% MENA, 5% South America, 5% rest of asia, 2% south Africa, 1% india, 6% everywhere else. And of course the current trend is those numbers rising relative to the US and EU.
So the point is that the rich people with the massive carbon footprints are all over now. Lots of Chinese tourists who can afford to fly round the world and so on.
I agree entirely that the excesses of those people have to be reduced somehow otherwise this problem cannot be dealt with. If you split the 1.5C carbon budget across everyone in the world we have 40 tonnes each for our entire lives. Radical action is now necessary to hit even 2C.
Population is a massive problem too, especially when you look 30 years forward, but excessive consumption is the problem right now., and the only effective and ethical way we know to manage population is to raise people out of poverty, whilst making sure contraception is available.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1509465942000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4307215', u'in_reply_to': u'107564095', u'id': u'107595258', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'MightyDrunken', u'text': u'I mean that if a country wants to use DDT for public health reasons, they can. description: Heatwaves, pollution and disease are the main health issues linked to global warming but action to halt emissions would deliver huge benefits
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: Heatwaves, pollution and disease are the main health issues linked to global warming but action to halt emissions would deliver huge benefits
og_fields.og:title: Climate change already bringing disease, air pollution and heatwaves
text:
The health of hundreds of millions of people around the world is already being damaged by climate change, a major report has revealed.
Heatwaves are affecting many more vulnerable people and global warming is boosting the transmission of deadly diseases such as dengue fever, the world’s most rapidly spreading disease. Air pollution from fossil fuel burning is also causing millions of early deaths each year, while damage to crops from extreme weather threatens hunger for millions of children.
The findings, published in the Lancet journal, come from researchers at 26 institutions around the world, including many universities, the World Health Organization, World Bank and the UN’s World Meteorological Organization (WMO). The WMO reported on Monday that the level of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere made a record jump in 2016 to hit a concentration not seen for more than three million years.
“Climate change is happening and it’s a health issue today for millions worldwide,” said Prof Anthony Costello, at the World Health Organization and co-chair of the group behind the new report. It follows a related report in 2009 that warned that climate change was the biggest danger to global health in the 21st century, an assessment repeated in the new report.
But Costello said acting to halt global warming would also deliver a huge benefit for health: “The outlook is challenging, but we still have an opportunity to turn a looming medical emergency into the most significant advance for public health this century.”
“Our scientists have been telling us for some time that we’ve got a bad case of climate change. Now our doctors are telling us it’s bad for our health,” said Christiana Figueres, who as the UN’s climate chief negotiated the Paris climate change agreement and also co-chaired the new report. 
“Hundreds of millions of people are already suffering health impacts as a result of climate change,” she told the Guardian. “Tackling climate change directly, unequivocally, and immediately improves global health. It’s as simple as that.”
One of the most striking of the 40 indicators assessed by the researchers was a huge increase in the number of people over 65 exposed to extreme heat. This rose by 125 million between 2000 and 2016 and worries doctors because older people are especially vulnerable to heat.
“There is no crystal ball gazing here, these are the actual observations,” said Prof Peter Cox, at the University of Exeter, UK. He said the 70,000 deaths that resulted from the 2003 heatwave in Europe looked small compared to the long-term trends: “We were alarmed when we saw this.” 
Most of the increase in exposed people resulted from rising temperatures, but the number of older people is also rising, creating a “perfect storm”, Cox said. The report also found that hotter and more humid weather was increasingly creating conditions in which it is impossible to work outside. In 2016, this caused work equivalent to almost a million people to be lost, half in India alone.
The report also found that climate change has increased the ability of dengue fever to spread, because the mosquitoes and the virus they carry breed more quickly. Dengue is also known as “breakbone fever” due to the pain it causes and infections have doubled in each decade since 1990, now reaching up to 100m infections a year now. Dengue was used as an example in the report and the researchers suggest global warming will also increase the spread of other diseases such as schistosomiasis.
Air pollution is known to cause millions of early deaths every year but the new report highlights the 800,000 annual deaths related solely to coal burning. The good news here, said Prof Paul Wilkinson, is that coal production peaked in 2013 and is now falling. “We are seeing the first turn [in the trend] but we have a long way to go,” he said. “It is a health dividend we are ignoring if we do not act.” 
The impacts of climate change are not limited to poorer nations, said Dr Toby Hillman, at the Royal College of Physicians, but also affect developed nations like the UK. He said air pollution kills about 40,000 in the UK each year and criticised low government funding levels for cycling and walking. Hillman also noted other impacts, such as sharp increases in mental health problems after extreme weather events like flooding.
The new report highlighted imminent threats as well, such as the loss of crops to increasingly hot and extreme weather. “We are going to see millions more undernourished children as a result of that,” said Prof Hugh Montgomery, at University College London (UCL). 
Montgomery said the potential benefits of climate change appeared to be small in comparison to the damages: “We are not ducking the potential benefits, we just find it hard to see what they are.”
Cox said it was not clear that global warming will actually reduce winter cold spells, which cause early deaths in higher latitude countries, because changes happening in the Arctic can exacerbate cold snaps. Prof Georgina Mace, also at UCL, said the evidence for a warmer climate increasing food production was often very localised and short term: ”Overall the overwhelming pattern is negative.”
Clare Goodess, a climate researcher at the University of East Anglia and not part of the Lancet report, said: “The indicators reveal some stark warnings for human health, as well as some glimmers of hope, [and] the key messages appear robust. The attribution of [climate change] temperature trends to human activities is now unequivocal, so the urgency of addressing the issues raised by this report is not in doubt.”

og_fields.og:title: Electric cars emit 50% less greenhouse gas than diesel, study finds
text:
Electric cars emit significantly less greenhouse gases over their lifetimes than diesel engines even when they are powered by the most carbon intensive energy, a new report has found.
In Poland, which uses high volumes of coal, electric vehicles produced a quarter less emissions than diesels when put through a full lifecycle modelling study by Belgium’s VUB University.
CO2 reductions on Europe’s cleanest grid in Sweden were a remarkable 85%, falling to around one half for countries such as the UK.
 “On average, electric vehicles will emit half the CO2 emissions of a diesel car by 2030, including the manufacturing emissions,” said Yoann Le Petit, a spokesman for the T&E think tank, which commissioned the study.
“We’ve been facing a lot of fake news in the past year about electrification put out by the fuel industry but in this study you can see that even in Poland today it is more beneficial to the climate to drive an electric vehicle than a diesel.”
The new study uses an EU estimate of Poland’s emissions – at 650gCO2/kWh – which is significantly lower than calculations by the European commission’s Joint Research Centre science wing last year.
But its findings will likely be welcomed in Brussels, where a new emissions standard for 2030 is set to be unveiled in November, along with some potentially more radical proposals. 
Speaking in the European parliament this month, the EU’s climate commissioner, Miguel Canete, said: “One option we’re looking at is a mandate to ensure a minimum share of low – for manufacturers it could be zero – emitting vehicles.”
 Today, just 1.7% of new vehicles sold in Europe are electric, and some EU officials question whether Europe has access to enough lithium to create a 5-10% market share for electric cars anytime soon. Its capacity to scale up construction of battery plants may also be in doubt.
“You can’t have a massive explosion of electric cars as there’s no plants here to build the batteries,” one EU source said. “In any case, when you take into account the emissions from battery manufacture and electricity supply, their GHG emissions are not so attractive.
The VUB study says that while the supply of critical metals – lithium, cobalt, nickel and graphite – and rare earths would have to be closely monitored and diversified, it should not constrain the clean transport transition.
As battery technology improves and more renewables enter the electricity grid, emissions from battery production itself could be cut by 65%, the study found.

. I'm sure you'll read whatever you want into what you see. If I'm silent in return, you're welcome to think you've scored a point. Silently, I'll be judging your reading comprehension skills.

So now is the time - it's your moment to shine as a scientific luminary - slamming the door won't win you the recognition you evidently feel you deserve.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1509965145000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16571315', u'in_reply_to': u'107808980', u'id': u'107819712', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ChapStewie', u'text': u'BQSTART

Your comparison would need to generate 3.2GW of dispatchable power for it to be similar.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1509964384000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16571315', u'in_reply_to': u'107808980', u'id': u'107819161', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ComfortablyPlumb', u'text': u'But all those things you mention (and more) are already accounted for in ECS and TCS modelling since the late 70's to a probability of 1ς - and the latency you refer to is solely TCS.
If you're going to ignore the literally thousands of corroborative models then you should give a reason.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1509962043000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14842422', u'in_reply_to': u'107808757', u'id': u'107817459', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'paulchevin', u'text': u'@jimmww I am beginning to think that you must inhabit some parallel universe in which black is white, true is false and the normal principles of science don't apply; that is certainly the only way any objective person could imagine that your contributions to this discussion have any merit at all!
You're now even suggesting that I've used ad hominem against you, but somehow don't recognise that accusing me of being a "danger to the young" is precisely that! You also described the IPCC as being "infantilely incompetent" and the highly respected Peter Hadfield as a "snake oil salesman"..... and all because they dare to do science the way it's supposed to be done and reached conclusions that contradict your ill-informed point of view.
For the record, I have described a number of your claims as being "silly", which they are (very!) and described you as being "ignorant" in relation to your knowledge and understanding of the science of climate change, which is self-evident to anyone who has a reasonable grasp of the subject. What you also fail to grasp is that there is an implied insult to the entire scientific community in your attitude; that somehow they have all been incompetent and missed "obvious" flaws in their conclusions. Can you not see why it is hard for any of us to take you seriously under such circumstances?
"Every fact I've noted is subject to possible refutation." and "I've cited facts which remain undisputed"
No! In science, an assertion requires support from verifiable evidence before it becomes a fact. I've given you detailed explanations as to why your key assertions with reference to climate change are incorrect; you may not like what I've said because it challenges misconceptions on your part that are clearly very deeply ingrained. However, to prove me wrong you need to address not me but the peer-reviewed literature that presents presents the evidence I've described to you.
Also, although some of your "facts" may be true, your lack of basic understanding means that you are misapplying them. For example the "Beer-Lambert Law" assumes constant concentration across the path length (hence my point about lab-based experiments) and therefore can't be applied to a column of air several miles high where the concentration is gradually falling. Jason Rogers also pointed out that it's actually far more complex than that anyway for atmospheric absorption of CO2.

Observations. "Land & Ocean Temperature Anomaly 1.565C 0.090 (+-) Relative to 1850-1900"http://berkeleyearth.org/temperature-reports/march-2016/
The first goal of the Paris Agreement was to try to limit warming to 1.5 above pre-industrial. Well that's gone, with a reading of 1.565 above 1850-1900.
Second goal was to remain well clear of 2 degrees above pre-industrial. Well 1850-1900 is about 0.2 +/- 0.1 above pre-industrial and so 1.565 +/- 0.09 is 1.575 to 1.955. That's not 'well clear' by any reasonable definition.
The second part that you quoted... The March land temperature was 2.752 +/- 0.162 above 1850-1900. Add in the 0.2 +/- 0.1 and you get a range for the current land temperature of 2.69 to 3.2. The land responds quickly to forcings, the ocean much slower. So the ocean is clearly still lagging and therefore cooling the land below it's final temperature. (note that I'm not talking about the 'at 2100 temperature as used in sensitivity discussions). So we can say with confidence that the final temperature with the *current* atmosphere would be greater than the 2.69-3.2 range. How much greater I don't know. I'm guessing significantly. Beyond that there's the matter of aerosol cooling. It's currently a strong negative forcing, the size of which is debated, but the consensus seems to be condensing in the 1.0-1.2 range. That's inescapable as we either stop now, and bear that warming, or we continue to burn coal and we'll eventually get that warming by adding CO2. So adding that gets us the range of 3.69-4.4 degrees from the current atmosphere minus the current aerosols. Remembering that this range neglects the cooling of the land by the ocean. So that's why the lowest figure in my statement "near certain catastrophe that 4 to 6 degrees of warming will bring" is set at '4'. I thought '4' sounded pithier than "...avoid the near certain catastrophe that some level of warming greater by an amount similar to the current cooling of the land by the ocean, than the range of 3.69-4.4 to 6 degrees of warming will bring" The "6 degrees" assumes in the absence of urgent action some unspecified time and emissions go by before we stop burning coal and the aerosols fall out.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1509929618000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14534311', u'in_reply_to': u'107794829', u'id': u'107808757', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'jimmww', u'text': u'@paulchevinWhew! What a load of nonsequiturs. Really got your panties in a bunch, didn't you.
If I cite physical theory, you shout that THIS ISN'T A LABORATORY EXPERIMENT! If I cite data, you shout that that doesn't accord with theory, and besides, other things besides CO2 are at play!
This is getting tedious, and probably unnecessary for the intelligent openminded reader. But I'll pick the low-hanging fruit and point out that Evolution by natural selection is demonstrated by so many disparate facts from so many disparate fields that there literally is no other explanation for the diversity of life except miracles. And we don't believe in those any more.
CO2 controlling climate however - note that you've already agreed that CO2 doesn't control climate - is not only bereft of evidence, but, unlike evolution, there are a myriad of alternative and supplementary reasons for climate change - changes in insolation, or in quality of solar radiation, or changes in cosmic rays, or orbital variations, or precession of axis, or AMO, or PDO, or El Nino, or volcanic activity, or clouds, or... miracles.
The Null Hypothesis for the diversity of life would be... what, that it's unknown? That didn't survive the massive data inflow. The Null Hypothesis for climate change is that a lot of things influence it and different ones at different times, and there's no evident lockstep control. As Dyson pointed out, our understandings are very good at explaining the past and terrible at predicting the future. Feynman told you how science works, but you most unwisely chose to disparage him.
In other words, we can't dial in a nice climate by turning the CO2 control knob.
Your appeal to consensus is amusing. But, hell, it works in sororities.
If you weren't insisting that CO2 controls climate rather than influences it, you wouldn't be in this Trumplike position. We could be discussing how much influence, at what levels, and over what period of time, and comparing those ideas to historical data. But no, you go all in. Well, kiddo, you're out of chips. I withdraw all my objections to continued coal burning. All we need is to get the nasty greenies out of the way. No need to supply energy for extraction of diffuse CO2 because I see that the scientists who must be respected, took time out of their busy day to write a great brochure full of exact details, like "The majority of the energy required to run the direct air capture plant comes from low-grade/waste heat." so no need to worry about Gibbs and his silly energy of mixing (waaait, was Gibbs a scientist?.... errr never mind). 
It's even being built in 'commercial' levels. So all our problems are over. So to pull our atmospheric CO2 levels back down to safe levels, we just need to remove say twice what we emit. That should get us down to safe levels in 20 years or so. So remove 16 000 million tonnes of carbon a year. That's about 60 000 million tonnes of CO2 every year. Their largest 'commercial' unit removes 5 tonnes a day. So we only need 34 million of them. Thank god for commercial quantities eh.
Oh, while I wrote this Raykalon gave some figures that the scientists must have been too busy sciencing to put in the brochure. 1500 kWh of thermal and 150 kWh of electrical for each tonne of CO2. Ok, so each year we just need 60 000 million times 1500 kWh of thermal. So that's errp, too many millions and billions. I might just change that to reasonable figures. 1.5x10^6 Wh x 6x10^10 comes out at 9x10^16 Wh. Call it 10^17 Wh. Divide by 10^12 to get TWh which is how this is usually expressed. 10^5 TWh per year. Oh, that turns out to be 2/3 of the entire planetary use of *primary* energy (or about equal to the final energy output of the entire world, but since the scientists who took time out from sciencing to write it made it clear that we're only using waste heat, we'll go with the primary rather than final). The maths for the electrical energy is easy, because it's a 10th. So 10^4 TWh. Well world electricity production is 2.4x10^4. So that's only a little under half of the entire planetary output of electricity. 
Then all you have to do is compress it for storage. CO2 is 44 g/mol, so that's 23000 moles per tonne. Times 22.4 (number of litres of gas in a mole at STP) is 515,200 litres.
A Bauer I 28.0-75 compressor compresses 3500 l/min to the required pressure. (that's a very big compressor btw). So it would take 147 minutes to compress that much CO2. It draws 72 kW while doing that, so it would draw 176 kWh. Compressor tech is very mature, and we're not going to see any big improvements on that. 
That's bit more than the separation took. So say 1.2x10^4 TWh/y. Making a total of 2.2x10^4 TWh a year compared to the planetary output of 2.4x10^4.
I think we can call that as near as makes no difference to the entire planetary output of electricity. 
So, problem solve, keep burning coal, keep respecting scientists and their mad brochure writing skilz.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1509834299000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'i see that the scientists who must be respected took', u'effect': u'no need to supply energy for extraction of diffuse co2 like comes'}, {u'cause': u"it 's a 10th", u'effect': u'the maths for the electrical energy is easy'}], u'author_id': u'14534311', u'in_reply_to': u'107758467', u'id': u'107770024', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ID2310987', u'text': u'BQSTART

We can't continue to sit on our hands and expect some miracle fantasy perpetual motion machine to be invented by teams of plucky scientists and engineers to save us. The comforting stories that the media and the Guardian in particular have been telling us are counter to everything we know about how the world works. The CO2 we put in the air will (for human timescales) stay there and we can't get it out. Far from 'just rolling' with it, we need to be fighting against it tooth and nail, like it's the fight of our lives, because it's the fight of our lives for our lives.
I wouldn't bother pointing out that despite reducing CO2 output heat continued to rise because it's obvious that decadal changes in emissions don't matter much in the context of the heat content of the oceans. It's the exact opposite. Since we can't depend on these fantasy carbon suckers, *dramatically* cutting CO2 emission is our only reasonable course of action. Yes it's now well too late to avoid a complete disaster. That's locked in. However we can avoid making it *even worse*. The more carbon we emit, the faster the permafrost will melt and the bigger the pulse of GHG will be. If we cut emissions *dramatically* right now, we can perhaps have that pulse spread out a bit.
