Even if your wife has studied Env Management (which is a pretty poor attempt at a plea to your own authority!), you clearly haven't demonstrated sufficient objectivity or insight to suggest that you understand the subject at all.', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1509628024000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16473314', u'in_reply_to': u'107679261', u'id': u'107681351', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Gerryofhamilton', u'text': u'Thanks again.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1509677763000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14555058', u'in_reply_to': u'107705062', u'id': u'107705625', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Gerryofhamilton', u'text': u'"Very easy to disprove." So already done then.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1509677592000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14555058', u'in_reply_to': u'107705221', u'id': u'107705588', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'jimmww', u'text': u'@paulchevinYou now say: " I have never said that CO2 "controls" climate. What I have said is that a rise in CO2 concentration in the atmosphere exerts a radiative forcing: THAT is what the theory says. The response of the climate to that forcing depends on whether other forcings are also in play at the same time."
But, no, that is a deliberate falsehood. What you did actually say was in response to my "From ancient data to the most recent, there's nothing to suggest that CO2 is in control of climate change, certainly not at this level and this rate of change", and you stated: "Incorrect! Now you have finally confirmed my fear that you didn't bother to watch the videos I linked to. If you had done so you would know that your statement is false." 
So now you clearly agree that my statement is correct, so we can agree that CO2 forcing is sometimes operative and sometimes not, depending on a multitude of other factors, and cannot be considered to be in control. From which it follows, as the night the day, that our pitiful attempts to control CO2 levels in the air are doomed to have no predictable effect whatsoever.
Thank you. You're almost there. I assume you've reviewed the Beer-Lambert Law and the Modtran model and can also agree that the GHG effect of CO2 radiative forcing exerts 50% of its effect in the first 20 ppm and declines exponentially after that. And that the statistical pause for the last 18 years translates to the minor increases in temp along the way being well within the error of measurement. And that radiative forcing is a function of molecular structure. And you might even acknowledge that exponential decay IS a logarithmic relationship. Splendid. So, how does it feel to have finally surrendered so gracefully? Perhaps we can all give it a rest now, eh?', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1509847135000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'18289901', u'in_reply_to': u'107773111', u'id': u'107773536', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Jason Rogers', u'text': u'Oh, in the unlikely case that you struggle with numbers larger than 5. 2x10^13 tonnes is 20 000 cubic km of water. Enough to drop the sea level by 5.5 cm per year. Oh, I haven't exactly managed to keep the numbers under 5...
But anyway, it solves sea level rise too! Win Win. 
(or we could just compress the gas the way the Icelanders do but that takes us back to the whole planetary output of electricity that you poo pooed.)', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1509846875000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14534311', u'in_reply_to': u'107772002', u'id': u'107773484', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'jimmww', u'text': u'Oops. I missed this:"You are really very naive (or more likely in denial) if you believe that the scientific community would have reached such a strong consensus "
And how long did it take for continental drift... ? The scientific community, bless its heart, is as fallible as any other community. And you know who you are.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1509765128000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'18289901', u'in_reply_to': u'107743911', u'id': u'107745764', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Jason Rogers', u'text': u'Actually, I will ad one more thing. Shanesw was on the money. It's the CO2 in the air that matters. Even if Coal CCS works a treat, and there are perpetual motion machines for all, and we can generate as much power as we want from coal. Who cares? Does it make any difference if it's coal with fantasy tech, nuclear, wind, solar PV? Not a jot. If it worked, yay! It won't but if it did, Yay!!! 
Still have to get the CO2 that's already there, out before we turn off coal or we'll go straight to 4 degrees above pre-industrial. That means direct air.', u'recommendation_count': u'6', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1509764716000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14534311', u'in_reply_to': u'107744041', u'id': u'107745699', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'paulchevin', u'text': u'"Looks", as in apparent age; plenty of people look younger than they really are .... and please don't try to pretend that it wasn't his appearance that you picked up on initially!', u'recommendation_count': u'6', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1509627279000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16473314', u'in_reply_to': u'107679022', u'id': u'107680717', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'DennisHorne', u'text': u'This comment was removed by a moderator because it didn't abide by our

For more detail see our FAQs.', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1509625649000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u"it did n't abide by our community standards", u'effect': u'this comment was removed by a moderator'}], u'author_id': u'4446531', u'in_reply_to': u'107679022', u'id': u'107679388', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'jimmww', u'text': u'@Gerryofhamilton "For example, in the Depression years 1929-1931, human CO2 output declined by 30% and temps kept rising to 1940. They then declined to 1965 despite a fair amount of CO2 production during WWII."
Well it matters to those who would like to see evidence that reducing human production of CO2 might have an effect on global temperature. They might hate to be throwing their money down a bottomless hole.
To the devout, the true believers, it may not matter a whit.
Very easy to disprove. Try it.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1509675845000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'18289901', u'in_reply_to': u'107645100', u'id': u'107705221', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'jimmww', u'text': u'Easier on us does not mean easy or problem-free. It means more people suffer and die in a slightly colder world than in a slightly warmer one. So a fortiori if CO2 were to make the world slightly warmer, which it doesn't, it would be preferable to having a colder world if we could manage that, which we can't.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1509675137000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'18289901', u'in_reply_to': u'107643778', u'id': u'107705062', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'paulchevin', u'text': u'"Feynman told you how science works, but you most unwisely chose to disparage him."
Right..... I had misunderstood the point you made further back up the thread. I didn't have the time to watch the entire video by Feynman and made my comment based on the impression you gave that he was supporting your position........ which he wasn't! Feynman did explain how a scientific study works but he did NOT say anything that remotely endorses your position, so I'm afraid you have mischaracterised him.
You see.... I am more than happy to acknowledge when I make a mistake, but how about you? No more claims that "CO2 is a forcing period"? Can I take your silence on this as a tacit acknowledgement that you were wrong? No acknowledgement that you were wrong about the "statistical pause"? 
"Your appeal to consensus is amusing. But, hell, it works in sororities."
The article I linked to on consensus couldn't have been clearer and explained EXACTLY why you are wrong. Your response, predictably, has been to descend into rhetoric.
"If you weren't insisting that CO2 controls climate rather than influences it"
You're repeating the same straw man again. I have never said that CO2 "controls" climate. What I have said is that a rise in CO2 concentration in the atmosphere exerts a radiative forcing: THAT is what the theory says. The response of the climate to that forcing depends on whether other forcings are also in play at the same time; it's actually very simple.... except to someone such as yourself whose only aim is to discredit science you find inconvenient.', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1509845013000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16473314', u'in_reply_to': u'107770842', u'id': u'107773111', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'paulchevin', u'text': u'@jimmww. With this latest post you are just digging yourself in ever deeper. Your confidence and arrogance are actually your weaknesses and although you have accused me more than once of using straw man arguments, your latest post is almost entirely constructed of them! On top of that, you are now "borrowing" comments from one point I've made and trying to apply them to others they never applied to - what a load of tosh you write!
"If I cite physical theory", you shout that THIS ISN'T A LABORATORY EXPERIMENT!
First of all, I tend to use capitals to emphasize something - it's not about shouting! Second, just to be clear (as context is crucial), my comment about lab-based experiments was in response to your fixation with "50% GHE at 20 ppm". First of all, I have yet to see a proper peer-reviewed reference from you for this, but even if it's correct it CERTAINLY isn't "physical theory" - it is, at best, an observation. My reference to laboratory experiments relates to the fact that while you might well find absorption of IR by CO2 quickly becomes saturated in a tube or tank in a laboratory, this bears little relation to the situation in an atmosphere several miles deep! The point Jason Rogers and myself have made repeatedly is correct and you are completely wrong if you imagine that adding more CO2 to the atmosphere will have a negligible effect.
"If I cite data, you shout that that doesn't accord with theory, and besides, other things besides CO2 are at play!"
This IS an example of a straw man! Greenhouse theory (or whatever else you may choose to call it) does NOT state that global temperatures will always rise in response to a rise in CO2 concentration. It actually states that the rise in CO2 levels will have a warming EFFECT (ie. a forcing). However, it should be self-evident to anyone who has a proper understanding of the science that if other forcings (either positive or negative) are active at the same time, the response of the climate will be the net effect of all of them. The problem here is NOT what I'm telling you but rather your ridiculously simplistic understanding of the science.
"Evolution by natural selection is demonstrated by so many disparate facts from so many disparate fields that there literally is no other explanation for the diversity of life except miracles."
.... and the scientific consensus in favour of human-induced climate change, which you find inconvenient, has been reached for the same reason! It is just in your mind that the evidence isn't there, because it challenges too many of your misconceptions.
"note that you've already agreed that CO2 doesn't control climate"
This is another straw man! A number of different factors can act as forcings and CO2 is one of them. If you can't grasp this there's no hope for you at all! You're just being very, very silly! "changes in insolation, or in quality of solar radiation, or changes in cosmic rays, or orbital variations, or precession of axis, or AMO, or PDO, or El Nino, or volcanic activity, or clouds..."
You're just repeating the same tosh as before here. There is a wealth of peer-reviewed scientific literature available that explains why none of the things on your list can explain the present warming trend. For the record, it has yet to be confirmed that cosmic rays can even seed clouds, let alone control climate.... and even if they can, cosmic ray flux has been going in the wrong direction for them to be responsible. Solar insolation has been falling, if anything over the past few decades, while temperatures have been rising. The Milankovitch can also be excluded as they are, if anything, having a slight cooling effect. Finally, although ocean cycles can have a major effect on atmospheric temperatures in the short term, they cannot drive a long term upward (or downward trend) in the longer term - it would defy the law of conservation of energy. So, contrary to your beliefs, scientists have thought about all of these things and excluded them - that's their job, for goodness sake!
"The Null Hypothesis for climate change is that a lot of things influence it and different ones at different times, and there's no evident lockstep."
I've already explained above why your understanding of the theory of climate change is far too simplistic. There is no null hypothesis, as it is a theory based on observations and facts. Just for the record, here is an excellent article that explains the difference between a hypothesis and a theory:
https://www.merriam-webster.com/words-at-play/difference-between-hypothesis-and-theory-usage
"A theory.......... is a principle that has been formed as an attempt to explain things that have already been substantiated by data." You can certainly make falsifiable predictions to test a theory, but the null hypothesis definitely does not apply.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1509844912000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'it challenges too many of your misconceptions', u'effect': u"it is just in your mind that the evidence is n't there"}], u'author_id': u'16473314', u'in_reply_to': u'107770842', u'id': u'107773091', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'jimmww', u'text': u'No, actually your ignorance is outdoing your stupidity. I wouldn't have thought it possible. "Yes, the presence of CO2 in the atmosphere retains a certain amount heat in the system" 
No, CO2 does not retain heat, nor does any GHG. They absorb energy at their resonant frequencies and immediately re-emit it - unless they bump into another molecule - in all directions, including down. They do not trap heat or retain it. They slow the transmission or IR to space. A little. But forcing is a property of the molecule - triatomic, we may note - not of its concentration.
In the case of CO2, that is an exponentially declining effect. Don't strawman me here, please. You'll look foolish.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1509764634000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'18289901', u'in_reply_to': u'107741721', u'id': u'107745687', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'AvMichelCroz', u'text': u'“As someone who used to be in environmental management I can say with certainty that you are talking nonsense and your lack of any evidence in support of your assertion says it all.”
So - what is the “Lifeboat” analogy about then? My wife is postgrad qualified in Env Management and I have seen the study materials & the underlying paradigms being taught. And I see them reappearing again and again in these threads. Artificial limits set arbitrarily low.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1509625456000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13022945', u'in_reply_to': u'107673083', u'id': u'107679261', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ID2310987', u'text': u'BQSTART
To refute things I have said - my words, not your paraphrase - as you need is a fact. Try it. It may be a novelty, but you might get fond of facts. Who knows?
BQEND
This from somebody claiming that he has only quoted Trenberth exactly and not misrepresented him when your first words on this were... 
BQSTART
CO2 changes, at this rate, at this level, are not going to produce any predictable effect on global temperature - as Trenberth discovered in 2009.
BQEND
That is not even close to what Trenberth said. He was talking about short term climate variability. That's what his study was about. That is what Trenberth has stated. You have misrepresented him. More honesty from you is required. Try it. You might even come to like it.', u'recommendation_count': u'7', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1509625338000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2515806', u'in_reply_to': u'107659751', u'id': u'107679175', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'paulchevin', u'text': u'@jimmww It's very difficult to have a sensible debate about science with someone who simply makes things up!
"Once again, that statement of Trenberth's was merelly an amusing side note."
Personally, I find it hard to believe that you would have made such an effort to justify your position in subsequent posts if it had simply been intended as an amusing anecdote.
"Please reply to "so the next doubling will yield 1.3% of the total greenhouse effect of CO2 which itself is only 20% or so of the total, and which is of course only one of the many physical inputs to climate change.""
If you can supply a link to a peer-reviewed paper that states this I will happily read it and address your point. Otherwise I could be forgiven for thinking that it is just something you've plucked out of the air. After all, the principal reason why climate scientists state climate sensitivity in terms of so many degrees of warming for a doubling of CO2 is that they expect it to remain broadly the same for each successive doubling of concentration.
"And then consider the years 1929-1931, when human production of CO2 declined by 30%, and temps kept rising to 1940."
You state these figures but never provide the links to confirm them. However, even if human production of CO2 fell by 30% that does NOT necessarily mean that CO2 levels stopped rising (the devil is always in the detail). More to the point, though, if you had actually bothered to check the scientific literature you would know that during the first half of the 20th century solar activity was still rising and the IPCC openly acknowledges that this accounted for some of the warming during that period. Then, of course, there is also the not-so-small matter of "thermal inertia" which means that a lot of the warming effect from any forcing actually takes a long time to work its way through the system.... but why would someone such as yourself, who clearly isn't interested in REAL science, bother about such details?!
"And I did address Rogers....."
No! Specifically, you addressed what I am more than happy to acknowledge was a generalisation on his part about "skeptical" websites. You most certainly did NOT address the technical point he made explaining why your own argument is fatally flawed.
"I neglected to mention that the only known factor capable of causing the current...er, warming... was missing in the emergence from the LGM, the Younger Dryas, the Holocene Optimum... oh, but you've seen all these before and in proper pious devotion ignored them completely as being inconsistent with The Faith."
No! CO2 wasn't a forcing during the periods you mention, but I've already explained why that is irrelevant to the current situation. I can only conclude that you are either being deliberately obtuse or that you have no understanding of the science at all!
"From ancient data to the most recent, there's nothing to suggest that CO2 is in control of climate change, certainly not at this level and this rate of change."
Incorrect! Now you have finally confirmed my fear that you didn't bother to watch the videos I linked to. If you had done so you would know that your statement is false. Probably the best single reference to check is one by Royer et al, which confirmed that once the gradual increase in solar intensity over time is taken into account, global temperature actually correlates very well with CO2 over the past 500 million years. Better still, just go and watch the videos and then you'll hopefully stop making the same mistake again!
"Your statements are completely unsupported by historical fact, and you can't even fathom it. For shame!"
My statements are supported by the peer-reviewed scientific literature; yours are just pure fiction!
"And we contribute 4% of the CO2 added annually."
I studied the carbon cycle as part of my degree. Your claim is best described as a "cherry-pick" in that it misleads by only telling part of the story - a lot like politicians abusing statistics!
The natural carbon cycle is more or less in balance, as the CO2 released due to natural processes such as decay and respiration is balanced by the uptake of CO2 by plants during photosynthesis. So although anthropogenic emissions may only be a small proportion of total emissions of CO2, they constitute the vast majority of the NET increase in CO2.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1509670777000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'natural processes such as decay and respiration', u'effect': u'as the co2 released'}], u'author_id': u'16473314', u'in_reply_to': u'107698702', u'id': u'107703988', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, ...]
description: Dana Nuccitelli: Global carbon pollution appears to be close to peaking
headline: N
og_fields.og:description: Dana Nuccitelli: Global carbon pollution appears to be close to peaking
og_fields.og:title: New data gives hope for meeting the Paris climate targets | Dana Nuccitelli
text:
Over the past half-century, growth in the global economy and carbon pollution have been tied together. When the global economy has been strong, we’ve consumed more energy, which has translated into burning more fossil fuels and releasing more carbon pollution. But over the past four years, economic growth and carbon dioxide emissions have been decoupled. The global economy has continued to grow, while data from the EU Joint Research Centre shows carbon pollution has held fairly steady.
China’s shift away from coal to clean energy has been largely responsible for this decoupling. Due to its large population (1.4 billion) – more than four times that of the USA (323 million) and nearly triple the EU (510 million) – and rapid growth in its economy and coal power supply, China has become the world’s largest net carbon polluter (though still less than half America’s per-person carbon emissions, and on par with those of Europeans). But as with the global total, China’s carbon pollution has flattened out since 2013.
That’s especially remarkable because it puts China about 15 years ahead of schedule. In an agreement with President Obama ahead of the Paris international climate negotiations, Chinese President Xi Jingping pledged that China’s carbon emissions would peak by 2030. Republican Party leaders grossly distorted this agreement at the time, with Senate majority leader Mitch McConnell claiming:
As I read the agreement it requires the Chinese to do nothing at all for 16 years while these carbon emissions regulations are creating havoc in my state and around the country
As the chart above shows, Chinese carbon emissions tripled between 1999 and 2013. To slow that rate of growth to zero as the Chinese economy continues to grow would require a dramatic shift in the country’s energy supply. But that’s exactly what’s happened, with the Chinese government cancelling over 100 planned new coal power plants earlier this year. Chinese coal consumption has in fact fallen since 2013. And China and the EU have pledged to strengthen their efforts to cut carbon pollution.
In 2016, American carbon pollution fell to below 1993 levels. The emissions decline began around 2008, which is also when natural gas, solar, and wind energy began rapidly replacing coal in the power grid.
The Trump administration has done everything in its power to reverse that trend. It began the withdrawal from the Paris climate agreement and the process to repeal the Clean Power Plan, has begun censoring EPA climate scientists and deleting climate change information from government websites, and proposed to prop up the dirty, failing coal industry with taxpayer-funded subsidies.
And yet, while these steps can slow the decline in American carbon pollution, the transition from coal to clean energy will nevertheless persist. Coal simply can no longer compete with cheaper, cleaner sources of energy, and the next American president can quickly reverse many of the Trump administration’s anti-climate orders.
In the meantime, many cities, states, and businesses have declared that they “will continue to support climate action to meet the Paris Agreement.” California has led the way, having passed climate legislation including the implementation of a carbon cap and trade system over a decade ago. The state’s economy has grown rapidly as its carbon pollution has fallen. California now gets over 25% of its electricity from renewables (another 10% from hydroelectric), and just 4% from coal.
To have a realistic chance of meeting the Paris climate target and avoiding 2°C global warming above pre-industrial temperatures, global carbon pollution likely needs to peak by 2020. That goal remains within reach, as we now appear very close to peak global carbon emissions.
That’s just a start – we still need a rapid decline in carbon after we reach the peak – but with the flood of bad climate news over the past year, it’s nice to see that we still have hope to prevent the worst climate change consequences.

That's a common misconception about engineering. It has plenty of shades of grey. Just as many as social science. We tend to concentrate on the hard answers because they "feel" nicer. 
There are many, many different designs of bridges that do not fall down. Some of them are better than others for reasons other than whether they fall down or not and often worse as well for different reasons again. Lane widths would be an example. Making them wider allows people to feel more comfortable at higher speeds, but this isn't necessarily "better" since when they do crash they are more likely to result in fatalities. You are balancing fatalities against time and there isn't a "correct" answer on where that balance should be.
BQEND
You've posted a rebuttal to a point I explicitly didn't make.
I stated that there were often many different solutions to a given problem. But I also stated that any solution which is adopted either is a correct solution or a failing solution. You can design your bridge any way you like from a Roman stone and mortar arch bridge to a very modern cable-stayed bridge but if it falls down shortly after erection, either that design was either inappropriate to the problem, that design was defective, or it was incorrectly constructed (which is somewhat but not entirely orthogonal to its design).
Various designs may have varying attributes: cost, carrying capacity, design lifetime, aesthetics, etc., but they all either stand or fall. And that is a "hard" (binary, black-or-white) answer. Most engineering is like that.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1509360888000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'they feel nicer', u'effect': u'we tend to concentrate on the hard answers'}, {u'cause': None, u'effect': u'fatalities'}], u'author_id': u'10100421', u'in_reply_to': u'107413327', u'id': u'107532824', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ToneLa', u'text': u'What a load of blinkered, typically alt right bullshit.

Genetics also plays a huge role. Look at the split by race Asian, White, Hispanic and Black american. How come Asians out perform Whites in academia? 
Yes. The men's hundred meter lineup at the Olympics is predominantly black. Swimming is predominantly white, (that's true too of the US Olympic team - so it isn't shortage of facilities). There's an excess of Chinese maths professors and a shortage of Chinese premier league football players.
If training and practice can only make 10% difference to your innate natural maximum attainment it won't be enough. 26% of physics Nobel prizes have gone to Jews, 25% of Fields Medal winners, 25% of ACM Turing Award winners and 9 out of the 19 world chess champions. The important point is that it's not all Jews it's disproportionately to Ashkenazi Jews rather than Sephardi Jews or Mizrahi Jews, yet they make up only about 2% of the US population.
The disproportionate representation of Ashkenazi Jews in academia also occurs in Israel (despite the culture being the same). Also note that the Ashkenazi exclusively had the white collar job of money lender for over a 1000 years. Plenty of genealogical records of the time show successful money lenders had more children - the link between intelligence and genetics is hard to ignore.
'Equal' means equal rights in law, it means equal opportunity. It does not mean equal outcome - outcome is determined mostly by genetics, the difference you can make is tiny by comparison, get over it.

When I graduated as an engineer (male) I nearly left the profession because most of the senior engineers I came across were extremely boring people who often took the position of waiting around for ‘interesting’ projects from their business masters. I stayed in engineering but forged my own path that saw me work in fields as diverse as manned space flight and technical journalism and on reflection that path was the correct way to go
Engineers being boring is the main reason people of whatever gender don’t go into engineering. Fortunately there are far more interesting opportunities for engineers, young and old, than when I started and now talented people don’t have to wait years for their betters to give them something half way interesting to do. 
I think a lot of people who take up engineering would be happier doing something very boring like actuarial forecasting or sports commentating and I now try and persuade early career engineers who have some spark in them to go into areas such as energy or aerospace or even wider while seeking to dissuade them from the financial sector.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1509224235000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'most of the senior engineers i came across were extremely boring people who often took the position of waiting around for \u2018 interesting \u2019 projects from their business masters', u'effect': u'i nearly left the profession'}], u'author_id': u'1157519', u'in_reply_to': u'107429580', u'id': u'107469506', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'jjc100', u'text': u'Oooh, touchy!', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1509223328000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'1157519', u'in_reply_to': u'107465773', u'id': u'107468933', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Mary Anne Holmes', u'text': u'Look at how much better Japanese girls are at math compared to American boys. Clearly culture and education play a << huge >> role. Isn't that ok? Shouldn't we stop this silly argument and just ensure that the way is smooth for any and every kid? Some kids don't even realize they will make a great scientist or engineer until they are older; why not provide them with the space and resources to make that important discovery?
No one is saying there are no differences between boys and girls, men and women. The question is, what difference does it make to becoming a scientist or engineer? Over half the PhDs in STEM today are being earned by women, in the U.S. So, what difference do any gendered variations make?', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1509218470000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16923725', u'in_reply_to': u'107345958', u'id': u'107466489', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'megreen831', u'text': u'I'll counter your anecdotal data with my own and we'll be exactly where we started. I'm a technology manager. I've employed men and women with it being overwhelmingly men. 
I once had a woman on my team and she was one of two females in a team of 20 engineers. She decided a public team meeting was the appropriate place to bring up that I didn't have enough women on my team. She was clearly calling me a sexist (pig?). And yet, what she failed to grasp was that I had hired every woman who applied, including her. She failed to see that more times than not when I posted an opening for a position, I would receive only applications from male applicants. 
 
Was she good at her job? Yes, she was. Are there good female scientists? Yes, there are. Does the fact that there are good female scientists and engineers mean that women aren't applying for jobs in STEM fields as frequently as men? 
One more anecdotal piece of information. Google is such a diverse place that they will fire a qualified engineer just for THINKING in a way counter to Google's policies on diversion. If they're so diverse, why isn't 50% of their population of engineers and scientists female? Either they're a sexist organization or there is some other explanation.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1509217459000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'18286382', u'id': u'107465773', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'xwookey', u'text': u'You keep saying he presented no evidence, when in fact there were quite a lot of references in his document. I don't agree with everything he said, but it was well-referenced, and _trying_ to be reasonable (he didn't entirely succeed there, but reactions like yours are most unfair IMHO).', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1509210755000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4307215', u'in_reply_to': u'107326625', u'id': u'107461032', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'AntonZ', u'text': u'BQSTART
But why did it change?
BQEND
My guess for the UK would be that it was down to A levels. The first 'A' in computer science was in 1974 if I recall correctly. Before that time if you wanted to do computer science at university, it was easy to get in. If you failed A level maths by not getting good enough grades, the computer science dept welcomed you. That's the route by which most students got into computer science. That remained the case until increased popularity caused them to slowly raise entry requirements. If there is any difference in the distributions, by the time you get to the 99.99th percentile it will be amplified.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1509126439000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u"if there is a change it ca n't possibly be due to biology", u'effect': None}, {u'cause': u'biology', u'effect': u"because if there is a change it ca n't possibly be"}], u'author_id': u'4199046', u'in_reply_to': u'107411194', u'id': u'107428138', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'DavidKeech', u'text': u'That's a common misconception about engineering. It has plenty of shades of grey. Just as many as social science. We tend to concentrate on the hard answers because they "feel" nicer.
There are many, many different designs of bridges that do not fall down. Some of them are better than others for reasons other than whether they fall down or not and often worse as well for different reasons again. Lane widths would be an example. Making them wider allows people to feel more comfortable at higher speeds, but this isn't necessarily "better" since when they do crash they are more likely to result in fatalities. You are balancing fatalities against time and there isn't a "correct" answer on where that balance should be.
We make tradeoffs all the time. Lots of decisions we make in engineering increase one good thing while increasing another bad thing. Or increase a good thing while decreasing a different good thing. And these things aren't always comparable using a common unit, such as fatalities and time.
In software engineering, we often give very little thought to the interface that the software we write presents to the user. In fact, we often don't even consider that to be part of software engineering at all and hire people with a different job title to do that part, such as Graphic Designer or at better places, UX Designer. And we usually pay these people less than Software Engineers because their jobs are seen as being not as important. Yet I can find you countless examples of cases where a misunderstanding of how a medical device works has caused a death. Probably more than cases where a bug in the software inside the device caused a death. But the use and mis-use of our software is part of the discipline of software engineering. We just ignore that part because it's difficult to measure and doesn't always have firm answers.
Another example would be choosing a language to write your next project in. There are a bunch of languages that can be rejected outright as being "wrong" but the decision among the handful of popular languages that are easy to hire for is usually made by which one the decision maker is most comfortable with, not any "hard" verifiable calculation on which language is correct. Even years later when the project has failed, it's rarely possible to say whether the language choice was right or wrong.
I think the biggest reason why we don't see more women in engineering is because we perpetuate the myth that engineering is full of "hard" answers and that women prefer shades of grey.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1509103313000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'they feel nicer', u'effect': u'we tend to concentrate on the hard answers'}, {u'cause': None, u'effect': u'fatalities'}, {u'cause': u'their jobs are seen as being not as important', u'effect': u'and we usually pay these people less than software engineers'}, {u'cause': u'a medical device works', u'effect': u'a death'}, {u'cause': u'a bug in the software inside the device', u'effect': u'a death'}, {u'cause': u"it 's difficult to measure and does n't always have firm answers", u'effect': u'we just ignore that part'}, {u'cause': u'we perpetuate the myth that engineering is full of hard answers', u'effect': u"the biggest reason why we do n't see more women in engineering is"}], u'author_id': u'16543131', u'in_reply_to': u'107327590', u'id': u'107413327', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'MrJoe', u'text': u'BQSTART

I'm sure we all remember the papers from the '70s that said we were headed for an ice age. There were other papers at the same time in equally respected journals suggesting we were on a warming trend. Andrew Wakefield had a paper published in the Lancet that wasn't retracted until 12 years later which has indirectly caused hundreds of deaths and hundreds of thousands of illnesses. Peer review is the best we have, but it is not a silver bullet.
Even when a paper is 100% accurate and true, it's still possible for lay people to misunderstand the paper or extrapolate unrealistic conclusions for the future from it, especially otherwise smart people with no experience in the field in question. We see people like Anthony Watts, Stephen Milloy, David Rose and James Delingpole doing this all the time with climate papers. Remember that paper in the last year about sun spots mirroring the Maunder minimum? The denier blogs reported that scientists were predicting an ice age.
Damore did this with at least some of the papers in his manifesto. He cited a real difference between the personal preferences of the sexes of a particular size, but then used it to explain a difference in employment practices of a very different size.
One of the silliest and most offensive claims he made was that in order to hire more women, Google would have to lower its standards. There were implicit assumptions in that claim that were not based on any cited paper or verifiable facts.For instace, this could only be true if Google had a method of ordering all possible candidates with 100% accuracy from most capable to least capable. Despite the considerable effort they have put into improving their hiring practices, Google still can't do this. They regularly reject people who are highly capable and less frequently hire people who are not good enough. (They specifically say that their process is biased against bad hires. They would rather reject a good candidate than hire a bad one.) Their interview process merely ranks candidates into two buckets: good enough and not good enough.It is also only true if Google has already hired all of the possible female candidates in the good enough bucket. If Google needs to hire a thousand new engineers this year and there is a field of 20,000 candidates above their hiring threshold, 10% of whom are female, Google could choose to hire only female engineers for two whole years without lowering their standards at all. It's possible that all 2,000 female engineers would actually be ranked before all the males within that pool of 20,000, but we have no way of knowing that and neither do Google.All that claim of Damore's achieved was belittling and alienating the existing female tech hires at Google.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1509094347000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'which', u'effect': u'hundreds of deaths and hundreds of thousands of illnesses'}], u'author_id': u'16543131', u'in_reply_to': u'107380598', u'id': u'107405896', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'AntonZ', u'text': u'BQSTART
I don't suppose this study explains why women were more than half of all computer science students up until the early '80s does it?
BQEND
That would be rather difficult because it wasn't - the Guardian makes up the most outrageous lies about this. In 1967, when Cosmo’s “The Computer Girls” article ran, 11 percent of computer science majors were women. In the late 1970s, the percentage of women in the field approached and exceeded the same figure we are applauding today: 25 percent. The portion of women earning computer science degrees continued to rise steadily, reaching its peak — 37 percent — in 1984. Then, over the next two decades, women left computer science in droves — just as their numbers were increasing steadily across all other science, technology, engineering, and math fields. By 2006, the portion of women in computer science had dropped to 20 percent. - Washington Post.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1509117541000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u"it was n't", u'effect': u'that would be rather difficult'}], u'author_id': u'4199046', u'in_reply_to': u'107406563', u'id': u'107423355', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'DavidKeech', u'text': u'This is what people in the tech industry call their "supply chain problem". The gender disparity in tech has existed for long enough that children deciding in the 90s whether they prefered biology or physics knew that working with computers meant working in a male dominated environment, so they didn't choose computers. From that, the assumption probably grew that men are good with computers and women are not which, regardless of whether it's true or not, leads women to choose other careers. The stereotypical computer geek in all popular culture is a man, not a woman, and there are very few counterexamples.
It sounds like a similar thing is happening in your wife's industry. Not that women and men are fundamentally, biologically different but that society has conditioned them from the moment they understand human speech that certain roles are "for women" and certain roles are "for men".
Most recruiters and CEOs throw up their hands in despair at this problem. Google can only manage to hire 20% of their tech workforce as women and they cite the lack of women applying as the reason for that. To make a difference here you need to improve the perception of your industry among the children of today, then wait 10 to 20 years.
A short term solution might be to offer men more, and make it public that you are doing this so that more will apply. You will get more of the currently available supply of men in this industry and as more people copy your strategy, the industry itself will become more attractive to men, which will mean in 20 years time there will be more men applying and you can go back to paying them the same as women.
This solution is the same for women in the tech industry. Figure out the value you get from having a diverse workforce and spend that amount attracting the people you have trouble attracting.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1509092086000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16543131', u'in_reply_to': u'107347747', u'id': u'107403826', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'glueface', u'text': u'I'm suggesting that perhaps women and men who do the same job with the same experience and qualifications are being paid the same amount.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1509116932000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16686513', u'in_reply_to': u'107420607', u'id': u'107423004', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'glueface', u'text': u'She had the unfair advantage of being a girl.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1509091494000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16686513', u'in_reply_to': u'107398970', u'id': u'107403344', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JulesBywaterLees', u'text': u'I suggest you enquire with the ONS as to their methodology but perhaps you are right and women with better qualifications and more experience are getting less in which the pay gap is effectively bigger.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1509113181000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4738374', u'in_reply_to': u'107418389', u'id': u'107420607', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'John Samuel', u'text': u'Projection suits you.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1509091397000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13496713', u'in_reply_to': u'107394875', u'id': u'107403285', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'John Samuel', u'text': u'BQSTART

One more comment about "egalitarian" societies like the Nordic countries. They are engaging in the necessary efforts to equalize gender roles. Their efforts are not yet complete. Pushing back against millennia of inequality takes more than 40 years.
BQEND
Kristin Mile the Equal Opportunities Commissioner for Norway is quite clear, all the measure they have taken to address inequality have made no difference "You get a one ot two year effect and then it falls again". She is quite adamant that it is not discrimination, nor is it a lack of academic ability. The answer is obvious when you ask people; women prefer jobs which involve interaction with other people, men prefer jobs involving interaction with things or systems, with only 10%-20% going against that general trend.
Camilla Schreiner, studied trend of girls’ technical education in 20 countries from Uganda to Norway and found that Girls in less egalitarian countries were more interested in technical education. Camilla had taken a survey with a set of 108 questions and the she didn’t find any equality in job interests in most egalitarian nations. In fact, she found the reverse, the more modern a country was, more was the divide in job selection.
It even has a name 'The Norwegian Gender Equality Paradox'. This is exactly what you would expect if women in advanced societies are free to choose, they will choose areas involving interaction with people, because you are giving women's psychology freedom to choose its own path. And of course there will always be 10-20% who will not follow stereotype (and a good many who fall in-between - this people-thing axis has a normal distribution after all).', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1509044053000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u"you are giving women 's psychology freedom to choose its own path", u'effect': u'if women in advanced societies are free to choose they will choose areas involving interaction with people'}], u'author_id': u'4199046', u'in_reply_to': u'107321830', u'id': u'107383443', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'AntonZ', u'text': u'BQSTART

It is published by Springer Science+Business Media and has become a leading journal in its field. Perhaps you could point to the retraction of the following article:
Sex differences in personality traits and gender-related occupational preferences across 53 nations: Testing evolutionary and social-environmental theories. Archives of Sexual Behavior.
Or the following in Social and Personality Psychology Compass the (peer reviewed) prestigious high impact online journal from Wiley.Gender Differences in Personality and Interests: When, Where, and Why?

description: John Abraham: The Google engineer’s infamous sexist manifesto is contradicted by the brilliance of women in science.
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: John Abraham: The Google engineer’s infamous sexist manifesto is contradicted by the brilliance of women in science.
og_fields.og:title: What does a sexist google engineer teach us about women in science? | John Abraham
text:
What does a sexist Google engineer teach us about women in science?
Nothing. 
That’s the short answer, but it deserves some commentary. In early August, a young Google computer engineer made lots of news in the US when he penned a manifesto that many described as sexist and which led to his firing. The memo was written as a backlash against efforts to improve diversity in the workplace. However, the arguments articulated by the manifesto were rightly described as offensive by Google executives. 
The explosive part in the memo involved comments about how biological differences explain the paucity of women in technology and leadership fields. While there are certainly both physical and mental differences between men and women, the comments about both genders are, in my opinion, misguided and offensive.
This article is not going to focus much on the content of this so-called manifesto. It also won’t focus on the author of this document, except to question the basis for how a very young engineer has the experience, training, or education to make such broad-brush generalizations. I mean, has he for instance managed scores of male and female engineers and been able to assess their quality of work and intellectual capacity? I doubt it. Has he studied this in any detail or published on the topic? I doubt it.
I found this manifesto so ironic because I give a lot of thought to differences between male and female scientists. I am not an expert in the area, certainly not in evolutionary biology. But I am a Full Professor with many years of instructing both undergraduate and graduate students in engineering. I am often struck by how small the female population is in my discipline (perhaps 20%), yet it is higher in other technical fields (biology, mathematics, chemistry, etc.). I am also impressed by how well female students do in technical courses and degree programs. I note a statistically significant performance gap between male and female students in courses; females consistently outperform their male peers.
I also have had the fortune to be a consultant for many different engineering companies from industries such as biomedical, aerospace, manufacturing, clean energy and other fields. In my work, I notice that women team members easily hold their own with male co-workers. I also believe (but I have no evidence) that women think differently than men. 
In my anecdotal experience, women are able to consider problems from a wider range of perspectives. This perspective has real value to design teams, it encourages companies to pay more for female employees (yes, our female engineering graduates tend to make more than their male counterparts). Diverse teams make effective teams. That includes gender diversity. So, in my 15 or so years as a professor, and in my perhaps 50 consulting positions, I have lived an experience very different from the one this young Google engineer articulated.
With all that said, I thought this event provided an excellent opportunity to showcase some female scientists who are either world-known or becoming world-known in the field of climate science. So, here are some short bios of brilliant women climate scientists.
Magdalena A. Balmaseda has been working at ECMWF since 1995. She currently leads the Earth System Predictability Section in the Research Department. 
Dr. Balmaseda has developed her career by helping us understand weather and climate. She has contributed to building bridges between the climate and weather sciences. Her expertise in ocean modelling in general, and in El Niño in particular, greatly contributed to ECMWF’s first steps in seasonal forecasting back in 1995. Now seasonal forecasts are one of the pillars of the EU Copernicus Climate Change Service (C3S), and the ocean is included in all ECMWF probabilistic forecasting systems, contributing the provision of forecasts of atmospheric conditions from days to months and seasons ahead. 
Equally important have been her contributions to the role of the ocean in a warming climate. The apparent slowing of the global rise in surface temperature in the first decade of the 21st century – the so-called “hiatus” – had puzzled the scientific community. In 2013 Dr. Balmaseda together with other colleagues demonstrated that a fair amount of energy trapped in the Earth system had actually been absorbed by deep ocean waters. This outcome was only possible thanks to a combination of information from ocean models, atmospheric winds, and ocean observations, using similar combination techniques as those employed for weather forecasting. 
Karina von Schuckmann is an oceanographer working in France at Mercator Ocean. She leads the ocean climate monitoring activities of the Copernicus Marine Environment Monitoring Service, which includes the development of a regular Ocean State Report with more than 100 authors. She is also a lead author of the upcoming Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change Special report on ocean and cryosphere.
Her research is focused on the ocean’s role in the Earth energy budget. This means she studies how much heat is stored in and how it flows throughout the ocean waters. Her studies particularly highlight the unique importance of measuring the global ocean as its global heat storage is the most fundamental metric defining the status of global climate change and expectations for continued global warming. With this topic she is also playing a leading role on international scientific collaborations under the framework of the World Climate Research Program.
Dr. von Schuckmann’s résumé reads like a seasoned superstar’s; she has worked at some of the best research labs in France, the USA, Germany. I was so surprised to find she only recently received her PhD (in 2006). I want to know how she has become a leader in the field so quickly. I guess talent will do that. Her dissertation topic was on ocean climate variability in the tropical Atlantic Ocean. 
Dr Jessica Conroy is a faculty member at the University of Illinois Urbana Champaign. She holds a dual appointment in the departments of Geology and Plant Biology. Another young and upcoming research scientist, she has been at the forefront of connecting modern climate observations and climate model outputs with long-past climate measurements (paleoclimate data). Her work has helped improve our understanding of past Earth climate. 
In addition, she has developed long paleoclimate records from regions that are very sensitive to climate change. For instance, remote islands across the tropical Pacific and the Tibetan Plateau. She goes where few scientists have gone to make measurements that even fewer can.
Part of her work relies upon lake sediment samples and on the use of stable isotopes (oxygen and hydrogen) to give clues about what past climate was like. Not only does this give information about past temperatures but these data also, perhaps more importantly, tell us what the water cycle was like in the past. She was recently selected as a National Academy of Sciences Kavli Fellow. 
Dr. Myhre is skilled in climate science as well as climate communication. Her area of research is in paleoceanography (the study of past climate and biology through the oceans). Her research requires her team to gather sediment cores from the seafloor, to analyze the chemical compositions and the shells of creatures that are contained within such cores, or to observe deep sea ecosystem using remotely operated submersibles. Her publications have appeared in some of the most prestigious scientific journals.
She may become even better known, however, for her work not only communicating about climate science to the general public but in training other scientists to be communicators. We scientists are often good at talking amongst ourselves, but we are less skilled at explaining why our research is important and how society can use our research to make informed decisions. This is where Dr. Myhre shines. She is a board member of the organization 500 Women Scientists and the Center for Women and Democracy, and is an uncompromising advocate for women’s leadership in science and society.
World-renowned expert in infectious diseases and health, Dr. Colwell has degrees in bacteriology, genetics, and oceanography; her pioneering use of computational tools and DNA sequencing helped lay the foundation for the bioinformatics revolution. This unique background has allowed her to make connections across these disciplines and enhance our understanding of water availability, disease, safe drinking water, and the effects of climate change on waterborne pathogens. 
Dr. Colwell has won numerous national and international awards, such as the 2006 National Medal of Science, the 2010 Stockholm Water Prize, and the 2017 International Prize for Biology, and has and been elected to multiple Halls of Fame. She served as the director of the NSF and has served on numerous advisory roles throughout her career. As with some of the other women discussed here, Dr. Colwell prioritizes scientific communication and engagement with the public, particularly children, and expanding participation of minorities and women in the STEM fields. 
Nasa Goddard Institute for Space Studies is fortunate to employ Dr. Cynthia Rosenzweig. Her technical focus is on climate change impacts – how society will be affected by a changing climate. In addition to her technical research, she has been a tireless service worker in the field, serving as a Coordinating Lead Author on the Fourth IPCC report as well as numerous editing and directorship roles with various climate and adaptation organizations. She also has an appointment at the Center for Climate Systems Research and Columbia University.
Perhaps her most current area of research is on climate and crop productivity. She wants to know how agricultural outputs will change as the climate warms and changes to water availability occur. 
Dr. Lubchenco is well known as a world leader in the field of environmental science. After decades of innovative research at the intersection of climate change and the ocean, President Obama tapped her to lead the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration – the federal agency that keeps the nation’s climate records, produces much of the federal agency climate science, and leads the U.S. National Climate Assessment. She has focused squarely on the intersection between climate change and human well-being, and the opportunities to mitigate and adapt to climate change through smarter coastal and oceanic policies and practices. 
With a technical record extending back more than four decades, it is challenging to find anyone with a stronger pedigree. She has used her prestige to raise the importance of scientific communication amongst her colleagues. In the past, communicating science to the larger public was an afterthought. Dr. Lubchenco made it a critical measure of one’s career. Most recently, she has issued a new call-to-arms for scientists to become more engaged with society to counter the post-truth mentality, enable citizens and leaders to have confidence in evidence and science and work together to solve climate and other urgent environmental changes.
None of these short biographies do the scientists justice, but hopefully they give a sense of how some of our top female scientists are contributing to our understanding of the world in which we live. I know they are making a sexist engineer formally employed at Google look a bit silly.
… we can’t turn away from climate change. The Guardian’s environmental coverage reports the scientific facts, social consequences and political choices that are shaping the fate of our planet. As the world's leaders turn their backs on the environment, we are at a crisis point. Individual consumer choices are important, but we need collective action to achieve the systemic change that will really make a difference. Our pioneering and our fearless reporting on the environment can play a vital role in that. But we need our readers’ support.
More people are reading and supporting our independent, investigative reporting than ever before. And unlike many news organisations, we have chosen an approach that allows us to keep our journalism accessible to all, regardless of where they live or what they can afford.
The Guardian is editorially independent, meaning we set our own agenda. Our journalism is free from commercial bias and not influenced by billionaire owners, politicians or shareholders. No one edits our editor. No one steers our opinion. This is important as it enables us to give a voice to those less heard, challenge the powerful and hold them to account. It’s what makes us different to so many others in the media, at a time when factual, honest reporting is critical.
Every contribution we receive from readers like you, big or small, goes directly into funding our journalism. This support enables us to keep working as we do – but we must maintain and build on it for every year to come. Support The Guardian from as little as $1 – and it only takes a minute. Thank you.

article_tags: [Greenhouse gas emissions, Climate change, Environment, Business, Global climate talks]
description: While almost all companies have plans in place to reduce carbon emissions, those plans don’t go far enough, according to the Carbon Disclosure Project
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: While almost all companies have plans in place to reduce carbon emissions, those plans don’t go far enough, according to the Carbon Disclosure Project
og_fields.og:title: Big companies' climate change targets are 'unambitious', say analysts
text:
Nearly nine out of 10 of the world’s biggest companies have plans in place to reduce carbon emissions, new research has found, but only a fifth of them are doing so for 2030 and beyond.
The Carbon Disclosure Project (CDP) also found that only 14% of its sample of 1,073 large companies around the world had “science-based targets” – that is, goals to reduce carbon emissions which are in line with the global agreement to hold warming to no more than 2C, enshrined in the 2015 Paris agreement.
“Targets [from companies] have previously been short in scope and pretty unambitious,” Marcus Norton, chief partnerships officer at CDP, told the Guardian. “That is improving.”
Companies are not bound by the Paris agreement, which requires country governments to take action to hold warming to no more than 2C, with an aspirational goal of keeping warming to even lower levels, of 1.5C. However, many large companies have taken their own steps to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, including investing in renewable energy, cutting down on waste and streamlining their operations.
Paul Simpson, chief executive of CDP, added: “This is great news for those companies seizing the opportunity of the low-carbon economy, but the rest need to pick up the pace or risk losing out. The majority of the large corporations we analysed do not yet appear to have the right science-based targets in place to successfully transition their business in line with the Paris agreement, though many have ambitions to take this step in the next two years.”
These efforts will continue despite the withdrawal of the US, the world’s biggest emitter, from the Paris agreement under President Trump. Governments will meet in Bonn this November under the auspices of the UN, a meeting known as COP23, to discuss the next steps to achieving the aims of the Paris agreement, and the attitude of the US government’s representatives will be keenly watched. Ahead of COP23, many companies and governments below the national level were keen to stress their commitment to fulfilling the aims of the Paris pact.
For instance, mayors of the cities of London, Paris, Los Angeles, Barcelona, Mexico City and Cape Town, along with a few others, announced they would stop buying petrol or diesel-driven buses from 2025 onwards, and that they would ensure that a large area of their city was “zero-emission” by 2030.
These actions are calculated to reduce air pollution, a serious problem in many major cities, as well as cutting down on global greenhouse gases.
Ahead of the Bonn conference, developing countries have also been a key focus. A group called the New Climate Economy has surveyed Africa and found that nations across the continent could benefit from environmentally sustainable economic growth, potentially “leapfrogging” developed countries by bypassing much of the fossil fuel economy in favour of clean technology, including renewable energy.
The report found that the best way to encourage such sustainable economic activity in Africa would be for governments to devise and implement new policies that would make investments in green growth more attractive, for instance by reducing existing subsidies for fossil fuels and removing import tariffs on sustainable technology.
Governments should also encourage entrepreneurship, the report found, by adapting policies to the conditions in their countries and of their economies, taking into account the available natural resources and the need to keep emissions low while lifting people out of poverty. “Africa has the natural resources and the determination to instigate a green industrial revolution,” said Carlos Lopes, a member of the Global Commission on the Economy and Climate, professor at the Graduate School of Development Policy and Practice, University of Cape Town. “Now we need the right policies to unleash economic transformation, green growth and entrepreneurship across the continent. A more prosperous and sustainable future is within Africa’s reach, we just need to seize it.”
