article_tags: [US news, Greenhouse gas emissions, Climate change, Environment, World news]
description: Interior department had moved to delay to 2019 methane regulation governing oil and gas production on federal land
headline: O
og_fields.og:description: Interior department had moved to delay to 2019 methane regulation governing oil and gas production on federal land
og_fields.og:title: Court orders Trump administration reinstate Obama emissions rule
text:
Rebuffing the Trump administration, a federal judge on Wednesday ordered the Interior Department to reinstate an Obama-era regulation aimed at restricting harmful methane emissions from oil and gas production on federal lands.
The order by a judge in San Francisco came as the Interior Department moved to delay the rule until 2019, saying it was too burdensome to industry. The action followed an earlier effort by the department to postpone part of the rule set to take effect next year.
US Magistrate Judge Elizabeth Laporte of the northern district of California said the department had failed to give a “reasoned explanation” for the changes and had not offered details why an earlier analysis by the Obama administration was faulty. She ordered the entire rule reinstated immediately.
The rule, finalized last November, forces energy companies to capture methane that’s burnt off or “flared” at drilling sites on public lands during production because it pollutes the environment. An estimated $330m a year in methane is wasted through leaks or intentional releases on federal lands, enough to power about 5m homes a year.
Methane, the primary component of natural gas, is a leading contributor to global warming. It is far more potent at trapping heat than carbon dioxide but does not stay in the air as long.
“It’s a good thing the courts are protecting Americans from oil and gas industry pollution, because the Trump administration has completely abdicated that responsibility,” said Michael Saul, a senior attorney with the Center for Biological Diversity, one of the groups that challenged the Trump rule along with California and New Mexico.
“The methane rule puts modest constraints on a dirty practice that endangers public health and wastes billions of taxpayer dollars,” Saul said. President Donald Trump and the interior secretrary, Ryan Zinke, “are not above the law and the court has made it clear they have to stop putting polluters above the people they were sworn to protect,” Saul said.
The court ruling follows a defeat in Congress, when the Senate unexpectedly turned back a bid to overturn the methane rule after three Republicans joined Democrats in voting to uphold it. The vote prompted Interior Department officials to promise to suspend, revise or rescind the regulation as part of a wider effort by the Trump administration to unravel what it considers burdensome regulations imposed by former president Barack Obama.
The methane rule imposes a “significant regulatory burden that encumbers American energy production, economic growth and job creation,” especially in North Dakota, Colorado and New Mexico, the department said.
Environmental groups sharply disagreed.
Rolling back the methane waste rule “makes no sense and is yet another example of the lengths this administration will go to sell out our public lands,” said Jenny Kordick, an energy policy expert for The Wilderness Society.
Democratic senator Tom Udall from New Mexico said the methane rule provides badly needed revenue to states such as New Mexico for public education and other services.
Prior to the rule, an estimated $100m in taxpayer-owned natural gas was wasted each year from oil and gas wells operating on public lands in New Mexico, Udall said, adding that the rule has helped to reduce dangerous air pollution across the west, including a methane cloud the size of Delaware that hangs over the Four Corners region of New Mexico, Utah, Arizona and Colorado.
“This rule is simply good policy good for taxpayers, good for the economy and good for the environment,” Udall said. He and other Democrats encouraged the public to speak out to defend the rule during a 30-day public comment period that begins on Thursday.

The fact that they're both good people is not the reason.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507370235000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'that', u'effect': u'my two very different indigenous friends'}], u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'106357513', u'id': u'106412101', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'I've yet to read Elizabeth Kolbert's book on "The Sixth Extinction: An Unnatural History" in regard to Late Pleistocene extinctions but 30 years ago read the North American scientific literature on the extinction of their Late Pleistocene megafauna and the movement of people from North East Eurasia into that continent. I did this as part of a essay for masters studies and received a pass mark from Tim Flannery who some years later touched on similar topics in his book "The Future Eaters" An Ecological History of the Australasian Lands and People." Tim stressed the role of humans in those late Pleistocene extinctions in Australia.
The sedimentary history of the Lake Eyre basin provides a record of late Pleistocene and Holocene wet and dry periods reflected in the lakes levels and whether it was ephemeral or perennial.
See Magee et al (2004) "Continuous 150 k.y. monsoon record from Lake Eyre, Australia: Insolation-forcing implications and unexpected Holocene failure."Geology Vol 32 no 10, 885-888palaeoworks.anu.edu.au/pubs/week1_monsoon.pdf
The perennial lake levels: 130 - 113 k.y. of 10 m above sea level, 100 - 80 k.y. of 5 m above, 65-60 k.y. of ~ - 3 m, ~40 k.y. of - 10 m reflect increasing aridity. The 38 - 12 k.y. dry ephemeral lake reflects an extra arid phase with episodic water table deflation.
This decline in the penetration of the Northern Monsoon is put down to a "a plausible boundary change that could affect the landward transfer of monsoon moisture is the large scale alteration of the biota - by human activity - across the northern half of the continent ; as suggested by Johnson et al (1999) from vegetation changes in the carbon isotope signature of emu eggshells."
So rather than an either/ or choice between climate change and human activities, it would appear that it is likely to be a combination of the two with the human activities causing some of the climate change.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507354867000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': None, u'effect': u'some of the climate change'}], u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'106357513', u'id': u'106405281', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'Which hypothesis becomes an established theory will depend on the evidence.

https://australianmuseum.net.au/diprotodon-optatum

Their proliferation, a move towards a natural propensity for a ferrel existence continues unabated, a lack of responsibility of many of their owners leaves the nocturnal nature of our national fauna particularly vulnerable.
Human activity is also a major factor in reducing habitat and the death of these creatures. Progress is the argument, the 'killer factor'.
The laws have to be tightened around these and similar animals and owners need to have to accept some legal responsibility if for example a cat is left out at night. I know this is easier said than done but that lack of control itself is proof positive that the situation must be curtailed. description: Deputy premier brands Australia ‘deforestation hotspot’ after a 45% jump in her state’s reef catchment clearing
og_fields.og:description: Deputy premier brands Australia ‘deforestation hotspot’ after a 45% jump in her state’s reef catchment clearing
og_fields.og:title: 'Alarming' rise in Queensland tree clearing as 400,000 hectares stripped
text:
Queensland underwent a dramatic surge in tree clearing – with the heaviest losses in Great Barrier Reef catchments – in the year leading up to the Palaszczuk government’s thwarted bid to restore protections.
Figures released on Thursday showed a 33% rise in clearing to almost 400,000 hectares in 2015-16, meaning Queensland now has two-thirds the annual rate of deforestation in the Brazilian Amazon.
The latest Statewide Landcover and Trees Study (Slats) report showed a 45% jump in clearing in reef catchments, where 40% of all clearing took place.
The deputy premier, Jackie Trad, said the rise of 100,000 hectares to 395,000 hectares cleared was “incredibly alarming”.
“We know that the current rates of land clearing in Queensland are unsustainable. Australia has become one of the deforestation hotspots in the world – the only advanced economy to be named in the 12 deforestation hotspots in the world. 
“[It’s] because Queensland has returned to the bad old days of bulldozing hundreds of thousands of hectares of woody and remnant vegetations in order to make way particularly for pasture for cows,” she said.
Rates of clearing surged when Campbell Newman promised to scrap restrictions, which his Liberal National party (LNP) government did in December 2013. Rates then reached a plateau of about 300,000 hectares for several years.
The minority Labor government tried to reverse the legislation last year, but was blocked at the 11th hour in August 2016 when its former MP turned crossbencher Billy Gordon sided with the LNP.
The Newman changes included wiping out protections for high conservation value regrowth, which made up about a third of clearing in 2015-16. The resurgence of clearing shown in the latest figures raises concerns about a fresh bout of “panic clearing” by rural landholders – primarily graziers – in anticipation of Labor’s changes going through.
Labor has promised to push through protections if returned to office with a majority at the upcoming election, while the LNP and One Nation – which could hold the balance of power – have said they will scotch reforms.
The environment minister, Steven Miles, said the latest report was “nothing short of devastating” because of the effects on wildlife, reef waters and coral, and Australia’s carbon emissions.
“It’s even worse than my worst fears for this next round of land clearing data,” he said. 
Miles said that “most concerningly” 35% of clearing was of remnant bushland, “138kha of old growth native forest, the most important habitat for native species”.
“We know that each year in Queensland 900,000 mammals lose their lives due to this loss of habitat.”
Miles said 40% of clearing was driving “more sediment into the Great Barrier Reef, literally suffocating our coral”.
“That’s not to mention the 45m tonnes of additional greenhouse gas emissions caused by this clearing.”
Deforestation in Queensland represents a hurdle not only to Australia’s priority goal of lifting water quality for the ailing reef but also its Paris climate commitments because it represents about 90% of the nation’s carbon emissions from land use.
Recent clearing for suburban development in the state’s south-east has also been linked to escalating pressure on koala populations from habitat destruction.
 “We need a parliament in Queensland that recognises this is an unsustainable problem that needs urgent redress,” Trad said.
Tree protections in Queensland were the critical factor in Australia meeting its Kyoto commitments on emissions cuts before the LNP wound them back after years of disquiet in the state’s rural areas.
Previous protections had brought clearing rates down from 500,000 hectares a year to 50,000. But Trad said they had subsequently “quadrupled” since the year before the Newman LNP government took office.
Conservation groups said the renewed surge belied claims from the LNP and the farm lobby that opposition to deregulation amounted to scaremongering.
Gemma Plesman, from the Wilderness Society Queensland, said the “shocking” figures showed a “hidden environmental crisis” that put Queensland “up there with the world’s worst offenders for forest destruction”.
Queensland Conservation Council coordinator Tim Seelig said the state’s “tree clearing crisis just got a whole load worse”. He called it “a catastrophe for wildlife and a catastrophe for the reef”.
Miles said the figures showed the state was “still suffering the devastating effects of decisions made by [LNP leader] Tim Nicholls and the LNP both when in government and since then in opposition, blocking our responsible legislation”.
He said the federal government had stalled after initially launching investigations into allegations of illegal clearing in north Queensland, and the National party had responded “so violently”. 
He stated: “The Turnbull government since then have failed to have any interest in assisting Queensland to protect our forests [or] to implement our long term sustainability plan for the Great Barrier Reef, which of course is incredibly disappointing.” 
Miles said clearing statewide was the “single biggest threat” to koala populations and that a ban on developer donations, promised by Labor on the recommendation of the corruption watchdog, would help conservation efforts.
According to deputy premier Trad, most land cleared statewide was for pastoral land, with a spike in “fodder harvesting” and “tree thinning”.
Protections would remove landholders’ scope for “self-assessment” and apply the “rigour of science” to clearing applications, she said, and the surge in clearing ahead of Labor’s touted reforms last year showed it was “landholders doing the wrong thing”.
Asked if a tree clearing ban was a “vote-winner” in rural Queensland, Trad replied: “This is the right thing to do, whether it’s in the bush or whether it’s in the southeast Queensland corner.”

[{u'author': u'the_fitzrovian', u'text': u'BQSTART
The world’s oceans are at last receiving the attention they deserve, as the scale of plastic pollution is finally becoming clear, the Prince of Wales has said
BQEND
The Prince of Wales could say that the Moon is made of green cheese.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507401285000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12274714', u'id': u'106430109', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'DerekCurrie', u'text': u'The phrases we know don't cover the scope of the problem. It's not just 'Climate Change'. It's not just 'Plastic Pollution'. It's not just the 'Greenhouse Effect'. I'm waiting for an actual encompassing description of what we humans are doing to ourselves and miracle planet Earth, our only home.
I call it 'Carbon Pollution' for the time being. I came to this term because it is vital to open our awareness to what else we've done to the oceans. We've caused the mass extinction of coral and molluscs around the planet through the creation of increased concentrations of CO2 in the air and therefore the water. This has resulted in the creation of carbonic acid, due to its equilibrium with CO2 in water. As a result, natural biological systems that fix calcium out of the water for the production of shells and skeletal support have been unable to work effectively resulting in the death of the animals that require calcium shell and skeletal support for their survival. 
This problem has been demonstrated all over the world within ocean environments from the arctic and antarctic to the equatorial oceans. The most dramatic and visual result has been coral bleaching and the subsequent death of vast coral reefs all over the world. At this time, the effect is being demonstrated across The Great Barrier Reef of Australia.
I personally had witnessed in 1978 healthy, productive and diverse coral reefs in the Caribbean. What I witness now are vast grey and algae covered plains of dead coral, not just in the Caribbean, but all over the world. The amount of coral reef death that has occurred over the past 40 years is beyond my comprehension. It is blatant and universal throughout the oceans.
There are many human created pollutants contributing to our destruction of planet Earth. That pollution is resulting in far more than 'Climate Change'. That phrase covers only a small part of the damage we humans, everywhere, do to our world every day. If we wish for ourselves and our planet of life to survive, our status quo is over and done, now and forever.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507370117000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u"it is vital to open our awareness to what else we 've done to the oceans", u'effect': u'i came to this term'}, {u'cause': u'we', u'effect': u'the mass extinction of coral and molluscs around the planet through the creation of increased concentrations of co2 in the air and therefore the water'}, {u'cause': u'its equilibrium with co2 in water', u'effect': u'This has resulted in the creation of carbonic acid , due to its equilibrium with CO2 in water .'}, {u'cause': None, u'effect': u'the death of the animals that require calcium shell and skeletal support for their survival'}, {u'cause': u'that pollution', u'effect': u'far more than'}], u'author_id': u'10170574', u'id': u'106412025', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'SergioCasa', u'text': u'Fake news again. They are as much a death cult as ISIS.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507359920000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12607949', u'in_reply_to': u'106397643', u'id': u'106406468', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'stuckinoffice', u'text': u'???', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507345863000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16584535', u'in_reply_to': u'106392085', u'id': u'106403896', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Iamfuture', u'text': u'Just another sublime contrived tactic to give SERCO power to police the Open Oceans under contract in behalf of British Government and Banker cohorts who along with Brits/South Africans/Australians/Canadians/NZ etc are again seeking to rape and pillage the resources from below using semi and robotic submersibles. description: Prince says catastrophic hurricanes are consequence of climate change and welcomes growing awareness of plastic pollution
og_fields.og:description: Prince says catastrophic hurricanes are consequence of climate change and welcomes growing awareness of plastic pollution
og_fields.og:title: 'Supreme wake-up call': Prince Charles urges action on ocean pollution
text:
The world’s oceans are at last receiving the attention they deserve, as the scale of plastic pollution is finally becoming clear, the Prince of Wales has said, hailing this growing awareness as the first step to saving the marine environment.
Prince Charles said it had taken years for the enormity of the problem to emerge, but promised to make it a key priority of his campaigning, alongside rainforests. 
But he also confessed to mounting despair over how little has been achieved in his four decades of environmental campaigning, fearing we are “no longer a rational civilisation” but are driven by economic ideology.
He pointedly chose not to mention President Trump, who has denied climate change, but warned: “If the unprecedented ferocity of recent catastrophic hurricanes is not the supreme wake-up call that it needs to be, to address the vast and accumulating threat of climate change and ocean warming, then we – let alone the global insurance and financial sectors – can surely no longer consider ourselves part of a rational, sensible civilisation.”
He blamed “some strange, ideological urge to test the world to destruction”.
The prince, who has long been a campaigner on rainforests, told a marine conference that oceans were now a twin passion for him. “While we should be relieved that the health of the ocean is now understood, alongside rainforests, to be one of the essential prerequisites for our physical and economic survival, I wonder if the ocean’s fragility is yet truly grasped and how susceptible it is to the impacts of our economic activities … We must never mistake [the oceans] for a new frontier for endless economic exploitation.”
At the Our Ocean conference, the EU also announced plans to devote more than €550m to protecting the health of oceans, with more than 30 initiatives including efforts to combat piracy and illegal fishing, a satellite monitoring system, and a new plastics strategy for the bloc.
Federica Mogherini, the EU’s high representative for foreign affairs and security policy, said: “The sea is a global common. We all have a responsibility to preserve it as a treasure and avoid that it turns into a threat. The EU believes that a globalised world needs a more cooperative global governance. It is impossible to imagine global governance without a cooperative oceans governance.”
Mogherini hoped that other countries would come forward with funding to bring the total to more than €1bn.
Karmenu Vella, the Maltese EU environment commissioner, said: “The EU has been a driving force behind the truly global effort [to protect marine life]. We have EU commitments on ocean governance, illegal fishing and the Arctic.”
One new EU initiative is to establish the first marine-protected area in the Adriatic. About 90% of fish stocks in the Mediterranean are currently over-exploited.
Another initiative announced at the conference to reduce the impact of plastic pollution was the consumer goods group Procter and Gamble’s plan to produce a new Fairy Liquid bottle made entirely of recycled plastic, including some retrieved from the ocean.
Sky announced it would remove all single-use plastic products from its operations and supply chains by 2020. The company will also invest £25m in a fund for startups and other businesses working on technology to solve the plastic problem.
In the Pacific, the small island of Niue, with the help of National Geographic and the UN development programme, is creating a marine-protected area covering approximately 127,000 sq km, more than 40% of its sea area. The island, a self-governing community in free association with New Zealand, is one of the world’s biggest raised coral atolls.
Chile is creating two new reserves, one around the Juan Fernández archipelago and another around Cape Horn, covering more than 1m sq km, bringing to 29% the amount of its seas surface area covered by reserves where fishing and extractive activities are banned.

Turning the bush into mess & scrub! as even my Dobbin-riding Father (A Drover from the Snowy Mountains) would have said.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507275012000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'18224897', u'in_reply_to': u'106354989', u'id': u'106355464', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'MGEvans', u'text': u'396000 ha per year at last count (15/16).
Total forested area of Queensland is 52 million ha https://www.timberqueensland.com.au/Growing/
52,000,000/396,000 is 131 years, not 10,000.
It takes 20-30 years for forest to reestablish, assuming it doesn't go saline or the beef growers just keep it cleared. I'd assume either or both, on past experience. So no recovery, worst case.
In 50 years at that rate, 40% of the Qld forest estate would be cleared. Effects of land clearing tend to be exponential so that's a glass well less than half full in real terms.
There's an old picture I've seen of some farmers developing the first bores in the Great Artesian Basin. They are recorded to have commented appreciatively that the water would last 100 years. That was 100 years ago, and the reality now is that the GAB is critically endangered in Queensland, so they were right but it doesn't help us.
Sustainable development means not overusing present day resources to the detriment of future generations, even if it seems like a very long time in the future. We are living in the unimaginable far future of the people who cut the old forests of this country, and those great forests are all gone now. What I didn't see mentioned is that deforestation also contributes to drought. The unprotected soil dries out faster, and becomes worthless. Trees not only provide shade to slow down drying out of soil and growth below it, but leaves of plants and trees produce oxygen and water vapour in the photosynthesis process. This water vapour collects in clouds and will produce rain. A lack of trees changes the climate to hotter and dryer. Not a good situation. Farmers clearing bushland will only profit from new grazing areas for a few years until the land becomes too dry to sustain any growth. Shame on them. This focus worries me. The key issue is how people live (and to an extent, also where they live) rather than simply 'how many'. No question that current rates of resource use are not sustainable, but as the Greens point out in their population policy, this is compounded by inequitable distribution of wealth and of power. This is not to suggest that SA are necessarily 'anti-immigrant' in some racist or xenophobic sense (whether implicitly or explicitly, as some have at times claimed). But in the current political context, to foreground population and especially immigration as the key focus for sustainability concerns is I think to offer a ready trojan horse to reactionary views that need to be firmly repudiated wherever they emerge. The Greens' policy emphasis on consumption and patterns of resource distribution strikes a better note, with the question of 'numbers' being demoted to an issue that needs discussion informed by broader understandings of the complexity involved.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507264621000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12225275', u'in_reply_to': u'106349978', u'id': u'106351106', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Filipio', u'text': u'Say again?', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507262973000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12225275', u'in_reply_to': u'106350429', u'id': u'106350773', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Nyxlii', u'text': u'Ozstralian and Anotherrose are correct. description: My heart belongs to Queensland but it has been broken by the latest land clearing data. We stopped it once, we must again
og_fields.og:description: My heart belongs to Queensland but it has been broken by the latest land clearing data. We stopped it once, we must again
og_fields.og:title: For the love of Queensland, this land clearing has got to stop | Lyndon Schneiders
text:
Queensland is again back in the news for all the wrong reasons. Coal capital, One Nation on the rise and now once again a world beater at clearing the bush.
For 30 years, Queensland was my home. I left for love and to start a family but my heart stayed in the state. The beauty of the rainforests, the splendour of the reef, the vast forested wildness of Cape York and the expanses of the outback all left an indelible impact. I also miss the honesty, directness and the no nonsense approach of Queenslanders.
For a generation, Queenslanders from all walks of life sought to create a new and vibrant Queensland after the repressive nothingness of the long Bjelke-Petersen era.
We were sick to death of being called the police state, of being the place where creativity was mocked, where race relations resembled apartheid-era South Africa and where the natural environment was under constant siege from all manner of state-sanctioned exploitation.
As a young “greenie” in Brisbane in the 1990s, one of the hardest things about being a Queenslander was the knowledge that massive amounts of forests and bushlands clearing was going on up and down the coast and throughout the vast rangelands of the interior.
All through the 1990s, hundreds of thousands of hectares of bush were levelled by enormous bulldozers and massive metal chains each and every year. In the year 2000, almost 800,000 hectares of forests and bushlands were lost. The cost to wildlife was massive with conservative estimates of tens of millions of animals killed each and every year.
And then after 30 years of unabated destruction, Queenslanders from all walks of life came together to say enough was enough. 
Across the state, communities convinced the government of Peter Beattie to step in and stop the chop. After a few missteps, in 2004, Beattie included tough new laws to dramatically decrease deforestation. These laws passed with the support of the Queensland Liberals, then in one of their periods of independence from the Queensland Nationals.
Even the peak farm body, Agforce, provided muted support for the new laws. It appeared Queensland had turned the page on a new chapter, one in which protecting the environment and building a sustainable economy was paramount. 
In Canberra, the Howard government supported the laws – reducing the rates of deforestation in Queensland meant a substantial reduction in greenhouse gas emissions and meant Howard could claim that Australia was on track to meet emissions reduction targets required under the Kyoto protocol.
And the laws worked. By 2010, clearing had reduced to 78,000 hectares, still a lot but substantially less than the bad old days. But then the tide turned.
In 2012, the newly-elected government of Campbell Newman broke an explicit election promise and gutted the land clearing laws. The old school Nationals were jubilant and the dozers were back into the bush en masse.
The legacy of Newman’s folly is written large in destroyed forests, soaring greenhouse gas emissions and further stress on an already critically ill Great Barrier Reef.
The release on Thursday of the 2015/16 annual land clearing data is heart breaking. Incredibly, 396,000 hectares of forests and bushlands were cleared, a 33% increase on clearing from the previous year of 2014/15. In total, a staggering 1.25m hectares of bush have been cleared since Newman took the axe to the laws.
Attempts by the new Queensland government to strengthen the laws in 2016 were defeated by the LNP and the cross benches.
The cost to wildlife is staggering with a recent report by CSIRO estimating that 50 million mammals, birds and reptiles are killed every year due to deforestation in Queensland and New South Wales.
Soaring emissions from deforestation, conservatively estimated by the Australian government as releasing 49m tonnes of greenhouse gases per year (9% of all Australian emissions), have almost completely cancelled out reductions in emissions delivered through the federal $2.24bn Emissions Reduction Fund.
And finally, massive amounts of clearing in the catchments that feed that Great Barrier Reef make a mockery of iron clad guarantees to reduce clearing made by the Australian and Queensland governments as part of the multi-billion-dollar Reef 2050 plan which saved Australia from the embarrassment of having the reef listed as “world heritage site in danger”. 
Queensland has a brighter future than this and Queenslanders, when confronted with the awful reality of what is happening, will again demand action and leadership. 
It is time for the LNP to recognise the folly of their actions in 2012, it is time for the Australian government to be firm and demand change on climate, reef protection and environmental grounds, and it is time for the Queensland parliament to commit to strong laws to end deforestation in Queensland.

From the abstract of the paper:
BQSTART
Our results support projections of a long-term, self-reinforcing carbon feedback from mid-latitude forests to the climate system as the world warms.
BQEND
Note the following:
1. The study was only done on mid-latitude forests. It doesn't say anything about non-forest soils, nor forest soils in the tropics.
2. The abstract only talks about a self-reinforcing carbon feedback. It does not claim that the feedback is large enough to cause a runaway warming - For that to happen, the release of CO2 from the soil would have to reach an amount which would warm the planet more than the original warming. Remember that the warming potential of CO2 decreases logarithmically with concentration(*)
The article also appears to confuse feedback loops with tipping points, which are not the same thing.
(*) Because CO2 emissions from fossil fuel burning by humans are, broadly speaking, expected to rise exponentially, the projected rise in temperature from this is expected to be approximately linear.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507245190000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': None, u'effect': u'a runaway warming for that to happen'}], u'author_id': u'3791246', u'id': u'106346432', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Iamfuture', u'text': u'This comment was removed by a moderator because it didn't abide by our

But there are reasons to think that this quarter of a century experiment does not consider the derivative (rate of change) - but rather the fixed ambient forcing that is applied. 
(Please do not advice me to read more about the Gaia hypothesis - and chaos-theory, important as it is, is not really what I get from this research. Such things leads to hypothesis that can not be defended. The "atmospheric rivers" are controlled by many things that are outside of albedo and trees for example).', u'recommendation_count': u'6', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507240654000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'such things', u'effect': u'hypothesis'}], u'author_id': u'4706143', u'in_reply_to': u'106342835', u'id': u'106344249', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'GreyBags', u'text': u'More evidence for the right wingers to ignore.', u'recommendation_count': u'12', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507240649000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12928860', u'id': u'106344246', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'DennisHorne', u'text': u'Can't give you details but much more methane from intensive farming and losses from pipelines and fracking.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507240468000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4446531', u'in_reply_to': u'106343384', u'id': u'106344159', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'nonsensefactory', u'text': u'Well, here's a specific example of a tipping point effect:
BQSTART
The Woods Hole Research Center, citing two 2015 studies on permafrost carbon says there may be a self-reinforcing tipping point where an estimated equivalent of 205 gigatons of carbon dioxide in the form of methane could cause up to 0.5 °C (up to 0.9 °F) warming by the end of the century, which would trigger more warming. Permafrost contains almost twice as much carbon as is present in the atmosphere. The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change does not adequately account for arctic methane in permafrost.
BQEND
Here, 'tipping point' refers to the inability of the system to return to its prior state after being forced a certain distance. It's a kind of non-linear effect, like bending a spring so far that it is incapable of ever springing back to its original shape.
In contrast, feedbacks (both positive and negative) either amplify or dampen, respectively, the ability of the system to move in any given direction - for example, air resistance is a negative feedback on the velocity of a projectile; the CO2 emissions from melting permafrost are a positive feedback on the rising amounts of CO2 in the atmosphere. If we force the CO2 high enough, then even if we cut off the initial driving force (fossil fuel combustion), the system doesn't go back to its old state, possibly not for several hundred thousand years if that.', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507239897000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'an estimated equivalent of 205 gigatons of carbon dioxide in the form of methane', u'effect': u'up to 0.5 \xb0 c up to 0.9 \xb0 f'}], u'author_id': u'16819288', u'in_reply_to': u'106340695', u'id': u'106343825', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'nonsensefactory', u'text': u'There's a couple curves to keep in mind when thinking about global warming. The first is the increase in atmospheric carbon dioxide, largely due to fossil fuels:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Keeling_CurveThere's no tendency towards flattening that out at all yet. What about the other major greenhouse gas, methane?https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atmospheric_methaneThis one is curious - almost a decade of little growth in methane (much less being released to the atmosphere as it was recognized as a valuable commodity, and was not being released at fossil fuel sites, but rather captured and combusted to CO2 in power plants). 
What's the explanation for the rise in methane ever since? It seems to be coming from tropical sources and Arctic sources, perhaps a combination of tropical soils and wetland releasing methane along with melting Arctic permafrost doing the same. 
If so, this means we hit the "tipping point" back in 2008 and even a complete halt in fossil fuel combustion over the next few decades will do little to prevent greenhouse gases from slowly rising, simply due to the biogeochemical feedbacks.
Still "slowly rising" over the next century is still a better outcome than "rapidly rising" over the next half century. . . Regardless, we'd better be thinking about building lots of extreme-weather resistant infrastructure, moving to higher ground, abandoning the flood plains and low-lying coastal zones to nature, and generally battening down the hatches. Which would also require that we admit that burning fossil fuels has created a massive problem, something the Trumpistas still deny. . . Idiots.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507239250000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'fossil fuels', u'effect': u'the increase in atmospheric carbon dioxide'}, {u'cause': u'the biogeochemical feedbacks', u'effect': u'even a complete halt in fossil fuel combustion over the next few decades will do little to prevent greenhouse gases from slowly rising'}], u'author_id': u'16819288', u'id': u'106343384', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'DennisHorne', u'text': u'It's not a question of "figuring" it's a question of demonstrating. People will always guess, and some will be "right", especially after the event.', u'recommendation_count': u'15', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507238735000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4446531', u'in_reply_to': u'106342011', u'id': u'106343003', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'samiamnotaus', u'text': u'BQSTART
All attempts to reduce emissions will be difficult. All attempts to reduce population will be just as difficult.
BQEND
Not at all, the latter (high emisions) will ensure the former (low population) is inevitable. It just won't be pleasant but it's the defacto choice we've made. Yes, I have reduced my emisions to about 2.5t per annum, had a vasectomy and have no children before folk say 'you first'
If the worlds population were ONLY 500 Million and they emitted like the USA , you would still have a problem, just delayed by a few more decades. This is NOT a population problem. The estimated carrying capacity of the planet with USA level consumption and subsequent emsisions is about 200 Million.
The assertion about emisions density is not mine, it's by Professor Kevin Anderson, see any of his lectures on youtube. Oxfam came up with something similar last year. Anything by Kevin is worth watching. The assertion on sustinable planetary carrying capacity is from EO Wilson.', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507238592000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12134580', u'in_reply_to': u'106341534', u'id': u'106342903', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'imipak', u'text': u'What matters is the system, not the variable.
At no point in the last three million years has the temperature risen so fast.
At no point has the soil been equally subject to chemical mistreatment or to a comparable loss of vegetation.
The albedo and the moisture above trees steers the atmospheric rivers. These are why Africa is so dry in places but abundantly forested in others, with evidence of being richly forested all over prior to massive deforestation.
The soil balance is a function of biodiversity, which has suffered severely in the last century. It's partially what is taken out of the soil and put back in, but also the bacterial colonies (hundreds, sometimes thousands, of species of bacteria per species of plant), as these alter the chemical composition as well.
Living vegetation alters the atmosphere and the climate. Therefore it influences the mean and variation of temperature.
There are many such factors and their interaction is highly complex. That, and chaos theory, is why we have probabilistic models and can use shotgun techniques to calculate likely scenarios.
It is also why the soil hasn't outgassed in the past, as you point out.
I advise reading books on chaos theory and the Gaia Hypothesis, if these subjects interest you.', u'recommendation_count': u'8', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507238468000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2479766', u'in_reply_to': u'106340007', u'id': u'106342835', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Iamfuture', u'text': u'Aw shucks, they just figured this out. LOL.....LOL....LOL...My my my aern't we the clever dickies, then? Can someone turn the lights off, as there appears to be NO intelligent life upon this planet. Here's the PROOF.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507237376000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17008137', u'id': u'106342011', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Gerryofhamilton', u'text': u'Here is the arithmetic: if the richest 20% are emitting 80% of the CO2, as you say, then the richest 20% must have their numbers reduced. There is a vast overpopulation in these countries: US, UK, Canada, France, Germany, Australia, Japan UAE, and so on. 
All attempts to reduce emissions will be difficult. All attempts to reduce population will be just as difficult. Both are the solutions we must work on.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507236696000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14555058', u'in_reply_to': u'106340732', u'id': u'106341534', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Billhook', u'text': u'Agreed. Yet there is a problem in the meaning of the term 'complacent'.
Over 30 years the Guardian has been reporting on AGW, and most of its staff doubtless wouldn't consider themselves complacent - yet the reporting has never yet described the threat posed by the widely documented scale and rate of acceleration of the eight Major Interactive Feedbacks [MIFs] that scientific research reports, nor their implication of our inevitable reliance on both the Carbon Recovery and Albedo Restoration modes of geo-engineering alongside Emissions Control to achieve the essential global cooling.
The 8 MIFs can be listed roughly in order of senority as:- Ocean Heating & Acidification;- Increased airborne Water Vapour;- Declining Polar Ice Albedo;- Rising Permafrost Melt;- Fertilized Peatbog Decay;- Rising Forest Loss;- Rising Soil-carbon Outgassing;- Rising Methane Hydrates' Melt.
The basics of most of these phenomena have been discussed in Guardian articles, but rarely with anything more than a passing reference to their feedback 'potential', when in reality they have been up and running for periods ranging from centuries to at least a decade. 
No attempt has been made to publish an article describing their combined action - the present article is the best yet in mentioning 3 MIFs in passing - despite the basic science on them having been widely available for decades. (I first learnt of the potential of 7 out of 8 of them in Dr John Gribben's 1989 book "Hothouse Earth").
What needs to be very widely understood is that the MIFs are not only interactive in the longer term - by the warming each one causes not only reinforcing its own warming output but also reinforcing all other MIFs' warming outputs after the 35-yr timelag on GHGs' warming effects due to the oceans' thermal inertia -but they are also interactive currently - by very diverse 'direct coupling mechanisms' between MIFs whereby physical changes caused by one drive the acceleration of another, which in turn drives the acceleration of others.
A commonly cited example of such a chain of 'direct coupling mechanisms' is that of Ocean Heating & Acidification driving the Polar Albedo Loss by melting ice - which yields warmer air masses above the Arctic Ocean that then move inland - where their signature has been recorded in accelerated rates of Permafrost Melt - which then contributes to Forest Loss with its further carbon output. And so on . . . 
The key observation is that none of the MIFs can reliably be evaluated in isolation since all are subject to acceleration by others and impose acceleration on others. They should instead be considered as a single organic system which has the potential to impose very abrupt warming on the planet - particularly under the present unprecedented rates of increase of anthropogenic airborne CO2, CH4 and other GHGs.
For the Guardian to get beyond complacency and instead become a part of the solution its reporters need to step away from the comfortable 30-yr position of the tacit 'Denial of Urgency' - such as underlay its total lack of critique of the grossly ambiguous and complacent UK goal for Paris that was agreed by Milliband, Cameron & Clegg as "Net-zero global emissions in the second half of the century" -and instead start to inform the readership of the existential threat that Climate Destabilization now poses to our society, against which we currently lack the political will to regulate emissions and to apply extant technologies at the maximum rate and also to develop the additional geo-engineering technologies that will be critical to society's survival.
No doubt there are Guardian journalists who think they're doing their best - they need to understand that they won't know what their best is until after they've tried far far harder.

BQSTART
Potential feedback loops, or tipping points, have long been suspected to exist by scientists, and there is some evidence for them in the geological record.
BQEND
The link given for tipping points is just somebody on the letters page.
Tipping points are not synonymous with feedback, feedback is a well defined scientific term. A complex topic I studied to degree level and still barely understand.

Tipping points not so much.

BQSTART
A climate tipping point is a somewhat ill-defined concept of a point when global climate changes from one stable state to another stable state, in a similar manner to a wine glass tipping over. After the tipping point has been passed, a transition to a new state occurs. The tipping event may be irreversible, comparable to wine spilling from the glass: standing up the glass will not put the wine back.

BQSTART
The Grauniad is a nickname for the UK national newpaper, the Guardian, because of a now ill-founded reputation for typos. The name was given to it by the satirical magazine Private Eye. The Guardian newspaper earned its reputation for lots of misprints in the days of hot-metal printing when it was published in Manchester (it was originally called the Manchester Guardian), and the editions that appeared in London were very early editions brought down by train, before all the errors had been spotted.
BQEND

Shut off your mobiles to conserve battery power (and recharging), turn off your computers and flat screen TVs, think how much the cumulative effect of growing coffee for all those lattes have on the land, etc. We have the power to reduce energy consumption, but where is the will?', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507323349000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15948257', u'in_reply_to': u'106341534', u'id': u'106397801', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'swimbouy', u'text': u'Thank you. Yes I agree this is an additional concern. However, I do not believe the reported paper justifies the alarmed nature of the reporting. Forest soils may, or may not be typical of all soil types; intuitively I would guess they were near to the extreme, and extrapolating them to cover other soil types would thus be dangerous. In addition, the paper states a positive feedback from this soil type alone, which even if valid for all soil types, may not be large enough to create a "runaway". In that regard, the article seems to be inflating claims that are not in the paper.
As I said in another response; this is somewhat academic, since we are nowhere close to doing enough to limit climate change from fossil fuel burning. It is, I think, important to be even-handed in our scepticism. I note that another commentator had similar concerns to mine', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507322728000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3791246', u'in_reply_to': u'106396898', u'id': u'106397548', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'glacier', u'text': u'You are cute. That is also indisputable. There is a "but" hidden here - you must come up with a way that reality work that survive the same scientific scrutiny as AGW has over - let us say 200 years - while adding better explanation to what is going on. 
I can not wait to read that paper that will make 97% of scientists bow in awe.', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507322602000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4706143', u'in_reply_to': u'106396558', u'id': u'106397496', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'glacier', u'text': u'I think it is wrong to say that the global climate is "fundamentally unstable". It is in fact amazingly stable. 
We have tested this over the last 2.4 million years - by observing "resetting/perturbation" of the global climate around 40 times. The glacial cycles. If it was deeply chaotic - this would have given some fascinating and random stuff happening. Instead we see the same patterns repeat themselves to very narrow values - even as the frequency change from 40,000 to 100,000 main cycles over time - with associated change in amplitude (as volume). 
Now - what the ice-age experiment also show us is that climate is non-linear of course. With the addition of huge self-enhancing feedback mechanisms. They also showed us the first truly bi-stable behaviour of the climate system - the Dansgaard-Oeschger events, linking bistability of atmosphere and ocean circulation. 
That discovery in the early 90's introduced some ideas that were taken straight out of physics (as UO explain) - leading to ideas of "reversed" ocean circulation (in simple terms - the ocean "Gulf Stream" rapidly start to flow in the other direction) - "flip-flopping". It also came out of "toy-models" and "box-models" of old - because this behaviour is built into physics itself. 
Now we know that this is not the case - it is general circulation that gets perturbed along thresholds - that actually are rather well understood (though the complete picture involving all sub-systems and chain of events are still discussed). 
I understand this can be confusing - because one do discuss different stable states. But these states are not "flip-flops" - they are more like "twins with different personalities" - or two "gears". 
This is of course a bit technical - and it is good to be aware of climate having different - let us call it "expressions" that can switch extremely rapidly under certain conditions. 
But it is wrong to say that climate simply want to "bite" us in "flipping" randomly. 
Non-linearity is in fact a continuum that one can slide a lever through. But it is still reversible. Even the DO-events that cause massive 10-degrees changes in Greenland and shift the entire Northern Hemisphere atmospheric circulation - is reversibel (taking around 1000 years to recover). 
So from a pure physical perspective - these things are not what many people think of as "flip-flopping" - they are continuum of each other. In other words in principle - reversible. "The rubber band is stretched but not broken". 
Positive feedback is as such not implying "run-away". Pretty much all positive feedbacks we see in the climate system is lovely (spring is a positive feedback). 
These are all principles and simplified concepts. 
And, this is important, they do not really tackle what we experience as surface dwellers. As again demonstrated by the ice-age experiment. The involved external forcing is really really low - pacing a whole suit of positive feedbacks into ice-ages. 
Not chaotic - not irreversible, not in physical sense "flip-flopping". Even if we follow RCP 8.5 emissions until year 2300, it is estimated to be back to normal by year 95,000 or around that time. 
This will obviously be copy-pasted by deniers - as it strongly indicate that AGW is perfectly linear and will go back to normal in less that 25,000 generations after small hickups last only for 250 generations according to the Ice-age experiment. 
So it is worthwhile to point out that when we discuss AGW we look at the future of the world that geologically is as short as - say the time from the Romans to present (rapid climate change in geology). But we also discuss something else - We are actually not performing a "natural" experiment (like ice-ages externally paced) - but more like a man-made supervolcano experiment that dig deep into the geological carbon cycle. Associated with mass extinctions. So it is more than physics at play. It is ecosystems at play. And we do not predict ecosystems from pure physical principles and they clearly behave very different during hyper-thermals than the pure physical climate system behave. 
As such - the breaking points are not so much in the physics of climate calculated as energy energy-transfer/volume transport/vectors and stuff. That simply respond physically. Life however - that follow different rules, with different thresholds. And humans, last time i checked is considered as "life" - not as some Q in physics. 
Finally - rate of change. It is not so stressfull for the pure physical side of the Earth system. That is more a question of getting phase-changes and the delays of feedback right. For evolution is is clearly more difficult when geological time starts to intervene by having asteroids or super-eruptions entering the scene. Evolution do not do selection for such things. Life reset at a whole different level when the geological carbon cycle gets involved.', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507322154000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': None, u'effect': u'ideas of reversed circulation'}, {u'cause': u'this behaviour is built into physics itself', u'effect': u'it also came out of models'}, {u'cause': u'one do discuss different stable states', u'effect': u'i understand this can be confusing'}, {u'cause': u'that', u'effect': u'massive 10-degrees changes in greenland'}], u'author_id': u'4706143', u'in_reply_to': u'106350037', u'id': u'106397293', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'swimbouy', u'text': u'BQSTART

However, it is somewhat academic anyway. As I pointed out, the paper is concerned with mid-latitude forest soils, which form only a part of the soils of the world. For you to get a runaway feedback loop, as Fiona Harvey suggests in the OP, you would need the nett runaway feedback from all the soils types across the world. This is not something that this paper comes even close to suggesting, for that reason I still maintain that this article reaches conclusions that the quoted paper cannot support.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507321902000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3791246', u'in_reply_to': u'106396588', u'id': u'106397188', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'GoldenAppleCorps', u'text': u'Ok. I'm not sure that the Guardian is the place to look for complacency - they seem to me to be doing a better job than almost any other significant media body.
The Paris accord is an interesting example - which we all know will not commit the participants to a path that gets anywhere near 2 degrees. However, it is designed to ratchet up and should pull the pathway down in future. It's the first international agreement of significance since Kyoto and could make a big difference. I am perhaps more "glass half full" than your post, but you make a great deal of sense.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507309195000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13126382', u'in_reply_to': u'106341281', u'id': u'106390331', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'swimbouy', u'text': u'BQSTART
It is your complacancy that is alarming.
BQEND
In what way am I complacent ? I merely pointed out that this article does not accurately reflect the paper it claims to be based on.

BQSTART
If there was even a tiny chance of this warning being accurate, given that it points to a catastrophe for human life on this planet, then we should be doing everything possible to tackle it now.
BQEND
The climate change we are faced with simply by burning fossil fuels is sufficient to warrant strong action - much stronger action than governments are willing to take, given the INDCs submitted to Paris 2015. The fact that this article may not accurately report the findings in the paper does not change this.
However, what is important is that scientific findings are accurately reported in MSM. The recent mis-reporting of MIllar et. al (see the excellent discussion here) incorrectly interpreted the science to downplay the threat. It seems to me that this article incorrectly interprets the paper to "upplay" the threat that the scientific findings reveal.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507307660000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3791246', u'in_reply_to': u'106347378', u'id': u'106389242', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'swimbouy', u'text': u'BQSTART
You seem to say two things - there is incomplete knowledge, therefore this is grounds to reject the knowledge we have.
BQEND
Nope, I certainly didn't say that. I certainly didn't say, nor imply that this study should be rejected. What I did say was that the conclusions in the OP cannot, it seems to me, be justified by the findings in the paper.
BQSTART
Secondly you are confused as to what a feedback mechanism.
BQEND
See my response to MikeSw above', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507306708000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3791246', u'in_reply_to': u'106356150', u'id': u'106388509', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'swimbouy', u'text': u'There are three kinds of feedback;
1. A self cancelling feedback. For these the initial feedback factor is less than 0, i.e. negative2. A positive, or self re-inforcing feedback. For these the initial feedback factor must be positive, i.e. greater than 03. A runaway feedback (this is the kind of feedback that is associated with rock concerts and amplifier). For this the IFF needs to be greater than 1. In other words the feedback mechanism provides a bigger initial factor than the original forcing.
Consider a feedback where the forcing provides a feedback 2/3 of the strength of the initial forcing. This is self-reinforcing since the feedback factor is positive. In this case the feedback produces an overall effect of 2;2/3 + 4/9 + 8/27 + .....which is a convergent series. Because the series converges, it does not lead to a "runaway" feedback.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507306394000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'the series converges', u'effect': u'Because the series converges , it does not lead to a " runaway " feedback .'}], u'author_id': u'3791246', u'in_reply_to': u'106347707', u'id': u'106388248', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Gleb17', u'text': u'"soils in Siberia that are rapidly warning",is there a mistake? "warming"?', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507294043000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15736285', u'id': u'106377059', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'pretzelattack', u'text': u'given your other comments, i think it is more likely that you misunderstand. it should be cooling slightly. all the warming over that is due to us.', u'recommendation_count': u'11', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507293856000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'us', u'effect': u'all the warming over that is'}], u'author_id': u'10767097', u'in_reply_to': u'106374676', u'id': u'106376887', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, ...]
description: 26-year study reveals natural biological factors kick in once warming reaches certain point, leading to potentially unstoppable increase in temperatures
headline: p
og_fields.og:description: 26-year study reveals natural biological factors kick in once warming reaches certain point, leading to potentially unstoppable increase in temperatures
og_fields.og:title: Carbon emissions from warming soils could trigger disastrous feedback loop
text:
Warming soils are releasing more carbon into the atmosphere than previously thought, suggesting a potentially disastrous feedback mechanism whereby increases in global temperatures will trigger massive new carbon releases in a cycle that may be impossible to break.
The increased production of carbon comes from the microbes within soils, according to a report in the peer-review journal Science, published on Friday. 
The 26-year study is one of the biggest of its kind, and is a groundbreaking addition to our scant knowledge of exactly how warming will affect natural systems.
Potential feedback loops, or tipping points, have long been suspected to exist by scientists, and there is some evidence for them in the geological record. What appears to happen is that once warming reaches a certain point, these natural biological factors kick in and can lead to a runaway, and potentially unstoppable, increase in warming. 
Other tipping points posited by scientists include the disappearance of ice in the Arctic, which creates areas of dark water that absorb more heat, and the release of methane, a powerful greenhouse gas, from thawing permafrost.
In the Science study, researchers examined plots of soil in the Harvard Forest in Massachusetts, a mixed hardwood forest in the US. They experimented by heating some of the plots with underground cables to 5C above normal levels, leaving others as a control. 
The long-term study revealed that in the first 10 years there was a strong increase in the carbon released from the heated plots, then a period of about seven years when the carbon release abated. But after this second calmer period, which the scientists attribute to the adjustment of the soil microbes to the warmer conditions, the release of carbon resumed its upward path.
In the last three years, the release of carbon has once again dropped back, which scientists attribute to another reorganisation of the microbes present. They suggest an increase in the number of microbes that can feast on the hard-to-digest organic matter, such as plant-based lignin, which gives clues to the possible cyclical nature of the process.
From 1991, when the experiment began, the plots subjected to 5C warming lost about 17% of the carbon that had been stored in the top 60cm of the soil, where the greatest concentration of organic matter is to be found.
Scientific understanding of the complexities of soil microbial activity is still limited, but the long-term nature of the study provides valuable insights into what might be happening, and is likely to happen in future, to vast swaths of forest soils across the world.
While deforestation has been the focus of most research into forests’ effects on climate change, with a recent study suggesting tropical forests are turning into carbon sources rather than carbon stores as a result, the impact of warming soils has remained much of a mystery. Soils are one of the world’s biggest natural carbon sinks, along with trees and the oceans.
Daniel Metcalfe, of Sweden’s Lund University, said: “If these findings hold more widely across major terrestrial ecosystems, then a much greater portion of the global soil carbon store could be vulnerable to decomposition and release of carbon dioxide under global warming than previously thought.”
The study was carried out by scientists at the US Marine Biological Laboratory, led by Jerry Melillo, with contributions from the universities of Massachusetts and New Hampshire. 
Melillo, who holds the position of distinguished scientist at the MBL, said: “Each year, mostly from fossil fuel burning, we are releasing about 10bn metric tons of carbon into the atmosphere. The world’s soils contain about 3,500bn tons of carbon. If a significant amount of that is added to the atmosphere, due to microbial activity, that will accelerate the global warming process. Once this self-reinforcing feedback begins, there is no easy way to turn it off. There is no switch to flip.”
He added: “The future is warmer. How much warmer is the issue.” While emissions from fossil fuels can be cut back, the reactions of the natural world to a warming climate may be impossible to control.
Some recent work has suggested that the warming of the globe may be progressing at a slightly slower rate than the upper range of previous studies estimated. However, feedback loops and tipping points have the potential to create sudden disruptions that are hard to take account of in standard climate modelling, and these could mean much greater changes and far higher rates of warming in the future.
Separately, research from Stanford Woods Institute for the Environment, and other institutions, published in the Annual Review of Ecology, Evolution and Systematics, and Global Change Biology, called for more work on how soil could be used as a carbon store. When agricultural soils are well-managed, they can store more carbon than they emit, which would allow them to be used as potential carbon sinks.
But the scientists warn that “we still don’t have a strong understanding of the interactions among biological, chemical and physical processes regulating carbon in soils”. They say much more research is needed, particularly as there are dangers in soils in Siberia that are rapidly warning, and could release vast quantities of carbon. They also warn that there may be 25-30% less organic matter in some soils than previously estimated. 
“Soil has changed under our feet,” said Jennifer Harden, a visiting scholar at Stanford. “We can’t use the soil maps made 80 years ago and expect to find the same answers.”

description: A wet July and August in Britain put a dampener on our midsummer butterflies
og_fields.og:description: A wet July and August in Britain put a dampener on our midsummer butterflies
og_fields.og:title: Butterflywatch: could be worse – verdict for the 2017 season
text:
I am still seeing butterflies almost daily, sunning themselves when they can and feasting on late-flowering ivy. Most are red admirals, a large, dark and powerful presence sailing through autumnal skies or feeding on rotten fruit in orchards.
It has been a vintage red admiral year, with numbers up by 75% on 2016 in Butterfly Conservation’s Big Butterfly Count. But sadly it has not been a vintage butterfly summer.
With much of southern Britain enjoying a sunny May and June it once looked as if it might turn out to be the best season for a decade. But a wet July and August put a dampener on most species, which do emerge midsummer. 
Heavy summer rains can wipe out whole generations. One butterfly recorder I spoke to reported seeing scores of speckled woods on his transect but, after a heavy rainfall, suddenly there were none.
It was not a disaster like 2016, when a glorious late summer arrived too late for the butterflies; nor was it like the sodden summer of 2012. Not bad, is most butterfly lovers’ grudging verdict on 2017, and that may be as good as it gets.
Our butterflies are well-adapted to the vicissitudes of the British summer but the long-term decline in two-thirds of our 59 native species shows they are less equipped to deal with rapid climatic changes or the dousing of farmland and gardens with pesticides.
Milder winters in particular appear to be disastrous for many butterfly species, though not the red admiral. Half a century ago it appeared unable to survive British winters and most individuals made the reverse migration to the continent. Now it is not only a successful hibernator, but the most commonly spotted butterfly throughout the winter months. Keep a lookout for this Christmas-coloured insect if Christmas Day is sunny.

No, we don't need them, thank you.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507335799000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15915689', u'in_reply_to': u'106352040', u'id': u'106402154', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Isaachunt60', u'text': u'If you read this Guardian article the percentage of regrowth being cleared relative to uncleared land is indicted in the graphs .As I said around two thirds is reclearing of regrowth [mainly brigalow because it suckers from remnant roots and regrows vigorously but eucalypts can do the same thing].I spent my childhood clearing suckers on my family farm so so I am familiar with the process.https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2017/oct/05/alarming-rise-in-queensland-tree-clearing-as-400000-hectares-stripped#comments', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507335531000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'it suckers from remnant roots and regrows vigorously', u'effect': u'is reclearing of regrowth brigalow'}], u'author_id': u'12014580', u'in_reply_to': u'106395709', u'id': u'106402091', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'anotherrose', u'text': u'Lumping all Queenslanders in this boat is a little like saying that all Japanese support whaling, or that all Chinese use animal body parts in medicine, or carve ivory. description: Accelerating rates of land clearing in Queensland are undermining Australia’s Direct Action greenhouse gas cuts
headline: Q
og_fields.og:description: Accelerating rates of land clearing in Queensland are undermining Australia’s Direct Action greenhouse gas cuts
og_fields.og:title: Queensland tree clearing wipes out federal emissions gains
text:
Accelerating rates of tree clearing in Queensland are wiping out any cuts to greenhouse gas emissions the federal government has made through its $2.55bn Direct Action fund, according to the latest data released by the Queensland government.
The results also point again to apparent holes in the federal government’s greenhouse gas accounting, as its official figures maintain that land clearing in Queensland is reducing, and that changes in land use across the whole country are cutting emissions rather than adding to them.
About 40% of the clearing in the state identified in the latest figures occurred in catchments that drain water into the Great Barrier Reef, which will increase pollution affecting the struggling coral, sparking further calls for the environment minister, Josh Frydenberg, to use his powers under federal law to stop some of the clearing.
On Thursday the Queensland government released figures showing 395,000 hectares of bush had been cleared in 2015-16, according to its statewide landcover and tree study (Slats). That was up a third compared with the previous year and almost 50% compared with two years earlier.
The state environment minister, Steven Miles, said the clearing in one year in Queensland alone caused 45m tonnes of greenhouse gas emissions.
The centrepiece of the federal government’s Direct Action policy on climate change is its $2.55bn Emissions Reduction Fund, under which it pays companies to pollute less.
In the last auction of the ERF, the government paid an average of $11.82 for each tonne of carbon abated, meaning the emissions from Queensland’s land clearing cancelled out more than half a billion dollars of abatement paid for by the taxpayer – a fifth of the total fund in one year.
“Deforestation has a major impact on climate change,” said Lyndon Schneiders, national director of the Wilderness Society. “Ending deforestation would be a fast, cheap and effective way to cut Australia’s greenhouse gas emissions.”
Meanwhile, the federal government’s national greenhouse gas inventory, which is the country’s official source of climate change accounting, continues to find that across the whole country, changes in land use – which includes land clearing – amount to a carbon sink rather than a source.
In the latest federal government figures, for the year to March 2017, changes in land use are counted as an abatement of 0.1% of Australia’s greenhouse gas emissions. The report on the figures says Queensland’s land sector emissions have been “reducing over time”.
Changes in the way the federal government measures greenhouse gas emissions have led to revisions of historical reports, with significant amounts of emissions disappearing. Explanations given for the revisions do not fully explain the reduced emissions.
The environment department said in a statement Queensland data was used to prepare the national figures and informed the national inventories.
“Each year, we update land clearing estimates based on latest satellite data. Where applicable, we also revise estimates to reflect improvements in remote sensing and estimation methods,” a spokesperson said.
The large amount of clearing occurring in the Great Barrier Reef catchments has led to renewed calls for Frydenberg to use his powers under the federal Environmental Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act to stop some of the clearing.
Frydenberg has previously stated that clearing activities require approval under the act if they “have, will have or are likely to have a significant impact on a matter of national environmental significance under federal environment law”.
He told the ABC in July the government had powers to enforce those laws and would continue to do so.
But a WWF report from July found 99.2% of properties where land had been cleared that appeared to need approval under the act, had failed to gain it. The only time the federal government forced a property owner to gain approval, it led to fighting within the federal Coalition.
“The amount of clearing in reef catchments should be ringing alarm bells with minister Frydenberg,” said Martin Taylor, a conservation scientist at WWF-Australia.
“When the Queensland parliament rejected tougher laws the commonwealth was the last line of defence. Minister Frydenberg’s department has the power under the EPBC Act to rein this in. But the EPBC protections only work if they’re used and that’s not happening,” Taylor said.
Frydenberg’s office did not respond to questions about the matter.
