description: World leaders must do more to defend custodians of natural world whose lives are at risk from big business, says UN rapporteur Victoria Tauli-Corpuz
headline: p
og_fields.og:description: World leaders must do more to defend custodians of natural world whose lives are at risk from big business, says UN rapporteur Victoria Tauli-Corpuz
og_fields.og:title: Protect indigenous people to help fight climate change, says UN rapporteur
text:
Global leaders must do more to protect indigenous people fighting to protect their land and way of life if the world is to limit climate change, according to the UN special rapporteur Victoria Tauli-Corpuz.
Speaking ahead of key climate talks in Bonn next month she urged politicians to recognise that indigenous communities around the world were the most effective custodians of millions of hectares of forest “which act as the world’s lungs”.
“Indigenous people’s rights need to be protected in the best way possible, not just for them but because they are also able to provide solutions to many of the world’s problems from climate change to biological diversity. 
“It is in the self interest of states and even corporations in the medium and long term to protect and listen to these people – the question is, will they realise this in time?” said Tauli-Corpuz.
A recent study found that a quarter of the carbon stored above ground in the world’s tropical forests is found in the collectively managed territories of indigenous peoples and local communities.
In Brazil, deforestation in indigenous community forests from 2000 to 2012 was less than 1%, compared to 7% outside those areas.
“They are the most effective stewards of these key areas,” said Tauli-Corpuz. “The needs of these indigenous people are converging with the wider environmental needs to protect these areas.”
Indigenous people are locked in fierce conflicts with mining, logging and agricultural companies and their private security firms in hundreds of places from Indonesia to Brazil. 2016 was the deadliest year on record for land rights defenders with about 200 people killed in conflicts in Latin America, Africa and Asia. In addition, thousands more community activists were threatened or harassed. A Guardian project working with Global Witness is highlighting the pressure many of these groups face and has identified at least 134 people who have been killed so far this year.
Tauli-Corpuz, who was speaking at the launch of a new global institution dedicated to securing the land rights of tens of millions of indigenous people, said there was an atmosphere of fear and intimidation in many of these communities.
The event in Stockholm was the official launch of the International Land and Forest Tenure Facility which aims to help communities protect their land resources as well as combat climate change.
Funded by Sweden, Norway and the Ford Foundation, a US charity, the Tenure Facility, has already provided grants and guidance for pilot projects in six nations.
The Ford Foundation president Darren Walker said it was an important development in the fight against climate change and inequality. “Creating mechanisms that allow indigenous peoples and local communities to gain tenure over their land or forests is a way to tackle both these problems.”
The Ford Foundation has pledged $5m, and Norway has announced a grant of $20m over the coming years. Sweden pitched in $10m during the pilot phase and will fund future projects. Walker said he expects donations to rise to $100m overall within a year.
The project aims to boost forestland properly titled to indigenous peoples by 40m hectares, an area twice the size of Spain, within a decade. Organisers say this would prevent deforestation of 1m hectares and the release of 500m tonnes of CO2, more than the annual emissions of Britain or Brazil.
Indigenous leaders representing tens of millions of people involved in land disputes in Asia, Africa and South America attended the conference. They said the tenure programme was an important step towards stopping the persecution of indigenous communities – but warned more needs to be done.
Rukka Sombolinggi, the first female secretary-general of the world’s largest indigenous organisation, Aman, which represents 17 million people in Indonesia, said: “Our houses are being burnt down, people are being killed, tortured, and sent to jail as we speak.”
Sombolinggi said some progress had been made, with much of the forests where indigenous communities live in Indonesia mapped for the first time. And she said “dominant communities” would benefit, not only environmentally from more rights for indigenous people, but argued they could also learn important lessons from the way many of these groups lived.
“If we want to see the beautiful centuries ahead … we need to shift our paradigm of what constitutes wealth or prosperity because too many people see happiness only in terms of material goods and achievements and it is having a devastating impact. Many of us have lost our ability to connect with natural things and no longer seem able to live in harmony with the simple happiness around us.”

description: Increasingly unfamiliar and unpredictable weather events mean that business as usual is not an option for these islands to survive
og_fields.og:description: Increasingly unfamiliar and unpredictable weather events mean that business as usual is not an option for these islands to survive
og_fields.og:title: Climate change in the Caribbean – learning lessons from Irma and Maria
text:
As a Caribbean climate scientist, I am often asked to speak about how climate change affects small islands. In the aftermath of Hurricane Maria, one of two category five storms to batter the eastern Caribbean in just a week, three words resonate in my mind.
The first word is “unfamiliar”. Scientific analysis shows that the climate of the Caribbean region is already changing in ways that seem to signal the emergence of a new climate regime. Irma and Maria fit this pattern all too well. At no point in the historical records dating back to the late 1800s have two category five storms made landfall in the small Caribbean island chain of the eastern Antilles in a single year. 
The intensification almost overnight from a tropical storm to a category five hurricane and the devastating intensity that lingered for several days are also unfamiliar, even to a region that is used to seeing hurricanes. Alongside other emerging climate patterns, there is a strong case to be made that there is something unfamiliar about the Caribbean’s climate today. We are seeing repeated and prolonged droughts, an increase in the number of very hot days, intense rainfall events causing repeated localised flooding, and rising sea levels that are consuming the beautiful beaches on which tourism in our region depends.
The problem with unfamiliarity is that daily existence in the Caribbean is built on familiar patterns of climate. Our economies are premised on industries and sectors that are extremely sensitive to climate variations, such as tourism and agriculture. In a year that follows expected patterns and pulls no surprises, we see favourable economic growth and improvements in our quality of life. Even when we’ve seen bad weather, we have always had a certain familiarity with the limits of how bad it can be. Until now, newer infrastructure in the Caribbean has largely withstood the ravages of hurricanes and tropical storms, as their design has accounted for the upper bounds of extreme weather experienced in the past.
Irma and Maria threw out the notion of planning and preparedness based on the expected and the familiar. Their ferocity destroyed even the strongest evacuation shelters and brought devastation of catastrophic proportions to our tiny islands. Just as climate change is heralding in an era marked by the unfamiliar, we need a paradigm shift in our approach to development planning in highly vulnerable regions. 
The second word that comes to mind is “unprecedented”. A business-as-usual scenario without global action suggests that by the end of the current century, the Caribbean region will warm a further 2-3C over the 1C already seen in the last century. We project annual rainfall amounts will decrease by up to 40%, posing a significant challenge to already water stressed islands. Projections also show sea levels rising by 1-2 metres, far exceeding the rise already recorded. 
Most frighteningly, given our experience in the last few weeks, is the expectation that we will see more of the strongest tropical Atlantic hurricanes (though not necessarily more overall). Cumulatively, the science of projections suggests that the region’s climate will be altered beyond recognition. This is to say, it will be outside the bounds of our lived experience to date. It will not just be unfamiliar at times, it may be unprecedented all the time. 
The stocktaking is hardly complete from Irma and Maria. Yet for Barbuda and Dominica at least, the setback to their economies will be measured in years. The initial estimates for rebuilding are staggering. Perhaps even more heartbreaking is the loss of those things that are economically unquantifiable. The drastic reductions in living standards, especially for the most vulnerable, that will continue for months to come. The loss of irreplaceable culture and cultural assets, the mental anguish and loss of lives, the loss of biodiversity, and the destruction of “island life” as we know it.
The small island of Barbuda, for the first time in 300 years, has no human inhabitants. They were all evacuated after the devastation wreaked by Irma and in anticipation of Jose and Maria. This seems to portend the challenge that climate change represents for the Caribbean region – a challenge that becomes more acute as the era of the unprecedented is ushered in faster than the region can prepare for its onset.
Finally, the third word that comes to mind is “urgent”. Admirably, although the Caribbean islands are minuscule emitters of greenhouse gases, they have made bold commitments regarding future use. But in the end, the future viability of the region is premised on collective global action to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. It is for this reason that the Caribbean and other small island and developing states have argued for a limit to global warming of 1.5C. It is this message that must reach the global community when they see the images of Irma and Maria. For those in the Caribbean, the lessons are all too clear. 
• Dr Michael Taylor is a physicist based at the University of the West Indies

article_tags: [Food, Farming, Environment, Animals, Agriculture, Rural affairs, UK news, Animal welfare, Climate change]
description: Letters: Readers respond to George Monbiot’s call for an end to raising animals for food
og_fields.og:description: Letters: Readers respond to George Monbiot’s call for an end to raising animals for food
og_fields.og:title: Inconvenient facts about livestock farming | Letters
text:
George Monbiot’s fear of the few remaining British farmers (Goodbye – and good riddance – to livestock farming, 4 October) reached new levels when he wrote that the “rich mosaic of rainforest and other habitats that once covered our hills has been erased” and blamed us for the tectonic drift that moved Britain from the equator towards the Arctic, perhaps 300m years ago. In the rest of his article he mixed unrelated science from all over the globe with the peculiar claims of noted eccentrics, and suggested that we should plough unsuitable land to grow soya, which will not grow in this climate, to produce artificial meat in urban factories.
He didn’t mention inconvenient features of the British ruminant livestock industry, such as the fact that most feed that animals get other than grass is made up of byproducts of the human food industry such as brewers’ grains, sugar beet and fruit-juice pulp, most of which would have to go to landfill if cows and sheep did not recycle it. Without the income from this form of recycling, the price of food in the shop would increase. We do need to moderate excessive meat consumption, and we do need to act on climate change, but this article sows confusion that will delay necessary change.Huw JonesSt Clears, Carmarthenshire
• Livestock has long formed part of the warp and weft of our countryside, and the issue of its potent role in greenhouse gas emissions and other forms of pollution cannot be ducked. Compared to other sectors, farming has done poorly. Emissions have risen since 2010, despite the increasing urgency to act. That does not mean that we should get rid of all livestock. The issues are complex. Even the Food Climate Research Network, cited by George Monbiot, concludes that grazing livestock has a limited place in a sustainable food system.
For us, this limited place means people in the UK should eat less but better-quality animal produce, whether dairy, eggs or meat. It also requires eating many more plants and challenging rising demand for animal-based proteins. The challenge for the farming sector is to make the shift to more sustainable and resilient systems, much less dependent on fossil fuels and set up to support a healthier population. We know this is possible because some farmers are doing this already, and very successfully too.Graeme WillisFood and farming campaigner, Campaign to Protect Rural England
• On this occasion George Monbiot’s evangelical zeal obscures some fundamental practicalities. First, much grazing land is simply unsuitable for growing crops. For example, an organic farmer friend on Dartmoor tells me his land will successfully grow only grass. He farms organically and the manure allows insects to flourish, encouraging a high number and variety of farmland birds. Many arable farms, with their vast acres of monoculture, are often deserts where wildlife is concerned.
Second, the implication that livestock farming is cruel is unfair and insulting. Like many farmers, my friend cares greatly about both the natural environment and the welfare of his animals. Third, would rewilding always be such a good idea? It would most likely produce impenetrable scrubland. We have a profound love of our farmed landscape, shaped in large measure by livestock grazing. Surely few of the 99% who are not vegans would consider veganism a price worth paying for its destruction.
In any case, replacing meat with vegetables is a second-order priority beside the existential issues of population growth and global warming. And, yes, I am a meat-eater and the vast majority of people are firmly of the opinion that the tastiest dishes are those based on meat.David ThomasHereford
• Our dependence on meat is mirrored by the Vikings who colonised Greenland during the Middle Ages. Although fish was readily available, they continued to raise cattle as this conferred social status. When the climate turned colder they perished. By contrast, the inhabitants of Tikopia, a small Pacific island, abandoned pig-rearing in the 17th century as they were rooting up vegetables and competing for food. This may be the only example of a society voluntarily abandoning meat consumption, and it allowed the Tikopians to maintain a population of 400 inhabitants per square mile without any recourse to modern agricultural technology. The question posed in my book The Gilgamesh Gene is whether humanity is behaving like the Vikings or the Tikopians.Dr Robin Russell-JonesStoke Poges, Buckinghamshire
• This is another stimulating article, but I wonder why George Monbiot does not make the point that the essential reason for not eating animal products is that the breeding, rearing and killing of sentient and intelligent animals is cruel and brutal, and unnecessary for human beings to survive and thrive. Of course, the supplementary point that the evidence shows that it is also potentially damaging to the future wellbeing of humanity is also relevant, but it is not the essential reason for avoiding animal products.Roger GibbsLoughton, Essex
• Join the debate – email guardian.letters@theguardian.com
• Read more Guardian letters – click here to visit gu.com/letters

It's calling a spade a spade.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507462599000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13496713', u'in_reply_to': u'106440344', u'id': u'106460827', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'q321gg8cla', u'text': u'Yes.It always prevails.Not always in the way we expect.yet again pictures of politician who has punished millions of her own people ,in a church .Please stop this tragic comedy hypocracy Guardian,its crass .', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507461843000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15119559', u'in_reply_to': u'106458496', u'id': u'106460194', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'WeAreMany', u'text': u'I'm not entirely sure they are more enlightened, yes they certainly are as regards the need for a left alternative government, but remember full independence (laudable though that might seem) may turn out to be regrettable in the long term. 
I certainly think that independence, followed by entry into the EU and Euro-zone would be a big mistake for the Scots, who seem to be clinging onto the idea that it is a benign, utopian organisation, rather than one essentially committed to a corporate, neoliberal agenda that unlike the UK also still has a massively over-leveraged banking system (present leverage of SG and DB is over that of annual French-German GDP combined)
It would suggest they are prepared to disengage from an incoming Corbyn government with a revitalised Scottish Labour Party under Richard Leonard and the chance of a nice fat Scottish Investment Bank with a £20 billion capitalisation - on top of the Barnett Formula too.
I seriously worry about the Scot's myopic attitude to the EU and (automatic) entry into the Euro when any reflationary powers will be given away to the ECB and severely restrained by the Fiscal Compact which requires annual balanced budgets and targets inflation rather than Keynesian methods of plugging 'gaps' in spare capacity.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507460507000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16770905', u'in_reply_to': u'106425746', u'id': u'106459125', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'upwithit', u'text': u'truth hurts doesn't', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507459754000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17884680', u'id': u'106458496', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'saveguardian', u'text': u'Thank you, you are commenting on yourself?', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507459100000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2439573', u'in_reply_to': u'106417887', u'id': u'106457952', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'chrisbrown', u'text': u'And yet it cuts both ways. Many times people moan about the number of "teachers, economists" and such in the Bundestag. The truth is that in most countries politics is overrun with lawyers or bright sparks with MBAs. Christian Lindner [FDP] for example, some kind of self-proclaimed "consultant" or other such event managers.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507459098000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3684556', u'in_reply_to': u'106417357', u'id': u'106457950', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'padav', u'text': u'BQSTART
And your views on Jeremy Corbyn delivering such a reform, should he win the next election?
BQENDIf Labour win the next election in a traditional sense, ie. they have a single party majority, no matter how slim, I believe effective voting reform will remain out of reach - a fudge of some description will be arrived at, meaning the reform will be once again, kicked into the long Westminster grass.
If, however another balanced Parliament ensues, something like the following; • Labour - 300 seats• Conservatives - 280 seats• Lib Dems - 20 seats• SNP - 30 seats• Greens - 1 seat• Northern Ireland - 18 seats• Speaker - 1 seatthat outcome would require both SNP and LibDem collaboration with Labour in some form or another to create a working administration - their input would mean any Constitutional Convention process would necessarily have to include both serious voting reform and serious dispersal of politcal power away from Westminster. 
The potential for introducing Single Transferable Vote in multi-member constituencies and moving towards the creation of a Federal British state would be very real - remember that the deliberations of the Convention would be in public - radical ideas would quickly become tangible possibilities rather than the ususal dream like proposals never ever likely to see the light of day - as that realisation dawned with Jo Public I believe interest in and support for real change would quickly develop an unstoppable momentum (pun intended)!
PS. I am a long standing member (elected to governing councils) of both Unlock Democracy (successor to Charter88) and the Electoral Reform Society', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507456822000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'1810100', u'in_reply_to': u'106449223', u'id': u'106455973', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Banter76', u'text': u'At least Labour want to try and fix the problems rather than only implement tax cuts for the richest 5% (& themselves). 
We've had enough of the society where it's all about the individual at all costs.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507455628000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16040553', u'in_reply_to': u'106430459', u'id': u'106454853', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Droner', u'text': u'I don't know how it is that people can believe A political party can address all problems. Surely looking at both Labour and Tories we should be asking different questions:1. How do we get more talent into politics?The present crew seem to have been doing just politics forever.2. How do we get to build some long term strategy into UK politics, one not subject to 5 yearly gyrations3. England needs a voice. Brexit is in part the result of the asymmetric structure of the UK. How to change it?', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507454607000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15954909', u'id': u'106453881', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JMColwill', u'text': u'Greed and egocentricity are (by definition) not uniting forces.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507454520000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'10106906', u'id': u'106453811', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'gowant', u'text': u'Please don't use the term "Architects" (even in a generic sense) in reference to Grenfell. The facts are that the reason it burned was that there WAS NO ARCHITECT involved with the design, nor any Engineer....just a private bean-counter retained by the Design and Build contractor to max his profits. Along with the late-recognised ignorance of the TMO you have the perfect storm to wreck any building.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507452528000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13295423', u'in_reply_to': u'106437441', u'id': u'106452163', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'atholforest', u'text': u'And your views on Jeremy Corbyn delivering such a reform, should he win the next election? I feel on that point, the young Labour supporters should give us great hope. The young people I meet at Left Unity meetings, almost without exception, support a massive overhaul of the entire political system in the UK.The main argument I've put forward in discussions about PR, is the present system leaves at least seven million people disenfranchised. I admit I admire the Tory voter in Barnsley South, who cast their vote in the knowledge that it was totally wasted. Blimey, Lady May of Kamikaze.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507410506000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17687768', u'in_reply_to': u'106436095', u'id': u'106436388', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'padav', u'text': u'Agreed @atholforest - the UK-wide Constitutional Convention platform I refer to would undoubtedly list potential fundamental reforms to the framework of UK governance - and moving to a Federal Britain model, replete with Constitutional Court, codified constitution and real/effective transfer of political power away from Westminster to meaningful and relevant sub-UK entities boasting their own Parliaments, is right up there.
Only the current Westminster Parliament could enact this kind of transformational process so it goes without saying that the complexion of a sovereign chamber effectively diminshing its own role would have to be very progressive in outlook and that can never happen with FPTP still in-situ?
A cursory glance at UK General Election results on a sub-UK Regional basis routinely exposes the basic democratic shortcomings of FPTP - usually the Conservatives gain about 55% of votes cast in S.E. England yet they bag about 95% of seats contested - Labour repeat this kind of skewed outcome in N.E. England - how such "undemocratic" results can be justified beggars belief. u'106437884', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Scaeva', u'text': u'Well of course you are right that the assertion in the article is incorrect, but not about the way it is incorrect: the "right" (whatever that means) of the Conservative Party did not repel voters, as was proved on May 23 2016; in fact they represented majority opinion and it was something of a miracle under the FPTP system that eventually that majority opinion was allowed to be heard. The disingenuousness of the "Left" (again, not the appropriate term, as I am sure you will agree) indicates the essential tendentiousness of their reasoning: it is preposterous to argue that Euro-scepticism repelled most voters given the referendum result, and it is extremely dubious to argue that pro-Brexit is a minority opinion, as you do. Now, it may or may not be true that Brexit is going to be economically disruptive to an extreme degree, or that Brexit will mean the loss of some or all employment and environmental protections as TruthSeeker79 claims (in fact we had both before we entered the EEC as it then was, and the Common Agricultural Policy in particular had a disastrous effect on nature in the UK and elsewhere in Europe, and there is nothing guaranteeing that the EU will always and everywhere be pro-worker and pro-environment), but when is the "Left" (sorry) going to ask itself how we got to Brexit as a serious question rather than resorting incessantly to laughable "rescue hypotheses" such as claiming that Brexit is unpopular (as this article does) or that only stupid and evil people are in favour of it?This is how we got here: Ted Heath took us in without a referendum and, I believe, no mandate from the prior Conservative manifesto. The "old Left" of the Labour Party wanted to come out when Harold Wilson came to power so he seized on the idea of a Referendum in order to prevent a split in the Labour Party. During the 1975 Referendum campaign the (much wealthier) "Yes" (Remain) camp ridiculed "No" (Leave) claims that the EEC was the thin end of a wedge the thick end of which was a USE.In the intervening (till 2016) years British governments signed a sequence of treaties bringing Britain ever closer (!) to immersion within a USE. Sometimes this was explicit (Maastricht and Lisbon), sometimes implicit (the laughable "four freedoms"), but whichever it was it was increasingly clear that they were disregarding British public opinion in doing so. What-on-earth the movers behind this thought would be the end-game is difficult to fathom. Did they think that people were as impressionable as geese and forget they had been manipulated into the EU? Probably. Well unfortunately for them it turned out that either people are not so dumb, or if they are stupid they nevertheless dislike being treated as stupid...I agree it's a terrible mess, but you have got to face up to the fact that there was never any mandate for the creation of the EU. Treaties popped up out of the Council and the Commission "out of the blue" and the public had no idea what was going on; for instance (and I take some risk in admitting this) I take some interest in politics, but I had no idea that the British government had renounced its right to control migration from the EU until about 2004."You" blew it, the "Left" or whatever you want to call yourselves; you know, the Left that likes labour-flows. "You" lied and dissembled and went beyond any mandate you had. That is what broke "the European dream". As the Americans say, "If it ain't broke, don't fix it." We had peace and prosperity in Europe; what did "you" need the Euro for? Or the "four freedoms"? What have they, really, got to do with peace and security? Why did "you" destroy Europe? Why do "you" try to blame the people you lied to for it?With sincere love.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507409845000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2722325', u'in_reply_to': u'106394951', u'id': u'106435952', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'republicantraveller', u'text': u'Osborne is trying to destabilise May and her ability to achieve a proper Brexit. u'text': u'I disagree @diddoit - here's why
The Tories are currently is a bad place, floundering around trying to make sense of something they don't deal very well with - something anathema to their very raison d'etre - it's called change! However we underestimate their tenacity to cling to the reins of power at our collective peril - and FPTP lies at the core of their obduracy, because it continues to provide them with mechanisms/avenues allowing them to wield virtually 100% of political power in the UK, on the basis of clear minority (and shrinking) support through the ballot box.
Labour (or at least a majority among the party, although their superior numbers are shrinking) are of course tarred with the same brush but it's not wholly unreasonable to imagine a scenario that might emerge capable of delivering radical (for the UK) constitutional change. 
If the Tories do actually implode, driven by a variety of factors such as a growing public realisation that Brexit is a "pig in a poke" economic disaster of ballooning proportions, compounded by the "ferrets in a sack" in-fighting currently being witnessed - end result, a fresh general election - but this time the fortunes of Labour and Conservatives are reversed, ie. a balanced (hung) Parliament with Labour as the single largest party - that means, constitutionally speaking, Corbyn has first dibs at forming a goverment but to do that he would need cooperation in some form or another from both LibDems and SNP (and the Greens would probably pitch in as well).
The price of such LibDem collaboration, even if it's only confidence and supply, is almost certain to include making good on a Labour Party manifesto pledge, which you can see here (something very similar is also in the LibDem counterpart) - namely the establishment of a, hopefully citizen focused and driven, UK Constitutional Convention - see here for a some outline ideas about how to set up and implement this body.
Such a body would take time but once in motion, I believe the public would begin to sit up and take notice of its public utterances and deliberations - for precisely the same reasons Labour's ideas, voiced through Corbyn, gained traction during the 2017 General Election campaign - and it's a racing certainty that profound voting reform would feature very higly on its agenda.
Yes, all of the above would need certain circumstances to fall into place but they are not entirely beyond the bounds of probability?', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507407318000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'it continues to provide them with mechanisms avenues', u'effect': u'however we underestimate their tenacity to cling to the reins of power at our collective peril lies at the core of their obduracy'}], u'author_id': u'1810100', u'in_reply_to': u'106430200', u'id': u'106434425', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Quaestor', u'text': u'Probably. I detest Uber, Ariana whatever her name is, Trump, Murdoch, Shaps, and neoliberals of all descriptions. They have created a proletariat, and their activities need to be reversed.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507406852000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2535633', u'in_reply_to': u'106398512', u'id': u'106434163', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Wassboy', u'text': u'When you tell everyone that it's a choice between you and chaos, the voters that chose you and then see utter chaos ensue while the other guy looks like an absolute boy get buyers' remorse.It was ever thus.

It needs reinventing, and I am not sure if there is a saviour in the present stinking heap.Remember Lyndon B Johnson?"If one morning I walked on top of the water, across the Potomac river, the headline that afternoon would read: " President can't swim".', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507405944000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17687768', u'id': u'106433584', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'clairesdad', u'text': u'Some of us have higher ambitions. Yet, one person makes a comment at a Labour fringe event attended by a few dozen people of no political importance stating that the social terms of the Holocaust should be extended to cover other persecuted groups, and there's a constant media barrage of accusations of antisemitism. 
At least their influence is definitely on the wane - the next GE will very probably be the first where the press won't chosen our PM for us in 40 odd years.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507405612000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16770905', u'in_reply_to': u'106418962', u'id': u'106433384', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ghotiface', u'text': u'yep, easy mistake to make, I think you could say that The Conservatives are UKIP with the honesty removed.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507405221000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15275475', u'in_reply_to': u'106428514', u'id': u'106433132', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'bretonbell60', u'text': u'They might have had more luck advertising at their local Job centre.Failing that, how about Lord Sugar does an episode of The Apprentice to choose one?Wouldn't I just love to hear him say "You're all bloody useless, you're all bloody FIRED".RNIP, Here lies the Tory Party:"They came, they saw, they thought they conquered, but in reality they F****d it up".', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507405119000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17687768', u'in_reply_to': u'106432556', u'id': u'106433074', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'pruneau', u'text': u'If I were to introduce the words honesty, integrity, truth, justice, social cohesion, compassion, empathy, humility, rationality into the current debate they would have absolutely no relevance save for their abscence. Morally bankrupt has always seemed a strange, sanctimonious collision but I don't know what expression to use to cover the venal, degrading and degenerate behaviour of our political leaders. That there exists no sanctions against them, except some loss of political favour, seems a tragedy. We are caught, and rightly so, in behaving in a civilised manner but there are moments, just moments, when I ache for a more physical and radical expression against them.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507405110000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4811300', u'id': u'106433066', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'padav', u'text': u'And as I have mentioned, @bulawayosweetrythms, every single that kind of lazy ill-considered and ill-thought out response comes up, you make a fundamental schoolboy error when you graft, wholesale and unaltered, voting behaviour under Single Member Plurality (FPTP), on to a profoundly different electoral landscape!
Firstly it's absolutely valid that those who hold views close to the UKIP ideological template are represented in the UK's sovereign chamber - or is expressing a viewpoint only valid if it falls within certain pre-defined limits of acceptability (dictated by you?) 
Secondly we are where we are precisely because of FPTP - it has shaped the policy outcomes of successive UK administrations, the manner in which UK media reports the development of such policies and how UK public sentiment interacts with them.
I am saying that UK governance and the public discourse environment they inhabit are materially diminished by the voting system lying at its core - the sooner the UK ditches FPTP, the better it will be for future generations - and yes, the process of constitutional transformation would be slow at first - you do not change deeply entrenched habits overnight?', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507405108000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'fptp', u'effect': u'where we are'}], u'author_id': u'1810100', u'in_reply_to': u'106431806', u'id': u'106433064', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'WeAreMany', u'text': u'BQSTART

Paul would have known a thing or two about that, his version of Christianity was one of the earliest attempts to establish socialism:', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507402655000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'18056838', u'id': u'106431194', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'BeenThereDunThat', u'text': u'You are talking about development aid here, and on some levels regarding this, I agree with you. I worked in this area briefly but found it quite frustrating for a number of reasons, including the sometimes paternalistic approach many aid workers took, but also, conversely, that in attempts to not be seen as neo-colonial, the contortions of political correctness also subverted what was intended - which is ultimately local self-sufficiencywith a reasonable standard of living.So I moved into emergency work - very much like firefighting. I worked as an engineer, so repairing or rebuilding hospitals, rural and urban, including city level, water and sanitation systems, setting up and running water & sanitation systems in refugee and IDP camps - sometimes with up to half a million inhabitants, so no small challenge, building emergency and intermediate level housing and shelter, building and providing technical support to orthopaedic centres which supplied, & fitted artificial limbs to mine victims and war wounded, plus a host of other activities, including supporting civil authorities in rebuilding their capacities to operate and maintain their infrastructure. This was not really in the neo-colonial vein you raise, as it was very much about sometimes doing your damnedest to stop people dying when state control had essentially collapsed, while trying not to get killed yourself - I did have friends, colleagues and even staff killed in this time - or in immediate post-conflict situations, providing technical support to existing authorities as part of the rebuilding process, usually very much on their terms.Most of my work was with the International Committee of the Red Cross - ICRC, although I did also work with Oxfam & Médecins Sans Frontières - MSF, this latter being solely in East & Central Africa - Rwanda, Burundi, Tanzania, Zaire, DRC...', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507402586000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3943146', u'in_reply_to': u'106412485', u'id': u'106431139', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JBigglesworth', u'text': u'Sorry. A change is coming. The Blairites had their day in the sun. description: Editorial: MPs in the Tory party have to realise that voters have grown up in a culturally permissive era and are not aroused by the holy anger of the right

og_fields.og:title: The Guardian view on Tory splits: doctrinal differences | Editorial
text:
Big as the blow was to Theresa May at the general election in June, worse has followed. Not only was the election an unnecessary fight for Mrs May to have picked, she has emerged a diminished figure. Her cabinet is united – but mainly in their desire to succeed her. On the day of Mrs May’s big speech at the Conservative party conference this week, everything that could go wrong, did. Then Grant Shapps, a former party chairman who once led a double life as a “multimillionaire” web guru, was unmasked as a parliamentary general aiming to topple Mrs May for her shortcomings. Despite boasting the backing of 30 MPs, none of Mr Shapps’ troops were prepared to follow their commanding officer over the top. Mrs May is hurt and the consensus is that she will stagger on. But the crisis in the Conservative party is here to stay: a toxic brew of personal ambition, ideological visions and electoral panic.
This at a time when Britain’s productive forces are stagnating and the biggest foreign policy issue of our times – leaving the European Union – is met with the political posturing of a clown wearing the mask of a roaring lion. The Conservative party was once steeped in pragmatism, dominated by the wish to win elections and to be in power. There always were differences of opinion. These differences in dispositions have now curdled into doctrinal differences.
The Brexit vote has helped widen gulfs in the party, intensifying the cultural nationalism on the right of the party. This group, who since the days of John Major have put forward anti-EU arguments with a burning passion, repelled the electorate to such an extent that the Tories could not win a majority for more than two decades. The bad news for Mrs May is that they are back. The result is that the Tories lost their parliamentary advantage this year. Yet those who profess this anti-European nationalist creed are feted in the current Tory party. It was their speakers who drew the crowds and cheers at conference, not the cabinet’s. That Mrs May relies on the votes of the anti-gay, anti-abortion climate-change deniers of the evangelical Democratic Unionist party to carry her through will mean MPs on the cultural nationalist right will be emboldened.
It speaks volumes about the mess the party is in that Jacob Rees-Mogg, the MP for the last century, who is against gay marriage and anti-abortion on the grounds of his faith, is such a star. Young people, having grown up in a culturally permissive era, are not aroused by the holy anger of the right. They are moved by issues such as climate change and education, where an egalitarian view of humankind prevails. Conservatives have in the past been able to accept social change and adapt to it. They have anticipated society’s needs and changed their policies to meet them. Now the party’s anti-Europeanism means they risk losing a section of voters for ever.
The Conservatives have also long been deaf to issues affecting the under-40s. Not only are these voters seeing their wages squeezed, they are unable to save for homes and pensions while the prices race away. Mrs May will find it difficult to sell capitalism to those with no capital. The last election threw into sharp relief the cracks in the Tory party’s support. Its voters are dying off faster than it can win over new ones. That is why Mrs May has accepted that there is a cost-of-living crisis and lifted policies from Ed Miliband, a man once derided as Marxist. The Tory leadership seems to think it does not require new ideas. It is content to make do with old ones. Mrs May needed to bring her party’s thinking in line with an environment it does not like. Replacing the leader will only work if the party understands that it needs to change too.

article_tags: [Climate change, Climate change, Population, Society, Politics, Family, Children, Environment, Membership]
authors: [Vicky Frost, Stuart Silver, Rowan Slaney, Lucy Lamble, Afua Hirsch, Damian Carrington, John Vidal]
description: In this monthly podcast, Guardian supporters ask the questions and a Guardian panel try to provide the answers. This episode focuses on whether people should be having fewer children for the sake of the planet – and if so, how that societal change might happen

Your theory suggests that over time, as overall "wealth" increases, so does happiness.
BQEND
No, that's not what I'm saying at all. I am saying that progress, not absolute wealth, contributes to happiness. That someone who sees their life improving over the years is far more likely to be happy than someone who sees no progress at all, or even a decline. 
Human history is one of improvement. People work to make their lives better. A neolithic farmer who chopped down trees to provide more land to farm could see progress. Building a better round hut to live in is progress. Growing more grain, building a bigger herd, a wooden bridge across a river to open up new farmland. He would still have been living in absolute poverty by modern standards, but to him life would be better than it ever had been before. 
The desire for improvement is intrinsic to human nature (which is why we have come to dominate the planet in such a way). Claiming that Costa Rica, which has seen rapid improvement over the decades, points the way to abolishing that desire for improvement, is ridiculous.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507537029000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3522873', u'in_reply_to': u'106483049', u'id': u'106493079', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Iamfuture', u'text': u'This was long prophecied to happen and its the cure, that is the real worry. The happiest country on the planet happens to be relatively poor.
BQEND
But growing fast. It's not absolute wealth that matters for happiness, it's progress. People in Costa Rica make 4 times what their parents made, in real terms, and that makes them happy. 
BQSTART
Consequently, having to face a future where growth slows or even stops does not mean we all have to be miserable.
BQEND

His comparison of the progress of North v South America IS interesting, despite the man. His later libertarian views shows he left his Scottish heritage well behind, giving up all concept of 'society' to favour low taxes above all else.
As someone with a Harvard MBA, I think that capitalism can help with solving sustainability, as it allows the pricing of scarce resources most efficiently. The problem is that above capitalism (dealing in money), we are meant to have a political process (dealing in votes) that sets the rules for the society. What has happened, especially in the Anglosphere (US, UK, Australia & Canada) is that a lack of rules (or enforcement) on political donations meant we have allowed the corporations to 'capture' the regulators. It is always going to be 'cheaper' for dirty utilities and fossil fuel firms to 'bribe' politicians, than to comply with environmental rules.
If a revolution against poor government could elect only candidates sworn to outlaw ALL political donations, we could see the necessary change. We would get publicly-spirited people (instead of carpet-baggers) running for office. Then we can address the clear problems posed by global warming and do what is necessary to meet the Paris climate agreement. Americans may be the last to join the effort, due to corporate control over so much of their media, but if the rest of the world pushes forwards on solar, wind and electric cars, then we will so much further along the cost-curve that the USA will join. Solar will win in the USA, despite the subsidies all incentivising in the wrong direction. No new coal plants have been built there, and despite Trump's bluster, it is unlikely that coal will make any significant return.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507471526000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'corporate control', u'effect': u'americans may be the last to join the effort but if the rest of the world pushes forwards on solar'}], u'author_id': u'4573599', u'in_reply_to': u'106465190', u'id': u'106466845', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'PieInSky', u'text': u'Good luck on that one. description: Chasing economic growth gains us nothing but global warming. We should follow the lead of tiny Costa Rica, where life expectancy is soaring
og_fields.og:description: Chasing economic growth gains us nothing but global warming. We should follow the lead of tiny Costa Rica, where life expectancy is soaring
og_fields.og:title: Want to avert the apocalypse? Take lessons from Costa Rica
text:
Earlier this summer, a paper published in the journal Nature captured headlines with a rather bleak forecast. Our chances of keeping global warming below the 2C danger threshold are very, very small: only about 5%. The reason, according to the paper’s authors, is that the cuts we’re making to greenhouse gas emissions are being cancelled out by economic growth.
In the coming decades, we’ll be able to reduce the carbon intensity of the global economy by about 1.9% per year, if we make heavy investments in clean energy and efficient technology. That’s a lot. But as long as the economy keeps growing by more than that, total emissions are still going to rise. Right now we’re ratcheting up global GDP by 3% per year, which means we’re headed for trouble.
If we want to have any hope of averting catastrophe, we’re going to have to do something about our addiction to growth. This is tricky, because GDP growth is the main policy objective of virtually every government on the planet. It lies at the heart of everything we’ve been told to believe about how the economy should work: that GDP growth is good, that it’s essential to progress, and that if we want to improve human wellbeing and eradicate poverty around the world, we need more of it. It’s a powerful narrative. But is it true?
Maybe not. Take Costa Rica. A beautiful Central American country known for its lush rainforests and stunning beaches, Costa Rica proves that achieving high levels of human wellbeing has very little to do with GDP and almost everything to do with something very different.
Every few years the New Economics Foundation publishes the Happy Planet Index – a measure of progress that looks at life expectancy, wellbeing and equality rather than the narrow metric of GDP, and plots these measures against ecological impact. Costa Rica tops the list of countries every time. With a life expectancy of 79.1 years and levels of wellbeing in the top 7% of the world, Costa Rica matches many Scandinavian nations in these areas and neatly outperforms the United States. And it manages all of this with a GDP per capita of only $10,000 (£7,640), less than one fifth that of the US. 
In this sense, Costa Rica is the most efficient economy on earth: it produces high standards of living with low GDP and minimal pressure on the environment. 
How do they do it? Professors Martínez-Franzoni and Sánchez-Ancochea argue that it’s all down to Costa Rica’s commitment to universalism: the principle that everyone – regardless of income – should have equal access to generous, high-quality social services as a basic right. A series of progressive governments started rolling out healthcare, education and social security in the 1940s and expanded these to the whole population from the 50s onward, after abolishing the military and freeing up more resources for social spending. 
Costa Rica wasn’t alone in this effort, of course. Progressive governments elsewhere in Latin America made similar moves, but in nearly every case the US violently intervened to stop them for fear that “communist” ideas might scupper American interests in the region. Costa Rica escaped this fate by outwardly claiming to be anti-communist and – horribly – allowing US-backed forces to use the country as a base in the contra war against Nicaragua. 
The upshot is that Costa Rica is one of only a few countries in the global south that enjoys robust universalism. It’s not perfect, however. Relatively high levels of income inequality make the economy less efficient than it otherwise might be. But the country’s achievements are still impressive. On the back of universal social policy, Costa Rica surpassed the US in life expectancy in the late 80s, when its GDP per capita was a mere tenth of America’s.
Today, Costa Rica is a thorn in the side of orthodox economics. The conventional wisdom holds that high GDP is essential for longevity: “wealthier is healthier”, as former World Bank chief economist Larry Summers put it in a famous paper. But Costa Rica shows that we can achieve human progress without much GDP at all, and therefore without triggering ecological collapse. In fact, the part of Costa Rica where people live the longest, happiest lives – the Nicoya Peninsula – is also the poorest, in terms of GDP per capita. Researchers have concluded that Nicoyans do so well not in spite of their “poverty”, but because of it – because their communities, environment and relationships haven’t been ploughed over by industrial expansion. 
All of this turns the usual growth narrative on its head. Henry Wallich, a former member of the US Federal Reserve Board, once pointed out that “growth is a substitute for redistribution”. And it’s true: most politicians would rather try to rev up the GDP and hope it trickles down than raise taxes on the rich and redistribute income into social goods. But a new generation of thinkers is ready to flip Wallich’s quip around: if growth is a substitute for redistribution, then redistribution can be a substitute for growth. 
Costa Rica provides a hopeful model for any country that wants to chart its way out of poverty. But it also holds an important lesson for rich countries. Scientists tell us that if we want to avert dangerous climate change, high-consuming nations – like Britain and the US – are going to have to scale down their bloated economies to get back in sync with the planet’s ecology, and fast. A widely-cited paper by scientists at the University of Manchester estimates it’s going to require downscaling of 4-6% per year. 
This is what ecologists call “de-growth”. This calls for redistributing existing resources and investing in social goods in order to render growth unnecessary. Decommoditising and universalising healthcare, education and even housing would be a step in the right direction. Another would be a universal basic income – perhaps funded by taxes on carbon, land, resource extraction and financial transactions. 
The opposite of growth isn’t austerity, or depression, or voluntary poverty. It is sharing what we already have, so we won’t need to plunder the earth for more.
Costa Rica proves that rich countries could theoretically ease their consumption by half or more while maintaining or even increasing their human development indicators. Of course, getting there would require that we devise a new economic system that doesn’t require endless growth just to stay afloat. That’s a challenge, to be sure, but it’s possible.
After all, once we have excellent healthcare, education, and affordable housing, what will endlessly more income growth gain us? Maybe bigger TVs, flashier cars, and expensive holidays. But not more happiness, or stronger communities, or more time with our families and friends. Not more peace or more stability, fresher air or cleaner rivers. Past a certain point, GDP gains us nothing when it comes to what really matters. In an age of climate change, where the pursuit of ever more GDP is actively dangerous, we need a different approach.

description: Supporters’ contributions to our podcast on population and climate change show exactly why we need to talk about this issue
headline: p
og_fields.og:description: Supporters’ contributions to our podcast on population and climate change show exactly why we need to talk about this issue
og_fields.og:title: Should we be having fewer children for the sake of the planet?
text:
Last month, on these pages, I asked if you might get in touch with your questions and thoughts on population and climate change. You did – in some numbers. These generous contributions form the heart of the latest edition of We Need to Talk About …, our podcast featuring supporters’ voices, in which your concerns are addressed by a panel of Guardian journalists and experts.
As a starting point, we used a Guardian article with an arresting headline: Want to fight climate change? Have fewer children. In the podcast, we hear from one of the academics who produced the research which this article refers to, but equally interesting were your responses to this issue, and the discussions they prompted in our studio. 
That’s why we’ve decided to publish some of them here. While we aim to hear from lots of voices and include differing points of view on the podcast, a lack of time means we sometimes have to cut people short, or use one person to represent the views of several who have contacted us making similar points. Here, we can give members a bit more space to air their views.
You can listen to the panel respond to them – our line-up is Damian Carrington, the Guardian’s environment editor; Lucy Lamble, the Guardian’s executive editor for global development, who often writes on and takes part in debates on global inequality; John Vidal, the multi-award winning former Guardian environment editor and Afua Hirsch, a writer and broadcaster for the Guardian and SkyNews among others, who has also worked in international development and the law. 
But first gain a flavour of the concerns of your fellow readers below. Many of these questions appear in the podcast, while others influenced the direction in which we headed.
The issue isn’t overpopulation – it’s poor resource allocation. We do not live in a world of lack, but of extreme waste and inefficiency. This is true of food, energy, land use and the financial system. The overpopulation argument is a way to once again deflect from real societal change that is needed, and instead focuses the discussion on families, usually poor families, having too many children.
While it is likely that the Earth does have some sort of maximum carrying capacity, even that is not guaranteed with recent technological advancements such as vertical farming. The question is whether those technological advancements will be put to use to raise the standard of living for every human being on the planet, or are put towards continuing to line the pockets of the wealthiest individuals and their investors.
To my mind, it is not the countries in Africa, or groups with a more traditional and much simpler way of life – such as Native people in North and South America, for instance – that have caused so many environmental problems, but the irrationality and consumerism of our western society. It is the fact that we consume without truly asking ourselves where all these goods come from, how they were produced, what the environmental impact is of producting all these mostly useless things. Unless we seriously address these questions, I cannot see any significant change or serious solution to climate change.
I‘ve often noticed that some westerners, who have no agenda at all on any environmental question, are keen to invoke “overpopulation” as the main and only threat to survival on Earth. Is overpopulation just a convenient way for westerners to put the blame on Africans for the environmental threats we face?
How can those with the largest carbon footprint be encouraged not to reproduce, when they are ones who make the greatest impact and have the greatest sense of entitlement?
Pope Francis recently condemned climate change sceptics. He is passionate about protecting the planet and has called on everyone to care for creation, particularly as climate change disproportionately impacts the poor. 
The Catholic church runs 25% of health and education systems worldwide and therefore, through its direct teaching and management, significantly reduces safe access to contraception for millions of women. No debate on controlling population growth and subsequent pollution can therefore exist without tackling this institutional barrier to action. Last year over 170 theologians issued a statement saying there was no reason for the Catholic church’s position against “artificial” contraception. 
How does the panel feel the church can continue to do great work on this issue, yet continue to block safe access to contraception for some of the world’s poorest women?
I am a gynaecologist working in Hong Kong, occasionally counselling women considering having another child. If someone is ambivalent about doing so, I add into the decision-making the idea that having more children impacts climate change.
Since I was a teenager in the 1970s, I have believed it is a woman’s right to choose whether to continue a pregnancy. Working as a volunteer in an African country where abortion is illegal, I have seen women saved from death after trying to procure an abortion themselves. They were lucky – the hospital was nearby, there were good doctors, antibiotics, surgery, and blood transfusion.
In African countries where abortion is often illegal, an unmet need for contraception is also common. I applied for a volunteer job in northern Uganda where women having five to six children is the norm; when asked, they say they would have preferred three or four . 
Donald Trump’s global gag rule which removes US aid from any NGO providing contraceptive advice, is a huge problem. Not only because maternal mortality due to abortion deaths will rise in Africa, but also because the UNFPA [UN population fund] will stop training midwives, and the resulting reduction in maternal mortality will diminish. In addition, there will be greater unmet need for contraception. 
Do you think our society can reach the point where choosing to have fewer children as an essential carbon-cutting strategy is as widely understood as conserving energy?
As a parent I would take a bullet for either of my two children. I’m certain almost all parents would do just about anything to ensure their kids have a decent life. Knowing this, I cannot help but feel that if young couples around the world have good information they will do the right thing. If they understand the ramifications of their family-size decisions on the quality of life – chance of survival even – of their children, then they will make the most loving, compassionate decision possible: to conceive no more than one child.
I joined Population Matters, an organisation that promotes smaller family size and reduced consumption, to find like-minded people and put my energies into a worthwhile organisation. I appreciate the impact we are having on the environment, and am mindful of that. However, I have found people around me such as family, friends and colleagues are largely not interested, or suggest they should have the freedom to do as they please.
How do we start making a difference? Also we seem to have failed with high-profile individuals, royals and celebrities in particular. So what happens now?
We have to reduce the population, hopefully not by severe climate change, war or disease. China’s one-child solution would not be accepted by most people. What do experts suggest? It seems money has the only power over most people. Should we pay people not to have children?
How do we get politicians to talk seriously about the links between population and climate change? The last three elections in the UK have barely mentioned the environment. Is there an agreement between the political parties to avoid this discussion?

I like children, but have never felt that I would like to have my own. 
I am very regularly treated as odd for this decision, and feel that if we don’t open up the discussion about not having children, people will never consider this decision thoroughly, whether for the environment or other reasons.
In the past three years, I have made a number of lifestyle changes in order to reduce my carbon footprint – which has only further cemented my feeling that I don’t want children. I often feel like I need to keep having what can be sometimes difficult conversations with people about this choice, so as to build conversation momentum around the subject. Alternative lifestyles need to be promoted. I would like to focus on supporting and improving the lives of people already on the planet. 
I have made the decision to be childfree, largely due to environmental reasons. As a childfree person, I am constantly surprised how this decision is commonly questioned by others as being a poor or “selfish” choice when the evidence suggests that it is anything but. 
Given the evidence that having fewer children isthe greatest decision one can make to combat climate change, do the panel think that society can switch from having a pro-reproduction stance, where policies promote reproduction and society views having children as the “correct” choice, to a neutral stance, where having children is considered optional and policies are made to promote other means of having a fulfilled life?

They ought to receive a premium price that reflects their greater reliability.
Contrary to the article, the higher price to be paid for dispatchable energy isn't to be paid by taxpayers, but by electric energy users, who are the ones that benefit from the greater reliability.
Further, wind & solar power receive greater subsidies per unit of output than any other form of power, plus mandates such as renewable portfolio standards and net metering policies. (Capital recovery allowances are received by all businesses and are not subsidies.)
If the theme of this article is to be taken seriously, ALL subsidies, mandates and other non-market mechanisms should be terminated, in which case coal would revert to its former 60%-70% market share.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508079892000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3964745', u'id': u'106825256', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'GRLCowan', u'text': u'BQSTART
If people haven't been harmed by nuclear waste it's not because it is safe.
BQEND
How true. And in theory it's quite dangerous. But it's interesting to review some of the basics of that theory. Humanity's nuclear power plants contain around 50,000 tonnes of uranium oxide. The continents contain 35,000,000,000,000 tonnes of it, and so, even though the stuff in the reactors has a lot of man-made radioactivity, it is minor compared to the natural radioactivity underfoot.
Although the ocean, too, famously contains much more uranium than we have ever handled, it contains only thousands of times more, not tens of millions. So if, without extinguishing them, we could somehow disperse all our reactors through the ocean, its radioactivity would be increased about 500-fold. Still weak compared to natural land radioactivity.
If the Fukushima meltdowns had been deliberate — and the intervention of the Japanese prime minister's office did make them a great deal worse than they would have been, to the great financial benefit, in later years, of the Japanese government — they would have been an attempt to ocean-disperse a small fraction of the world's reactors.
Had complete dispersion been achieved, with fission continuing unabated, ocean radioactivity would have been increased about fourfold. The health of us land creatures, immersed in natural radioactivity at thousands of times marine levels, suggests no sea life would have been harmed by a mere fourfold increase.
However, two more small fractions came into play: the radioactivity of a demolished reactor, a few years after demolition, is reduced ten thousand-fold, and when seawater percolates ruined nuclear fuel, very little of it dissolves. (It's rock.)
That is why, measured in ocean units of radioactivity, the marine contamination due to Fukushima was briefly in the neighbourhood of 0.000001 but is much less now.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507996960000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'it is safe', u'effect': u"it 's not"}, {u'cause': u'fukushima', u'effect': u'the marine contamination'}], u'author_id': u'2641110', u'in_reply_to': u'106674808', u'id': u'106782531', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'mrpoohead', u'text': u'Thankfully the prat is not in charge of the Budget. Germany has already tried introducing a coal levy, but they scrapped it in July 2015 following protests from the coal industry:
BQSTART
RWE Surges After German Government Decides Against Coal Levy BloombergBusiness, July 2, 2015 
RWE AG, the utility whose coal-fired plants make it Europe’s largest carbon emitter, surged after Germany’s governing coalition agreed not to introduce a coal levy that had been discussed for months.
German Chancellor Angela Merkel, Economy Minister Sigmar Gabriel and Bavaria Prime Minister Horst Seehofer decided against a levy on lignite plants, the Economy Ministry said in a statement Thursday.
BQEND
The proposed coal levy would have led to the immediate closure of almost all of Germany's lignite plants. BQSTART
Germany set to widely miss climate targets, env ministry warns Clean Energy Wire, 11 Oct 2017 
Germany’s environment ministry fears high emissions from coal-fired power plants and transport will make the country miss its 2020 climate targets by a wider margin than previously anticipated.
Without further action, Germany's CO₂ emissions will only be 31.7 to 32.5 percent below 1990 levels, an internal environment ministry paper seen by the Clean Energy Wire shows. Given the official target of cutting emissions by 40 percent, the ministry warns that a failure of this magnitude would constitute a “significant blow to Germany’s climate policy”, and would amount to “a disaster for Germany’s international reputation as a climate leader.”

Yes, but it's not a good sign. It is _possible_ that Germany will have slow reductions to start with, accelerating later, but that's clearly a dangerous strategy, and it really ought to be easier to do the first bit of reduction (plenty of efficiency slack) than the last bit.
It's a much safer strategy to take the easy wins first and reduce overall emissions, because that gives you significantly more time if there are problem later because now you are running your carbon budget down at half the speed (say). Shooting for late-success is a great way of using the budget up fast and ultimately failing.
The UK has done a _much_ better job of decarbonising the grid, from a similar starting point.
The energiewende _has_ helped show other countries that wind and solar really do work, I agree with you there. But the nuclear shutdown is unarguably completely stupid and a massive setback to actual decarbonisation. You can make a case for not building any more (although even that remains tricky for high-latitude countries) but shutting down working ones is completely counter to actually solving the problem, and Germany's behavour here is unforgivable. The US is doing a better job than Germany despite its obvious political problems, and at the same time Germany makes a fuss over how forward-thinking it is.
I am not at all impressed. You are right that it's not impossible for this all to come out OK in the end, but given the urgency, I am very worried that Germany is indeed going to fail. For Western Europe 80%-90% decarbonisation should be 2040, not 2050. Are they really going to have fixed everything by then?
The last 20% is going to be the really hard part (cement, aviation, agriculture, coking coal, gas balancing). We must never forget them. And continue to write about them and their desires. 
Even if we accept that they do not want poor people to emit as much as them in the US and Australia does - we can certainly emit 90 gigatons per year well in advance of year 2100 - that also will bring atmospheric CO2 levels to 1000 ppm by then. 
What IPCC in general talk about is that the people of the planet has some wit and understanding and stabilise emissions as net-neutral by the time we reach 550-600 ppm to avoid crossing a 3 degree temperature burst-through. 
Our dear denial friends wants us to cross that level of 2xC02 before 2050. And we are on schedule for making their wishes come through. USA is of course again leading the way - as they have been a super-power since 1950. Even Paris as standing now (yes - that communist liberal hoax) will bring us to 2xCO2 by around 2050. But that as not fast enough. 
This is important to remember: Climate sensitivity, as often talked about - is not based on a floating target. It is based of how much change we have at 2xCO2 from pre-industrial times, or per doubling, if you like. 
Thus - we can also conclude that the scientific term "climate sensitivity" does not state where we are going with the guidance of denial. We are going towards 2xC02, 3xCO2 and 4XCO2 forcing from now until 2100 - give or take a decade of two. And since fast equilibrium response and feedbacks takes a few decades - and slow equilibrium responses and feedbacks can take a few thousand years - let us just forget about the 3 degree target. We will have committed that as we go through 2040 - similar to how we lost the 1.5 degree target around 1990. 
We can discuss exactly what decade and the exact decimal of response (more when we talk about access to predictable rain or lack thereof). But remember - science has advanced rapidly since the first coupled model-results became available in the 1980's. Including that the hind-casting is becoming better. And in this case - blogs, newspapers, political documents become historical evidence - and climate science becomes as important as DNA became important for cold-case forensic science back in the days. 
Why? Well - somebody will be paying for what caused to 1.5 degree target that one could hope for as the cold war ended - and someone is going to pay for why we are now loosing the 3-degree target. 
We are also aware of bankrupt companies changing names when faced with lawsuits. AMOCO is of course not named any longer. Now they are BP. Look at the big investment-funds on this planet being busy going all ratty and swimming to better and more sustainable islands. They know better. Just look at how one attacked the mob a few decades ago. Separation of accounts as deniability by spreading the impact stopped working so well. In April, Secretary of Energy Rick Perry announced that he was requesting a study about whether today's electricity markets are doing an adequate job in terms of providing grid reliability, reliance and stability. Under most circumstances, an announcement of such a proposed study would cause everyone to fall asleep. Nowadays, though, this proposed study was considered revolutionary and perhaps obscene. 
The general weltanschauung (German used quite deliberately) of studies under the last administration did not encourage looking at questions of mere grid reliability. The only allowable questions seemed to be: "How can we get more renewables (and gas backup) on the grid?" When Secretary Perry asked for a reliability study, he set the natural gas industry into a state of shock. They had a pretty good idea of what such a study would show. They didn't like it one bit.

Samuel needed to stay off the opiates.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507724896000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'106600042', u'id': u'106617983', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'AvMichelCroz', u'text': u'My observation is that a combination of commercial interest, naivety of politicians, doctrinaire view of some advisors, and a popular demand to do SOMETHING soon, has seen massively more construction of wind facilities than is useful - far beyond diminishing returns on any basis that can be foreseen in the short to medium term. In systems blessed with significant hydro, for example the developing system in China, certain parts of the USA, perhaps France and potentially Switzerland, greater amounts of a feed as variable as wind can potentially be useful. Of course if there is an excess of water, additional wind capacity will simply see a diminishing return on either the hydro or wind installation.
Of course, this situation may change in the future, if battery-powered (or other form of energy-storage-reliant) transport actually takes off, but this is off the current horizon.
David MacKay’s 2009 paper on energy alternatives for the UK “Sustainable Energy Without the Hot Air” provides a nice summary of a range of alternative solutions for a country with limited hydro capacity. Only one of the options he proposes has any significant amount of wind power, and he notes on the one that does that 100 major lakes will required to be converted to pumped storage in order to make it work. Australia - particularly South Australia - is a worse case
In my view, what we are observing during this phase of the energy transition is far too much faith and far too little genuine analysis. Otherwise the South Australia situation (massive over expenditure on wind capacity, given the current and foreseeable complementary generation & storage capacity available to them) should never have arisen. And perhaps Germany could be further along the track to decarbonisation if that were their genuine priority. Realpolitik dictated that Germany appease their Greens, and so some of the decisions and the resultant mis-spending is no doubt the cost of Merkel remaining in power. Given her contribution to creating conditions that encouraged Brexit, I wonder if this is a cost that anyone could consider reasonable under the circumstances.
My reply to you was in the same character as yours to me, although I was less condescending. I note that others object to your tone also.
