description: Dana Nuccitelli: Coal can no longer compete in the free market, so the Trump administration wants to prop it up with taxpayer subsidies
headline: T
og_fields.og:description: Dana Nuccitelli: Coal can no longer compete in the free market, so the Trump administration wants to prop it up with taxpayer subsidies
og_fields.og:title: Trump’s plan to bail out failing fossil fuels with taxpayer subsidies is perverse | Dana Nuccitelli
text:
The conservative philosophy of allowing an unregulated free market to operate unfettered often seems to fall by the wayside when the Republican Party’s industry allies are failing to compete in the marketplace. Trump’s Energy Secretary Rick Perry recently provided a stark example of this philosophical flexibility when he proposed to effectively pull the failing coal industry out of the marketplace and instead prop it up with taxpayer-funded subsidies.
The Trump administration has made no secret of its love for the coal industry. However, that industry has been losing badly in the free market, due largely to its inability to compete with cheaper natural gas and renewables. That was in fact the finding of Perry’s own Energy Department’s report, published just 3 months ago. The report also concluded:
Most of the common metrics for grid reliability suggest that the grid is in good shape despite the retirement of many baseload power plants … The power system is more reliable today due to better planning, market discipline, and better operating rules and standards
Perry’s new proposed rules directly contradict his department’s report, claiming “the resiliency of the electric grid is threatened by the premature retirements of these fuel-secure traditional baseload resources.” Perry tried to shift the goalposts from reliability to “resiliency” of the electric grid, essentially arguing that we need power plants that can store 90 days’ worth of fuel (i.e. huge piles of coal) to ensure that the grid remains “resilient.”
However, Perry also made the mistake of referencing the 2014 Polar Vortex to try and support this argument. The cold temperatures associated with that weather pattern caused electricity demand to spike, but as experts have noted, while wind energy produced above expectations during the Polar Vortex, coal power failed (emphasis added):
However, [Perry’s proposal] conveniently fails to mention that nearly 14 gigawatts (GW) of coal capacity was forced offline during the Polar Vortex, roughly 25 percent of all coal capacity in [the region]. 1.4 GW of nuclear was forced offline as well. Most of these generator outages were due to temperatures below the operating limit of power plant equipment ... Additional coal capacity was unavailable due to frozen coal piles.
Perry’s argument is so ludicrous that it bears repeating. He claims that we need to subsidize huge coal piles to ensure grid resiliency to extreme events like the Polar Vortex. But during the Polar Vortex, coal plants were shut down because they couldn’t operate at such low temperatures, and because their big coal piles were frozen. And this isn’t the only example of grid resiliency without coal – during Hurricane Harvey, coal piles were too wet to be transported to power plant boilers. During record heat waves this summer, California’s grid proved reliable as a result of factors like renewables and energy storage, not coal.
It’s abundantly clear that the Trump administration is looking for an excuse to prop up the failing coal industry, because they’ve made it a cog in their culture wars. And so Rick Perry ignored the findings of his own department’s grid reliability report and made up some nonsense about how we need huge piles of coal to justify giving the industry a bailout in the form of taxpayer-funded subsidies.
Along similar lines, a new study published in Nature Energy found that at current oil prices of $50 per barrel, about half of not-yet-developed oil fields are only profitable if the industry receives subsidies to pay for them. Worse yet, the oil industry pockets most taxpayer subsidy dollars in the form of profits:
At the price of US$50 per barrel, we find that a bit more than half (53%) of subsidy value (in net present value terms) goes to projects that would have proceeded anyway. That fraction rises to nearly all (98%) of subsidy value at US$100 per barrel. As others have found, regardless of the oil price, the majority of taxpayer resources provided to the industry end up as company profits.
Oil would obviously only be extracted from a given field if doing so would yield a profit; otherwise it would stay in the ground until something changed to make its extraction profitable (like taxpayer subsidies or higher oil market prices). 
To meet the Paris climate target in a cost-effective way, the U.S. would produce oil equivalent to 30 to 45 billion tons of carbon dioxide pollution allowed by 2050. At the current price of $50 per barrel, the oil industry subsidies would make an additional 17 billion barrels’ worth of oil reserves profitable, resulting in another 6 billion tons of carbon dioxide pollution. That would eat up 13 to 20% of America’s carbon budget for oil.
Another report by Oil Change International found that American taxpayers are footing the bill for $20 billion in direct fossil fuel industry subsidies every year. That’s about $80 per year per American taxpayer.
The purpose of subsidies is to keep a product’s prices low and competitive, usually because it somehow benefits society. Some people object that renewables are subsidized, but at least they produce low-carbon energy that also result in cleaner air and water and improved public health. Those are clear societal benefits.
So what is the benefit of subsidizing coal and oil? They have been the dominant fuels for over a century; do they really still need taxpayer money to keep them competitive with newer, cleaner fuel sources and energy technologies? If they do (as the Trump administration admits is the case for coal), why should taxpayers continue to prop them up? The subsidies will help keep gasoline prices low, but only because Americans are paying for it up-front in the form of taxes.
They result in dirtier air and water, worse public health, increased mortality, and accelerated climate change, the latter of which results in additional taxpayer costs. America has been battered by those expensive climate costs over the past few months with numerous intensified hurricanes, floods, heatwaves, wildfires, and droughts. Those climate costs likely amount to several hundred dollars per American taxpayer per year. And as the Nature Energy study lead author Peter Erickson pointed out to me,
by Congress’ own Joint Committee on Taxation analysis (post-Trump), the tax subsidies to oil and gas outweigh the tax subsidies for all charitable giving to health and education.
Each American taxpayer is giving the fossil fuel industry $80 per year, most of which is pocketed as profit. The rest goes to digging more coal and oil out of the ground, which increases air and water pollution, degrades public health, and accelerates climate change and the damages it causes. Failing to make polluters pay for that fossil fuel carbon pollution is effectively another $5 tn annual subsidy, globally.
But rather than working to eliminate this wasteful spending, the Trump administration is coming up with bogus excuses to dramatically increase fossil fuel subsidies to keep the failing coal industry afloat, proposing increased government regulations and spending taxpayer dollars to undermine the free market. It could not be a more perverse and counter-productive proposal that would use American taxpayer money to hurt us, to the exclusive benefit of the fossil fuel industry and the politicians in their pockets.

He was right.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507785651000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15302667', u'in_reply_to': u'106653053', u'id': u'106654426', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JamesCA', u'text': u'Sorry, you're just blathering and repeating nonsensical lies.
The reality of AGW is indisputable. The reality of GW from CO2 was established over a century ago. Our contribution to CO2 increases in the atmosphere was established over 50 years ago. The reality of a 0.2/decade temperature rise has been documented by several independent sources that all strongly agree with each other.
And basic physics predicts what we are seeing.
In the scientific community there is no debate about those fundamental facts, any more than people debate the reality of germs or atoms or plate tectonics. The only debate is about the details -- will various thresholds be crossed in 50 years or 70 years? Can we tolerate another 1C rise or is 0.5C the limit? Will devastating hurricanes be five times as likely or ten times as likely? NO ONE is presenting any evidence whatsoever that the current changes are completely natural, or that temperatures will begin to drop anytime in the next few centuries. Not one scientific paper, anywhere, by anyone.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507785197000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'10053869', u'in_reply_to': u'106653911', u'id': u'106654264', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JamesCA', u'text': u'Why do you bring up colleges? I was referring to profession scientific organizations.
As far as I know, none of those are tied to any university.

Some ships did make Northwest traversals before then, but they either travelled over the ice on sleds, used massive ice-breakers, or took several years to take advantage of local temporary opening to progress a few miles at a time.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507730335000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'10053869', u'in_reply_to': u'106607312', u'id': u'106623299', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JamesCA', u'text': u'BQSTART
Yet average sea temperatures haven't varied by a degree in 100 years.
BQEND
If temperatures had already shifted a full 1C we would be close to game over -- end of civilization. Yes, it good that it hasn't been quite that disastrous, but that doesn't mean (AT ALL) that things are ok. Do you understand that? 
BQSTART
Maybe the answer is we just don't know.
BQEND
No. That's complete false. We know. For a fact. With exquisite detail. Beyond any plausible doubt.
BQSTART
Has there always been an Arctic? No.
BQEND
Yes there has always been an Arctic. It hasn't always been frozen, though. In fact. for most of Earth's history it was not. 
BQSTART
Was the Antarctic once sub-tropical? Yes.
BQEND
Not quite. The Antarctic continent was once sub-tropical, but it was located further north then. So when the Antarctic (as defined by latitude) was ice-free and temperate, Antarctica (the land mass) was closer to the equator and hotter.
BQSTART
Not explainable. Just the way the cookies crumble.
BQEND
Completely explainable. And explained in the scientific literature. In great detail.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507784561000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'10053869', u'in_reply_to': u'106652056', u'id': u'106654039', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JamesCA', u'text': u'typo: 1834 should be 1824. By Joseph Fourier, same guy who came up with the Fourier transform.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507730240000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'10053869', u'in_reply_to': u'106623120', u'id': u'106623207', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JamesCA', u'text': u'The first paper on climate science was written in 1834, when the notion of greenhouse gases was suggested. CO2 and H2O were identified in the 1850's, before the Civil War. The basic law for climate sensitivity to CO2 was published in the 1890's. Concerns over our CO2 release were strong enough by the 1950's that every President since then has been warned. A movie was made about climate change in 1958. LBJ gave a special address to Congress warning about our release of CO2 in 1965.
The basic science establishing the reality of AGW and the danger it poses was in place by 1960. 
The papers you allude to about global cooling were all "what if?" scenarios. What if we had a nuclear war? What if we increased our aerosol production by a factor of 4? (we actually reduced it). Etc. In the last 100 years the population has grown nearly 5 times, CO2 production rocketed. During that time the Arctic has been at one of it's largest and smallest - the former being in the 70's.
I am merely suggesting that there are, as of today, no definitive answers - we don't know. Is it man, is it the cycle of earth, is it Santa Claus? We may have put a man on the moon but there remains vast swathes of knowledge yet to be garnered about Earth.

So far not looking so good - no real rise in average temperatures, no unusual extreme weather just better PR of storms.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507775704000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15302667', u'in_reply_to': u'106650365', u'id': u'106651580', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'derekcolman', u'text': u'That's incorrect."Clean coal" is a term coined to describe a coal fired plant which burns powdered coal for more complete combustion and has scrubbing technology to remove pollutants from flue gases. It predates the idea of carbon sequestration, and has that specific meaning. I know it's confusing to the anti-coal lobby, but that's probably because they don't research their subject before they start shouting. It is for them to come up with a new term to describe a clean coal plant with sequestration. How about "clean coal plus" or "extra clean coal" or "super clean coal" Clean coal plants significantly reduce pollution of the things which are said to shorten lives. A recent study of four clean coal plants in the USA found that there was no more air pollution downwind from them than upwind, which means the technology is very effective. As for CO2 sequestration, it's probably not viable, and it's not a technology that is presently available, with trial sites having little success.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507721100000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u"they do n't research their subject before they start shouting", u'effect': u"that 's probably"}], u'author_id': u'2600028', u'in_reply_to': u'106577184', u'id': u'106613726', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'mrpoohead', u'text': u'Why? Charging points for EVs don't need specialist locations, they can be installed anywhere there is a parking facility. - and the power doesn't need specialist transportation.', u'recommendation_count': u'8', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507652634000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'fuel needs to be stored in big underground tanks', u'effect': u'fuel stations are needed now'}], u'author_id': u'2923581', u'in_reply_to': u'106557630', u'id': u'106569998', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'mrpoohead', u'text': u'Then lets all applaud the oceans as they have yet to rise one degree in temperature despite your admonishments.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507672656000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15302667', u'in_reply_to': u'106583693', u'id': u'106585089', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JamesCA', u'text': u'BQSTART
And why is that?
BQEND
They could not progress because there was never a continuous open stretch of water, period. Satellite data would not have helped there.
Ships now can sail straight through in the summer, even if they choose to ignore any satellite information of any kind. 
And plankton species are also now drifting through for the first time in 800,000 years. They freely moved from the North Pacific to the North Atlantic for about two million years, then stopped about 800,000 years ago when the Arctic Ocean froze over, and then resumed in 2005. 
Whales are also now migrating through the Arctic Ocean for the first time in at least 400 years. Again, because the passages are wide open and they don't need to work their way under ice from polynya to polynya.
The volume of Arctic sea ice in September has now dropped to about 1/5 to 1/4 of what it was just 30 years ago. If that trend continues at the same rate, the volume will very likely approach zero in under ten years. Multiyear sea ice volume has already effectively plunged to zero -- all of the remaining ice tends to be less than about three years old, as compared to the 70's when virtually all of it was older than three years.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507775128000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'there was never a continuous open stretch of water period', u'effect': u'they could not progress'}, {u'cause': u"the passages are wide open and they do n't need to work their way under ice from polynya to polynya", u'effect': u','}], u'author_id': u'10053869', u'in_reply_to': u'106650351', u'id': u'106651406', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JamesCA', u'text': u'Climate change due to AGW was already a profound issue before 1960, your ignorance notwithstanding.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qF9WdV8pUPk
Here's a quote from LBJ's warning to Congress in 1965:
BQSTART
Air pollution is no longer confined to isolated places. This generation has altered the composition of the atmosphere on a global scale through radioactive materials and a steady increase in carbon dioxide from the burning of fossil fuels.
BQEND
http://www.presidency.ucsb.edu/ws/?pid=27285
Given just the data and science available in 1965 we already had more than sufficient evidence to require us to act to reduce CO2 emissions. Suggest you look up "exploration" think you'll find the first folk to cross the US had similar issues crossing the mountains, deserts in Australia; generally finding mountain passes, water in deserts, routes through jungles holds people up. Just different topography to the Arctic.

description: Scott Pruitt says he will sign rule on Tuesday withdrawing policy that imposed restrictions on emissions from coal-fired power stations
og_fields.og:description: Scott Pruitt says he will sign rule on Tuesday withdrawing policy that imposed restrictions on emissions from coal-fired power stations
og_fields.og:title: 'The war on coal is over': EPA boss to roll back Obama's clean power rules
text:
The head of the Environmental Protection Agency said on Monday that he would sign a new rule overriding the Clean Power Plan, an Obama-era effort to limit carbon emissions from coal-fired power plants. 
“The war on coal is over,” EPA administrator Scott Pruitt declared in the coal mining state of Kentucky, at an event with one of the state’s US senators, the Senate majority leader, Mitch McConnell. 
For Pruitt, getting rid of the Clean Power Plan will mark the culmination of a long fight he began as the elected attorney general of Oklahoma. Pruitt was among about two dozen attorney generals who sued to stop Barack Obama’s push to limit carbon emissions.
Closely tied to the oil and gas industry in his home state, Pruitt rejects the consensus of scientists that emissions from burning fossil fuels are the primary driver of global climate change.
Donald Trump, who appointed Pruitt and shares his skepticism of established climate science, promised to kill the clean power plan during the 2016 campaign as part of his broader pledge to revive the nation’s struggling coal mines.
In his order on Tuesday, Pruitt is expected to declare that the Obama-era rule exceeded federal law by setting emissions standards that power plants could not reasonably meet. 
Appearing at Whayne Supply, a Hazard, Kentucky, company that sells coal mining supplies, Pruitt said: “The EPA and no federal agency should ever use its authority to say to you: we are going to declare war on any sector of our economy.”
Whayne Supply has laid off about 60% of its workers in recent years. While cheering the demise of the clean power plan as a way to stop the bleeding, McConnell conceded most of those lost jobs are never coming back. 
“A lot of damage has been done,” said McConnell. “This doesn’t immediately bring everything back, but we think it stops further decline of coal-fired plants in the United States and that means there will still be some market here.” 
Obama’s plan was designed to cut US carbon dioxide emissions to 32% below 2005 levels by 2030. The rule dictated specific emission targets for states based on power-plant emissions and gave officials broad latitude to decide how to achieve reductions.
The supreme court put the plan on hold last year following legal challenges by industry and coal-friendly states.
Even so, the plan helped drive a recent wave of retirements of coal-fired plants, which also are being squeezed by lower costs for natural gas and renewable power, as well as state mandates promoting energy conservation.
The withdrawal of the clean power plan is the latest in a series of moves by Trump and Pruitt to dismantle Obama’s legacy on fighting climate change, including the delay or roll back of rules limiting levels of toxic pollution in smokestack emissions and wastewater discharges from coal-burning power plants.
The president announced earlier this year that he would pull the US out of the landmark Paris climate agreement. Nearly 200 countries have committed to combat global warming by reducing carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases that contribute to global warming.
“This president has tremendous courage,” Pruitt said. “He put America first and said to the rest of the world: we are going to say no and exit the Paris accord. That was the right thing to do.”
Environmental groups and public health advocates quickly derided the decision as shortsighted. 
“Trump is not just ignoring the deadly cost of pollution, he’s ignoring the clean energy deployment that is rapidly creating jobs across the country,” said Michael Brune, the executive director of the Sierra Club.

[{u'author': u'SimonCrase', u'text': u'BQSTART
Apparently one needs special permits to go visit area...
BQENDSource?

BQENDIf you have some evidence that permits are needed, you might be able to answer your own question.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507786816000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12271848', u'in_reply_to': u'106601378', u'id': u'106654901', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'glacier', u'text': u'Oh - science is eager and busy to study what happens with a planet that increase home-temperature with excess of one degree per century. 
Remember - 90% of all scientists who ever worked are alive now. None can claim to be Einstein or Fourier or the few who really made some theoretical findings more than a century ago. But a lot of attention is payed to that math. 
What science has now is however a unique viewpoint of watching a planet that change temperature on a rate that as of now change by almost 3 degrees per decade. 
So AGW is a really cool experiment. Here we are on a planet that is more than 4 billion years old - and we can study how it behaves while changing energy balance above equal to 0.03 degrees in temperature per year. 
In light of that 4.5 billion year old age - or even 1000 years - or even 100 years - that is rather spectacular, especially when studying life itself. As the physics is same all over the universe - but life being cause and effect - as far as we know - we choose to do that experiment on the only planet we know life exist on. 
The physics is the same everywhere, of course. But what it does with life - now that is something that can only be observed on this planet. So deniers are the gift that keeps giving for science - in checking out where life starts to hurt. Really interesting, since past hyper-thermals has over the last 3 decades provided science a lot of information of consequences - but not really the details to know exactly why 70% of life can die out. 
It is really interesting to be allowed to live in such interesting times. And Science Denial is the gift that keeps giving. 
And still all scientists beg for the experiment to stop. 
I wonder why?', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507750405000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4706143', u'in_reply_to': u'106575053', u'id': u'106639426', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'peggyschuyler', u'text': u'for what?', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507740431000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16517822', u'in_reply_to': u'106586198', u'id': u'106632513', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'kglowe', u'text': u'And it now has lots of species which weren't around in those times. It might seem like much but big chunks of ice like that will cause some kind of effect. 
The thing i'm curious about was a theory from a few years back when archaeologists discovered that North Africa used to be fertile grass land up until around 5000bc-ish if i remember what they said and one of the theories they had was that the global ocean currents changed and caused a great deal a climate change.

It's finding and recruiting skilled operators and the massive ongoing expenses needed to hire, keep, provide for and insure the people necessary for the project to produce good results. 
It's all about the people. It takes rare talents to safely operate a ship and the scientific equipment in those conditions, and they need some incentive to take an incredibly remote one-time or seasonal gig over a regular paycheck somewhere. 
If it were just the hardware costs, we'd have corporate logos stuck all over 2 dozen research vessels all trying to put corporate branding on the latest discoveries of biologists and glaciologists. Lol', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507624664000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13085893', u'id': u'106545552', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'celsius233', u'text': u'The last time some sections of this seafloor were clear of the ice shelf, the Earth still held thylacines, moas, dodos, quaggas, Stellar's sea cows, passenger pigeons, diprotodons, mammoths, Neanderthals ...', u'recommendation_count': u'25', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507591139000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'10145868', u'id': u'106533684', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Silgen', u'text': u'Time to recharge your tin foil hat.', u'recommendation_count': u'13', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507624435000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3956624', u'in_reply_to': u'106538231', u'id': u'106545394', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Erik Frederiksen', u'text': u'According to the renowned glaciologist Richard Alley most ice shelves are sensitive to changes in temperature of around 1 degree C.
Ice shelves are the floating terminations of glaciers at the ocean and they act as buttresses for the glaciers behind which drain the ice sheets by adding friction to glacial flow rates.
When the Rhode Island-sized Larsen B ice shelf on the Antarctic Peninsula collapsed over five weeks the glaciers behind sped up by a factor of 3-8--luckily the Peninsula isn’t big--and are still flowing at that accelerated rate today because the cork was removed.
Increased glacial flow rates have been observed hundreds of kilometers inland, so what happens at the coast doesn’t stay at the coast, but impacts the whole ice sheet.
So when we destroy ice shelves, the whole ice sheet responds, quickly. (1)
If we sped up all of Antarctica’s glaciers by a factor of 6.5, the rate of sea level rise would be 4m per century, the same rate which occurred for 4 centuries around 15,000 years ago.
There were larger ice sheets then, but that rate indicates that the ice sheets can do dramatic things when they retreat.
1 When the tide rises it slows glacial flow rates. When the tide goes out glacial flow rates increase, as measured by high time-resolution GPS devices placed on glaciers. It only takes a few hours to observe the effects of rising and falling tides on glacial flow rates 80 km inland so the ice responds quickly over long distances.', u'recommendation_count': u'14', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507589997000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'the cork was removed', u'effect': u'are still flowing at that accelerated rate today'}], u'author_id': u'15131989', u'id': u'106533195', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ethelfrida', u'text': u'Posting this in reply to every other comment rather dilutes your message.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507624353000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13620487', u'in_reply_to': u'106544705', u'id': u'106545333', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Silgen', u'text': u'Yeah, just like it's pure luck that Houston has had three "1 in 500 years" events in the last 18 months. Hmm, what could have recently changed to allow it to happen? What a mystery. The ice did not melt. The ice cracked...a completely natural process The tide rises and falls and this repeated movement cracks the ice at the shoreline..the "hinge". Make good documentary. Be real interesting and worth it for the science aspect alone. 120,000 years is a long time to be under the ice and it would be amazing to monitor and film the change that is now taking place upon sea-life, seaweeds from direct exposure to sunlight and warmer sea temperatures. A few millions funding from genuine donors will be money well spent and likely to have subsequent commercial payoffs. I am sure there are a few people about who are bored or have bucket list who would be willing to pay for passage to come.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507612986000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17008137', u'in_reply_to': u'106534556', u'id': u'106539382', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'MikeFlanagan', u'text': u'We've still got the Neanderthals Celsius, they're the chief bottle washers and cooks running the joint!', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507610979000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'11914131', u'in_reply_to': u'106533684', u'id': u'106538819', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'emptyCan', u'text': u'We just got lucky that two areas ice that have been covered for 100 000 years btoke off in less than 20?', u'recommendation_count': u'28', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507610917000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'1344616', u'in_reply_to': u'106538492', u'id': u'106538806', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'surferdave', u'text': u'bollocks. what do you mean 'couple hundred years'? actually this has been happening for millennia, this is a natural event and within the bounds of normal processes. the article makes zero mention of any attribution to AGW so just pull your head in heh?', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507609655000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3324344', u'in_reply_to': u'106532880', u'id': u'106538492', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'surferdave', u'text': u'Why does the title say 'damage'? description: British Antarctic Survey researchers will study area opened up by loss of iceberg A68, which has been hidden for up to 120,000 years
headline: L
og_fields.og:description: British Antarctic Survey researchers will study area opened up by loss of iceberg A68, which has been hidden for up to 120,000 years
og_fields.og:title: Scientists hope damage to Larsen C ice shelf will reveal ecosystems
text:
A team of scientists is planning an expedition to examine the marine ecosystem revealed when an enormous iceberg broke off the Larsen C ice shelf earlier this year.
In July, the iceberg known as A68 broke off the shelf, leaving the area at its lowest recorded extent. Researchers are now hoping the event may lead to novel revelations from their investigations of the area opened up, which had been hidden under ice for up to 120,000 years. 
Scientists from the British Antarctic Survey (BAS) will embark on the research ship RRS James Clark Ross in February 2018 to take the first look at the newly exposed ecosystems under the ice – if the conditions work in their favour.
“You can never predict the ice,” said mission leader Dr Katrin Linse. “There are still several hundred kilometres covered in sea ice which has to move and melt. Fortunately this often happens now during the Antarctic summer, so that is why we are hopeful for February.” 
If everything works out, the scientists will have the chance to look at 5,800 sq km of sea floor that had been shielded for tens of thousands of years. Planning for such expeditions normally takes several years, but urgent funding schemes are available during such unpredictable natural events, like the volcanic activity over Iceland in 2010.
It is not the first time that scientists have been given the chance to take a look at these hidden marine worlds. After a similar iceberg broke off from the Larsen B shelf in 2002, a team of scientists set out to Antarctica, although it took much longer to get there. 
Prof Dr Julian Gutt, a marine ecologist at the Alfred Wegener Institute for Polar and Marine Research in Bremerhaven, Germany, was the first to lead a vessel to the area. He said: “We went to the area five years after it broke off. We had to try and learn what lived under the ice shelf when it still existed, so were never absolutely sure if our interpretation was correct.”
This presents a unique opportunity for the BAS team: “The Larsen C break-off is recent, so if the British scientists are successful – under the difficult conditions they are facing – they could really encounter a pristine situation,” says Gutt.
The BAS team expect to find organisms resembling those in deep-sea environments because of the areas’ similar conditions: a lack of nutrients, sunlight and wind. 
A short timespan between the breakoff and research is crucial, says Linse. 
“What Julian Gutt’s team found there five years after were already pioneer species, which slowly colonise the area. When we go this February, organisms will not have had enough time to settle down and adapt to their new environment,” she said. 
The final decision on whether the project goes ahead will be made at the end of the year.

BQSTART

A man who pretends he can shuffle off to London to deliver a speech so profoundly deficient in basis that it simply condemns him as incompetent? A man who thinks said speech is 'speaking his mind'! Such hubris. It reveals his wilful ignorance, but he thinks it shows his 'independence'.
BQEND
May response to you on this point is simply SO WHAT? His speech may have all of the deficiency you claim or it may be utterly brilliant. But he is simply a backbrench MP and he is entitled to have any opinion and share that opinion at any venue for any audience who are willing to listen your level of rancor is simply WAY out of proportion here.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507791385000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16787174', u'in_reply_to': u'106652777', u'id': u'106657041', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'NewmanOldjoke', u'text': u'Abbott tells deliberate untruths, is that clear enough for you Bob? He's a liar.
He's on record cautioning the public that not everything he says is true.
He lied about SPC's workers agreements and alleged they were hurting the company's bottom line, for instance. He promised no cuts to specific institutional budgets before the election, and broke that promise.
He said this in London:
BQSTART
"The growing evidence that records have been adjusted..."
BQEND
There has always been evidence that records have been adjusted! It's standard practise! Homogenisation of temperature data sets is a necessary part of improving their quality. The raw data in the global network shows a greater trend than the adjusted! Abbott could know that, as his scientific advisors would have told him...if he didn't snub them
BQSTART
.. that the impact of urban heat islands has been downplayed
BQEND
UHI is an effect that has been known for several hundred years. In the last fifty years there is an extensive literature on accounting for it in weather recording. It is a lie to claim it is downplayed.
BQSTART
Contrary to the breathless assertions that climate change is behind every weather event...
BQEND
No one has made such an assertion. The UN IPCC has never claimed it. No national scientific bodies, no national weather bureaus, no government acting on the advice of their knowledge base have ever made this claim...it is a fiction. I have not read a single journalist make such an assertion, breathlessly or otherwise. It's a lie. It cannot be excused as dumb rhetoric, not from a national leader or even a backbencher pretending he has no responsibilities.
BQSTART
More than 100 years of photography at Manly Beach in my electorate does not suggest that sea levels have risen despite frequent reports from climate alarmists that this is imminent."
BQEND
Even a mediocre arts graduate like Abbott should know something about measurement, and know anecdote from data. Of course he does. As a keen swimmer he'd know how much a beach profile shifts around season to season.
He's heard of Fort Denison, and knows it has a long tide gauge record that unequivocally shows sea level has risen....and it's not far from Manly. And as for being 'imminent' it's been happening for decades. His 'ignorance' is inexcusable.
How do I know he's a liar? Because he sits in the heart of an information network design to give him as a public representative access to the best scientific knowledge on the environment, on data gathering, on climate, and on the economy. He does not need to have a personal opinion in areas in which he has absolutely no practical training, he can cite expert opinion which is credible...he chooses not to, because he does not want to be limited by truth telling.
Abbott's life would be dull if he wasn't able to lie when he considers necessary. Audacious lying is his core skill as a politician, he has few others.
He's a fool as well: in his leafy near-coastal home he experiences a climate moderated by the ocean, thus his reckoning of climate change:
BQSTART
After two decades' experience of the very modest reality of climate change.
BQEND
is just another useless anecdote.
Globally there has been massive documented change. If he shuns knowledge about that, he has no place aspiring to leadership.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507714951000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'he does not want to be limited by truth telling', u'effect': u'he does not need to have a personal opinion in areas in which he has absolutely no practical training cite he chooses not to'}], u'author_id': u'12684952', u'in_reply_to': u'106597950', u'id': u'106606554', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'NewmanOldjoke', u'text': u'Abbott tells deliberate untruths, is that clear enough for you Bob? He has published 60 academic papers and six books. His research focuses on the study of climate dynamics and global change.Professor Fritz VahrenholtFritz Vahrenholt was one of the founders of the environmental movement in Germany. He has served in several public positions with environmental ministries. He is the author of the 2012 bestseller The Neglected Sun and is Chairman of the German Wildlife Trust.

They are raiding the common wealth and directing it to the 1%...crippling government and regulation built on science and social knowledge for the common good.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507763131000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12684952', u'in_reply_to': u'106645919', u'id': u'106647302', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Tammar', u'text': u'A thoughtful article - but really, who knows what drives the mad monk - a mechanism to fight Labor or just revenge that he knows could run the Coalition into opposition.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507684071000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15282527', u'id': u'106590368', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, ...]
description: The pitch behind the London speech was that a climate ruckus aids the Coalition. He should have been laughed out of the room
og_fields.og:description: The pitch behind the London speech was that a climate ruckus aids the Coalition. He should have been laughed out of the room
og_fields.og:title: Tony Abbott's climate frolic is strange and sad – and all about politics | Katharine Murphy
text:
It would be tempting to laugh at Tony Abbott’s feelings about how carbon dioxide is secretly good for humanity, and his insights into the goat sacrificing habits of primitives subduing volcano gods – except it isn’t that funny.
The London outing is more strange and sad, and the strangeness and the sadness manifests itself on multiple fronts.
Let’s start with strange.
The bloke who hobnobbed with the climate sceptics at Global Warming Policy Foundation is the same bloke who took a decision as prime minister to sign Australia up to the Paris international climate agreement.
He’s also the same bloke who produced a set of initiatives in government which was badged as a policy to incentivise emissions reductions.
That policy still exists and it’s called Direct Action.
He’s also the same bloke who kept Australia’s renewable energy target, while abolishing the mechanism designed to give the market certainty to make future investments in baseload power generation.
Abbott has a whole lot of feelings, and some loyal media megaphones to help him spread his singular insights, but these are basic facts he can’t escape.
Abbott’s record in government points to him being a “warmist” (as Andrew Bolt is fond of characterising the modest band of weirdos who don’t think they know better than the world’s most eminent climate scientists).
London’s hardcore climate sceptics, frankly, should have laughed him out of the room.
Now let’s get to sad. Abbott’s climate frolic isn’t about a substantive issue. It’s about politics, because Australians haven’t had quite enough of politics, right?
Abbott wants to cause a ruckus. He wants to make enough ruckus to constrain Malcolm Turnbull from producing a sensible energy policy.
The lightbulb moment he’s trying to manufacture for colleagues is simple: the Abbott rationale is we can win the next election like I won the election in 2013 – by belting Labor on climate and energy policy.
The country, the national interest, actually needs the major parties to come to terms and settle the climate wars which have generated the current problems we are all experiencing in the energy market, and settle them in sensible fashion.
But politicians behind in the polls like to win elections.
Put simply, Abbott’s pitch is an appeal to baser instincts – a pitch that prolonged polarisation serves the Coalition’s immediate interests.
The former prime minister has also positioned himself in the public domain as a critical player in Turnbull’s ultimate settlement of energy policy, when the truth is all the heavy lifting on the new policy is happening completely outside Abbott’s orbit.
The actual decision makers in the government are heads down bums up on the new investment framework, swerving around the many obstacles, trying to land something vaguely credible, which doesn’t blow up the Coalition.
That’s the objective. Whether the government can produce something credible, given one of the core objectives has to be not blowing up the Coalition, is at this point seriously moot.
Meanwhile, Abbott’s persistent wrecking tactics allow Labor to claim with a veneer of truth and credibility that the former prime minister is driving the government’s energy policy rather than Turnbull – elevating his status from fringe agitprop activist to centre-stage.
In politics that sort of caper is called frontrunning, but I struggle for a word to adequately characterise that behaviour.
Perhaps we can just keep it nice, and say cynical?

There isn't much thinking going on in that tank.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507677304000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'11969538', u'in_reply_to': u'106583768', u'id': u'106587867', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'rockyrex', u'text': u'This is typical of so-called climate sceptics.
So-called climate sceptics have only one plan - to confuse people.
They provide a selection of conflicting ideas, along these lines:
When considering global temperature rise, declining sea ice area, melting glaciers, or sea level rise .........
(a) it is not happening and
(b) it is a natural event and
(c) it is a good thing
All at the same time, or one at a time, as required.
Some say "Temperatures havn't changed for ...... years." (With various different numbers in the gap.)
Others say "The Earth has been cooling for ..... years." (As above)
Some say "It's the Sun causing the warming." (solar scientists don't agree).
Others say "It's all a hoax".
Or "It's a religion".
Others say "There's an Ice Age coming".
Or "It's all caused by volcanoes."
And so on and so on.
Some say there is no such thing as a greenhouse effect (there is), others say the rise in CO2 is natural (it isn't).
When one of them posts any one of the above ideas, strangely the others (who have posted different ideas just before) don't pile in and argue with them.
They only argue with people posting material based on scientific research.
It's a fringe view, based on no evidence.
They appear to be just another group of conspiracy theorists -but of course some are linked to various vested interests.
These folk are only sceptical of things from actual scientific sources, never from stuff produced by fringe eccentrics, who they believe no matter how confused and contradictory that material might be.', u'recommendation_count': u'19', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507645188000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': None, u'effect': u'the warming'}, {u'cause': u'volcanoes', u'effect': u'it'}], u'author_id': u'2923581', u'in_reply_to': u'106562352', u'id': u'106564005', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'gFROMw1958', u'text': u'You just caused a vision in my head that is terrible. He's not only spouting utter garbage, he's on a vindictive rampage within the LNP, desperately trying to ensure that his values and beliefs prevail. The bizarre thing is, it seems to be working. Mal mostly just smiles and makes another dismissive"broad church" comment, seemingly oblivious to the way this unedifying spectacle makes him look more spineless and ineffectual by the day. Abbott now seems so mad and so destructive that the Libs really need to lop his head off, one way or another. I sense a showdown is not too far off. But with any luck they'll hold off long enough for it to be a lesson to the whole country just before the next election.', u'recommendation_count': u'11', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507644495000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'11870037', u'id': u'106563456', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'leaherring', u'text': u'Well it is all a bit complicated, but I will do my best to explain;
Direct Action means farmers are paid money not to cut down trees. With trees growing carbon is not put into the atmosphere.
Since the LNP is proposing to build a coal fired power station it will put carbon into the atmosphere. To off set that carbon going into the atmosphere from coal fired power stations Australia pays a foreign country not to cut down trees (international Permit). That makes the coal fired power station carbon neutral.
Now under Julia Gillard a number of businesses had to cut their carbon emissions or buy an off set carbon credit, like farmers not cutting down trees, or buy carbon credits that are generated with domestic solar systems because domestic solar systems make electricity without producing carbon emissions.
So the coal fired power station being proposed to be built by the LNP that will produce carbon emissions rather than buying International permits, off set the carbon emissions with Australia's own carbon off set carbon credits from domestic solar system or another renewable energy producer, like wind farms.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507666964000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'domestic solar systems make electricity without producing carbon emissions', u'effect': u'buy carbon credits that are generated with domestic solar systems'}], u'author_id': u'16602772', u'in_reply_to': u'106549889', u'id': u'106580694', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'arsellona', u'text': u'Oh dear mountainmaid. On what do you base that assertion that it is just propaganda? I guess you do at least say it is your opinion - but based on what? And do we wait for extremely obvious concrete evidence? By then it's too late. The predictions that have been made over the past 30 years (yep, in 1987 even Margaret Thatcher spoke about global warming as it was called then as a moral duty to combat) are now happening - is that enough to stop and say perhaps we need to do something to curb our emissions?', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507676450000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15938720', u'in_reply_to': u'106581807', u'id': u'106587424', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Beekeeper49', u'text': u'Abbott, in his comments about the effects of climate change, seems to be saying that Australian farmers do not count. Never mind their crops won’t survive record temperatures. He assumes the United Kingdom will get a little warmer and thinks that is a good outcome. It shows where his heart truly is.
The irony is that scientists are concerned the UK climate may get colder, matching that of the Scandinavian countries. I won’t try to explain the science. Suffice to say that when I undertook environmental studies about fifteen years ago, it was a talking point then. Uneducated people who have not studied science, sometimes have little understanding of how geography, ocean temperatures etc create weather patterns. 
Abbott should stop making up “science” as he goes. He has no idea what he is talking about. But isn’t it galling that he could not care less about record temperatures in parts of Australia in late September having ruined some vegetable crops, let alone the damage that will occur when temperatures are even higher. Stock will also suffer. I recall hundreds of fowls on our farm dying as a result of one particular heat wave when I was young. As higher temperatures occur more often, it does not bear thinking about, knowing how the animals and poultry will suffer.
And presumably Abbott does not care about massive fish kills that occurred during the last El Nino event. The people of Chile care, however. It was an economic disaster.', u'recommendation_count': u'11', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507644363000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14883613', u'id': u'106563357', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Stalga', u'text': u'Last paragraph, excellent point.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507666406000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17200335', u'in_reply_to': u'106564005', u'id': u'106580243', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'anotherrose', u'text': u'We knew that. description: Tanya Plibersek says Abbott’s speech to climate sceptics in London was ‘actually just weird stuff’
og_fields.og:description: Tanya Plibersek says Abbott’s speech to climate sceptics in London was ‘actually just weird stuff’
og_fields.og:title: Tony Abbott's climate change speech 'loopy', says Labor
text:
Tony Abbott has “left the realm of the merely destructive and entered the realm of the loopy”, Labor says, after his provocative speech arguing climate change was “probably doing good”.
The deputy Labor leader Tanya Plibersek said on Tuesday Abbott’s speech to a group of climate sceptics in London was “actually just weird stuff from the former prime minister” at a time when the government was trying to settle its energy policy. 
While Abbott’s London outburst forced government colleagues into various acts of public diplomacy on Tuesday, one fellow conservative, the Sydney Liberal MP Craig Kelly, and chairman of the backbench committee on climate and energy, defended Abbott’s rationale.
“The point that Tony makes is 100% correct, and the chief scientist has actually confirmed this, the chief scientist has said, no matter what we do here in Australia with our emissions, it’s not going to change the weather, it’s not going to change the temperature of the globe, it’s not going to prevent bad storms,” Kelly told Sky News.
The government this week has continued to signal that it will not pursue the clean energy target modelled by the chief scientist, Alan Finkel, in his review of the national electricity market published mid-year.
Abbott has opposed the Finkel recommendation from the outset, branding further subsidies for renewables “unconscionable”, and, alongside fellow government conservative George Christensen, has threatened to cross the floor in the event the government attempts to legislate it.
With the government working to finalise its policy and present it during the final parliamentary sitting weeks before the summer break, the energy minister Josh Frydenberg used an energy summit on Monday to argue low emissions technologies may not need further subsidies once the current renewable energy target winds down after 2020.
That signal has rattled industry players, who had assumed the government was working on a modified version of the Finkel recommendation.
As industry alarm about the government’s policy direction intensified, the chief scientist publicly defended his mechanism as being important to provide investor certainty.
While the clean energy target has broad ranging support from industry, the energy sector and state governments, the heavily contested internal dynamics of the Coalition renders the Finkel recommendation hard to deliver.
The government’s new energy policy is expected to include an overhaul of the national electricity market rules to provide incentives to bring more dispatchable power in the market.
While Finkel’s target has clearly hit an internal roadblock, the policy is expected to include mechanisms to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, including the use of international permits, which the government first signalled when it launched a review of its Direct Action policy.
Industry sources also expect the existing Emissions Reduction Fund, which is the Coalition’s voluntary scheme that gives incentives for farmers and landholders to reduce emissions, to be given renewed funding.
A range of groups, from the business lobby to environmentalists, want the major parties to reach a bipartisan agreement on energy and climate policy and end a wretched decade of partisan argument.
As the government is moving to finalise its policy, Labor has increased its public overtures that it is prepared to deal with the Coalition in the event it can produce a credible policy.
But Labor has also grabbed Abbott’s public frolic to argue Malcolm Turnbull is not in charge of the Coalition’s policy formulation.
Labor’s treasury spokesman, Chris Bowen, said on Tuesday Abbott’s intervention underscored the “catastrophic failure” of Turnbull “to stand up to the climate deniers in his party”.
Bowen said Abbott was “an effective handbrake on the elected prime minister, stopping any sensible policy progress when it comes to climate change and energy”.
He said Labor has not given the chief scientist the task of drafting a policy settlement for climate and energy, that request had come from the government.
“Alan Finkel has delivered a very good report which says here’s a way forward,” Bowen said. “We’ve got this remarkable circumstance with the opposition of the day willing to be bipartisan but the government can’t reach an internal partisan position.
“We can’t negotiate with a puff of smoke.
“We need the government to have a position so that we can reach that policy certainty. We don’t have that because frankly Malcolm Turnbull is just not up to it.”

og_fields.og:description: Climate change campaigner and Marshall Islands politician who was instrumental in securing the Paris agreement
og_fields.og:title: Tony de Brum obituary
text:
To live on one of the Pacific atolls is to come face to face with climate change on a daily basis. Few people in the world had such personal experience as Tony de Brum of the realities of sea level rises and storm surges, of warmer seas, receding beaches and abandoned land. Fewer still have been able to turn that experience into international action to save the islands, and the rest of the planet with them.
De Brum, who has died aged 72, acted as ambassador on climate change for the Marshall Islands, a sparsely populated group of more than 1,000 tiny islands spread out over nearly 30 coral atolls. In 2015, he was instrumental in securing the Paris agreement on climate change, by which the world’s governments collectively agreed, for the first time, to hold global warming to no more than 2C above pre-industrial levels, which scientists say is the limit of safety, and with an aspiration to ensure warming does not exceed 1.5C.
The 1.5C provision was crucial for the low-lying Pacific island states: scientists estimate that, at 2C of warming, the atolls would be overswept by sea level rises and frequent storm surges. Only a lower limit would give them a lifeline, but the challenge of cutting greenhouse gas emissions in line with such a goal is immense, and while small developing countries were keen, many big economies balked at it. In the tense final days of the negotiations, De Brum helped to lead a coalition of developing and developed countries to forge a compromise and carry the day, resulting in the historic accord. He was hailed as “a real hero, a giant of history, a custodian of our shared future” by the Marshall Islands’ president, Hilda Heine, and by the former UN climate chief, Christiana Figueres, as “an inspiring leader, a pillar of determination”.
De Brum’s work on climate change, while it will form perhaps his most lasting global legacy, was only the third of the great causes he espoused in a five-decade career of public service, during which he served as foreign minister of the Marshall Islands for three separate terms, interspersed with periods as minister of finance, of health and the environment, and as assistant to the president.
De Brum was born on Tuvalu, a former British colony 700 miles north of Fiji, as the war in the Pacific was nearing its final deadly stages. The family later moved to Likiep, in the Marshall Islands, at that time a trust territory of the US, which had wrested control from Japan. His father, Joe, became manager of Majuro airport; his mother, Cecilia, was a teacher.
When hostilities ended, the US began 12 years of nuclear testing in the area, with close to 70 blasts by 1958. As a boy, De Brum witnessed one of the consequences from a fishing boat. He later recalled: “I was fishing with my grandfather. He was throwing the net and suddenly the silent bright flash, and then a force, the shockwave. Everything turned red: the ocean, the fish, the sky, and my grandfather’s net. And we were 200 miles away from ground zero.” This was the Bravo Shot, the largest of the US nuclear tests carried out on Bikini Atoll, more than a thousand times as powerful as the bomb that destroyed Hiroshima.
The Marshall Islanders’ campaign for freedom from the US lasted through the 1970s, with independence coming in 1979. After studying at Chaminade University, then the University of Hawaii – he was one of the first Marshall Islanders to attend university, according to Heine – De Brum took part in the negotiations, and in the independent governments that followed.
His experience of nuclear testing led to a lifelong crusade for nuclear disarmament, culminating in filing lawsuits against all nine nuclear-armed countries in the international court of justice in 2014. “Nuclear weapons are a senseless threat to essential survival. There are basic human and ethical norms, not to mention longstanding treaties, which compel those who possess them to pursue and achieve their elimination,” he said. The legal bid failed.
Unassuming in manner, grey-haired and grey-suited, De Brum could have been indistinguishable from the hundreds of other functionaries milling through the halls of UN meetings. There was nothing grey about his personality, however: affable and friendly, he was always ready with a quip or a wink for journalists, and shared stories about his beloved islands, his childhood and his family. He was as happy to greet groups of schoolchildren, or students dressed as polar bears, as to mingle with world leaders.
De Brum’s work at the two-week-long Paris talks was a masterclass in diplomacy. The debate over whether the 1.5C target should be included had the potential to wreck the talks – it had wrecked the previous attempt, eight years earlier in Copenhagen. By agreeing a compromise, he showed a pragmatism often absent from the negotiations, and helped lead his fellow small island states and least developed countries in joining with the EU and various others in the “coalition of high ambition”.
Some dismissed the 1.5C aspirational target as unachievable, but De Brum’s faith was borne out by a new study, published soon after his death in Nature Geoscience, a prestigious peer-review journal. It concluded that keeping within 1.5C was possible, though it required effort.
De Brum is survived by his wife, Rosalie (nee Maddison), whom he married in 1969, three children, 10 grandchildren and five great-grandchildren, and by his father.
• Anton de Brum, politician, born 26 February 1945; died 22 August 2017

Hence the strange arm swinging gait and the darting tongue just like a goanna.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507840124000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3708166', u'in_reply_to': u'106574698', u'id': u'106704134', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Nijinzky', u'text': u'"If you've ever expressed the least bit of skepticism about environmentalist calls for making the vast majority of fossil fuel use illegal, you've probably heard the smug response: “97% of climate scientists agree with climate change” — which always carries the implication: Who are you to challenge them?
The answer is: you are a thinking, independent individual--and you don’t go by polls, let alone second-hand accounts of polls; you go by facts, logic and explanation.
Here are two questions to ask anyone who pulls the 97% trick.
1. What exactly do the climate scientists agree on?
Usually, the person will have a very vague answer like "climate change is real."
Which raises the question: What is that supposed to mean? That climate changes? That we have some impact? That we have a large impact? That we have a catastrophically large impact? I'm afraid you'll have to do better than that.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507769022000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15336029', u'in_reply_to': u'106592472', u'id': u'106649322', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Reddenbluesy', u'text': u'That's how the Paris Agreement is intended to work.
Each sovereign nation-state acts to segue to carbon-neutrality within its jurisdiction, and its performance is open to scrutiny by everyone else. No 'country' has fixed targets imposed; everyone is expected to do their best, according to their circumstances.
Given that Australia is well-placed to replace the use of coal with solar/wind/hydro/tidal in generating electricity within its jurisdiction, yes... it is entirely possible that Australia could be an exporter of fossil-fuels whilst 'banning' their use for such purposes itself.
The Paris Accords represent the fundamental agreement that humanity shares one planet, and that we collectively need to get to being greenhouse-emission neutral ASAP. Once there we can collectively think about remedial action to reverse the AGW already in the Earth's climate system... so long as we haven't nudged it past a tipping-point where we've unleashed a self-sustaining trend that will break the glacial-cycle we've physically and culturally evolved in, on a one-way trip to a hotter, wetter planet than our genus (let alone species) has ever experienced.
Sure, the Earth always survives climate-change, it's natural and life on Earth will most-likely persist until the Sun goes red-giant. But we're playing with it on a timescale of decades, converting fossil bound-carbon bio-geologically sequestered over hundreds of millions of years into free atmospheric greenhouse-gases.
Seriously, on geological timescales our evolution from monkey-primate to Homo sapiens, and the mass-extinction of other species associated with it, has occurred in the blink of an eye.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507767254000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15623900', u'in_reply_to': u'106647757', u'id': u'106648821', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'WIZICAL', u'text': u'Australia's Trump!!!', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507766734000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14807895', u'id': u'106648664', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ohyeahsure', u'text': u'Coal must be phased out worldwide as soon as possible. description: The former Australian prime minister’s misleading speech to a London thinktank was full of climate denial mythology
og_fields.og:description: The former Australian prime minister’s misleading speech to a London thinktank was full of climate denial mythology
og_fields.og:title: Tony Abbott dares us to reject evidence on climate, but reveals a coward | Graham Readfearn
text:
Tony Abbott titled his London speech on climate change “Daring to Doubt” – a challenge, if you will, to reject mountains of evidence and instead lick your fingers and shove them into the plug socket of denial.
Go on, I dare you.
Throughout his speech, the former Australian prime minister urged listeners to think that dismissing decades of research backed by the world’s leading scientific institutions required bravery and fortitude, rather than other less celebrated human attributes.
But what would constitute bravery for a conservative politician like Abbott? Changing your mind when the evidence tells you you’re dead wrong, or saying what you’ve always said, using the logical fallacies that you’ve always used? One step is brave, the other is cowardly.
Abbott was giving the Global Warming Policy Foundation’s annual lecture – an “honour” previously bestowed on his spiritual and political mentors John Howard and Cardinal George Pell. 
Nobody should be surprised that what we got was an absolute crap speech from a man who confessed he still thinks climate science is “absolute crap”.
Abbott went for the whole canon of tired climate science denial talking points – carbon dioxide is just food for plants, the climate has always changed, it’s the sun – in what constituted a warmed-up meal of misinformation with a side order of supercilious gravy.
Several leading Australian climate scientists have hit back. How tired they must get of debunking this stuff.
Abbott’s speech was also chock-full of internal contradictions.
He suggested a conspiracy to tamper with temperature readings, but admitted the globe was warming. He described carbon dioxide as a “trace gas” and dismissed its role in warming, but elsewhere thought warming (which might not be happening) would be good. And the “trace gas” is insignificant, but not when it comes to its ability to “green the planet” and help plants grow. 
Professor Steve Sherwood, deputy director of the University of New South Wales Climate Change Research Centre, read the speech and said it was “the usual mix of misdirection, falsehoods and tirades against ‘brigades’ who supposedly say this and that but are never clearly identified”.
The @thegwpfcom wouldn't let me attend @TonyAbbottMHR's speech. But here's what he said https://t.co/cutUHcZZ4L pic.twitter.com/peDjtdveC4
Abbott told the thinktank – which had denied requests from seasoned climate reporters to attend – that past climate changes that occurred millions of years ago showed there was nothing to worry about now.
“Abbott is trying to hide the fact that it is the scientists themselves – who know more about past climate changes than he does – who are sounding the alarm,” said Sherwood.
The former prime minister confined his scientific missteps to seven or eight paragraphs in the middle of his speech. 
Abbott presents an absurdly and intentionally distorted viewpoint, reminiscent of a conspiracy theorist
Professor Mark Howden, director of the ANU Climate Change Institute, said Abbott’s claim that other factors, such as sunspots cycles or wobbles in the Earth’s orbit could be just as important as carbon dioxide, was simply false.
“The evidence that our climate is changing due to human activity is overwhelming,” said Howden. “2016 was globally the hottest year on record, surpassing the 2015 record, surpassing the 2014 record. There is 99.999% certainty that humans are driving the observed temperature rises via greenhouse gas emissions.”
Abbott’s claim that “no big change has accompanied the increase in carbon dioxide concentration” was “problematic”, said Howden, given “research shows that the world has already warmed by approximately 1C since pre-industrial times”.
“We are already experiencing changed patterns of rainfall, more and more days with extreme temperatures, increasingly intense natural disasters and rising sea levels, impacting on almost all facets of life in Australia.”
Professor Andrew Pitman, director of the Australian Research Council’s Centre of Excellence for Climate Extremes, said while it was true that CO2 is essential to life, “life also requires many trace elements that at higher concentrations are toxic”.
“It is a myth to imply that because CO2 is essential to life, more of it is good.”
Abbott also deployed another favourite talking point from climate science misinformers – that warming (which, remember, he thinks might not be happening) will cut the number of people dying of cold. 
Pitman said this argument, too, was misleading, saying: “It is true that in rich countries which tend to be in the mid to higher latitudes, some warming might help reduce deaths from cold. In the lower latitude countries – the subtropics and tropics – people rarely die of cold. In contrast they die of heat and lack of clean water. 
“So, countries responsible for global warming might gain a minor benefit from warming while those least responsible will wear the consequences.” 
Dr Liz Hanna, an expert on the impacts of climate change on human health, said human-caused warming was already implicated in the deaths of many thousands.
“In 2003, 70,000 people died in western Europe, and in 2010 a further 55,000 people died in Russia and eastern Europe. These figures far exceed deaths from cold snaps. The decade 2001-2010 saw a 2,300% increase in heat deaths above the previous decade. Mr Abbott’s assertions don’t tell the whole story, as they’re based on what has happened in the past rather than what is projected to happen in future. While more people die from cold than heat in Melbourne at the moment, this will reverse as more summer days reach the high 40s.”
Away from his errors on the evidence, Abbott tried to characterise climate science and environmentalism as being hamstrung by a religious-type fervour that gets in the way of “common sense”. Abbott said:
Environmentalism has managed to combine a post-socialist instinct for big government with a post-Christian nostalgia for making sacrifices in a good cause. Primitive people once killed goats to appease the volcano gods. We’re more sophisticated now but are still sacrificing our industries and our living standards to the climate gods to little more effect.
Beware the pronouncement, ‘the science is settled’. It’s the spirit of the Inquisition, the thought-police down the ages. Almost as bad is the claim that ‘99% of scientists believe’ as if scientific truth is determined by votes rather than facts.
As a Roman Catholic libertarian free market ideologue, Abbott is, presumably, immune to such group think.
Climate scientist Ben Henley, of the University of Melbourne, also spots Abbott’s facile argument. In an email he told me:
“By implication, Abbott superstitiously questions the foundations of science, and in doing so, he questions the same scientific method which discovered wifi and penicillin, and proved the Earth was not flat.
“Abbott presents an absurdly and intentionally distorted viewpoint, reminiscent of a conspiracy theorist.”
Abbott’s attitude to climate change seems to rest on a Boy’s Own “who dares wins” approach to policy that’s neither brave or daring. It’s stupid.
 Graham Readfearn is the Guardian’s Planet Oz opinion columnist
