BQEND
Thanks. This is certainly an interesting concept, and a good article (if a bit light on technical detail).
My understanding is that while H2 distribution via a natural gas network is certainly possible, it would be at pressures similar to natural gas, and require blending with a dilutant/inerter for safety reasons. It would still require processing and compression (to 700 bar!) at filling sites before being usable in vehicles. This itself requires considerable energy and still requires large storage tanks at the filling site if it is to be able to handle significant volume.
Secondly, this would require complete replacement of Natural Gas equipment, such as boilers and cook-tops, with H2 equipment at every premises on the network. It would be hard to do this piecemeal: you'd have to shut down the Natural Gas network, region by region, spend many months or years upgrading equipment at every customer site, and finally start it back up with H2. This itself may well make it a non-starter!
I can't help but think they have the entire concept backwards: they are trying to promote an H2 network to justify continued Natural Gas exploration/production, to produce H2 via steam reformation with the idea that CCS will make it carbon neutral. (CCS is, unfortunately, unproven and very expensive - and many CCS trials have failed.)
A far better idea, perhaps: Use H2 to produce synthetic natural gas. This is actually not difficult once you have the H2, and you can use CO2 extracted from the atmosphere:
CO2 + 4 H2 → CH4 + 2 H2Ohttps://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sabatier_reaction
This carbon-neutral gas could be blended seamlessly with the existing gas supply, with the proportion increased over time as more H2 production becomes available. No need to replace domestic equipment, or even to replace metal pipes with PE.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507848072000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'10113286', u'in_reply_to': u'106695146', u'id': u'106708999', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Dave Whisker', u'text': u'So give us the figures on electric vehicles. Period."', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507840413000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17964061', u'in_reply_to': u'106700454', u'id': u'106704339', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'xwookey', u'text': u'BQSTART
CCS is, unfortunately, unproven and very expensive
BQEND
We know how to do it. But it is indeed, expensive. It works much better with pure CO2 sources than flue gasses.
Thing is, some CCS is almost certainly necessary in the UK. We cannot get to net zero emissions, which is necessary to arrest, rather than merely slow, global warming without some negative emissions. Cement, agriculture, steel-making and (so far) aviation all have emissions that are very hard to remove and there will be other residual activities. We do not have enough land for BECCS at the scale required, and we do have _lots_ of undersea storage and facilities and suitable pipelines connected to it. We are almost certainly going to have to use those for CCS in the next 30 years, and it would be a good idea to set it up before they get decomissioned.
The tricky part is working out how to pay for it, because it needs a carbon price around £200/tonne to make it commercially attractive, and currently the ETS is 6 euros and the UK carbon floor is £18. But, like the rest of decarbonisation, we don't really have a choice. Prof Stuart Haszeldene's favoured scheme is a simple requirement that CO2 emissions have to have corresponding CO2 disposal certificates, so there will be a market in disposal. That could work. It also adresses the problem quite directly.
This was discussed at the Royal Society last week: https://royalsociety.org/science-events-and-lectures/2017/10/decarbonising-uk-energy/', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507905164000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'it needs a carbon price around \xa3 200/tonne to make it commercially attractive and currently the ets is 6 euros and the uk carbon floor is \xa3 18', u'effect': u'the tricky part is working out how to pay for it'}], u'author_id': u'4307215', u'in_reply_to': u'106708999', u'id': u'106740923', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'RJander', u'text': u'Really? BQSTART
"Assuming that all the signatories reported their credentials accurately, credentialed climate experts on the list are very few." The problem is made worse, Lahsen notes, because critics "added bogus names to illustrate the lack of accountability the petition involved".[20] Approved names on the list included fictional characters from the television show M*A*S*H,[21] the movie Star Wars,[20] Spice Girls group member Geri Halliwell, English naturalist Charles Darwin (d. 1882) and prank names such as "I. C. Ewe".
BQEND
So we don't even know if many of the people are real. But it gets worse... 


BQSTART
Of the 26 we were able to identify in various databases, 11 said they still agreed with the petition —- one was an active climate researcher, two others had relevant expertise, and eight signed based on an informal evaluation. Six said they would not sign the petition today, three did not remember any such petition, one had died, and five did not answer repeated messages.
BQEND
This was back in 2001 and already six out of 26 had changed their minds. That was of the people they were able to identify. Since then fifteen of the warmest years on record have happened and we have just had the three warmest in a row.
 So that's the ones they were able to identify, which is another problem. From wiki again... 
BQSTART
A cursory examination by Todd Shelly of the Hawaii Reporter revealed duplicate entries, single names lacking any initial, and even corporate names. "These examples underscore a major weakness of the list: there is no way to check the authenticity of the names. Names are given, but no identifying information (e.g., institutional affiliation) is provided."
BQEND
Which is why...

BQSTART
George Woodwell and John Holdren, two members of the National Academy of Sciences, responded to Jacoby in the International Herald Tribune, describing the petition as a "farce"
BQEND

description: Council plans to start phasing out polluting vehicles including taxis, cars and buses from city centre area in 2020
headline: p
og_fields.og:description: Council plans to start phasing out polluting vehicles including taxis, cars and buses from city centre area in 2020
og_fields.og:title: Oxford aims for world’s first zero emissions zone with petrol car ban
text:
Petrol and diesels vehicles will be banned from Oxford city centre under plans to bring in what officials believe would be the world’s first zero-emissions zone.
The proposals aim to slash air pollution in the historic university city, which has seen levels of the harmful pollutant nitrogen dioxide rise above legal limits in some areas.
Under the plans being put out for consultation on Monday, the ban would be introduced in phases, starting with preventing non-zero-emitting taxis, cars, light commercial vehicles and buses from using a small number of streets in 2020.
As vehicle technology develops, the zero-emissions zone will extend to cover all non-electric vehicles, including HGVs, in the whole of the city centre by 2035, according to the joint proposals by Oxford city council and Oxfordshire county council.
The introduction of the zero-emissions zone could see levels of nitrogen dioxide, much of which comes from traffic fumes, particularly diesel engines, fall by up to three-quarters by 2035, the councils said.
Data released by the World Health Organisation last year showed that Oxford was one of 11 British cities to breach the safe limits set for toxic particles known as PM10s. It also breached the limit for PM2.5s.
The city has already won £500,000 of government funding to install charging points for electric taxis, and £800,000 to install 100 electric vehicle charging points for residents, but officials say more will be needed to support the zero-emissions zone. Other schemes being considered to support the zone include reduced parking fees for electric vehicles, electric taxi-only ranks, and electric delivery vehicle-only loading areas.
Councillor John Tanner of Oxford city council said: “Toxic and illegal air pollution in the city centre is damaging the health of Oxford’s residents. A step change is urgently needed; the zero emissions zone is that step change.
“All of us who drive or use petrol or diesel vehicles through Oxford are contributing to the city’s toxic air. Everyone needs to do their bit, from national government and local authorities, to businesses and residents, to end this public health emergency.”
Oxfordshire county council councillor Yvonne Constance said: “We want to hear from everyone who uses the city centre, including businesses, bus and taxi firms and local residents ... Pragmatism will be an important part of anything we plan, but we have set the ambition.”
The mayor of London, Sadiq Khan, called last month for the environment department to amend the Clean Air Act to allow for the creation of zero-emission zones.
Other cities that have tried to introduce measures to tackle vehicle emissions include Madrid, whose city council ordered half of the city’s cars to be banned in 2016, and Oslo, where the authorities eventually backtracked on a plan to ban all private cars in the Norwegian capital.

That said, what are the costs of decommissioning batteries?', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508019319000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17327835', u'id': u'106795395', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'oldbat', u'text': u'"The advantage of switching to EVs is that only a quarter of electrical energy is needed to replace oil" Do you have a link to that assertion? I am genuinely interested as a physicist as it seems counter intuitive.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507960867000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'1128992', u'in_reply_to': u'106728312', u'id': u'106766779', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'geofarce', u'text': u'BQSTART
So-called "Carbon Capture and Storage" (CCS) which captures Carbon Dioxide gas is a fraud because the gas will leak eventually.
BQENDThis is something of meaningless statement. The Earth will be consumed by the sun -
eventually.The quesion is, will it be released from storage in a meaningluf time frame. You have to provide a mechanism or evidence that natural hydrocarbon reservoirs that have held fluids (including methane and even CO2 ) for millions of years will suddenly start to leak, rapidly, at the same time, over the next few hundred years.
I also think you are missing the point about CS potential fro both non-power station use (e.g. cement works) and BECCS. It is simple to create the incentive for not leaking from flues, meter and pay for the liquid CO2 entering the reservoirs.', u'recommendation_count': u'6', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507910978000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3003624', u'in_reply_to': u'106733708', u'id': u'106745933', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Mazter', u'text': u'BQSTART
To add to Mazter- in purely energy terms a gallon of diesel is 50 KWh, and petrol is a bit less at 45 KWh.
BQEND
That's interesting, so let's say 40 miles for 45kWh = 0.89 miles / kWh, v's about 4 miles per kWh for EV's.
So 4/0.89 = 4.5 times more, very close to your original statement of needing 1/4 of the energy from leccy. In fact probably very, very close when including distribution losses and battery charging losses.
Cool.
As and when I get a domestic battery to further reduce my import, I should have enough export left over to run an EV for six months of the year.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507987683000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'11150889', u'in_reply_to': u'106774321', u'id': u'106778855', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'sbolter', u'text': u'Hydrogen nuclei are very much smaller than, for example oxygen nuclei, but hydrogen molecules are only slightly smaller than oxygemolecules.Coal gas, used in domestic mains gas until the late 1960s, had a large proportion of hydrogen in it, and that did not have a leakage problem.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508016730000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4178917', u'in_reply_to': u'106681854', u'id': u'106794081', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'xwookey', u'text': u'There is a pile of CO2 emissions that can only be dealt with by negative emissions (cement, agriculture, blast furance coke). Most sensible poeple think that CCS is the best way to deal with that. If you insist that it won't work due to fraud - what's your better plan? We have limited land for BECCS in the UK, although that may well help a bit.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508016583000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'fraud', u'effect': u"that it wo n't work"}], u'author_id': u'4307215', u'in_reply_to': u'106778533', u'id': u'106794013', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'WilliamHBonney', u'text': u'BQSTART
Battery denial is the new science denial
BQENDby the time you've raped the Earth on a massive scale for the minerals necessary to power whole countries by batteries (without generating a single kWh, I might add), you will have created environmental problems equal to the worst excesses of fossil fuels.
Do the job properly, go with nuclear. There's no such thing as a free lunch.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507958593000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15009244', u'in_reply_to': u'106756692', u'id': u'106766315', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'WaitForPete', u'text': u'Damage that they do? The non-existent carnage of mythical birds?Ignore the cost of building the most expensive object on earth (Hinkly-C)?Ignore the CO2 and sulphates and NOx etc. pumped endlessly into the atmosphere?', u'recommendation_count': u'8', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507909744000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'1301439', u'in_reply_to': u'106744274', u'id': u'106744773', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ScottishScientist1', u'text': u'BQSTART
Cement works are responsible for significant CO2 emissions.
BQENDThe link you had on that text is faulty. Will this do?
Wikipedia - Environmental impact of concrete
"The concrete industry is one of two largest producers of carbon dioxide (CO2), creating up to 5% of worldwide man-made emissions of this gas, of which 50% is from the chemical process and 40% from burning fuel.[1] The carbon dioxide CO2 produced for the manufacture of one tonne of structural concrete (using ~14% cement) is estimated at 410 kg/m3 (~180 kg/tonne @ density of 2.3 g/cm3) (reduced to 290 kg/m3 with 30% fly ash replacement of cement)."
Which is a carbon footprint worth paying at least while we are using concrete to build up the infrastructure of a low carbon economy.
BQSTART
BECCS , in theory, can be carbon negative.
BQENDWell why didn't you just type this in the first place?
"BECCS (Bio-Energy with Carbon Capture and Storage) is a technology that integrates biomass systems with geological carbon storage."
Tacking the CCS fraud onto biomass ruins it. With friends like BECCS, biomass doesn't need any enemies.
BQSTART
Biochar is an alternative avoiding gas reservoirs.
BQENDBiochar is climate friendly. Like I said above -
BQSTART
The only kind of Carbon Capture and Storage which should be considered "climate friendly" is when the carbon is captured as carbon or carbonate (solid) but not as carbon dioxide (gas)
BQEND____________
BQSTART
The problem with your conspiracy theory about deliberately leaking CO2 is that it would be picked up from locally stationed monitoring detectors
BQENDLocally stationed monitoring detectors can be corrupted locally too just like the local police and local government can be corrupted in places where they grow the plants to make the drugs that are a mainstay of the local economy.

BQSTART
and independently from the CO2 satellite sensors starting to be deployed to monitor national GHG commitments.
BQEND
Carbon dioxide which is leaking from seabed injection wells or from fractures in the reservoir geology will
dissolve in the seawater making satellite detection a non-starter.
For CCS sites leaking into shallow holomictic seas, the mixing sea water will eventually transport the carbon dioxide from the sea bed to the surface where it will diffuse into the atmosphere in a dispersed way that will be impossible to pinpoint the culprit leaking CCS site.
For CCS sites leaking into deep meromictic seas, the carbon dioxide will accumulate in the cold sea depths seemingly without a problem until when many years in the future, those layers become saturated with carbon dioxide when further leaking and bubbling up of CO2 or some other disturbance may set off a limnic eruption which is a catastrophic release of all the "stored" CO2 at once, with lethal consequences not to mention exposing the folly of CCS even to non-scientists.
BQSTART
It also presupposes that all those involved in CCS are out to pull a fast one and are homicidally disingenuous.
BQENDNo it doesn't. CCS workers are the most exploited victims of the CCS fraud.

BQSTART
It should not be difficult for you to face-to-face confront the Scottish engineers involved at Edinburgh directly.
BQENDThat's easy for you to say.

BQSTART
But then it is always easier to pass broad brush accusations about others integrity from behind a keyboard.
BQENDIt is CCS which lacks scientific integrity and my ability to expose the CCS fraud from behind a keyboard is the beauty of the internet which will save our planet.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507986767000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14857627', u'in_reply_to': u'106773664', u'id': u'106778533', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'AMeyer', u'text': u'Here are the accumulated projections of future carbon consumption from BEIS.
As can easily be seen, these use up the UK's share of what globally available under the terms of the Paris Agreement, long before BEIS projected path-integral (accumulated emissions) are projected to reach zero emissions.
BEIS state this as *globally exemplary* against the temperature target (well below 2° C) agreed in Paris. Against this quite false claim, these projections are once again a recipe for doing too little too late.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508015377000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2417966', u'in_reply_to': u'106780668', u'id': u'106793350', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'TonyW', u'text': u'It can't all be utilised at no cost. Some can't at any cost.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507954063000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2414407', u'in_reply_to': u'106688923', u'id': u'106765493', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Jambazi', u'text': u'Ignore the damage the wind turbines do, ignore the cost of building, them ignore the limited life, ignore the use of rare metals or the damage done mining, ignore those who know know better and think wind will provide everything, truth is wind is just as bad in the belly.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507909213000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16587834', u'in_reply_to': u'106742796', u'id': u'106744274', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ID5673601', u'text': u'One problem it seems to me is that the world's oil reserves will eventually be pumped out, whether that takes 10 years or 100 - and all that carbon will end up in the atmosphere regardless of the amount of renewable energy we generate in the mean time.It's a similar thing when motor vehicles were invented people thought they would stop using horses, but actually the price of horses went down so much that they were still competitive for many years. The same thing could happen with oil, so carbon capture may be the way ahead.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507986351000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2755499', u'id': u'106778396', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'sbolter', u'text': u'There are safty issues with all energy sources. Even including all the accidents with old plant from the early days of nuclear energy, nuclear is safer than coal, oil, gas, hydroelectric, and even solar. The deree of risk is close to that of capturing wind energy.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508014405000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4178917', u'in_reply_to': u'106679251', u'id': u'106792796', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'TonyW', u'text': u'Well, of course, if you make up your own definition of safety or only focus on that, then you can claim any form of energy is the safest. Meanwhile tens of thousands of people had their lives devastated by nuclear accidents.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507953986000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2414407', u'in_reply_to': u'106688162', u'id': u'106765481', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'WaitForPete', u'text': u'Here we go again.The wind is always blowing somewhere, especially up hills and out at sea.We have already built a lot of Gas fired power stations which can be used as backup, they just don't need to run at high power all the time any more.The importance of having a mix of renewables.Current power storage research is already providing significant leads and installed infrastructure.', u'recommendation_count': u'7', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507907528000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'1301439', u'in_reply_to': u'106732050', u'id': u'106742796', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'AMeyer', u'text': u'Why do think there is anything 'natural' about continuing to burn fossil fuels?', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507984487000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2417966', u'in_reply_to': u'106772670', u'id': u'106777800', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'AMeyer', u'text': u'"Full-term global path-integral"', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508014160000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2417966', u'in_reply_to': u'106780668', u'id': u'106792662', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'TonyW', u'text': u'Indeed. And as the number of reactors goes up, so does the likelihood of a major accident.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507953776000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2414407', u'in_reply_to': u'106685659', u'id': u'106765458', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'TonyW', u'text': u'But it's not sustainable. Not many forms of energy are, mind you. At some stage, humans will have to come to terms with that.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507953499000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2414407', u'in_reply_to': u'106679153', u'id': u'106765429', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'WaitForPete', u'text': u'Google search term study meat production c02is a happy hunting ground. Enjoyhttp://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0308521X10000387', u'recommendation_count': u'6', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507907294000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'1301439', u'in_reply_to': u'106742088', u'id': u'106742602', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'AMeyer', u'text': u'The term 'cumulative emissions' is fundamentally significant in terms of UNFCCC-Compliance. 
The global goal of UNFCCC is the stabilisation of the 'atmospheric concentrations' of CO2 and these are a function of 'cumulative emissions' full-term - i.e. since 1750 - i.e. for as long as we emit, we are *adding* to the total of emissions and not *subtracting* from it. 
The UK started burning fossil fuels and emitting CO2 and adding this cumulatively to the global atmosphere. Here is a record of that for the UK against the UK Climate Act.
The full analysis is hereSo when BEIS adopts this terminology of UK 'cumulative emissions' *falling* for five successive five-year UK carbon budgets, it is - quite deliberately - misleading. 
Given the rate of emissions deceleration it is certainly not *global example* (as claimed in the report and in the UK Climate Act on which it based) that will result in UNFCCC-Compliance.
This is the heart of the whole dilemma - we can only now try and stop things getting too much worse by setting a good global example and cutting emissions very rapidly.
For these reasons, the comments from BEIS to the media at the launch of this report state that the UK has cut emissions 42% since 1990 are false', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507984048000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'that', u'effect': u'unfccc compliance'}], u'author_id': u'2417966', u'in_reply_to': u'106767784', u'id': u'106777643', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'jiandhoh', u'text': u'"The grownups have finally won and everyone in the UK, from those in cold homes to those on polluted streets and in flooded towns, will benefit."
It's certainly a good thing to reduce pollution, but let's not pretend that "grownups" have gone through the rigors of a scientific analysis of climate change predictions. They haven't, so they haven't "won" anything. Most people have simply swallowed propaganda or just tuned out, to avoid having to think about complicated things. It has always been so. And, as always, the real winners here are those who profit from the ignorance of the public. Good on them, I guess.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508009908000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16871942', u'id': u'106790364', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Dave Whisker', u'text': u'"We need to forget about growth and figure out what real happiness is."
What a great post. This sentiment should be made compulsory in schools in the UK and the USA.
Let's get them young'uns on the road to happiness before they get too old to become cognisant.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507942507000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17964061', u'in_reply_to': u'106762404', u'id': u'106763622', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'meltyman', u'text': u'"But there is no mention of the reduction in meat consumption deemed essential in beating global warming by scientists" I would like to see peer-reviewed studies that support this view. Sure it would be helpful but it's very far from being the root cause of our climate problem.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507906637000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3993289', u'id': u'106742088', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ComfortablyPlumb', u'text': u'Well said.I would extend this to fraccing sites - the protesting against of which does nothing to abate demand for gas by a single therm.All a ban means is that we would be forced to continue import gas from Qatar, Algeria, and now fracced gas from the US.. all at an imported (LNG) 70-90gramsCO₂/kwh higher emissions than domestic fracced gas.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507984035000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14842422', u'in_reply_to': u'106771236', u'id': u'106777638', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'malcolm_tent', u'text': u'This comment was removed by a moderator because it didn't abide by our

⡷ The "legacy" of Germany's decision to phase out their affordable clean, safe, low carbon nuclear is that they've started six new coal power stations to help keep the lights burning 24/7 and consequently no carbon reduction (per MWh) over 16 years.
⡷ There are many active commercial CCS operations running.
⡷ There are zero wave power operations running.
It's good that you accept the need to decarbonise, but may I suggest that you check your facts before deciding which (if any!!) carbon reduction technologies should be added to your list of prejudices.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507983553000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14842422', u'in_reply_to': u'106776131', u'id': u'106777469', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'malcolm_tent', u'text': u'BQSTART

BQEND

description: Government’s clean growth strategy unequivocally states that tackling climate change and a prosperous economy go hand in hand
headline: p
og_fields.og:description: Government’s clean growth strategy unequivocally states that tackling climate change and a prosperous economy go hand in hand
og_fields.og:title: UK climate change masterplan – the grownups have finally won
text:
The grownups have finally won and everyone in the UK, from those in cold homes to those on polluted streets and in flooded towns, will benefit. The most important aspect of the UK government’s new clean growth strategy is its unequivocal statement that tackling climate change and a prosperous economy are one and the same thing.
This has been clear to many for some time, including Philip Hammond, if not his predecessor George Osborne. There is no long-term, high-carbon economic strategy because the impacts of unchecked climate change destroy economies, as Lord Nicholas Stern puts it.
But the Conservative party has long been swinging between the green dream and fossil-fuelled fantasies. David Cameron went from pledging the “greenest government ever” to dismissing the “green crap” in three years. Recent years have seen one green policy shredded after another, destroying confidence among the businesses we need to deliver a low-carbon economy.
The new strategy published on Thursday signals a new, if belated, beginning. It is the beginning of the end of the fossil fuel age: it is highly notable that the government plan omits any mention of fracking, having previously been its cheerleader.
The government had to produce this plan under its own climate laws to explain how it will get on track to meet the nation’s legally binding carbon targets in 2030 and beyond. But ministers have rightly made a virtue of the plan’s necessity.
The proposals themselves are ambitious but lack concrete suggestions in many areas. However, ambition always precedes action and there are plenty of groups, not least the government’s official advisers, the Committee on Climate Change, who will hold ministers to account.
If the government’s efforts to cut emissions from buildings have been slow, it is now taking seriously the need to address energy efficiency. Energy that isn’t used – negawatts – are by far the cheapest way to cut both emissions and energy bills. But as the vast failure of the green deal showed, efficiency is hard to make happen and it is here where firm plans are most urgently needed.
Along with heating, transport also needs urgent action – emissions here have been rising. There is plenty in the new plan to harness the surging market for electric vehicles, though little of it is new. Ministers have also once again failed to explain how expanding aviation with Heathrow’s third runway fits with its climate change plan.
Electric cars will need clean power and the UK’s electricity grid is already greening fast – coal power has fallen from 40% to 2% in the last five years. The new plan rightly builds on the UK’s success in dramatically driving down the cost of offshore wind power, yet it all but ignores an even cheaper source – onshore wind. It seems that even the conviction that the green economy is the UK’s future is not enough to face down the rural Tory-voting minority who continue to tilt at windmills. Solar power also seems destined to suffer the same fate.
Despite looking these gift horses in the mouth, and ignoring tidal power, the plan promises yet more cash for those with their snouts in the nuclear trough. The hyper-expensive Hinkley Point farce has not dulled the appetite for more new nuclear power and it intends to plough by far the biggest sum of its innovation funding into the one energy technology where costs are always rising.
But the biggest worry is the very limited support for carbon capture and storage, the technology that takes emissions from fossil fuels and buries them under the ground. CCS is seen as absolutely vital by the Committee on Climate Change, the National Audit Office and the UN’s climate science panel and the UK’s emptying North Sea fields are perfectly placed carbon reservoirs. But CCS gets only about a quarter of the investment of nuclear and just a tenth of the £1bn promised in the plan so abruptly canned by Osborne in 2015.
Trees are natural carbon stores and the new plan pledges to “establish a new network of forests in England, including new woodland on farmland”, which offers a tantalising glimpse of the radical change to farm subsidies that may follow Brexit. But there is no mention of the reduction in meat consumption deemed essential in beating global warming by scientists.
However, while many of the details are missing, the clean growth strategy marks an important and vital step forward for the UK. As the prime minister Theresa May says in the plan’s foreword: “Clean growth is not an option, but a duty we owe to the next generation. Success in this mission will improve our quality of life and increase our economic prosperity.” The strategy is now crystal clear – it is time to deliver.

BQSTART
"UK action on climate change is based on the 2008 Climate Change Act. This is the basis of their statement about Brexit having no effect. But the international treaty unlike the CCA would have had actual legal force prior to 2050.

https://www.hunker.com/12003502/which-rocks-absorb-heat-the-best
"Natural stones with high energy density and excellent thermal conductivity are soapstone (by far the best) and marble. These are perhaps the best stones for absorbing large amounts of heat quickly. Some types of granite can be good heat conductors, but are not great at storing heat."
I wanted to achieve a mini version of my friend's inertia-mass stove by "walling-in " my wood-burner (it is a model designed to be enclosed, so not as hideous as it sounds ) and did some research on different types of stone to see which would be most appropriate. I found out (to my surprise ) that there was not a huge difference between types of stone, but was astonished to read that water has (from memory ) something like four times the storage capacity of the "best" stone.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507894375000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'18075100', u'in_reply_to': u'106705016', u'id': u'106732090', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Matthew2012', u'text': u'BQSTART
I thought we were talking about whether Brexit meant suddenly the UK loses any commitment under Paris.
BQEND
We are debating both points. But what I think you fail to realise is that the UK's INDC requires zero extra emission reductions.
Your secondary sources don't state otherwise and have inaccuracies to boot. We started to talk about Paris in detail BTL from the draft text was first available prior to its press release.
If you look at what the UK signed up to it was to agree to the EU terms. Which are 40% below the 1990 level. The UK is already claiming to have done this.
Therefore, unless you are predicting an increase in emissions then it has no legal force. Our contribution to a Green fund remain but this too was rebranded,
BQSTART
We haven't submitted an INDC. We didn't need to.
BQEND
Yes we did, it falls under the EUs heading. But that is our submitted INDC without one we could not have been a signatory. We could have added our own voluntary INDC which was in excess of the separate EU INDC but didn't.
I fully understand everything to do with the INDCs. 
The CCC are a very mixed bag when it comes to information over climate change. For starters, their budgets have no legal force but they like to pretend that the UK government will meet them.
If you want the full equivocation to the Paris agreement by the CCC it is given here:
https://www.theccc.org.uk/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/UK-climate-action-following-the-Paris-Agreement-Committee-on-Climate-Change-October-2016.pdf
They might use things that are suggested elsewhere but it doesn't make it right. For example they mistakenly work on the basis that BECCS is carbon negative, it is not. 
The key sentence is buried in the introduction which states:
"We currently have no scenario for how the UK can achieve net zero emissions"
The question is: "why not?"
BTW his is including their magic -ve CO2 despite being sources ideas.
They speculate for about 10 pages about what the implied section about 1.5C would mean which never actually was pledged meaningfully but fair enough. But they state that they don't know what that means.
At the end of chapter 1: they finally state what I said which is that the only way the UK is signed up is to the aforementioned 40% by 1990. They assume that their budget will be enough to exceed this so no change is given.
There is no mention of the UK's consumption index figures either.
And while we will meet the INDCs the report states:
"The Committee’s assessment in our 2016 Progress Report was that current policies would at best deliver around half of the emissions reductions required to 2030, with no current policies to address the other half. "
The CCC don't support what you are saying but spend a lot of discussion pretending that not only failing on the current pledges that the government might seriously try for 1.5C.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507892470000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'10230223', u'in_reply_to': u'106722952', u'id': u'106730552', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'derstar', u'text': u'Who are you to judge me?

When we enquired about redoing all our huge sash windows with double glazed ones, the lady at the council had a fit of the vapours. We have no wall cavities--built in 1903, have ourselves insulated the roof, every gap in the house is stuffed with various forms of draught exclusion--any other suggestions? In our late 70s--we heat 2 rooms only
BQEND
I live in a listed property in a conservation area, with single-glazed windows, brick walls almost two feet thick and modern, gas-fired central heating. I used only to heat rooms twice a day - the classic set up - and nearly expired from cold, not to mention wake up each morning to windows and walls covered with condensation. One day I could not take it any more so did some research on the internet about how to fix condensation and I tried a new course.
These days I have the central heating on all day long, extremely low. Several windows are opened a couple of millimetres to make a tiny air vent. The result has been transformative: the house stays at a steady 20-21 degrees; I get no condensation to speak of any more; and I warm. Bizarrely my heating bills have plummeted. I'm clearly using far less gas than in the days when the heating was on high twice a day. This new draught-sealing advice from the govt, in my view, is as disaster-in-waiting for old houses. They must, must breathe. Listed houses represent only about 1% of housing stock in this country anyway. Their effect on climate change compared to cars/industry/aviation industry is minute.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507887947000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15685818', u'in_reply_to': u'106678220', u'id': u'106726429', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'DecemberElle', u'text': u'If you had put the remarks in your second comment into your first comment, that would have been useful. Assuming upgrades at every opportunity it comes out to about 550-570ppm', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507882846000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'10230223', u'in_reply_to': u'106708252', u'id': u'106721727', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'RobinS77', u'text': u'Ahh, its not like the good old days anymore!', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507882808000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2019694', u'in_reply_to': u'106672486', u'id': u'106721702', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'RobinS77', u'text': u'In an ideal world we would all have heat pumps but there are lots of reasons why this doesn't happen in practice - mainly the high cost but also they rely on decent building fabric performance (which often isn't a given) and installation hurdles that make them a challenging proposition in many existing properties (space / site disruption in case of GSHP and planning / noise considerations for ASHP).
In the absence of strong legislative and financial support for heat pumps then an efficient condensing gas boiler is going to be the least-worst affordable option for most people for some time to come.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507882628000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2019694', u'in_reply_to': u'106707670', u'id': u'106721543', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'stilldpack', u'text': u'Well put, reducing energy use by savings in efficiency and waste such as good insulation and draft proofing is good (even if the motive is profit which seems likely. Windows are much worse than walls in general, but a decent triple-glazed window (U=0.9) is twice as good as a solid brick wall (U=2) and better than an unfilled cavity (U=1.5). Only once the wall has some actual insulation in it does it beat the windows. And a decent modern wall should be U=0.2 or better.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507832243000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4307215', u'in_reply_to': u'106672494', u'id': u'106698357', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JulesBywaterLees', u'text': u'I use two 40 watt fans, very quiet, the fridge makes more noise, it not like an extractor fan, it low volume - you could have it on a timer to coincide with heating the house and for periods when you occupy it.outside of domestics homes in the UK they are common- there is no debate, they save energy, keep the air fresh and there is no dust/dusting.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507856950000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4738374', u'in_reply_to': u'106706852', u'id': u'106712163', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'misterbaxter', u'text': u'Yes, you're probably right there...', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507832022000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3995969', u'in_reply_to': u'106690653', u'id': u'106698146', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JulesBywaterLees', u'text': u'I'm unable to assess a building remotely, but if you have a lot water around your foundations and means for the walls to wick moisture, i.e. the top of the wall is exposed then it is possible for your wall to get water logged [although it means something is really wrong with your build.Rising damp is very rare. your house sounds like a pile of problems.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507856572000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4738374', u'in_reply_to': u'106705634', u'id': u'106712061', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Mick James', u'text': u'BQSTART

In Germany, where we tend to have newer homes and thus well insulated, the procedure is to open windows wide every day in winter for a few minutes to exchange the air. Do not know if that might also apply to your sort.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507831522000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3257583', u'in_reply_to': u'106687046', u'id': u'106697747', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Landlord52', u'text': u'Who are you to judge me? 
"if people didn't have to pay their landlords such exorbitant rent "
I have rented out my property and in seven years have not increased the rent for my tenant. Do you think it is not possible to be a landlord and ethical?. 
The Green party are vindictive lefties. Osborne stole a policy idea from the Greens manifesto. 
Taxes for landlords would go up (but not corporate landlords and hedge funds). Some landlords (depending on their tax position) could end up paying £1.20 in tax for every £1 in rent. Is there any business which gets taxes at 120%?. 
So I have a choice, either to up the rent to cover the tax or sell up. Either way my tenants looses.
Their policy idea has an impact on good landlord who pay their taxes, not tax cheats!.
If the Greens cared so much for the environment, why not tax breaks for landlord like me who charge below market rents? or tax breaks for landlords who fit solar panels?? I give my money to Friends of the Earth, WWF and other groups who are doing more for the environment then the Green Party. 
As for building councils houses, look at the junk they built in the 1960s. New  Labour under Blair/Brown gave Councils are further £40bn to renovate council housing and bring up to date. It is n't just about 'building' homes, but paying council staff to look after them and then every few years giving money for major renovations. Look at the mess over 120 councils used the same cladding as in Greenfell. Money wasted by the state and councils.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507854724000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'10184317', u'in_reply_to': u'106698112', u'id': u'106711559', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'R Anon', u'text': u'18 degrees is plenty to many people turning the thermostat up to 21 or higher.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507831489000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17206208', u'in_reply_to': u'106692346', u'id': u'106697720', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ozcitizen', u'text': u'BQSTART
In turn this has contributed greatly to increase emission.
BQEND High energy prices do not lead to increased emissions. If the energy source is fossil fuel it will lead to emissions, and low prices will encourage more use, and therefore higher emissions. Look at the US.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507851226000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'bqend high energy prices', u'effect': u'increased emissions'}, {u'cause': u'it', u'effect': u'emissions'}], u'author_id': u'14126773', u'in_reply_to': u'106703478', u'id': u'106710415', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'WilliamHBonney', u'text': u'Fearmongering

Are you sure? Normally people quote the 20% by 2020 target. On the Paris timeframe this becomes 27% by 2030. Put the FITS back up to the levels they were before that idiot George (whats in my freezer) Osborne lowered them, that will allow all those many small Solar Panel installer buisnesses that closed to reopen again, it will mean more people will have Solar panels installed because they will now be viable and save them money, and the government will go along way towards meeting their carbon targets.Unfortunately, the Torys have buddies in the Energy companys which don't want this to happen.That coupled with their old fashioned ideaology and we've got no chance.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507825075000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'they will now be viable and save them money', u'effect': u'solar panels installed'}], u'author_id': u'4187731', u'id': u'106692054', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'R Anon', u'text': u'You really never ever think about anything but your "property" & "profit" do you?
Is there a soul in that vessel you call a brain?', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507831349000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17206208', u'in_reply_to': u'106694345', u'id': u'106697608', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'xwookey', u'text': u'BQSTART

BQEND
Only if you don't care at all about emissions, and the urgent need to decarbonise. A new boilder is probably a bad idea about now anyway and a heat pump will be lower carbon now that our grid is greatly improved. Burning fossil gas won't be allowed for more than about another 20 years, which is the lifetime of a boiler.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507845379000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4307215', u'in_reply_to': u'106691060', u'id': u'106707670', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'grumpyoldman0147', u'text': u'In my area, whilst there are many semis, there are also a lot of detached bungalows; one wall borders their drive, the other forms the border with an adjoining property; therefore, although three walls are clearly on their land, the wrapping of the fourth would impinge upon the neighbour's drive. Moreover, they were built for Austin 7s and push-bikes, so they are quite narrow and can just about accommodate a modern car (with wing mirrors tucked-in)
So wrapping this fourth side isn't really an option, as I see it, unless it is done inside', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507824639000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12669811', u'in_reply_to': u'106667473', u'id': u'106691636', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'seedysolipsist', u'text': u'This conversation reminded me of a SPAB report I read a while back on u values for stone walls. Some may be unaware that the energy efficiency ratings of houses are based on standard formulae rather than measurement. These include assumptions about heat loss through walls - the u value. The lower the u value the better. 
SPAB found that when actually measured stone walls performed much better than the formulae predicted. Ie instead of being in the 2 - 3 range they were 1 - 2. Whilst not good by current standards the results suggest that as well as being potentially damaging to listed buildings wall insulation may not even be cost effective. 
Clearly it’s a different matter where the shell of a building is being restored and no features are lost by insulating.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507831021000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15802413', u'in_reply_to': u'106693331', u'id': u'106697379', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'xwookey', u'text': u'BQSTART
New homes in Scotland anyway are subject to air leakage tests
BQEND
And in the UK, but the required standared is 5 ACH, which is pathetic. Same as the rest ofd the building regs. No-one should be building houses significantly worse than passivehous by now (which is 30 yr old science and practice). It's easy to retrofit to 3ACH. New houses should be 0.5ACH.
None of this particularly difficult and neither it is expensive any more (it used to be). Over the building lifetime it is _much_ cheaper. People who build their own houses build much better houses than developers who don't care how much it costs to run.
Irish building regs are nearly twice as strict as the UK ones.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507845172000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4307215', u'in_reply_to': u'106670739', u'id': u'106707551', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'konallis', u'text': u'If the government promotes energy efficiency enough, then hopefully the regs will be revised to enable listed buildings to be retro-fitted more easily. Double glazing would be a good first step.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507824285000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13835343', u'in_reply_to': u'106678921', u'id': u'106691273', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'xwookey', u'text': u'BQSTART
no pollution from EVs, is there?
BQEND
Of course there is, as you well know. How much depends on the grid intensity in your country, or whatever else is used to charge. Plus tyre particulates. EVs are less polluting than ICEs in countries with clean grids like France and Norway, somewhat better in the UK, much the same in Germany, and worse in India or Poland.
That will improve over time, but the space, danger and congestion issues remain unchanged. Motor vehicles in urban areas, and especially their overuse, are/is a problem however they are powered. We know you hate bicycles, but lots of other people understand that they are a really important part of a decarbonised transport system due to huge health, safety, cost, noise, sociability, convenience and space advantages.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507830744000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'huge health advantages', u'effect': u'a really important part of a decarbonised transport system'}], u'author_id': u'4307215', u'in_reply_to': u'106683134', u'id': u'106697130', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ContactSection', u'text': u'Anthropocene
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anthropocene', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507844443000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16608783', u'in_reply_to': u'106675591', u'id': u'106707137', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'userles', u'text': u'One did not hear about this wind of change. Does anybody want to buy any dachshunds going cheap. I am the one who is Barking', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507824257000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13465775', u'id': u'106691237', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'xwookey', u'text': u'BQSTART
houses need to breathe to prevent damp
BQEND
Building physics is a lot more complex than that simplistic statement. Houses need to be designed and upgraded in such a way that air, heat and moisture movement are all correctly managed. They all affect each other, so you have to consider all three together.
The best way to treat most houses is external insulation and internal airtightness, with vapour permeability preferably everywhere, but otherwise impermeable layers on the inside. It's very easy to get this right. Internal insulation is more complicated because it leaves the structure cold, so humidity levels in said structure have to be lower.
The idea that the only way to make houses that work is the 19th century 'very draughty, no insulation' scheme is nonsense.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507830310000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'it leaves the structure cold', u'effect': u'internal insulation is more complicated so humidity levels in said structure have to be lower'}], u'author_id': u'4307215', u'in_reply_to': u'106672940', u'id': u'106696769', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'RonanPt', u'text': u'Hard to judge whether MVHR is, like EVs, selling a problem (extra electricity consumption) as a solution (saving electricity). I agree that there may be a health advantage if units are fitted with filters, especially now we have to mind polyester fibres along with other factors. Two doubts. I make 100W by 24 hours 2400 watt hours, and the motor will be audible in dead of night.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507844011000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3296387', u'in_reply_to': u'106689667', u'id': u'106706852', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Langside', u'text': u'Best of luck. I've tried many times. The Guardianistas will get you in the end.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507824112000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17103185', u'in_reply_to': u'106676624', u'id': u'106691102', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Landlord52', u'text': u'The Green Party are a useless political party. They have done nothing to move the Green agenda forward. They don't appeal to the working classes, even though their policies closer to the hard left. They also alienate people on the right, because they think a conservative voter does not have concerns about the environment, even though it is the well off who can afford to buy organic and fair trade produce. 
The Greens only represent the hipsters in Brighton.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507830157000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'they think a conservative voter does not have concerns about the environment even though it is the well off who can afford to buy organic and fair trade produce', u'effect': u'they also alienate people on the right'}], u'author_id': u'10184317', u'in_reply_to': u'106692240', u'id': u'106696650', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Harris Bodango', u'text': u'Is there nothing constructive to say about a reasoned analysis of house design? The UK is a damp climate and we need to aerate our properties to minimise the damage to them as well as reduce health risks through cleaner air.
Or is that too much to take on board when you just want to snipe?', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507842595000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17043301', u'in_reply_to': u'106697608', u'id': u'106705917', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, ...]
description: Ministers publish long-delayed blueprint for hitting target of cutting emissions by 57% in next 15 years
headline: D
og_fields.og:description: Ministers publish long-delayed blueprint for hitting target of cutting emissions by 57% in next 15 years
og_fields.og:title: Draughty homes targeted in UK climate change masterplan
text:
Millions of draughty homes in England and Wales will be insulated and overhauled by 2035 to save families as much as £300 a year on their energy bills, under the government’s climate change plans.
The long-delayed blueprint for how the UK will hit its binding target of cutting emissions by 57% by 2032 includes about 50 policies supporting everything from low-carbon power and energy savings to electric vehicles and keeping food waste out of landfill.
Big winners in the 164-page Clean Growth Strategy include offshore windfarm developers, which will be guaranteed a further £550m of subsidies. Experts believe that could more than double the UK’s existing offshore wind capacity. 
Energy efficiency for businesses and householders is at the heart of the plan, which the government was required to publish under the Climate Change Act.
There is an aspiration that all houses will be brought up to the minimum of energy band C by 2035, but how that will be achieved is not spelled out. Existing schemes to improve insulation will be extended until 2028.
New nuclear power stations are encouraged, but they will only go ahead if developers can do so at competitive prices. Solar power was given tentative support, while onshore windfarms won partial backing.
The business secretary, Greg Clark, compared the changes under way in energy today to the big changes wrought by the UK’s first coal power station in 1882.
“This government has put clean growth at the heart of its industrial strategy to increase productivity, boost people’s earning power and ensure Britain continues to lead the world in efforts to tackle climate change,” he said, launching the plan at the Olympic Park in east London. 
Green campaigners, industry groups and businesses mostly welcomed the plan but said it needed more ambition and lacked detail in some areas.
Robert Gross, the director of the Centre for Energy Policy and Technology at Imperial College London, said the politics of the strategy were key, and showed the greener wings of the Tory party had won out.
“In 2015 the government started hacking and slashing at all manner of green policies. This has stopped, and that’s very welcome,” he said.
Richard Black, the director of the Energy and Climate Intelligence Unit thinktank, echoed that view. He said the strategy showed a “sea change” in “top-line thinking about the low carbon economy”, with Theresa May’s government seeing it as an opportunity rather than a cost as it was viewed under David Cameron.
Claire Perry, the climate minister, said May’s foreword to the plan was important and showed how seriously the government was taking it.
Asked if the strategy showed green-minded Tories were winning out after a slew of climate programmes were axed by the Conservatives in 2015, she said: “This isn’t about factions winning, it’s about getting on with capturing the opportunity [for business].”
She told the Guardian: “This is doubling down on the green ambition, actually saying we see the economic benefit from doing this.”
The minister said there would be a new “triple test” for whether the government backed clean technologies. They would have to maximise the amount emissions come down; show they can become cheaper in the future; and be an area in which the UK could lead the world.
She said a proposed £1.3bn tidal lagoon at Swansea – which an independent government review backed in January but on which government has yet to signal its view – would have to pass that test.
New policies included a green light for onshore windfarms on remote Scottish islands being allowed to compete for subsidies. The move was welcomed by Orkney and companies including SSE, which plans a windfarm on Shetland, jointly owned with the community.
There is also £100m of funding for research on carbon capture and storage (CCS). However, that is a fraction of the £1bn government competition on the technology that was cut two years ago.
The plan is also scant on any detail of how the UK will cut emissions from heating, talking instead of simply exploring the best options. Low-carbon alternatives to gas include electrification via heat pumps, or using greener gases such as hydrogen.
Many of the ideas in the strategy have already been announced, such as phasing out petrol and diesel cars by 2040 and £246m to develop batteries for cars and energy systems.
Despite the wide-ranging policies, the strategy concedes that the UK is still not on track to meet its legally binding carbon targets for the late 2020s and early 2030s. The government noted it had ‘flexibilities’ on meeting the targets under the Climate Change Act, but might not need to use them.
The Committee on Climate Change, the UK’s statutory climate advisers, welcomed the strategy but warned ministers against using the law’s flexibilities in meeting its carbon targets. “This should not be the plan,” said Lord Deben, the group’s chairman. The authority will pass its verdict in January after analysing the plan.
Campaign group ClientEarth said it was weighing its options, given the legal requirement for government to close the gap.
Jonathan Church, a lawyer at the group, said: “The UK government is still in breach of the Climate Change Act. The UK is on course to miss its 2023-27 emissions reductions targets by 116MtCO2e – equivalent to more than the Philippines’ emissions in a whole year – and the clean growth strategy does not fix this.”
The Green party said the strategy was a missed opportunity. Caroline Lucas, the party’s co-leader, said: “Government has blown this enormous opportunity to put Britain on track to meet its climate target.”
Other observers, including the London School of Economics, said the broad thrust of the strategy was good, but it was too vague. The union Prospect said there were “still too many unanswered questions”.

Qatar's the latest.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1507954298000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12540701', u'id': u'106765525', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Nijinzky', u'text': u'HERE’S WHY ELECTRIC CARS ARE USELESSRange, on the flat, just over 200 miles in summer. In winter lucky to get 100 miles. And in winter – no heating!
To suggest, as some ignorant people have, that electric cars ‘emit no CO2’ is absurd because the power stations that charge them do. To charge an electric vehicle (such as a Tesla), just once, requires the burning of 43 kilogram of coal.
A petrol car will require about 20 kilogram of petrol for the same distance. It follows that the electric car is emitting more than twice the CO2 of a petrol car.
Here are the sums:
Drax uses about 0.31 kilogram of coal per KWhr generated.
1 A Tesla battery is rated at 70 KWhr and fast charging is only 50% efficient. It will need 140 KWhr of electricity for a single charge; this works out as about 43 kilogram (0.31 × 140) of coal for a full charge.
The cost of electricity for the range available in a Tesla—200 miles in summer; 100 miles in winter—works out at £22.50. The petrol for 200 miles costs very little more and most of that cost is tax (currently about 60%) – about £28. In winter, for 100 miles, the petrol costs just £15.
During trials between 1927-30 of British steam locomotives a typical result was that, for a 500 ton express train, coal was consumed at the rate of 20 kg per mile.
2 Over 200 miles therefore 4000 kg was consumed. Scaling down to a 2 ton car: 4000÷250=16 kg coal. Even allowing for economies of scale, compare this to the 43 kg required by a Tesla.
Further issues
Battery cycling – the deterioration of the capacity of a lithium battery with charging – must be allowed for, costing about £3 per cycle.3 Fire: even small lithium batteries are liable to catch ﬁre or even explode, releasing deadly toxins such as COS, HF, CO.
4 The huge dangers for occupants in event of an accident are obvious. Firehoses would only exacerbate the problem, causing electrocution of victims.
5 This has already happened: www.mirror.co.uk/news/world-news/richard-hammond-switzerland-car-crash-10599134
WeightThe Tesla battery weighs 800kg—that’s nearly a ton—equivalent to 10 people. Battery/petrol equivalent weight ratio—in summer 50:1, in winter 100:1.
Further hazards
In winter, in severe conditions, electric cars become death traps. Firstly, the battery power halves every ten degree drop in temperature, so you are likely to get stuck in a snowstorm. Then there will be no heating in the car and a blizzard outside. You will freeze to death inside and, outside the car, you may die seeking help. This would not happen in a petrol car. A petrol car’s engine remains at full power down to the last drop of petrol and has plenty of heating. The electric car loses power almost immediately as the battery drains—and has no heating.
As most of the numpties, who think electric cars are viable, live in towns the above point doubtless passes them by, but the huge potential for trafﬁc clogging due to ‘dead’ electric vehicles has not been considered
6 , nor has the issue of time to recharge. Currently an average petrol car takes about 5 minutes to ﬁll up with petrol, pay and depart. If an electric car takes a minimum of 75 minutes to recharge, the queues are going to be astronomical and the time wasted also astronomical.
The BBC tried to take an electric car from London to Edinburgh. It took more than three days, slower than a stagecoach. Strangely, people sometimes need to get to places quickly.
In case anyone thinks that there is a miracle battery just over the horizon, I can absolutely assure him or her that there is not. Battery technology is mature, and, to quote Mr David Hume, “Miracles do not happen.” (at least in technology). Just where is all this power to come from anyway? The Climate Change Act requires that by 2045 all gas heating be replaced by electric heating and all cars be electric.
Besides the stupidity of turning huge amounts of electricity back into heat, clearly no one in government has done the maths. The results are horrendous!
Electric HGVs anyone?
Drax power station in Yorkshire 4 gigaWatt = 4,000,000 kiloWatt
17 million gas using households @ 30kW (to replace gas boiler) 17 million chargers for electric cars @ 8kW 38kW

description: Australia Institute wants free access to bus lanes after electric cars accounted for just 0.1% of new car sales in 2015
headline: p
og_fields.og:description: Australia Institute wants free access to bus lanes after electric cars accounted for just 0.1% of new car sales in 2015
og_fields.og:title: Australia lagging on electric cars and tax breaks needed to drive demand – report
text:
Tax breaks and free access to bus lanes should be used to help reverse Australia’s poor uptake of electric vehicles, a new report has said.
Australians remain deeply reluctant to buy electric cars, which accounted for just 0.1% of new car sales in 2015. Australia is increasingly falling behind other countries, particularly in Europe, where sales of electric cars represented 1.2% of new European Union car sales in the same year.
In Norway, electric vehicles made up 22.8% of new car sales, thanks largely to a suite of financial and policy incentives. Electric cars are allowed to use Norwegian bus and taxi lanes, pay no parking fees and are exempt from road tolls, VAT and registration charges.
 Drivers in France are given a rebate for low-emitting cars and charged an extra fee for high-polluting vehicles. France’s scheme reduced average carbon emissions for a new car from 149 grams per kilometre in 2007, a year before the policy was introduced, to 114g in 2014. In the same year the average for a new car in Australia was 188g.
The Australia Institute, in a report released on Friday, warned Australia risked becoming a “laggard” on electric cars by international standards. Australia offered “disappointingly few” incentives for buyers of electric cars, the report said, and lacked proper battery charging infrastructure. 
Trials of electric vehicles in state government fleets were too small to produce meaningful results, the report said. Victoria used only 54 electric or hybrid cars between 2010 and 2014, in an overall fleet of 4.5m vehicles in the state.
“Electric vehicles promise benefits to both consumers and governments,” the report said. “Nonetheless, the market for electric vehicles remains underdeveloped and progress has been slow.
“Australia’s electric vehicle market is, by international standards, a laggard. This is in no small part due to a lack of public investment in establishing the conditions necessary for growth.”
The Australia Institute said it had conducted its own survey showing majority support for policy incentives to encourage the uptake of electric vehicles.
The report recommends exempting electric vehicles from the luxury car tax, which applies to more expensive types of electric cars, including the Tesla Model S. It also calls for tax breaks to build a “visible, densely distributed network” of charging stations, to ease consumer concerns about being left stranded with a flat battery.
“The development of this network requires careful management,” the report said. “Left unregulated, there is a risk that competing technology standards cannibalise the EV market.”
Australia should also allow a Norwegian-style scheme to allow electric cars access to bus lanes, although such a perk should be time-limited to avoid congestion as the uptake of electric vehicles grows, the report said. 
The measure would also require number plates that identify cars as electric. It should only apply to all-electric vehicles, the report said, to reduce congestion in bus lanes. 
The report also recommended adopting a carbon pricing scheme, similar to that operating in France, which made cleaner cars cheaper to buy.

Great article. However, in my opinion you are forgetting one big thing here. China is about to have an ETS (before the end of the year). This means that our food, iron, aluminium etc will become globally uncompetitive unless we switch to a lower emissions economy. The businesses know this and will start to act (unless of course they simply decide to shut their doors). In that world, which is only a few months away, it won’t matter whether we have a carbon price or not. Anyone who is trade exposed to China (ie, just about everyone) will be paying a carbon price in some form anyway. Then it won’t matter whether Tony Abbott is in charge or Humphrey Bear. I’m optimistic that the businesses will start to take the lead on this, and then investment will follow. Political leadership will be replaced by companies who need to address carbon liability for their shareholders. It’s already happening as I’m sure you know.Cheers for a great article.
