description: Dana Nuccitelli: Coal can’t compete with cheaper clean energy. The Trump administration can’t save expensive, dirty energy.
headline: v
og_fields.og:description: Dana Nuccitelli: Coal can’t compete with cheaper clean energy. The Trump administration can’t save expensive, dirty energy.
og_fields.og:title: The war on coal is over.  Coal lost | Dana Nuccitelli
text:
Last week, Trump’s EPA administrator Scott Pruitt announced, “the war on coal is over.” If there ever was a war on coal, the coal industry has lost. According to a new report from the Union of Concerned Scientists, many old American coal power plants are being retired or converted to natural gas, and new coal power plants aren’t being built because they’ve become more expensive than natural gas, wind, and solar energy: 
The share of US electricity coming from coal fell from 51 percent in 2008 to 31 percent in 2016—an unprecedented change. New UCS analysis finds that, of the coal units that remain, roughly one in four plans to retire or convert to natural gas; another 17 percent are uneconomic and could face retirement soon.
Natural gas has now surpassed coal to supply 32% of US electricity (up from 21% in 2008), and solar and wind are up to 10% (from 3% in 2008).
This trend will continue. As old coal plants continue to retire and be replaced by cheaper renewables and natural gas, their share of the US electricity supply will continue to plummet, and coal will become a fossil fuel in every sense of the word. That’s why American companies continue to invest in cheap, clean renewable energy. As a result, our air and water are becoming cleaner, Americans are becoming healthier, and our carbon pollution is falling.
Two more coal plants to close in Texas. Believe that makes 12 this year nationwide: https://t.co/8n1kUQUJSc
The shift away from coal poses a challenge for regions in which the local economy depends on the fossil fuel, but the transition is inevitable. A wise economic policy would involve funding programs to help those regions adapt to the change (Hillary Clinton proposed one such plan during her presidential campaign). A recent study showed that Americans are willing to pay a carbon tax with some of the revenue going to assist displaced coal workers. The Trump administration has instead opted to try and slow coal’s inevitable decline.
The Trump administration seems hell-bent on causing as much global warming as possible. First there was the historically irresponsible decision to withdraw from the Paris climate agreement, joining war-torn Syria as the only world countries to reject the treaty. Then just a few weeks ago, Trump’s Energy Secretary Rick Perry announced a plan to effectively take coal out of the free market and instead subsidize it with taxpayer dollars to bail out the industry and keep uneconomical coal power plants open. The hypocrisy ran thick – as Perry called for propping up the coal industry with increased taxpayer subsidies, Pruitt called for an end to subsidies for renewable energy: 
I would do away with these incentives that we give to wind and solar. I’d let them stand on their own and compete against coal and natural gas and other sources, and let utilities make real-time market decisions on those types of things as opposed to being propped up by tax incentives and other types of credits that occur
Soon thereafter, Priutt announced that Trump’s EPA will repeal the Clean Power Plan. That policy represented America’s most significant effort to cut its carbon pollution, but had been mired in a legal battle over whether the plan exceeded EPA’s regulatory authority under the Clean Air Act. Rather than let the courts decide the case, which many experts felt the EPA would win, Pruitt stopped defending the case in court and ended the program. 
The problem is that according to the US Supreme Court, the EPA is legally required to regulate dangerous carbon pollution. Pruitt’s EPA may propose a dramatically weakened plan that probably wouldn’t survive a court challenge, or he may just try to run out the clock on Trump’s term. As with the disastrous Republican effort to repeal the Affordable Care Act, they don’t have a replacement plan. In the meantime, states and environmental groups will take his Clean Power Plan repeal to court.
I will sue to stop the Trump Admin’s irresponsible and illegal #CleanPowerPlan repeal, which threatens NYers public health & environment. pic.twitter.com/utm5Q0VWrF
Pruitt’s Clean Power Plan repeal justification is largely based on bogus economics, which the Trump administration is using to reduce government estimates of the ‘social cost of carbon.’ This figure – which estimates how much a ton of carbon pollution costs society in terms of damages caused by climate change – is integral to many government policies. A majority of economists think the government’s estimate is too low, but Pruitt’s EPA manipulated the math by ignoring the costs of America’s carbon pollution to the rest of the world, and by using a high discount rate, which essentially says we care more about saving money now than preventing climate damages and suffering for future generations.
However, because renewables and natural gas are now cheaper than coal, an analysis by the Rhodium Group found that the US will meet the Clean Power Plan target of cutting carbon pollution from electricity generation 32% below 2005 levels by 2030 despite its repeal. 
That being said, with the Clean Power Plan in place, the US likely would have beat its targets. As this excellent tool created by Carbon Brief shows, many states like California and Idaho are ahead of the curve, but other states like Texas and West Virginia would have been forced to accelerate their transitions to clean energy, had the Clean Power Plan been enforced.
The good news is that none of the Trump administration’s moves are permanent. The next president can rejoin the Paris climate agreement, have the EPA draft new rules to regulate power plant carbon pollution, and revise the social cost of carbon based on real science and math. As Citizens’ Climate Lobby Executive Director Mark Reynolds wrote:
Those who cheer the EPA’s move should remember that President Obama initiated the Clean Power Plan in 2015 in the face of Congress’s inaction on climate change. Without effective legislation to combat climate change, a future president could just as easily go down the path of executive action and regulations again. The best answer here is for Congress to pass legislation putting the market to work on solving climate change.
There’s been some movement in this direction. A group of Republican elder statesmen in the Climate Leadership Council called for a revenue-neutral carbon tax, which would grow the economy. Senator Lindsey Graham (R-SC) recently called for a price on carbon pollution and is said to be working with Senator Whitehouse (D-RI) on climate legislation. The House Climate Solutions Caucus is now up to 30 Republican and 30 Democratic members and is trying to craft a bipartisan replacement for the Clean Power Plan.
The Trump administration is taking every possible step to burn away our future, but fortunately the transition to a clean energy economy is unstoppable, and many of his party members are coming to grips with that reality.

[{u'author': u'Don9000', u'text': u'It is useful to remember that in the ten thousand or so years before Europeans colonized North America, the largest ruminant in residence on the mainland was the American Bison and while there are some higher estimates, from what I've read the bison's peak pre-European population was likely in the 15 to 20 million range. That's one reason scientists can say with confidence that 90-plus million cattle currently in the US are contributing more methane to the atmosphere than the fauna on the continent prior to European colonization did. American bison of course also existed in those large numbers in a much more natural ecosystem. Their dung would have helped fertilize prairie plants and grasses that covered vast swaths of the American plains, and those prairies were important carbon sinks: their soils could be several meters deep and contained a lot of carbon.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508278154000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2242225', u'id': u'106949061', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Jon Davies', u'text': u'I agree, and also would like to say that is the cattle were not there, we would have the millions of buffalo on the American plains that were there originally. "Are flatulent shellfish really contributing to climate change?"

You wouldn't normally look to the Guardian for headlines both hilarious and somehow disturbing, but there should be some kind of award for this one.
And to answer a comment below, while shellfish have been around a lot longer than people, the sea pollution we are now producing ("run-off from agricultural fertilisers") may be making them fart a lot more: so it is possible that human-induced changes are, at a remove, contributing to climate change in this way.
Personally, I remain more concerned about potential positive feedback effects from permafrost methane and undersea clathrate thaw, but admittedly this threat remains unquantified ... so for now I will ask my wife to do her bit to save the planet by chowing down more of those lethally gaseous oysters (someone's got to, but they remind me of cold phlegm).', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508178615000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2412184', u'id': u'106882996', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'jimble675', u'text': u'In the countryside they have loads of massive white fans to cool things down. description: Scientists investigating marine life in the Baltic Sea have found mussels, oysters and clams are emitting greenhouse gases – but cows still trump them
headline: A
og_fields.og:description: Scientists investigating marine life in the Baltic Sea have found mussels, oysters and clams are emitting greenhouse gases – but cows still trump them
og_fields.og:title: Are flatulent shellfish really contributing to climate change?
text:
Swedish scientists have found that flatulent shellfish are creating vast amounts of greenhouse gases, leading to a predictable slew of comments about farting cockles and clams. But beneath the schoolboy humour, there is a serious point. The two gases in question – methane and nitrous oxide – are potent agents of climate change, with a warming potential 28 and 265 times greater than carbon dioxide respectively.
Scientists studying the Baltic Sea off the coast of Sweden have found that shellfish are producing one-tenth of all the greenhouses gases released there – the equivalent to the amount produced by 20,000 cattle. If the same situation is being replicated around the rest of the world’s seas and oceans, we have a serious problem.
Chief scientist Stafano Bonaglia, from Stockholm University, is certainly concerned: “It sounds funny, but small animals in the seafloor may act like cows in a stable, both groups being important contributors of methane due to the bacteria in their gut.”
He also points out that shellfish were releasing these gases long before global warming became an issue, and believes that the recent emissions may have been exacerbated by the enrichment of coastal waters, due to the run-off from agricultural fertilisers.
To put this into perspective, the average cow produces 120kg of methane every year – 1,000 times as much as even the most flatulent human. With almost 100m head of cattle in the US alone, that means that 12m tonnes of gas are being released annually, dwarfing the efforts of the shellfish.
The major animal producers of methane are cud-chewing creatures known as ruminants, such as cattle and sheep – it’s the bacteria in their stomachs that causes the problem. However, kangaroos have a different digestive system, so produce a lot less methane – kangaroo steak, anyone?
Other creatures that create huge amounts of methane include the world’s 2,000-plus species of termite. Each only produces a tiny amount – roughly half a microgram a day, so it would take 2m termites to produce a daily dose of one gram of methane. However, there are so many of them that their annual emissions may top 20m tonnes a year. The big difference between termites and cattle is, of course, that termites – and the gases they release – are part of the natural ecosystem. Cattle aren’t.

description: Guardian Essential poll finds 65% support for doomed target recommended by the chief scientist Alan Finkel
headline: p
og_fields.og:description: Guardian Essential poll finds 65% support for doomed target recommended by the chief scientist Alan Finkel
og_fields.og:title: Coalition balks on Finkel target but will unveil energy and emissions policy
text:
The Turnbull government is poised to unveil a new energy investment framework that will impose obligations on the electricity sector to reduce emissions consistent with the Paris agreement. It will also create new reliability obligations to ensure there’s enough dispatchable power in the system.
Cabinet, and the government’s backbench committee on environment and energy, considered the government’s new policy on Monday night before a party room debate slated for Tuesday morning.
Government sources have confirmed the Coalition will not adopt the clean energy target recommended by Australia’s chief scientist, Alan Finkel, in his review of the national electricity market.
The vociferous internal critics of Finkel’s proposal, led by the former prime minister Tony Abbott, have made it clear for months they will not accept any policy that contains new subsidies for renewable energy. The existing renewable energy target peaks in 2020 and will run out to 2030.
It is understood the new obligations for reliability and emissions reduction will be imposed as part of an overhaul of the national electricity market rules recommended by the Australian Energy Market Operator and the new Energy Security Board, established by the Council of Australian Governments to drive the recommendations of the Finkel review already endorsed by state and federal energy ministers.
While key details of the policy are not yet clear, government sources claim the required emissions reductions in electricity will be consistent with the Paris framework, and the new policy approach will have a more positive impact on power prices than the clean energy target, which Finkel said would lower energy prices compared with business as usual.
The government is also expected to keep the emissions reduction fund and it flagged the potential use of international permits to help meet Australia’s emissions targets at lowest cost in its review of the Direct Action policy, launched in March.
The government’s efforts to resolve its energy policy comes as the new Guardian Essential poll finds a clear majority of voters support the now dumped clean energy target to help drive the transition to low emissions power sources.
The new poll shows support for a clean energy target at 65%.
It also suggests Coalition conservatives who have campaigned against the Finkel proposal are out of step with the views of their own supporters.
While the total approval for the clean energy target is 65% in the new survey, 68% of Coalition voters in the sample of 1,845 voters said the government should implement a clean energy target.
And while Coalition conservatives have railed for months against subsidies for renewable energy – Australians are on a different page.
Australians are overwhelmingly supportive of incentives for low-emissions technologies, with 74% of the sample backing ongoing support for renewables, and 75% of Coalition supporters endorsing that view.
A majority of voters, including a slim majority of Coalition voters, also support Labor’s policy goal to source 50% of electricity from renewable sources by 2030 – a policy regularly attacked by the Coalition.
Labor’s policy was supported by 62% of the sample, and 52% of Coalition voters said they approved of it.
At the beginning of a critical week for the government on energy, voters are inclined to see the government in Canberra underperforming on a key issue, although they are not as frustrated with the Coalition as they were in February.
The Turnbull government is not doing enough to ensure affordable, reliable and clean energy for Australian households and businesses, according to 61% (down from 71% in February). Only 15% think it is doing enough, and 19% (up 5%) say they don’t know.
More than half (56%) of Coalition voters think there has not been enough action, and 22% think it is doing enough.
With Tony Abbott spending the past several months front running the government’s energy debate, and leading the opposition to the Finkel recommendation, 42% think the former prime minister should resign from parliament (down 1% from April), while 30% think he should stay in parliament in some capacity (down 2%).
Liberal/National voters were more likely to think Tony Abbott should stay in parliament (38%) than Labor voters (27%) and Greens voters (17%).
Labor is still in front in the new poll, leading the Coalition on the two-party preferred measure 52% to 48%, but that is an improvement on the government’s fortunes from a week ago, where Labor led 54% to 46%.
The major parties traded blows over energy in parliament on Monday, when Labor asked a series of questions about why the prime minister had given early public endorsement to the clean energy target when the government now intended to dump it.
Labor has signalled it is highly unlikely to support an energy policy which abandons the core Finkel recommendation but the shadow climate minister, Mark Butler said on Monday the opposition held out “some hope” that the government would produce something sensible.
A major business group, the Business Council of Australia, urged the ALP to “stop, pause, and look at the detail” before forming a position on the government’s plan, because stakeholders needed bipartisanship for investment certainty.
“The worst thing that could happen now is that we go into another round of never ever, pure politics or this won’t work or it’s not our scheme, so it’s not a good scheme,” said the BCA’s chief executive, Jennifer Westacott.
Westacott said it was “hugely important” for the government to set a trajectory for emissions reduction, and a establish a clear trigger, so businesses understood how emissions would be treated, because “if you’re trying to do a major project you want to price risk.”

article_tags: [Greenhouse gas emissions, Climate change, Trees and forests, Environment, Conservation, World news, Paris climate agreement]
description: Natural solutions such as tree planting, protecting peatlands and better land management could account for 37% of all cuts needed by 2030, says study
headline: p
og_fields.og:description: Natural solutions such as tree planting, protecting peatlands and better land management could account for 37% of all cuts needed by 2030, says study
og_fields.og:title: Regreening the planet could cut as much carbon as halting oil use – report
text:
Planting forests and other activities that harness the power of nature could play a major role in limiting global warming under the 2015 Paris agreement, an international study showed on Monday. 
Natural climate solutions, also including protection of carbon-storing peatlands and better management of soils and grasslands, could account for 37% of all actions needed by 2030 under the 195-nation Paris plan, it said. 
Combined, the suggested “regreening of the planet” would be equivalent to halting all burning of oil worldwide, it said. 
“Better stewardship of the land could have a bigger role in fighting climate change than previously thought,” the international team of scientists said of findings published in the US journal Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences. The estimates for nature’s potential, led by planting forests, were up to 30% higher than those envisaged by a UN panel of climate scientists in a 2014 report, it said. 
Trees soak up heat-trapping carbon dioxide as they grow and release it when they burn or rot. That makes forests, from the Amazon to Siberia, vast natural stores of greenhouse gases. 
Overall, better management of nature could avert 11.3bn tonnes of carbon dioxide emissions a year by 2030, the study said, equivalent to China’s current carbon dioxide emissions from fossil fuel use. 
The Paris climate agreement, weakened by US president Donald Trump’s decision in June to pull out, seeks to limit a rise in global temperature to “well below” 2C above pre-industrial times. 
Current government pledges to cut emissions are too weak to achieve the 2C goal, meant to avert more droughts, more powerful storms, downpours and heat waves. 
“Fortunately, this research shows we have a huge opportunity to reshape our food and land use systems,” Paul Polman, CEO of Unilever, said in a statement of Monday’s findings. 
Climate change could jeopardise production of crops such as corn, wheat, rice and soy even as a rising global population will raise demand, he said. 
The study said that some of the measures would cost $10 a tonne or less to avert a tonne of carbon dioxide, with others up to $100 a tonne to qualify as “cost-effective” by 2030. 
“If we are serious about climate change, then we are going to have to get serious about investing in nature,” said Mark Tercek, chief executive officer of The Nature Conservancy, which led the study.

article_tags: [Wildlife photographer of the year, Wildlife, Environment, Photography, Natural History Museum, Photography, Climate change]
description: A ceremony at the Natural History Museum, London, will reveal the winners of its Wildlife Photographer of the Year competition on Wednesday. Two overall winning images have been selected from the winners of each category, depicting the incredible diversity of life on our planet. They are on show with 99 other images selected by an international panel of judges at the 53rd exhibition, which opens at the museum on Friday.

“Existing records of past Atlantic tropical storm or hurricane numbers (1878 to present) in fact do show a pronounced upward trend, which is also correlated with rising SSTs (e.g., see blue curve in Fig. 4 or Vecchi and Knutson 2008). However, the density of reporting ship traffic over the Atlantic was relatively sparse during the early decades of this record, such that if storms from the modern era (post 1965) had hypothetically occurred during those earlier decades, a substantial number would likely not have been directly observed by the ship-based “observing network of opportunity.” We find that, after adjusting for such an estimated number of missing storms, there is a small nominally positive upward trend in tropical storm occurrence from 1878-2006. But statistical tests reveal that this trend is so small, relative to the variability in the series, that it is not significantly distinguishable from zero (Figure 2). In addition, Landsea et al. (2010) note that the rising trend in Atlantic tropical storm counts is almost entirely due to increases in short-duration (<2 day) storms alone. Such short-lived storms were particularly likely to have been overlooked in the earlier parts of the record, as they would have had less opportunity for chance encounters with ship traffic.
Figure 3 (click to enlarge)
Figure 4 (click to enlarge)If we instead consider Atlantic basin hurricanes, rather than all Atlantic tropical storms, the result is similar: the reported numbers of hurricanes were sufficiently high during the 1860s-1880s that again there is no significant positive trend in numbers beginning from that era (Figure 3, black curve, from CCSP 3.3 (2008)). This is without any adjustment for “missing hurricanes”.
The evidence for an upward trend is even weaker if we look at U.S. landfalling hurricanes, which even show a slight negative trend beginning from 1900 or from the late 1800s (Figure 3, blue curve). Hurricane landfalling frequency is much less common than basin-wide occurrence, meaning that the U.S. landfalling hurricane record, while more reliable than the basin-wide record, suffers from degraded signal-to-noise characteristics for assessing trends.
While major hurricanes (Figure 3, red curve) show more evidence of a rising trend from the late 1800s, the major hurricane data are considered even less reliable than the other two records in the early parts of the record. Category 4-5 hurricanes show a pronounced increase since the mid-1940s (Bender et al., 2010) but again, we consider that these data need to be carefully assessed for data inhomogeneity problems before such trends can be accepted as reliable.
The situation for Atlantic hurricane long-term records is summarized in Figure 4. While global mean temperature and tropical Atlantic SSTs show pronounced and statistically significant warming trends (green curves), the U.S. landfalling hurricane record (orange curve) shows no significant increase or decrease. The unadjusted hurricane count record (blue curve) shows a significant increase in Atlantic hurricanes since the early 1900s. However, when adjusted with an estimate of storms that stayed at sea and were likely “missed” in the pre-satellite era, there is no significant increase in Atlantic hurricanes since the late 1800s (red curve). While there have been increases in U.S. landfalling hurricanes and basin-wide hurricane counts since the since the early 1970s, Figure 4 shows that these increases are not representative of the behavior seen in the century long records. Not me.', u'recommendation_count': u'17', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508706207000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2515806', u'in_reply_to': u'107169704', u'id': u'107171585', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'pretzelattack', u'text': u'lol "climate reality training session". what?? too much nonsense, too many non sequiturs in your posts.', u'recommendation_count': u'21', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508630876000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'10767097', u'in_reply_to': u'107130253', u'id': u'107133862', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'rockyrex', u'text': u'You asked what are scientific societies.
They are also sometimes called academies.
They are formal professional bodies - the oldest is the Royal Society, which was set up in London in the 1660s.
In the USA the equivalent is the National Academy of Science, set up in 1863.
Apart from most countries having an academy of that type, there are many in specific fields of science in each country, such as the Geological Society of London, the American Institute of Physics, etc etc.
You speculated about what are the possible futures that could come from the climate change currently happening.
A paper worth looking at is -
"A human-induced hothouse climate?" - Kidder & Worsley, 2011
Here's a key quote from the Conclusions:
"The likely cool greenhouse in which about half of Antarctica is still ice-covered means devastation from the tens of meters sea level is likely to rise (e.g., Ward, 2010), and poleward shifting of warm climate belts."
So the appropriate term for what's likely to happen is a 'cool greenhouse', which sounds harmless, but is not.
It's a very interesting paper.
How quickly?
Another quote:
"a cool greenhouse seems imminent within perhaps a century or two."
However, although those conditions could set in within that time, the process of melting half of the ice on Antarctica would take around 1000 years.
Meanwhile the
"poleward shifting of warm climate belts."
means that the equatorial regions will become increasingly inhospitable - but over time, not in a couple of weeks.
On this point, the most useful comparison is probably with the Palaeocene-Eocene Thermal Maximum, which was around 56 million years ago.
The fossil record in rocks formed around the equator during the PETM is really poor, an indication that life was extremely stressed.
Agriculture is basically adapted to the mostly-stable Holocene - that is not going to be the offer from Earth systems as the effects of CO2 continue.
People can't grasp this, because it truly is outside any human experience.
In fact when there have been short, sharp climate shocks, humans have found it very difficult to cope.
In 1815 there was a big eruption in Indonesia.
It caused global temperatures to drop by a degree or so for a few years, and created an event in 1816 called "The Year Without a Summer", leading to failed crops and near-famine conditions in many places.
In 1258 there was a European famine across many countries, and this is now linked to a major eruption in 1257 on Lombok in Indonesia - it has a much bigger sulphate peak in the ice cores than Tambora in 1815, so it was a bigger eruption.
We are now looking at a much longer-term change, of an extraordinary kind.
Although changes over a century or two seem fast in human terms, this is fast compared to events such as the PETM which happened over a much longer time scale.
The current rate of CO2 output is far faster than during the PETM.', u'recommendation_count': u'18', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508706092000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'it truly is outside any human experience', u'effect': u"people ca n't grasp this"}, {u'cause': None, u'effect': u'failed crops and near famine conditions'}, {u'cause': u'it', u'effect': u'global temperatures to drop by a degree or so for a few years'}], u'author_id': u'2923581', u'in_reply_to': u'107169704', u'id': u'107171515', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ID2310987', u'text': u'Mann and Gore "collaboration" has nothing to do with the topic. So when all those scientific institutions say that AGW is real and a growing threat we should ignore them and listen instead to some anonymous guy on the internet?', u'recommendation_count': u'21', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508585565000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2515806', u'in_reply_to': u'107094332', u'id': u'107111792', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'kent31', u'text': u'As for the rest of your comments, it was just nonsensical word spewing. I assume you were referring to Inhofe with the snowball. Well, if that’s what you’re referring to, you’ll be shocked to know that I think he’s a dork. Just as I think the average alarmist is a dork when he/she tries to say one hotter than average summer in Europe, or a busy hurricane season in one part of the globe is proof of impending doom thanks to climate change. Total hogwash.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508550872000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15456519', u'in_reply_to': u'107097605', u'id': u'107098550', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'kent31', u'text': u'Again, I think you’ve lost your grip a bit. All I said was that the last thing we need is more fiction in this debate. Obviously, you would disagree and I certainly expected that, but how you got to the notion that I’m scared of fiction is a bit of a reach. In another comment you talk about some pause that I guess refers to some point skeptics make. But I never have made that point. I do believe that the rate of temperature increase has slowed based on data I’ve seen, but I don’t make a big deal out of it because I don’t try to make the point that AGW is a hoax. 
What I do debate is the notion that we’re killing the planet with fossil fuel burning and that famines, wildfires, droughts and storms will make life miserable in decades. Such a stupid assertion based on nothing in reality. Yes, warming is happening and sea level is rising. I’ll advocate for sea level adaptation in a heartbeat because that is verifiable fact based on HISTORICAL TRENDING. You can’t say that about famines, droughts, or storms..... there is no verifiable linkage to those things....yet. A lot of conjecture is out there in the media, but not enough data exists to make those leaps scientifically.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508550415000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'that is verifiable fact based on historical trending', u'effect': u'advocate for sea level adaptation in a heartbeat'}], u'author_id': u'15456519', u'in_reply_to': u'107097605', u'id': u'107098472', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'glacier', u'text': u'I mean - there are republicans voted into position by many many people holding a snowball who backtrack better than you do from your original comment.
Now denial is to be afraid of art? Right?', u'recommendation_count': u'19', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508545505000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4706143', u'in_reply_to': u'107097284', u'id': u'107097605', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'glacier', u'text': u'Or are you happy to discuss how science fiction can confuse people without much understanding of facts into believing anything?', u'recommendation_count': u'20', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508545093000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4706143', u'in_reply_to': u'107097284', u'id': u'107097532', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'glacier', u'text': u'By the way - as resent events go - how did that make your "pause" look as recent event? 
Do I really have to post that escalator GIF again for people with little to no physical knowledge?', u'recommendation_count': u'19', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508544966000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4706143', u'in_reply_to': u'107097284', u'id': u'107097510', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'glacier', u'text': u'hey - it is you that is scared by fiction. 
And science will never comply with your claim that fast disaster i needed to prove AGW. It is you guys who always pull that false dichotomy out of the hat.

To the extent of going full tinfoil conspiracy theory-scared into thinking that science use entertainment to implant false "evidence" into the heads of innocent book-readers and movie-goers.”
Glacier, I think you’ve lost it. Remember me? I’m the one with positive outlook on the future. The one that thinks all the famines and droughts are pure conjecture without basis in any fact. You guys get on here and hype the impending doom of life on Earth. Who’s scared? And who just wrote 5 paragraph soliloquy telling me I’m scared. I simply stated that it’s time for a real analysis of current facts relative to what’s been predicted about tipping points over the past several decades. No global catastrophes, but only some upticks in temperature and sea level. Don’t give me a hurricane or wildfire diatribe.... you know that recent events cannot yet be attributed to climate change.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508543900000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15456519', u'in_reply_to': u'107094335', u'id': u'107097284', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'kent31', u'text': u'“i assert that if you jump off a high building you will fall and hit something. whether you want to quibble over whether that's a fact or not, it will happen.”
What a ridiculous comparison and thank you for putting your really ludicrous example out there to instill a chuckle. So if you think it’s a rational comparison to predict the result of jumping off a building (minimal variables in that equation) relative to predicting the state of climate in 100 years (numerous variables some of which may be undiscovered), then there is no hope in having a rational debate with you. Not only are you unable to comprehend your own assertions, but the closed mindedness of your position is also off the charts.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508543275000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15456519', u'in_reply_to': u'107094098', u'id': u'107097110', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'glacier', u'text': u'This, I suppose, is why you struggle so much. Not being able to untangle "evidence" from within a sponsored blog and from science. 
I can only feel for you in trying to wrap your head around pondering science fiction as a new source of evidence with such a loose definition of "evidence". 
"Day after tomorrow", "Jurassic park" and "Contact" are all fiction (even though the latter is based on a script from Carl Sagan who was a pretty damn good cup of scientist to paraphrase the fictional world of Twin Peaks). 
You sound kind of scared, I must say. To the extent of going full tinfoil conspiracy theory-scared into thinking that science use entertainment to implant false "evidence" into the heads of innocent book-readers and movie-goers. Maybe without science itself understanding what is going on - since it may be a global political conspiracy in feeding subliminal messages by techniques perfected by CIA? 
One need a special kind of mind-frame to think that scifi is used as evidence. Those people are usually loving each other on youtube in discussing HAARP, contrails and why cold fusion has been made illegal to discuss by some very very very bad international secret agenda - like the UN. 
In reality, however, most people are perfectly able to separate the scientific effects of for example radiation (including the joy of x-rays when a limb is broken) from the cause of mutants going hockey-stick shaped in numbers in the x-men franchise. 
As you seem to be a huge fan of historical revisionism - sometimes called "speculative history" - you should really have a firm grasp of the concept of evidence and how evidence does not change because of fiction. 
For nerds who truly like science fiction outside or inside of comic-con - you know - us who think 2001 is kind of good, who trace up the radio-theatre versions of "Survivors" etc - we know the difference between fiction and science. 
Climate deniers are the only group I know of who struggle with that concept - as ready to believe anything as long as it fuel own ideological definition of reality, even when the "evidence" is completely inconsistent internally.', u'recommendation_count': u'23', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508536717000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'fiction', u'effect': u'how evidence does not change'}], u'author_id': u'4706143', u'in_reply_to': u'107089091', u'id': u'107094335', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'kent31', u'text': u'Hehe. I’m not over-turning anything that’s verifiable fact, i.e. temperature trends and severe storm trends of the past. But it is easy to call out people like you that say they know what life on Earth will be like in 100 years. 
Crazy isn’t it to think anyone is all knowing about future famines and droughts and wildfires?', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508536711000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15456519', u'in_reply_to': u'107092736', u'id': u'107094332', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'kent31', u'text': u'Nah.... I’ve been told your opinion about the believability of model guessing games. My opinion differs from yours. But neither of know about the future, so neither of us know what will happen. I understand that but you are having issues with that unless you have a crystal ball. So I’ll try this again..... is this really that hard to comprehend?', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508536353000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15456519', u'in_reply_to': u'107092779', u'id': u'107094142', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'pretzelattack', u'text': u'i assert that if you jump off a high building you will fall and hit something. whether you want to quibble over whether that's a fact or not, it will happen.', u'recommendation_count': u'15', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508536284000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'10767097', u'in_reply_to': u'107089879', u'id': u'107094098', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, ...]
description: John Abraham: If you’re not familiar with the new genre of climate fiction, you might be soon.
headline: A
og_fields.og:description: John Abraham: If you’re not familiar with the new genre of climate fiction, you might be soon.
og_fields.og:title: CliFi – A new way to talk about climate change | John Abraham
text:
Cli-Fi refers to “climate fiction;” it is a term coined by journalist Dan Bloom. These are fictional books that somehow or someway bring real climate change science to the reader. What is really interesting is that Cli-Fi books often present real science in a credible way. They become fun teaching tools. There are some really well known authors such as Paolo Bacigalupi and Margaret Atwood among others. A list of other candidate Cli-Fi novels was provided by Sarah Holding in the Guardian. 
What makes a Cli-Fi novel good? Well in my opinion, it has to have some real science in it. And it has to get the science right. Second, it has to be fun to read. When done correctly, Cli-Fi can connect people to their world; it can help us understand what future climate may be like, or what current climate effects are.
As I write this, we are getting a steady stream of stories out of Puerto Rico the island was devastated by Hurricane Maria. It is hard to imagine the devastation, what life is like without electricity, food, or water. What is life like on an island of 3 million people, each fending for themselves, just trying to survive.
Another thing that is hard to imagine is the future. What will the world be like decades from now when Earth temperatures have continued to rise? What will agriculture be like? What will coastal communities be like? What will international relations and armed conflict be like?
It is also hard to imagine what living a subsistence agriculture life is like, today. What happens to lives and communities when the rains change, or don’t come at all? What would that world look like? 
Cli-Fi stories are vehicles that can help us imagine. The authors get us to think about these what ifs – these future Earths. Cli-Fi novels (and movies for that matter) can make experiences far more real than endless graphs or plots of temperature variations. And that, perhaps, is the most important contribution Cli-Fi can make to the discussion of climate change in our everyday lives. These authors get us to imagine what experiences are or would be like. 
One recent example of Cli-Fi literature is South Pole Station by Ashley Shelby. In this book we follow an artist, Cooper Gosling, who is traveling to a research location on Antarctica to create paintings. Yes, an artist is sent to live with researchers and crew – with funding from the National Science Foundation. After arriving at the South Pole, Cooper has to become acquainted with the strange social system that exists there. Ashley writes the book in such a way that you actually feel you are huddled in the cold with her and her co-workers.
Cooper doesn’t uplift her life to travel to the South Pole on a whim. It is an outcome of a family tragedy and a history that involves romanticized stories of adventure to this remote place. While Cooper is stationed at the pole, she hears news that a radical scientist is coming. This scientist claims that climate change is a hoax – and his presence further upsets the delicate social balance that exists at the research location. 
You see the expected reaction of the regular scientists when this climate denier arrives to perform his research. There is backstabbing and sabotage where in the end we find Copper helping this climate-denying scientist carry out an experiment. The experiment goes awry and there are repercussions all the way back to the US mainland, and the halls of Congress.
I liked this book because I don’t like fiction. That is, I find it really hard to get into fictional books because my mind always runs back to science, or my email, or papers to grade, or kids’ soccer practices to get to. I never feel like I have time to just read for fun. But this book was really engaging. It was the first fictional book in a decade that I didn’t want to put down. 
It is funny with really quick-witted humor that made me laugh. At the same time, I was impressed by how I felt like I was there – working amongst the staff and scientists. I enjoyed how Ashely weaved in threads of real and accurate science. And this, perhaps, is what makes the Cli-Fi genre so important. We can unintentionally learn real science. 
Ashley’s book is at the edge of this genre. It is not “dystopian” and it is not about a post-apocalyptic world resulting from climate change. It is topical and, though fiction, is as present-day as a news headline. This book is about what people, dedicated to facts, are really doing today. It doesn’t seem futuristic. It seems like we are at a point when a bunch of scientists and friends of facts could take over a research station and say, “Stop the madness!”
Salman Rushdie recently said that in the present day the country is so filled with lies and fantasy and fiction surrounding the truth, that it might require the fiction writer to plainly lay out what is reality and what is not. I think Ashley’s book fits that notion.
So, take a look at this new (newish?) form of literature. Particularly if you want a break from the usual genres. If you find something you like that I didn’t mention, please send it to me.

I didnt say that another method would result in the same set of understandings.

Condemnation sits better than spurious reinvention.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508487846000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13015581', u'in_reply_to': u'107058562', u'id': u'107059490', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'sidarthur', u'text': u'I'm not trying to answer the questions you pose, just pointing out that the heads of christianity disagree with your interpretation of the bible.
Sorry if that is inconvinient for you.
The Clapham sect did no more than win an argument with the official church that had owned slaves. It's rather like declaring christains that they were to the fore in the gay rights movement. Utterly laughable.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508537250000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'1595197', u'in_reply_to': u'107088302', u'id': u'107094638', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Beekeeper49', u'text': u'The King James Version of the Bible was one of many different translations, each of which was influenced by many factors. It comes as no surprise that another early version was, for example, produced by Puritans. More recently, yet another different version of the Bible was published.
Interestingly, the King James Version was compiled by a large number of scholars who formed a number of committees. As I understand it, the choice of language reflected desired policy outcomes stipulated by the Church of England hierarchy at that time.
Once I got my head around the fact that individual books contained in the Bible were written in a range of different languages, at different times, often long after the events referred to, and there have been many different translations in the English language, it became clear to me that one's focus needs to be on discovering the purpose and intent of each book, rather than placing undue emphasis on individual words. 
When you understand the historical setting of ancient texts, it can explain why, for example, certain rules were laid down. For example, without the benefit of refrigeration, certain rules about food preparation made sense. Attitudes to women and slavery reflected the social mores of the time, but are now understood to be inappropriate. 
Within the Christian church there are many separate churches with different understandings of what Christianity represents. Catholics are guided by the Pope and again, emphases communicated by each Pope can and do change. Tony Abbott's views on a number of matters, including climate change and what should be our response to it, differ from those of Pope Francis.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508537082000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14883613', u'in_reply_to': u'107056172', u'id': u'107094547', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Aussiealltheway', u'text': u'He's the one alright. Such a good Catholic boy, is he not? I seriously doubt that he ever attends church at all these days. There was a time when he said, more or less that he went when he had the chance. I think Catholicism still demands that you attend Mass on one day each week, preferably Saturday evening or Sunday.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508577286000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12398991', u'in_reply_to': u'107099545', u'id': u'107106441', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'sidarthur', u'text': u'BQSTART

description: From refugees to environment, the Judeo-Christian warrior doesn’t grasp what he is supposed to have studied
og_fields.og:description: From refugees to environment, the Judeo-Christian warrior doesn’t grasp what he is supposed to have studied
og_fields.og:title: Tony Abbott needs to go back to Bible class if he quotes it on climate change | Geoff Thompson
text:
For a former seminary student Tony Abbott is not a very good interpreter of the Bible. Of course, he’s very strong on defending western culture and its Judaeo-Christian roots. For this cause he is an unwavering ideological warrior. But as in all wars, truth is often the first casualty. In this case, it’s the truth of the very scriptures Abbott himself employs.
His latest intervention, invoking Genesis to push back against the “religion” of climate change, is a prime example. His use of the Bible was clumsy – and not for the first time.
A few years ago on Q&A, he was asked “What would Jesus do?” in relation to refugees. Stunningly, his first impulse was to invoke the example of Jesus clearing the temple. When pressed, he expanded on the connection. Jesus knew everything, he told us, and this included that there was “a place for everything and it is not necessarily everyone’s place to come to Australia”. Are we to believe that when Jesus cleared the temple of what didn’t belong there he was giving us a mandate for the treatment of refugees? What possible connection was Abbott drawing? The mind boggles.
But perhaps this cavalier attitude to the Bible is not unrelated to the battle he wages for western values. 
His 2015 Margaret Thatcher lecture, addressing Europe’s refugee crisis, was an earlier occasion when he linked a oblique Bible reference to the roots – and preservation – of the west:
[T]he imperative to “love your neighbour as you love yourself” is at the heart of every western polity. It expresses itself in laws protecting workers, in strong social security safety nets, and in the readiness to take in refugees. It’s what makes us decent and humane countries as well as prosperous ones, but – right now – this wholesome instinct is leading much of Europe into catastrophic error.
The command to love the neighbour is invoked, but circumscribed. The “error” to be avoided is allowing the influx of refugees to “possibly changing [Europe] for ever”. In other words, Europe and its preservation is the goal. Biblical teachings (or allusions to them) serve to defend western culture – as idealised by Abbott and his fellow cultural warriors. It can be used to critique other cultures, but not “the west”.
It is therefore not surprising to discover that the former prime minister’s recent speech to the Global Warming Policy Foundation displayed a similar juxtaposition of the Bible and an endorsement of the west. On this occasion, however, there was an added concern: the alleged advance of a new religion. 
Climate change is by no means the sole or even the most significant symptom of the changing interests and values of the west. Still, only societies with high levels of cultural amnesia – that have forgotten the scriptures about man created “in the image and likeness of God” and charged with “subduing the earth and all its creatures” – could have made such a religion out of it.
The logic seems to go like this. Climate change is replacing Christianity as the west’s religion. But if we’d just stick to the Bible we would realise that climate change isn’t a problem. After all, the Bible teaches that we are to “subdue the earth”. In other words, climate change is actually part of the divinely-mandated human vocation. 
It is regrettably true that the teaching about “subduing the earth” (found in Genesis 1:28) has been used as an ideological tool to justify exploitative and destructive attitudes towards the earth. But even a cursory engagement with the critical discussion of this verse will quickly reveal that this use and English translation of the text are themselves in some tension with its use in Genesis 1. 
The text preceded the industrialised world by at least a couple of thousand years and was pitched at an agrarian society. Even if we take the resonances of the English word “subdue” at face value, it would have meant something quite different in that earlier context. To invoke it to justify the climate change produced since the industrial revolution is a straightforward category mistake. 
But, and this is the crucial point, we shouldn’t take the English translation at face value in any case. We need to engage the meaning of the original Hebrew word: kabash. 
All exercises in translation are complex, and, yes, there are some problematic dimensions to this word where it surfaces in other parts of the Bible. But in Genesis it’s connected to the divine declaration of creation’s goodness. In this first chapter of the Bible kabash can suggest the idea of “development”, argues Old Testament scholar Terence Fretheim. “This process offers to the human being the task of intra-creational development, of bringing the world along to its fullest possible creational potential.” 
When the original readers of this text read it they would not have heard a cavalier “change the climate at your convenience”. Instead, they are more likely to have heard something like, “make something good of this earth”.
If this is what subdue means in Genesis 1, and if human actions harm the earth, despoil it of its goodness, and frustrate its potential, then this biblical teaching becomes a critique of the environmental damage humans have caused, not a justification for it. That the west has undeniable Christian roots does not mean that the Bible is simply there to defend whatever “the west” has become.
Convinced that climate change is the new religion, Abbott argued in his London speech for “less theology”. Actually, Abbott himself needs more Christian theology if he’s going to quote the Bible. As a former seminary student, perhaps he could rekindle his own theological studies. He would discover that the Bible contains literature capable of calling every culture into question, not least “the west”. And he would be better informed for those occasions when he makes theological pronouncements from the various platforms he is given as a former PM.

comments:
[{u'author': u'rockyrex', u'text': u'Indeed.
The terms global warming and climate change have both been used for decades, and mean slightly different things.
There's a scientific paper written in 1955 and published in the journal Tellus in 1956.
"The Carbon Dioxide Theory of Climatic Change" - G. N. Plass 1956
This idea that "global warming" was changed to "climate change" is yet another myth invented by so-called climate sceptics to confuse people.
Global warming creates an effect called climate change.', u'recommendation_count': u'20', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508417841000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2923581', u'in_reply_to': u'107021195', u'id': u'107025514', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Shadeplant', u'text': u'Some people get very defensive if you suggest we might not be about to tech our way out of the consequences of climate change, not to mention the energy situation. Progress is like a religion for a lot of folks. What happens, then, when "progress" turns out to be a one-time bonanza based on the exploitation of oil, and we move into a period of de-gress (?) and consequences? That's a horror movie Hollywood's too scared to make.', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508417761000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12130406', u'in_reply_to': u'107022925', u'id': u'107025445', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'mikedow', u'text': u'No, Exxon isn't responsible for everything; BP, Shell, Aramco, etc. are also part of it.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508417609000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3887757', u'in_reply_to': u'107024516', u'id': u'107025313', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Shadeplant', u'text': u'Climate change is probably going to keep being mixed into the general setting of films for at least the rest of our lives, but it's not totally new. In They Live (1988), we learned that aliens have been guiding us to change our climate to better fit their own. Rich people were working with them in order to maintain their lives of luxury. Seems to sum up what's going on in this world today, doesn't it?', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508417361000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12130406', u'id': u'107025127', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'vammyp', u'text': u'The most surprising thing was that Ryan Gosling didn't act like someone with a brain injury.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508417325000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12827599', u'in_reply_to': u'107024399', u'id': u'107025099', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'NeverMindTheBollocks', u'text': u'Betteridge's law applies yet again here.The answer to this silly question is a very clear no.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508417289000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3699054', u'id': u'107025068', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'catch18', u'text': u'If you go to sea surface anomaly, the Pacific Equatorial region is anomalously cool. Take that away and air surface temp would be even higher.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508417077000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13899889', u'in_reply_to': u'107022784', u'id': u'107024899', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Matthew2012', u'text': u'The thing is that if you look for it movie makers have been trying to ensure public attitudes are more enlightened towards renewables and the threat of climate change. This had significant influence over the cold war and nuclear weapons. 
If you look at Sci-fi series most of these will touch on climate change at some point and point out that it is not something that even the geniuses can solve unlike their everyday impossible challenges. 
The DC comic book series "Flash" in the latest episode showed a windfarm as an everyday thing.
A lot of TV clips have included a wind turbine in the background.
The issue is really that people aren't talking about the problem enough to realise just how big some of the issues have become. Not only does this give us the likes of Trump but also opponents far better who are still nowhere near accepting what must be done.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508416968000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'10230223', u'in_reply_to': u'107023122', u'id': u'107024817', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Matthew2012', u'text': u'Really, I think that the bigger villains are the politicians allowing the vested interests to control the debate. Exxon and co aren;t responsible for all of the inaction from politicians who publically claim to care.', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508416625000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'10230223', u'in_reply_to': u'107022953', u'id': u'107024516', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Matthew2012', u'text': u'Climate change has made various references to various film and TV since it came to public prominance. As one would expect for such an important issue.
However, we still massive franchises using the other end of reality such as "winter is coming" in game of thrones or Disney's frozen.
It still rarely though sees climate change given the bite that it deserves and the main problem hollywood has that it likes happy endings which means a quick fix rather than a story of hopelessness following failure to heed warnings.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508416515000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'10230223', u'id': u'107024423', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'deltajones', u'text': u'The real horror of Blade Runner 2049 is that there is barely a living thing apart from humans and replicants. There are some kind of farmed maggot/shrimp, some bees and maybe a dog. The rest is sprawl, rubbish dumps, dust, and an angry dead ocean.
Given the mass extinction that we're perpetrating that could be a future to come.', u'recommendation_count': u'6', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508416484000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3535208', u'id': u'107024399', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'vammyp', u'text': u'I've got a script from a few years back that's just lying in a drawer, it's called The Human Centigrade . Here's the pitch: 
Taylor Kitsch is flipping through the job ads in his local newspaper, he's been out of work a while and he's looking for something that's going to pay the bills. All of a sudden the power goes out - he's been cut off - 'if only I'd invested in solar panels instead of an expensive tariff of non-renewable energy' he says. Using the last seconds of juice on his mobile he calls a mysterious number on a BP ad. 'Be at industrial unit 442 in the petroleum-meat packing district at 11pm, come alone'. 
In the world of Taylor Kitsch a paycheque is a paycheque, so he heads down to the industrial unit in the dead of night. Think the industrial estate from the finale of Robocop, but filmed on location in Mansfield - the plumbing supplies store would be edited out in post. Inside the industrial unit is a load of generic oil drums and a green BP branded drilling machine that's fracking loads. All of the workers are wearing little face masks because of the pollution that's spilling out into the warehouse. From the warehouse the pollution is then vented off into the playground of a local primary school. Taylor's shocked, he has a copy of National Geographic in his bathroom, he can't believe someone would willingly destroy the natural world like that. *Twonk* John Browne clacks Taylor over the head with the exhaust unit of a diesel car, knocking him unconscious. 
He awakes sometime later, his vision foggy with PM10's, his temperature blazing like a world without rainforests. Where is he? He tries to move but he can't, he stuck to something. Suddenly lights come on in the room. Several other D-grade celebrities have been sewn together, mouth to anus, like the Emmys directed by Tom Sixx. There's Ludacris, Denise Van Outen and James Corden. The horror. John Browne enters to spout some exposition :
'In order to facilitate the accelerated use of fossil fuels and boost our company profits we have joined you together, the human body being excellent at generating power. Don't think about the science, just know that petro-chemicals are evil'
He then wanders over to Kitsch and starts pouring a tank of gasoline down his throat. He coughs and splutters as it makes it's way down to his belly, igniting in the acids of his stomach. Electrodes planted into James Corden's skull, wired up to the national grid, start crackling. Cut to the living room of a 'nuclear' family - the lights get brighter, the TV louder as the electricity surges into their home. Cut back to the warehouse, a hosepipe stuck up Ludacris' anus starts pumping out treated diesel. Cut to a local gas station, the price of diesel plummets, everyone's buying up and consuming like never before. 
John Browne laughs an evil laugh of pure corporate irresponsibility. Trees wither and die in the new climate, grass turns brown before disintegrating in the sooty winds. It's like storm Ophelia on spice. The world looks to be doomed. 
Michael Jackson's Earth Song kicks in - what's that? it's Elon Musk travelling through the air on a solar panel like the Silver Surfer, the atmosphere clearing up and flowers blooming in his wake. He smashes through the window of the warehouse, hopping from his solar panel which flies toward John Browne, decapitating him. He then pulls apart the Human Centigrade and declares the world saved. We then cut to a epilogue where Taylor Kitsch and the rest of them win a collective Oscar for saving the planet. #OscarsSoGreen.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508416199000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u"the pollution that 's spilling out into the warehouse", u'effect': u'all of the workers are wearing little face masks'}], u'author_id': u'12827599', u'id': u'107024146', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'PaulieB', u'text': u'No. Has this article been posted from 2011 when this was actually relevant rather than another god awful Gerard Butler film as he struggles to keep his entourage in credit.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508416085000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'1083130', u'id': u'107024047', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ID3277273', u'text': u'This comment was removed by a moderator because it didn't abide by our

Ghostbusters of 1984 had the Environmental Protection Agency as the bad guy while the 2016 version changed the E.P.A. to the Department of Homeland Security as the Environmental Protection Agency (formed under executive order by 'Mad Dog' Nixon in the early 70s) is a pretty good idea after all. 
The orange lunatic appointed Scott Pruitt to be the current head of the E.P.A. and Pruitt doesn't believe that human activity exacerbates climate change. Like other Republicans, such as Ted Cruz, Pruitt claims that he's not a climate scientist and so he can't himself attest to humans as primary contributors. In that spirit, I'd like to say again that Ted Cruz is the Zodiac killer since, because I'm not a San Francisco police detective, I feel that I'm not in a position to say that Ted Cruz is not the Zodiac killer.', u'recommendation_count': u'7', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508415226000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u"i 'm not a san francisco police detective", u'effect': u"i feel that i 'm not in a position to say that ted cruz is not the zodiac killer"}], u'author_id': u'2836106', u'id': u'107023288', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'GoldenAppleCorps', u'text': u'In the future when people (if there are any) are looking for why we couldnt grasp the nettle of sustainability they will have a clear reason- we can't take anything seriously unless it can be communicated in 90 mins of trite hollywood crap.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508415010000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17327071', u'id': u'107023122', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Ethan Hawkins', u'text': u'Climate Change isn’t the villain here, it’s ExxonMobil.', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508414805000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17811466', u'id': u'107022953', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'yoghurt2', u'text': u'Geostorm, a timely warning for those who have taken the following fallback position:

You ain't seen nothing yet (reminds me of Backman Turner Overdrive). Embrace Spirituality and your unique path to Gnosis.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508584579000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17530995', u'id': u'107111213', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'evolution rhythm', u'text': u'"optimistically suggests that we could circumvent the cataclysmic heavy weather caused by climate change if only we tasked someone like scientist-astronaut Gerard Butler to invent a network of weather-controlling satellites"
Great. Now Holywood will be narrating how best to mitigate human caused climate change to the mass audience. Whilst reforestation, restoring peat lands educing carbon emissions etc are the actually practical solutions needed to mitigate anthropogenic climate change, these subjects don't get bums on seats in the cinema's. 
Whilst certain technologies can help humanity mitigate carbon emissions, in general we can not build or innovate our way out of ecosystem degradation. We have to restore much of what has has been removed. And live within our means, which means sustaining a healthy ecosystem and not bring reliant on industrial infrastructure that pollutes. I think the term is circular economy. Thus products are designed with their full " life" cycle in mind and the resources the products are made from reused. 
Currently we have in general a linear economy. Aquire resources > manufacturer products > use products > dispose of when broken or used.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508561769000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'climate change', u'effect': u'the cataclysmic heavy weather'}], u'author_id': u'15713576', u'id': u'107100005', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'snowwalling', u'text': u'This comment was removed by a moderator because it didn't abide by our

Even that communist greenie rage The Guardian admits that 'they changed the name'"!I despair sometimes.', u'recommendation_count': u'11', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508443110000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17443130', u'id': u'107044469', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Erik Frederiksen', u'text': u'It is not very likely that all the ice would melt in 500 years. But all it would take is a small fraction of the roughly 65m of sea level rise equivalent of ice to melt to cause us big problems. 
Just 1m of SLR puts both SF Bay Area airports out of commission, as well as those for NYC and many other cities.
And consider that we've never watched an ice sheet retreat before so all we know is that some of them can go fast, just not sure how fast.
"The millennial (500–2000-year) timescale of deep-ocean ventilation affects the timescale for natural CO2 change and thus the timescale for paleo-global climate, ice sheet, and sea level changes, but this paleo-millennial timescale should not be misinterpreted as the timescale for ice sheet response to a rapid, large, human-made climate forcing."
https://www.atmos-chem-phys.net/16/3761/2016/acp-16-3761-2016.pdf', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508442626000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': None, u'effect': u'big problems'}], u'author_id': u'15131989', u'in_reply_to': u'107043915', u'id': u'107044182', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Erik Frederiksen', u'text': u'The subject of global warming isn't easy to capture on film. But one photographer figured out an effective way to visually convey it by scattering time lapse cameras across the North to document the shrinking glaciers.
He made the Emmy-award winning documentary Chasing Ice (there's a stunning short clip below of their film crew filming the largest documented ice calving event).
They found glaciers which had receded more in the previous ten years than they had in the previous 100.
The ice melt is accelerating, and as the planet will keep warming significantly this century that rate will continue to accelerate.
Some big chunks of ice, like the West Antarctic, are threshold systems, once they start to go, they go fast.

Sea level rise is a serious issue without nonsense hysterical propaganda alarmism pitched by you.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508442194000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15456519', u'in_reply_to': u'107037148', u'id': u'107043915', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Erik Frederiksen', u'text': u'And when might Thwaites get off its stabilizing sill?
BQSTART
When I asked Richard Alley, almost certainly the most respected glaciologist in the United States, whether he would be surprised to see Thwaites collapse in his lifetime, he drew a breath. Alley is 58. ‘‘Up until very recently, I would have said, ‘Yes, I’d be surprised,’ ’’ he told me. ‘‘Right now, I’m not sure. I’m still cautiously optimistic that in my life, Thwaites has got enough stability on the ridge where it now sits that I will die before it does. But I’m not confident about that for my kids. And if someday I have grandkids, I’m not at all confident for them.’’
BQEND
The thing is that's West Antarctica alone. You'd also have thermal expansion, mountain glaciers and that little block of ice sitting on Greenland.  A more distant problem is the much larger EAIS.
https://www.nytimes.com/2015/11/15/magazine/the-secrets-in-greenlands-ice-sheets.html', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508441658000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15131989', u'in_reply_to': u'107042855', u'id': u'107043601', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Erik Frederiksen', u'text': u'And the next 100 years could see several meters. At Thwaites Glacier, West Antarctica, “once you get off of the stabilizing sill, whenever that is in West Antarctica, the time scale of getting rid of the West Antarctic [3.3 GMSLR, 4m in the Northern Hemisphere], it’s not centuries, it’s multi-decadal. This is not maybe the best case, it’s not the worst case.” My emphasis.
