"
Here is NASA's former lead climate scientist to correct Lovelock
BQSTART
Climate change deniers argue that the Sun is the main cause of climate change. But the measured energy imbalance occurred during the deepest solar minimum in the record, when the Sun's energy reaching Earth was least. Yet, there was more energy coming in than going out. This shows that the effect of the Sun's variations on climate is overwhelmed by the increasing greenhouse gasses, mainly from burning fossil fuels.
BQEND

https://www.ted.com/talks/james_hansen_why_i_must_speak_out_about_climate_change/transcript', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508438642000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15131989', u'in_reply_to': u'107040437', u'id': u'107041683', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'thismonthspecial', u'text': u'thanks for the worse case scenario which will never happen, you doomster would be great company not', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508438617000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'18088866', u'in_reply_to': u'107037148', u'id': u'107041666', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Erik Frederiksen', u'text': u'Actually, we are learning a lot about how global warming is affecting clouds, and the news isn't good, two amplifying feedbacks.
"Here we show that several independent, empirically corrected satellite records exhibit large-scale patterns of cloud change between the 1980s and the 2000s that are similar to those produced by model simulations of climate with recent historical external radiative forcing. Observed and simulated cloud change patterns are consistent with poleward retreat of mid-latitude storm tracks, expansion of subtropical dry zones, and increasing height of the highest cloud tops at all latitudes. The primary drivers of these cloud changes appear to be increasing greenhouse gas concentrations and a recovery from volcanic radiative cooling. These results indicate that the cloud changes most consistently predicted by global climate models are currently occurring in nature."
https://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v536/n7614/full/nature18273.html', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508438435000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15131989', u'in_reply_to': u'107040437', u'id': u'107041521', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'SiberianNights', u'text': u'But are those links really multidisciplinary? To me, the whole problem with climate change science is that anything that is not multidisciplinary represents such a tiny piece of the jigsaw that it can only be misleading, while everything that is multidisciplinary becomes so complex and so embedded in unknowable variables that it simply cannot help industrial or political decision making.One scientist hero of mine who pioneered multidisciplinary climate change research in the 1970s is Freeman Dyson, quoted below - 
BQSTART
The models solve the equations of fluid dynamics, and they do a very good job of describing the fluid motions of the atmosphere and the oceans. They do a very poor job of describing the clouds, the dust, the chemistry and the biology of fields and farms and forests. They do not begin to describe the real world we live in.  And, in 2009: 
What has happened in the past 10 years is that the discrepancies between what's observed and what's predicted have become much stronger. It's clear now the models are wrong, but it wasn't so clear 10 years ago.
BQEND
The famous mini ice age that froze the Thames so often in the 17-18th century has been correlated to a decrease in sunspot activity on the basis of Greenwich Observatory records. Jim Lovelock also believes that solar physics is currently playing a role in climate change that is not being correctly accounted for. He has even claimed that climate change could be arrested by adding a simple ingredient to aviation fuel.I have even read of models based on estimates of the rate of decay of radioactive elements in the earth's core, with are affecting the electric currents and hence the magnetic field around the earth, this in turn affects cosmic ray and solar wind interaction with the upper atmosphere, which in turn influences the thermal properties of the atmosphere.The chemistry might be unambiguous, but as for the true nature of its impact on climate change - is that really so unambiguous?', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508436862000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2674834', u'in_reply_to': u'107035466', u'id': u'107040437', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JetexJim', u'text': u'If the trailers any guide at all this will be complete bollox.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508436758000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3697005', u'id': u'107040371', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Pagey', u'text': u'There was a time when had no alternative.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508436215000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'1467460', u'in_reply_to': u'107032600', u'id': u'107040040', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'rockyrex', u'text': u'Ice-ball events (usually called Snowball Earth) happened at times when the Sun was producing less energy - it's a Main Sequence star, and MS stars produce more energy as they age.
The Sun's output was about 5% lower than now during the Cambrian, for example.', u'recommendation_count': u'6', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508435884000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2923581', u'in_reply_to': u'107039517', u'id': u'107039826', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'SiberianNights', u'text': u'But surely, those 'ice ball' phases that the earth went through were not cyclical but run-away, both because they lasted so long and because it appears to have been only non-cyclical unprecedented events that caused them to have ended. The first 'ice ball' period that planet earth went through about 2.1 billion years ago is believed to have lasted 300 million years, and the second 'ice ball' period, when the planet was once again almost entirely covered with ice for tens of millions of years about 0.7 billion years ago, also seems to have ended for unprecedented organic reasons.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508435430000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'that', u'effect': None}, {u'cause': u'they lasted so long and because it appears to have been only non - cyclical unprecedented events that caused them to have ended', u'effect': u'but surely phases were not cyclical but run away both'}, {u'cause': u'it appears to have been only non - cyclical unprecedented events that caused them to have ended', u'effect': u'because they lasted so long and'}], u'author_id': u'2674834', u'in_reply_to': u'107038897', u'id': u'107039517', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'glacier', u'text': u'It is true - Natural processes spent some 30 million years to harvest and make atmospheric carbon into geological carbon as a continuum from a plateau. 
Ice-ages are clearly not run-away. If they were run-away they would not cycle. They are well within linear physics. If anything - it is the interglacials (that we live in - 10% of time of Pleistocene) that are the run-away situation. 
Remember - there are may ways to make your hands hot. You can light up a fire. You can rub your hands together. You can bang them into a wall. You can have a fever. And yet and therefore - medicine does not monitor your core temperature by the surface temperature of your hands. Traditionally, that was done by putting a instrument up the behind of kids (now it is more remotely sensed by sticking a device into your ear). UK is like the hands of the planet. And these extremities were slightly warm 2000 years ago - also because the entire planet was circling around the sun slightly different. 
What "macro-level" are you talking about? Cherry-picking as macro-level study sounds like the wrong method for the wrong question.', u'recommendation_count': u'6', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508434478000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'also the entire planet was circling around the sun slightly different', u'effect': u'and these extremities were slightly warm 2000 years ago'}], u'author_id': u'4706143', u'in_reply_to': u'107033575', u'id': u'107038897', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'glacier', u'text': u'(TLDR - go to the Lampoons half down)
Some say there are only 7 plot-lines in existence. 
Climate as villain here falls under the umbrella of "humans meddle with nature - and feels the consequences". Popular since Jekyll made a potion, Frankenstein explored making life, Eve took a bite of an apple or probably since humans experienced the first tsunami/eruption forest-fire or whatever and attributed it to some violation of divine rules. 
In the last century this narrative has been told as humans meddling with medicine (creating zombies), atoms (creating Godzilla, bad mutants, china syndromes and nuclear winters), chemicals (doing all sorts of bad things - like causing climate change). In LOTR the dwarfs dug so deep from greed that they unleashed a Balrog as an early environmental story. Even meddling with physics, opening wormholes and portals to distant parts of the Universe has a tendency to unleash the revenge of nature upon us. 
Anyways - I do not see Hollywood use climate as anything else than the other "proxies" for villains. 
That said - there are exceptions. "Wall-E" and "Up!" do use modernity and environment as a very tactile and more peaceful backdrop - with little pointing morality and lots of laughter. And Hollywood has also made very relevant biographical movies about the environment (Erin Brockovich). Hence it is possible to make relevant scripts. 
I am, by the way, bummed out by "geo-farse", sorry "Geostorm". It is a chance blown by exploring much more realistic scenarios of human meddling with Terraforming and correction. 
Problem, of course - slightly more realistic scenarios never approach the speed of nuclear/asteroid impact that allows a script to cover a few days and to allow the CGI-shops to create scenes of cities being crashed in a second by 1000 feet tall waves. 
There are only 7 plot-lines. 
Climate change makes for a very poor villain. The backdrop of climate change could, however, make for a nice back-drop of a political thriller or two (and I do not mean the feeble attempts that James Bond has been given to rescue the world from eco-terrorism). Hollywood had a history of writing thriller-manuscripts of "secret documents on the loose before the congress is about to vote" kind of story-lines. 
Personally I would like to see National Lampoon's goes off grid  with the scene with decorating the house with Christmas-lights as an eye-watering memory. 
Just make one such Lampoon movie - where they go through a year of vacations - with zero-carbon footprint. Give us Chevy Chase fixing solar panels on the roof. Let them go on holidays with an EV. Let them have a climate neutral vegan Thanksgiving. 
The pop-industry has not really pondered how funny we are in trying to make the world a bit better, mostly as individuals, since governmental advice and infrastructure is so lacking. 
Let the Lampoons install a huge wind-mill in their garden. Just because someone funny can take that scene and make it crazy funny. Let them wake up and see their effort being shot to pieces because of noise-pollution. Because it would be true
Make room for Donald Trump (as government) tweeting his suggestion of fitting the Mexican wall with solar panels, apparently not knowing exactly where the sun is on a north-south axis. 
I would have loved that film. Because it is as realistic as when the Griswold family graciously moved in with their family in Germany(?). And because - this humour. 
To LOL in the face of the real villain is important. So Hollywood - we are all the Griswolds. Make us laugh. Do not be afraid to prove deniers right in the argument that it is wrong to try (like with wanting home to be lovely and shiny for Christmas with a million bulbs in serial that may take some time).', u'recommendation_count': u'6', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508433704000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': None, u'effect': u'climate change'}, {u'cause': u'just someone funny can take that scene and make it crazy funny', u'effect': None}, {u'cause': u'noise pollution', u'effect': u'their effort being shot to pieces'}], u'author_id': u'4706143', u'id': u'107038391', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'nonsensefactory', u'text': u'Take a look at what the world would be if all the ice melted (Antarctica and Greenland combined): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VbiRNT_gWUQ
That might be what the world looks like 500 years from now, on the present trajectory. But climate change is already evident, the Hadley Cell continues to expand polewards, extreme periods of drought, flooding, heat waves and violent storms around the world are increasing, ecosystems are steadily changing, and the fossil CO2 in the atmosphere continues to increase at high rates with no end in sight. The Keeling Curve is nowhere near flat:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Keeling_Curve
Once the Keeling Curve flattens out, it will still take 50-100 years for the climate to finish catching up. This mean significant global warming will continue for the next century, a bit slower with a rapid transition to renewables, though. Hence, infrastructure protection and in many cases, relocation to higher ground, or transitioning to other crops, or managing millions of climate refugees, will also be required. Hopefully the rise of Mad Max tribal warfare will be thus limited.
"Welcome to the Wasteland."', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508432010000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16819288', u'id': u'107037148', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Savellator', u'text': u'LOL...scroll back and find out, Will. Not exactly ricket science...', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508430850000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2903387', u'in_reply_to': u'107035457', u'id': u'107036299', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'RollyOn', u'text': u'God is punishing us for making films like this - and for Gerard Butler.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508430184000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'10019233', u'id': u'107035783', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'rockyrex', u'text': u'Science is based on evidence.
Religions are based on folk stories.
Do you think climate science is based on folk stories?
Which ones?
Goldilocks and the three thermometers?
Jack and the hockey-stick?
Snow White and the seven glaciologists?', u'recommendation_count': u'9', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508430162000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2923581', u'in_reply_to': u'107031539', u'id': u'107035763', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Matthew2012', u'text': u'BQSTART
Yes, CO2 has gone from 280 to 400 ppm within 60 years - and human activity is likely to be driving it, though the same effect could be due to fluctuations in the balance between volcanology and plate tectonics, among a host of other candidates.
BQEND
No. Chemistry is unambiguous:
When you burn a hydrocarbon such as methane in Oxygen you will release CO2.
We have released more CO2 than has been added to atmosphere, therefore, all other sources and sinks of CO2 have had a net negative effect.
The fact that you can account for the long /slow carbon cycle too doesn't mean that we even need to know about this to understand the cause of the CO2:
https://earthobservatory.nasa.gov/Features/CarbonCycle/page2.php
Also you are out with your figures. We haven't been as low as 280ppm until the start of the industrial revolution and we are now at a levelised CO2 of 407ppm:
https://www.esrl.noaa.gov/gmd/ccgg/trends/
Seen a lot of new volcanoes have you?', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508429802000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'fluctuations in the balance between volcanology and plate tectonics', u'effect': u'though the same effect could be among a host of other candidates'}], u'author_id': u'10230223', u'in_reply_to': u'107033575', u'id': u'107035466', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'WilliamHBonney', u'text': u'What was your point again?', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508429783000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15009244', u'in_reply_to': u'107034302', u'id': u'107035457', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'rockyrex', u'text': u'BQSTART

Oh yes this is a key part of Act 4.', u'recommendation_count': u'6', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508428974000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2923581', u'in_reply_to': u'107034531', u'id': u'107034840', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Matthew2012', u'text': u'The other normal plot development is:
 that despite the immanent destruction of life on Earth and possibly the planet, is that the people volunteering debate whether returning to die horribly is more important than saving the Earth without being able to return.
Also normally the young son will have run off to save the dog and so the plan to save all life on Earth is put in jeopardy to make sure the son is found before saving the Earth.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508428545000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'10230223', u'in_reply_to': u'107026314', u'id': u'107034531', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'rockyrex', u'text': u'BQSTART
with plate tectonics exposing fresh calcium-based rock to absorb the CO2 to become calcium carbonate, we have a possible candidate for the magic thermostat.
BQEND
But it's very slow.
CO2 in rain makes a weak acid, which causes chemical weathering (especially of carbonate rocks like limestone, but of other rocks as well).
Rivers carry the carbon compounds down to the oceans, where various processes (such as the formation of calcareous shells by organisms) eventually deposit the material on the ocean floor.
This is the long, slow, part of the carbon cycle.
After the PETM warming event around 56 million years ago, it took around 20 million years for CO2 levels to fall sufficiently for glaciation to begin in Antarctica, at the Eocene-Miocene transition.
The CO2 was mainly taken up by weathering of the newly-rising Himalayas.
Of course, if we burn all the fossil fuels we've already located, we'd create enough CO2 to reverse that process, and eventually Antarctica would be ice-free.', u'recommendation_count': u'9', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508428477000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'which', u'effect': u'chemical weathering especially of carbonate rocks like limestone'}], u'author_id': u'2923581', u'in_reply_to': u'107033575', u'id': u'107034480', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Savellator', u'text': u'BQSTART
No one found 'The Day After Tomorrow' credible
BQEND
No one? Really? Have you spoken to each and every viewer of the film? 
So let me state this for the third time, Will: let's say it was a film about a post-apocalyptic nighmare caused by climate change that you -together with a lot of other people- do not find credible. It still doesn't change my point.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508428219000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'climate change', u'effect': u'a post - apocalyptic nighmare that you find'}], u'author_id': u'2903387', u'in_reply_to': u'107034100', u'id': u'107034302', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'rockyrex', u'text': u'BQSTART
though the same effect could be due to fluctuations in the balance between volcanology and plate tectonics
BQEND
No, human activity is producing over 100 times as much CO2 per year than all the Earth's volcanoes.
For volcanic activity to produce this much CO2 we'd need 2 supervolcanic events per year - they are actually very rare indeed and the last one was over 70,000 years ago.
The extra CO2 has an isotopic mix that shows the carbon is of biological origin - in this case from ancient fossil fuels.
Of course the climate has changed for various reasons in the past, but attribution studies have eliminated the 'natural' factors from responsibility for the current change.
One attribution study is
"A probabilistic quantification of the anthropogenic component of twentieth century global warming" - Wigley & Santer, 2012.
Their results showed that the expected warming due to all human influences since 1950 (including aerosol effects) is very similar to the observed warming.
Here are two more attribution studies:
"Global temperature evolution 1979–2010" - Foster & Rahmstorf, 2011
BQSTART
...........we list the linear trend in the signals due to ENSO, volcanic forcing and solar variation in table 3. The magnitudes of these trend contributions are quite small compared to the overall trends. In fact the net trend due to these three factors is negative for all data sets except UAH, for which it is zero. Hence these factors have not contributed to an upward trend in temperature data, rather they have contributed a very slight downward trend.
BQEND
"Anthropogenic and natural warming inferred from changes in Earth’s energy balance" - Huber & Knutti 2011
BQSTART
We find that since the mid-twentieth century, greenhouse gases contributed 0.85 °C of warming (5–95% uncertainty: 0.6–1.1 °C), about half of which was offset by the cooling effects of aerosols, with a total observed change in global temperature of about 0.56 °C.
BQEND
All the current warming is related to human activity, because the sum of all natural forcings would be cooling the Earth very very slowly now.', u'recommendation_count': u'10', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508428138000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'fluctuations in the balance between volcanology and plate tectonics bqend', u'effect': u'though the same effect could be'}, {u'cause': u'all human influences since 1950 including', u'effect': u'the expected warming'}, {u'cause': u'enso', u'effect': u'we list the linear trend in the signals'}, {u'cause': u'these three factors', u'effect': u'the net trend'}, {u'cause': u'the sum of all natural forcings would be cooling the earth very very slowly now', u'effect': u'all the current warming is related to human activity'}], u'author_id': u'2923581', u'in_reply_to': u'107033575', u'id': u'107034242', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Erik Frederiksen', u'text': u'Here’s a graph of the last 400,000 years of global temperature, CO2 and sea level. http://www.ces.fau.edu/nasa/images/impacts/slr-co2-temp-400000yrs.jpg 
Notice how they track roughly together, and how far current CO2 has blown off the graph.
It takes time for sea level and temperature to rise to equilibrate with just our current forcing and we could blow much further off that graph.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508428014000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15131989', u'in_reply_to': u'107033575', u'id': u'107034143', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'WilliamHBonney', u'text': u'No one found 'The Day After Tomorrow' credible, even the most enthusiastic environmentalists remarked it didn't contribute anything to climate change awareness..because it wasn't credible, it wasn't scary.

It still doesn't change my point.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508427604000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'climate change', u'effect': u'a post - apocalyptic nighmare that you do not find credible'}], u'author_id': u'2903387', u'in_reply_to': u'107033301', u'id': u'107033789', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'MAppeal_62', u'text': u'This comment was removed by a moderator because it didn't abide by our

For more detail see our FAQs.', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508427458000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u"it did n't abide by our community standards", u'effect': u'this comment was removed by a moderator'}], u'author_id': u'13957529', u'id': u'107033655', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'SiberianNights', u'text': u'A switch to clean sustainable renewables is self-evidently valid irrespective of the science. But the multitude of complex subplots behind the macroscience of climate change are anything but self-evident, alas. Now load up your weaponry, because here comes the heretical bit:- Yes, CO2 has gone from 280 to 400 ppm within 60 years - and human activity is likely to be driving it, though the same effect could be due to fluctuations in the balance between volcanology and plate tectonics, among a host of other candidates. Paleoclimatology tells us that that the CO2 level has been over 10 times higher in previous epochs, and yet the planet has remarkably never experienced a runaway greenhouse effect, though it has constanlty experienced runaway icehouse effects. Even before the arrival of oxygen into the atmosphere, when it was mostly methane, ammonia and CO2, there was still no runaway greenhouse effect that any researchers can identify. When we compare Earth with Venus, plate tectonics could be our magic thermostat. Venus has plenty of volcanoes but no plate tectonics - and a hellish surface temperature of 500 C - whereas earth has volcanoes aplenty, but with plate tectonics exposing fresh calcium-based rock to absorb the CO2 to become calcium carbonate, we have a possible candidate for the magic thermostat.In Roman times the UK was a wine-growing region, which may have been due to a multitude of factors - but man-made carbon emissions were not one of them. For the last 2.5 million years ice sheets have expanded and contracted over Europe in accordance with a cycle that has a period of 26k years. We are presently emerging from a mini ice age.I would love to believe that changing human behaviour could arrest climate change - and we should all behave as if it can - but the whole macroscience picture is way beyond our current understanding, and the climate has never not been in some kind of cycle of long-term change.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508427356000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'fluctuations in the balance between volcanology and plate tectonics', u'effect': u'though the same effect could be among a host of other candidates'}, {u'cause': u'here comes the heretical bit:- yes gone though the same effect could be due to fluctuations in the balance between volcanology and plate tectonics', u'effect': u'now load up your weaponry'}, {u'cause': u'a multitude of factors', u'effect': u'which may have been'}], u'author_id': u'2674834', u'id': u'107033575', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'WilliamHBonney', u'text': u'Not a credible one. Make it credible, and no one would want to see it. No special effects required.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508427018000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15009244', u'in_reply_to': u'107033089', u'id': u'107033301', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Savellator', u'text': u'Perhaps, but it's still a film about a post-apocalyptic nighmare caused by climate change. Which was actually the point I was trying to make.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508426785000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'climate change', u'effect': u'a post - apocalyptic nighmare'}], u'author_id': u'2903387', u'in_reply_to': u'107032534', u'id': u'107033089', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'jhvance', u'text': u'The author of this bit of journalism is apparently too young to have seen the 1961 film “The Day the Earth Caught Fire”, whose premise was the simultaneous use of nuclear devices knocks the planet’s orbit askew and sunward. It wasn’t the greatest of films by any stretch and certainly didn’t have a comparable impact on audiences as the earlier “The Day the Earth Stood Still” had, but its imagery of a biosphere heating to an untenable point for human civilization to sustainably exist might become more relevant to the challenges we’ll actually be facing in coming decades and centuries.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508426503000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4453412', u'id': u'107032857', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Flashbleu', u'text': u'This comment was removed by a moderator because it didn't abide by our

description: Eco-thriller Geostorm, with Gerard Butler as a weather-busting scientist, is the latest movie to battle the environment. From Blade Runner 2049 to Alexander Payne’s Downsizing, film are turning up the heat on the big screen
og_fields.og:description: Eco-thriller Geostorm, with Gerard Butler as a weather-busting scientist, is the latest movie to battle the environment. From Blade Runner 2049 to Alexander Payne’s Downsizing, film are turning up the heat on the big screen
og_fields.og:title: Is climate change Hollywood's new supervillain?
text:
In 2004, when climate change was still called global warming, it was considered sensational enough to get top billing in The Day After Tomorrow, a city-smashing blockbuster by disaster master Roland Emmerich. But the incremental death march of the real thing was considered a little too slow for Independence Day’s king of kablooey. So impatient was he to bring forth a biblical flood and subsequent ice age that was epic enough to swallow the Statue of Liberty, Emmerich conspired to make his cataclysm happen in days, not decades, courtesy of a cosmically unlucky (and scientifically unlikely) flash freeze.
In 2017, the desire to accelerate climate change – even in the name of brash, mass-market pop art – is quaint yet horrifying. The nagging feeling that humankind may already have zoomed past some sort of ecological tipping point thanks to our voracious appetites for cheap energy and consumer goods seems increasingly undeniable. Previously, we looked to the multiplex to vicariously experience the catastrophic aftermath of freak super-storms and monster tsunamis; now we see these images appear with increasing and distressing regularity in the news.
Perhaps that is why climate change is a common theme across a broad range of movies this year, either as an obvious baddie or a subtextual spectre. The forthcoming eco-thriller Geostorm optimistically suggests that we could circumvent the cataclysmic heavy weather caused by climate change if only we tasked someone like scientist-astronaut Gerard Butler to invent a network of weather-controlling satellites. But when that system malfunctions, the planet reaps the whirlwind (not to mention mega-storms and tidal waves). Director Dean Devlin, who produced Independence Day with Emmerich, seems keen to outdo his old partner in terms of on-screen mass obliteration, with cities such as Dubai, Tokyo and Moscow in his apocalyptic sights. Whether global audiences will be excited by such destruction after recent natural disasters in Mexico, Sierra Leone, Puerto Rico and the Caribbean, remains to be seen.
Similarly direct is An Inconvenient Sequel, the follow-up to Al Gore’s Oscar-winning documentary, An Inconvenient Truth. The 2006 film was a crucial climate change primer that compiled scary collapsing icebergs and even scarier statistics (in short: tundra-enlightening, very, very frightening). Some reviews suggest the statesman’s sequel – which ponders how to tackle climate change in the increasingly science-sceptical era of Donald Trump – may have been unnecessary as well as inconvenient. But it is not as if the planet’s situation has improved, and Gore’s impassioned yet measured messaging bears repeating.
Postapocalyptic sci-fi will always be a popular film playground, but increasingly it seems as if we are being invited to look at worlds worn out rather that instantly shattered. Before it blasted into space, Christopher Nolan’s Interstellar painted a plausible portrait of the US as a parched, crop-free dustbowl beyond resuscitation. Earlier this year, Logan presented a harsh, scrappy near future that looked as exhausted as its ailing hero, a planet teetering towards a more relatable kind of collapse than the apocalyptic threats of superhero cinema.
The central message of Aronofsky's Mother! is consistent: what is wrong with these people?
Even the imagery and palette of screen dystopias seems informed by freakish weather that climate change has made commonplace. The whooping, bestial carnival of Mad Max: Fury Road seems like one of the only sane responses in a world where 18-wheelers are dwarfed by electrified dust-devil storms that block out the sun. The crimson-choked Las Vegas of Blade Runner 2049, meanwhile, might not even be three decades away; cinematographer Roger Deakins was inspired by the Australian storms of 2009 that gave the Sydney Opera House a Martian makeover (in reality, red topsoil scooped up from the heart of Oz).
A shared anxiety about how we have abused our planet and how it might ultimately retaliate has seeped into recent cinema in other intriguing ways. Darren Aronofsky’s densely allegorical Mother! encourages any number of environmental interpretations, with Jennifer Lawrence as a barefoot earth mother whose Edenic dream home is invaded by selfish, rapacious squatters – an intensifying nightmare that leaves her traumatised but mostly bewildered. Despite its surreal, disorientating escalations, the central message is consistent: what is wrong with these people? How can they do this?
In the forthcoming Downsizing, Oscar-winning writer-director Alexander Payne imagines a near future where eco-conscious Norwegians have developed a sci-fi shrink-ray that can zap people, such as stressed everyman Matt Damon, down to just five inches in height. Everything about this growing community of nu-Lilliputians is smaller – particularly their carbon footprint. In the film, the procedure is marketed as a quasi-altruistic lifestyle choice that doubles as a lottery win, suggesting participants will improve the planet’s sustainability as well as artificially extending their savings. 
Payne’s movie is a sociocomic parable that has the reassuring presence of Damon at its centre, an actor audiences have seen surviving in tough environments. But with the shrinking process irreversible, Downsizing seems to make a subtle but important point, one arguably as frightening as any large-scale disaster movie where a catastrophe annihilates humanity. Any real-world solution to our inescapable climate change problem is likely to be similarly and uncomfortably extreme – an even more inconvenient truth. Until we overcome our indifference to this monumental problem, the outlook is only going to get worse. Where’s Gerard Butler when you need him?
• Geostorm is released in the UK and US on 20 October.

And that the resulting increased horizontal temperature gradient between high and low latitude regions of the N Atlantic would drive superstorms unlike any today.
He provided multiple lines of evidence that during the previous interglacial, at temperatures less than 1 degree C above today, there were storms which moved boulders 10 times the size that modern storms move.

They had not thought it was feasible for hurricanes to head north so near the coast of Europe.', u'recommendation_count': u'9', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508594627000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'it', u'effect': u'the united states hurricane centre to recast its maps so that they could track the storm'}], u'author_id': u'12717079', u'in_reply_to': u'107113878', u'id': u'107116502', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'peggyschuyler', u'text': u'where was that?', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508592271000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16517822', u'in_reply_to': u'107082360', u'id': u'107115264', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'peggyschuyler', u'text': u'in the 20 years i've been in ireland i got used to weather. while it was worse farther sough here in donegal it was fairly normal windy weather. and even in the south it wasn't unheard of bad.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508592107000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16517822', u'id': u'107115169', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'NeverMindTheBollocks', u'text': u'There is no indication that climate change played any meaningful role in this storm.Once again, what we see here is people being over-excited about exclaiming "climate change!!!" regardless of the science.
This alarmism and abuse of science undermines credible environmental concern. It does not help.', u'recommendation_count': u'6', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508589550000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3699054', u'id': u'107113878', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'CrypticMirror', u'text': u'Air temperature is cooling, oceans are warming. The sharp divide between air temp and water temp was part of what kept Ophelia going for so long. It is also why the Jetstream is dipping further and further south and, while being part of a general warming trend globally, is making the UK cooler on average as we end up on the Scandinavian side of the divide during summers instead of the European side as we used to. 
Cooler summers and wetter winters are in our future.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508589083000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4693821', u'in_reply_to': u'107071486', u'id': u'107113627', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'latrodecta', u'text': u'It wasn’t just Ophelia that formed mid-Atlantic miles way from the usual start point south of the Cabo Verde islands – so did Lee. Which suggests that that the waters further north are becoming warmer considering one essential ingredient, water at a temperature of 26 degrees or higher. 
It should be noted too that in the usual catchment area such storms are occurring earlier. The official hurricane season is June-November but Arlene blasted in during mid-April and by the time Harvey arrived the water temperature was well above the critical 26.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508587644000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17328308', u'id': u'107112857', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ninfa1469', u'text': u'Interesting post thank you. the Sagan quote echoes one I heard from Sufism :" God seeks to know her/him/itself through us."', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508587449000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13913741', u'in_reply_to': u'107097320', u'id': u'107112752', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Readout_Noise', u'text': u'But the 3rd person to die was killed as he drove home from work. If his employer had given him the day off, he would still be alive!', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508584143000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14575232', u'in_reply_to': u'107072588', u'id': u'107110937', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ShedSheeran', u'text': u'Yes, and the Mediterranean sea around Sicily and Malta is still warm enough to swim in right now and yet there are no hurricanes here either.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508564947000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'18253134', u'in_reply_to': u'107089123', u'id': u'107100466', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'evolution rhythm', u'text': u'Though we are physical objects and due to evolution can make good moral decisions. I think science can provide a good sense of moral purpose. e.g. By understanding what humans are we can advocate a social framework that nurtures the best out of us and doesn't repress some inherent normal behaviour. 
When science ( evidence) isn't used ideology takes presidence. As an example of too many, Chimpanzees ( our closest relatives) are not monogamous ( neither are the majority of other species that could be termed as mega fauna.) Though birds tend to display a social monogamous behaviour ( pairing to breed) most species regularly mate with many other individuals. However, some human cultures ( Though not all) repress promiscuity. Thus, if this is generally against humans true nature it could lead to symptoms of depression, violence. In fact in western culture people justify violence ( or at least don't condemn it) against individuals whom have not conformed to the monogamous narrative.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508560356000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'evolution', u'effect': u'though we are physical objects and'}, {u'cause': u'it', u'effect': u'symptoms of depression'}], u'author_id': u'15713576', u'in_reply_to': u'107097320', u'id': u'107099839', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'evolution rhythm', u'text': u'In the short sighted term.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508559065000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15713576', u'in_reply_to': u'107099673', u'id': u'107099686', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'evolution rhythm', u'text': u'Warmer oceans= more energy = more potential for hurricanes ( of course extremely simplified and missing many other potential variables that could effect the climate). 
Though the nuisances of climate change ( complexity) is one reason why ignorant climate deniers ( a biased agenda = cherry picking " facts ", rather then accepting the general scientific consensus) have managed to confuse the general public on the issues if anthropogenic ( human caused) climate change . Well, that and the inconvenient truth that the measures needed to mitigate human caused climate means it's easier for fossil fuel powered consumerism culture to ignore the issue.', u'recommendation_count': u'12', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508558971000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'human', u'effect': None}], u'author_id': u'15713576', u'id': u'107099673', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'glacier', u'text': u'I understand you want to ideologically apply the physics of reality into a good understanding or reality. 
But science can not be applied like that (as climate deniers also learn from their ideological context) 
The earth is not in the process of "revenge". Earth is just in the process of gaining new energy equilibrium with the Universe as it is being loaded with certain molecules. Morality is something that is falling out of the sleeve of evolution. Physical reality does not care much about morality, we have learnt. 
Remember - the entire Universe is what science call a "pretty big thing" - and it is constructed to instantly kill us life (and morality) in a very short time if we are exposed to it. Imagine the astronauts on the ISS and what the universe would do to them if it made a small hole in their cocoon. The blood inside their veins would instantly reach the pressure-temperature of boiling. 
The laws of universe is very very hostile. And definitely not moral by any human standards. Even the right-wing love of "survival of the fittest" as some socio-evolutionary principle of economics becomes rather stupid when confronted with basic laws of the universe. 
Fact is - we are surrounded by a universe that is an estimated minimum 3 times bigger than the speed of light could have travelled since it all came into existence. To the best of our knowledge - this pretty big place is yet to provide even the tiniest planet where we can walk outside in a shorts without near instantly being killed by vacuum, high energy particles from a star or even high energy cosmic radiation originating from big bang itself. Add to this that the universe is more than happy to sling asteroids towards us, making stuff bursting out gamma-rays or collapsing into black hole singularities that are not happy with just pulling our limbs apart - but does not stop until it have pulled the stuff making primary particles of atoms apart. Physics - it is not a moral or friendly place. 
Remember that the oxygen we love and need so much - it killed pretty much everything alive that evolved for billion of years as anoxic because evolution invented a thing called photosynthesis. Science as of today do appreciate anti-oxidants because of this. Oxygen is really not kind to organic carbon-compounds. It makes stuff rust. 
Nature is not moral - because the universe is not moral. 
This fact makes the quote from Carl Sagan interesting. We are star-dust. But it makes another Sagan quote even more interesting. 
BQSTART
We are a way for the cosmos to know itself 
BQEND
To me this quote indicates that we are outside of the pure physics and chemics of he Universe that wish to kill us with some interesting method ranging from cold to vacuum to radiation to little gravity/excess of gravity and more. We - as being consequence of evolution as consequence of big bang could invent morality. Even faith. Even struggle and love and creativity and histories. 
And as such - to make the universe from big bang create self-awareness. A thing so complex that it studies itself by looking back at itself with telescopes. 
And what we learn is that it is not moral. We live despite of - not because of. 
So physics is clearly not a mirror of the human conditions. It refuse to be compared to the kind loving and nurturing thing that we feel under blue sky and above green grass while a gentle summer breeze dry skin and hair after a dip in the ocean. It refuse the similarly ideal image of denial when tiny humans can not affect nature. 
The universe just is. I do not think that mass of the universe (that happens to be more about very dispersed atoms in vacuum and mass and energy we can not even observe than about consciousness want revenge because of some life climbing down from trees a few million years ago). 
Do not claim laws of the Universe for some kind of moral ideology. We are the result of them laws. And we better obey them and act in accordance with them. 
Because the universe is clearly ready to kill us. Even astronauts 400 kms away - safe inside the magnetosphere of this planet are gently killed by the universe long before they journey outside of planet Earth's natural protection. They have to tuck inside from even the cutest solar flare that makes tourists at on the ground go all giddy with aurora and beauty of the universe. 
Science and nature is not moral. Even for those that imagine social Darwinism as a tool to learn from reality.', u'recommendation_count': u'10', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508544054000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'evolution invented a thing called photosynthesis', u'effect': u'that evolved for billion of years as anoxic'}, {u'cause': u'this', u'effect': u'science as of today do appreciate anti - oxidants'}, {u'cause': u'the universe is not moral', u'effect': u'nature is not moral'}, {u'cause': u'some life climbing down from trees a few million years ago', u'effect': u'to be more about very dispersed atoms in vacuum and mass and energy we can not even observe than about consciousness want revenge'}], u'author_id': u'4706143', u'in_reply_to': u'107090105', u'id': u'107097320', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'glacier', u'text': u'A "problem" with global warming is that the western world is hit rather softly by it. Only sea-level is semi-equal (distributed by small variations of gravity, tidal and boundary current push effects). 
Except from this - the effects are not hitting North America or (north) Europe much, other than in providing "refugee crises" and such inconvenience to comfort. 
Climate is physics. And that is often morally unfair. It is also morally unfair to compare a storm in the UK now with the realities on Caribbean Islands now. Definitely not something to gloat about in make Europeans "experience" a bit. Because it is not comparable. Because stuff does not work like that.', u'recommendation_count': u'14', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508532158000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4706143', u'in_reply_to': u'107090105', u'id': u'107091746', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Iamfuture', u'text': u'It will be good experience for UK & Europe to remind them of the realities of what faster and faster accelerating climate change at 170 times natural forcing will bring them as time moves on. Twenty plus years on one can be sure annual damage will start to cripple UK/EU & Mediteranean economies as happens where such powerful storms now impact. Be wise and start making the necessary reinforcements to your homes aware that even reinforced concrete steel structures are being rip to shreds. A small Dome on platform able to float chained to the ground won't go amiss.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508529018000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17008137', u'id': u'107090105', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'glacier', u'text': u'Kind of difficult to spin up a hurricane inside the subtropical high representing the northern edge of the Hadley cell. Those falling air-masses does a great job of stripping the already moisture-starved air for latent energy potential, for example. The c. 20 degrees of surface temperature in the Mediterranean does not help. Nor does the general horizontal air circulation that push the doldrums from east to west. 
Now - put in context - this map shows hurricanes - and nicely illustrates how climate works in the chaos of weather. 
https://aamboceanservice.blob.core.windows.net/oceanservice-prod/news/historical-hurricanes/hht.jpg
Kind of beautiful, no? It also illustrates that remnants of tropical Hurricanes are not unknown to have hugged the UK in the past - but massively over-represented by them who bounce off the east coast of the US/curls around the "Azores High", more or less tracking the core of the "gulf stream" (or North Atlantic Current, as better name) as it spins off the subtropical gyre and skips across the Atlantic to hug the Eurasian continent as pretty much an eastern boundary current, ready to become deep-water once the density-engine of heat-loss has done it's thing up in the Nordic Seas. It is really strange to look at the track of Ophelia. Seriously counter-intuitive. 
The whole system gives me a very "hybrid" sensation. 
This said - how fantastic has not meteorology become these days? Having observed and monitored the cold winds blowing south-easterly off west Greenland days ago. Predicted that this air will curl up rather forcefully south of the UK days ago. 
Now - that is some serious understanding of physics and number-crunching going on right there. A pretty amazing example of science hard at work over 200 years - or 110 years since Bjerknes outlined weather prediction not only in scientific papers - but also as a series of 3 long "letters" to a Norwegian newspaper - which "obviously" assumed that the general newspaper-reader were well advanced in solving differential equations and bringing fluid- and thermodynamics together by physics. (now THAT was the days of science communication). 
30 years ago these same physical principles and equations obviously existed (they are from the 19th century) . But the power to apply them and calculate them fast enough at good enough resolution did not exist. So only 30 years ago - many such perfect storms came and bit us badly with hardly any warning. Movies have been made about those old days of the 1980's and 90's where weather could sneak up unnoticed. 
Storms do not do that surprise bite any longer. Neither does climate. Over the last 200 years - science has continued to unmix reality. That so much insight in discovered post WW2 is explained in this figure that shows it is not just driven by computing power - but also numbers of brain-power: 
https://qph.ec.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-c1bd165089464979d8782a1945865048
As hockeysticks go - 80% of all scientists that ever lived - are alive at present. 
Science measure Higg's, falling out of equations half a century ago, measure gravity-waves falling out of equations a century ago. And with equally amazing physics, science now predict air-masses will bomb - days before it happens.', u'recommendation_count': u'11', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508527263000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4706143', u'in_reply_to': u'107065361', u'id': u'107089123', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JennyWren', u'text': u'Um - haven't we already had a taste of this in 2013 - 2014 when we had gales and storms every other day for months and months - a lot weren't named by the Met Office as they already had names - they came up and round the Atlantic and then to us - courtesy of the Jet Stream which got stuck and funneled them all to us. That was horrendous - I do hope it doesn't happen again.', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508515413000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12513417', u'id': u'107082360', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'John Samuel', u'text': u'What does the word "oscillation" mean to you?', u'recommendation_count': u'15', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508505718000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13496713', u'in_reply_to': u'107071486', u'id': u'107074344', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'mountainrunnermum', u'text': u'Yes we did - and 3 people died.', u'recommendation_count': u'15', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508503538000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13049145', u'in_reply_to': u'107063897', u'id': u'107072588', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'GuyWarren', u'text': u'Isn't the north Atlantic cooling?
https://climatedataguide.ucar.edu/climate-data/atlantic-multi-decadal-oscillation-amo', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508502191000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13408113', u'in_reply_to': u'107062943', u'id': u'107071486', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'glacier', u'text': u'There are two ways to make a good storm. 1) Go down to the tropics/warm ocean and make a tropical storm that is fuelled by latent heat. Or 2) Go to an area of atmospheric fronts and let the frontal gradients spin it up. 
Typically, storms hitting North Europe UK/Scandinavia are caused by frontal cyclogenesis. More rarely we do get remains of hurricanes that moves across over the Atlantic after having tracked eastern North America. But those typically gives massive amounts of rain, more than extreme winds. 
Long stories short - storms can form over hot water with little pressure-gradients (baroclinic) or from from air-mass fronts (usually more barotropic). The latter does not need hot water as they are driven by contrasts in the atmosphere - and thus our winds and storms up north are usually hitting us more in winter - compared to tropical storms that form during late summer/autumn. (You also have meso-cyclones that form over land - but the wind in those are mostly associated with them dropping tornados). 
Storms are similar - but also different. And some times - conditions align to make a memorable one.', u'recommendation_count': u'19', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508498481000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'frontal cyclogenesis', u'effect': u'storms hitting north europe uk scandinavia'}], u'author_id': u'4706143', u'in_reply_to': u'107057615', u'id': u'107068426', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'inti', u'text': u'Your reply reminds me of those that used to deny the health effects of smoking by pointing out that people suffered from cancer, heart disease and so on in the days before tobacco came to Europe.
True, but beside the point. It is a matter of probability. We are seeing previously rare weather events with increasing frequency. Major storms and hurricanes are dumping record quantities of water. 
These are the effects previously predicted by science to arise from the global temperature rises we have seen in recent decades; not more, but more powerful and destructive weather events.', u'recommendation_count': u'17', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508497924000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4191128', u'in_reply_to': u'107057615', u'id': u'107067966', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ShedSheeran', u'text': u'I am currently watching the golf being played on the costa del sol. It is warm and sunny and yet there is no sign of a hurricane. Very strange.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508494887000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'18253134', u'id': u'107065361', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Bus Stop Boxty', u'text': u'Happy days, as most of us in Ireland effectively got a day off work on Monday.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508493196000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17219690', u'id': u'107063897', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'exmetman', u'text': u'Ooops!I got my calculations all wrong it was 30 miles every 10 years and not every year.So the time it would take the 26°C SST isotherm to reach our shores would be 2078/3 = 692.7 years or in the year 2709 (cue Zager and Evans).Maths was never my strong point!', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508492040000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'11994494', u'in_reply_to': u'107058488', u'id': u'107062943', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'exmetman', u'text': u'And so if the North Atlantic did continue to warm at this rate, I calculate that the 26°C SST isotherm to be lapping on the beaches of the Cornish Riviera in a little over 69 years!
I do think Paul Brown did manage to completely miss the point with this article about Ophelia though, and instead of repeating the "hurricanes only form over water of 26°C" mantra like we've never stopped hearing from the BBC weather presenters of late, the question that he should have been asking was "why did Ophelia intensify to a major category three hurricane over an Ocean with marginal SST of between just 22 and 24°C"?
Here's a chart of tropical cyclones that did form close to the Azores [1851-2017]', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508486536000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'11994494', u'id': u'107058488', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'John Samuel', u'text': u'Man has been influencing the atmosphere with CO2 since the industrial revolution.https://www.metoffice.gov.uk/news/releases/2017/30th-anniversary-of-the-1987-storm', u'recommendation_count': u'22', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508485850000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13496713', u'in_reply_to': u'107057615', u'id': u'107058093', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Saqr98', u'text': u'And the storm of 30 years ago was down to what? Climate variability? Act of God? Little Green Men?', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508484971000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17227758', u'id': u'107057615', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}]
description: An off-the-charts hurricane that tracked to Ireland points to climate change pushing ‘tropical oceans’ northward and putting the continent in the firing line
og_fields.og:description: An off-the-charts hurricane that tracked to Ireland points to climate change pushing ‘tropical oceans’ northward and putting the continent in the firing line
og_fields.og:title: Weatherwatch: Ophelia's arrival hints at a new vulnerability for Europe
text:
Ophelia formed so far to the east in the Atlantic it caused the United States Hurricane Centre to recast its maps so that they could track the storm. They had not thought it was feasible for hurricanes to head north so near the coast of Europe.
As it was, the cold sea south of Ireland took the sting out of the 15th named storm of a busy Atlantic hurricane season. Even so the winds of up to 100 miles an hour were only just below hurricane strength when they hit the south coast of Ireland.
And Ophelia may be the shape of things to come. To form, tropical storms need sea temperatures to be at least 26C; they usually grow in strength until they make landfall or head over cooler seas. 
Climate change means 26C “tropical seas” are now extending further north. Research tracking these storms has shown this is allowing hurricanes to reach maximum power about 30 miles further north than 10 years ago.
The ability of hurricanes to sustain themselves as they travel north in these warmer seas is expected to be a continuing trend, putting Europe potentially in the firing line for hurricanes.
In the meantime, the main concern in Britain will be storms coming from the west. Brian, the second potentially damaging autumn storm, is out there somewhere in the Atlantic. These storms are named when the Met Office calculates they need to issue weather warnings.
The depressions do not need warm seas to form, although climate change is giving them extra energy and they carry more rain. With the jet stream speeding up the outlook is currently turbulent.

article_tags: [Air pollution, Transport policy, Travel and transport, Electric, hybrid and low-emission cars, Pollution, Technology, Road transport, Cycling, Life and style, UK news, Motoring, Ethical and green living, Environment, Greenhouse gas emissions, Climate change, Politics, Cities, Road safety, Local government, Local politics, Self-driving cars, Society, Transport, Couriers/delivery industry, Business]
description: Roads minister Jesse Norman says government could push councils to do more to fight pollution and inactive living
headline: d
og_fields.og:description: Roads minister Jesse Norman says government could push councils to do more to fight pollution and inactive living
og_fields.og:title: UK may consider electric vehicle subsidy to increase cycling
text:
The UK government could potentially consider providing subsidies for electric bicycles and electric cars as part of a concerted policy effort to get more people cycling, the roads minister, Jesse Norman, has said.
With the UK facing health crises from pollution and inactive living, other plans could include using electric cargo bikes to deliver packages from internet retailers rather than vans, Norman told the Guardian.
Saying his ambition was to “make the transition to a world where a 12-year-old can cycle safely”, Norman said he could not promise extra funding for cycle routes, but said central government could start pushing councils to take more action.
A review into cycling safety announced last month would be broad, possibly including whether cyclists should be forced to wear helmets and high-visibility clothing, Norman said. But he promised any conclusions would be led by evidence.
People buying electric or hybrid cars can receive up to £4,500 off the purchase price through a government subsidy scheme. However, there is no equivalent policy for e-bikes, where a small electric motor provides a boost when the rider pedals.
These are increasingly popular with novice or older cyclists or those facing a hilly or lengthy commute, but can often cost £1,500 or more.
Norman said an e-bike subsidy could happen: “We’ve done some work on that already, and I haven’t looked at the outcomes yet, and they might not be ready yet. There’s a case in principle.”
He said there was “tremendous opportunity” for more packages to be delivered by electric-assist cargo bikes: “If you think about what in terms of local deliveries, a lot of these Amazon deliveries are lighter things – you don’t need a Transit van to be doing that.
“I think e-bikes and ebikes-plus are a really interesting potential way of handling that last mile or two of deliveries.”
Norman, who was appointed in June, faced accusations of anti-cyclist bias last month over his response to the case of Charlie Alliston, who was jailed for killing a pedestrian, Kim Briggs, after hitting her on a bike without a front brake.
After the trial Norman said he would examine a possible new offence of causing death by dangerous cycling, and announced the review of cycle safety. He also wrote a letter to cycling organisations warning them riders should abide by the Highway Code.
Norman said critics had “missed a wider point” that the safety review would also cover the danger posed to cyclists by drivers, including those “using cars in ways that are intentional and punitive”.
Asked if he had experienced dangerous driving while cycling, he replied: “I bike every day, so absolutely.”
On possible laws for helmets and high-visibility clothing, Norman said the review would “ask very general questions and if the feedback is that we should consider that stuff, then we’ll look at it”.
He added: “Obviously there will be some people who feel very strongly that there should be hi-vis, and there will be plenty of people who think very strongly the other way. It’ll be the same with helmets. The literature on risk is quite a well developed one, I don’t need to tell you.”
About 1-2% of trips in the UK are made by bike, considerably fewer than in many other other European countries. 
A report by MPs in 2013 called for a share of 10% by 2025, to be achieved by spending £20 per person annually on cycling provision, notably safe bike lanes.
Norman said the current spend had risen from £2 a head in 2010 to £6 after the launch in April of a new cycling and walking strategy, but he did not know if this would increase further: “Six weeks before the Budget it would be a brave minister indeed who made any pronouncements.”
He raised the idea of a more proactive approach from Westminster over cycling, saying he was “not ruling out” the idea of ministers pushing local councils to do better on the issue, or mandating national standards for bike lanes.
With the advent of driverless vehicles and other moves away from traditional cars, governments needed to think about how road transport was being transformed, Norman said, saying cycling would be key to this.
He said: “It’s not just, if I may say so, the actions of a government which is supportive of cycling, it’s also the actions of a government that understands that the whole nature of the way in which we use the roads, and the way we think about cities, is going to change dramatically over the next decade or two, and possibly earlier. We need to be fully abreast of that.”

I told them this is what we needed and nothing less. In fact I then said ideally more but this was optimum. They reluctantly gave in when my boss said 'if Bert says we need it, we need it'. 
A few years later there was a heat wave in Melbourne with four or five days in the low forties. All the air conditioners in the rest of our buildings failed as they could not move heat into an outside temperature that I measured as 52C.
Or laboratory kept its cool and the system performed as it was designed. My boss was in a panic as we had very valuable biological crystals that cost more than a few hundred thousand dollars to produce and would dissolve with any rise in lab temperature. 
He looked at me in amazement when I said ' I calculated the parameters for the cooling of the laboratory with the worst possible case in mind' I added 'only a fool does not contemplate this scenario'. 
It is the same with Global Warming. This is a ridiculous and criminally irresponsible flaw in the policy.', u'recommendation_count': u'20', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508561960000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'the coal operations pass off many of the costs onto the community and the governments of australia', u'effect': u'this includes the policy loading massive extra costs on the community'}], u'author_id': u'2668563', u'id': u'107100029', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Stopthelibs', u'text': u'If renewable energy is not going to receive any subsidies from 2020, the same should apply to fossil fuels.
A study back in 2014 found Australian fossil fuel subsidies of $4billion per annum.
The Australia Institute around 5 years ago:
It is estimated that those in the fossil fuel business receive more than $10 billion per year in government subsidies, with the mining industry receiving the lion’s share. 
One of those subsidies is the enticingly named Fuel Tax Credit Scheme. It is worth more than $5 billion per year. Under this scheme if you use diesel for transport on non-public roads you do not pay fuel excise tax. 
Originally it was primarily aimed at farmers but the biggest beneficiary is the mining industry.
The huge mining trucks that tower over everything around them are never driven on public roads and actually wouldn’t fit on a normal road. Therefore the diesel that goes into them is covered by this scheme and is tax free. This saves the mining industry billions of dollars every year.
The fossil fuel industry has had benefits for many years prior. 
Further back I believe governments used taxpayer money to build coal fired power stations as well as the grid.
Now Queensland politician Christiansen wants the government using taxpayers money to build a new hele coal fired power station in Queensland.
He thinks this is a good use of our money. But no subsidies for renewables.
Again suggests donations from fossil fuel interests might be a reason.', u'recommendation_count': u'22', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508561956000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12714836', u'id': u'107100028', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Joan McColl', u'text': u'"I recognise that it is so so tempting to just say ..... Grid Load = Powered Active grid including all the variations over a 24-Hour cycle.That includes the Power grid that are connected ie. Queensland, NSW, Victoria, Tasmania and South Australia is a single grid!2. A power Station Exports power from it to the Grid.3. All customers Import Power from the Grid.4. All Renewable power generation (Wind & Solar) and batteries that are connected to any Grid without operators controlling them operate in Base Load Mode.• Base Load Generation is when the generation output is set be the grid frequency and voltage.• The Kw output of the generation is controlled by the weather conditions and time of the day.• Should the grid suffer a major disturbance the control of the grid Voltage and Frequency can only be controlled by a power that has export capacity.• The renewable generation has no ability to assist with any load changes on the Grid.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508561911000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14021758', u'id': u'107100021', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'pascalredman', u'text': u'Unlike most current politicians and journalists, Ms Murphy is offering ideas on ending the energy nexus. Justice! and equality.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1508561801000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16678880', u'in_reply_to': u'107099039', u'id': u'107100008', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'BertFromEltham', u'text': u'My air-conditioner that was fourteen years old developed a noise that sounded like a stuffed bearing in the compressor. It was a 7kW split unit that could heat and cool.
It was replaced about four months ago by a more modern and more efficient unit again of 7kW capacity. The installer thought I was nuts to have what to him was far too big for my house. I told him that my design parameters were for 50C days. He looked shocked that I understood the thermodynamics better than him.
The old unit could pump a bit over two kilowatts of heat for every one kilowatt of electrical energy. The new unit can do a bit more than four kilowatt for every one kilowatt of electrical energy.
This unit is bit less than half the cost to heat my house than a gas heater. I ran the experiment by using the air-conditioner to heat the house rather than gas and compared the bills. I will ditch the gas supply and install PV panels and battery backup to save even more.
Even at my age of 68 it is worthwhile as I only have to last another ten years and even then my daughter will inherit the lot.
When a burnt out old physicist can work out how to beat the energy suppliers by generating his own energy with renewables it is a sure sign that we are being gouged or robbed. 
Malcolm can waffle all he likes I and many others are opting out! Sean Kelly writes that the Abbott Turnbull conflict reminds him of the Black Knights in Monty Python.
Bleeding outAbbott and Turnbull are slowly destroying each otherBY SEAN KELLY
BQSTART
And so we have Abbott, willing to become more and more absurd, and Turnbull, willing to disappoint and disappoint, with each hoping the other hits the limits of absurdity or disappointment first. If Abbott can’t force Turnbull to call on a spill, he can at least erode his support until a spill becomes inevitable. 
It put me in mind of the Black Knight in Monty Python, declaring “It’s only a flesh wound” after losing both his arms in a duel, insisting on carrying on the fight (by kicking his opponent). Eventually, his opponent tires of him, saying, “What are you going to do, bleed on me?” Only in this scenario we have two Black Knights, each reduced to bleeding on the other, desperately hoping the other bleeds out first. 
BQEND
